PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
We are opposed to the Parliament imposing a Bill of Rights on the people of Australia and we ask that the Senate reject the Bill entirely.
Your petitioners humbly pray: That should the Honourable House decide to pass the Bill in amended form it will retain the amendment applying the legislation to trade unions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That numerous provisions exist in industrial legislation and awards which purport to provide special protection to women workers but which have been shown to be detrimental to their achievement of equality in employment. Noting the relevant provision in Article 11 of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women to which Australia is a party your petitioners request that urgent action be taken to ensure that these legal barriers to equality be removed.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. The present Australian national flag is not distinctively and uniquely Australian and is confused with other national flags.
2. The people of Australia have never had an opportunity to express their views on an appropriate Australian national flag in a referendum.
3. The present Australian national flag does not properly represent Australia as a sovereign, independent nation.
4. The present Australian national flag falsely proclaims Australia as a colony, homeland, protectorate, dominion or government department of Great Britain.
5. The first condition in the flag competition of 1901 required that the design should show Australia's loyalty to the British Empire. The British Empire no longer exists.
6. A public opinion poll held in 1984 using the Gallup Method revealed that 52% of Australians surveyed wanted a competition for a new design for the Australian flag.
7. There is no inherent link between Australia proclaiming a unique and distinctive flag and the political issue of Australia moving to a republican form of government.
8. The adoption of a truly Australian national flag would serve as a focal point for Australia's bicentennial celebrations in 1988.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable house will:
(a) Appoint a Committee of the Parliament with representatives from both Houses and all parties to invite and consider proposals for the design of a new Australian national flag, and

(b) Require that Committee to make recommendations on the form of a minimum cost referendum at the time of the next general elections, in which the electors will be given the opportunity to vote for a flag from a selection of at least three designs which will include the present Australian national flag and the winner of the Ausflag-Bulletin-2MMM.FM competition of March 1985.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notices of Motion Nos 1 to 3 standing in my name for the next day of sitting, for the disallowance of Fisheries Notices Nos 158 and 160 and Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan No. 3. I seek leave to make a short statement.

—by leave-These notices of motion concerned two fishery notices in the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan. The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned that certain discretionary decisions should be subject to review, that the power exercised in the notices and the plan were lawful and that retrospectivity did not prejudice anyone. The Committee wrote to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) seeking his advice. The Minister has replied to the Committee having obtained legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department. It appears in the light of this advice that retrospectivity does not prejudice anyone. The Minister will amend the legislation to make the exercise one of two discretions mentioned by the Committee subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal review. The Committee accepts the Minister's explanation for not making the exercise of second discretion, in connection with the suspension of licences, reviewable because of the practicalities of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of advice from the Attorney-General's Department the Minister is satisfied that the legislative package comprising the notices and the plan is a lawful exercise of his power and the Committee accepts his assurances on this matter. The Committee expresses its appreciation to the Minister for the consideration he has shown to it and for the detailed advice he has given, including his undertaking to extend a right of review. As is the Committee's usual practice with matters where its scrutiny has raised important issues of law or propriety, I seek leave to incorporate the Committee's correspondence in Hansard for the information of honourable senators and interested persons.
Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
15 April 1986
The Hon. John Kerin, M.P.
Minister for Primary Industry
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered Fisheries Notice No. 160 which prohibits the taking of prawns in certain areas off the Northern Australian coast. The Notice was made under the Fisheries Act 1952 and tabled in the Senate on 11 March 1986. The Committee seeks your advice in connection with retrospectivity in the Notice and review rights missing from it.
Retrospectivity

Notice No. 160 was made by you on 17 February 1986. Sub-paragraphs (b) (i), and (b) (ii) retrospectively prohibit the taking of prawns from the schedule areas ``during the period commencing on 1 December [or 15 December] 1985 and finishing on 7 April 1986''. Sub-section 8a (1) of the Fisheries Act provides for the tabling and disallowance of Fisheries Notices as if they are regulations to which section 48 of the acts Interpretation Act applied except for inter alia sub-section 48 (2). Sub-section 48 (2) voids any instrument expressed to take effect retrospectively where the retrospectivity is prejudicial to an individual.

It appears therefore that the retrospectivity is lawful. However, the Committee noted that in the offence provisions of the Fisheries Act, namely paragraph 13 (1) (i), it is provided that a person shall not do an act prohibited by a Fisheries Notice. Under paragraph 18 (g) of the Act, penalties for a criminal offence can be fines of as much as $250,000. Given the terms of the Notice it makes possible the imposition of a fine of a quarter of a million dollars for commission of an innocent act made criminal by the retrospective operation of a relatively obscure instrument of delegated legislation.

Notwithstanding its apparent validity under the Fisheries Act, the Committee would regard it as quite improper from the point of view of principle that such retrospective criminality should have been created for otherwise innocent acts done between 1 or 15 December 1985 and 17 February 1986, the date of your signature on the Notice. The Committee doubts that you intended to create such retrospective criminality. The Committee would be grateful if it could have your comments and advice on this matter, including your indication as to whether any person, natural or corporate, has been prosecuted, punished or otherwise adversely noted for any retrospectively criminal act committed between 1 or 15 December 1985 and 17 February 1986.
Review Rights

Sub-section 8 (2) of the Fisheries Act provides that a Fisheries Notice may provide exemptions from fishing prohibitions. These prohibitions make certain fishing activities a criminal offence. Paragraph (d) of the Notice exempts certain fishing boats from a prohibition on carrying certain fishing equipment between December 1985 and April 1986 provided that the master of the boat:
``(i) obtains the approval of the officer stationed at Karumba, to undertake fishing gear trials with the use of the boat . . . not less than 24 hours before undertaking the trials.''

As of the date of this letter, the period during which this exemption might have been obtained has expired. Nevertheless, the Committee wishes to draw to your attention for the future the absence of any right to have a denial of approval by the Karumba officer, or any other officer with similar responsibilities, reconsidered or reviewed in some way.

On the Committee's reading of the paragraph in the light of the decision of the Federal Court in Mudginberri v Longhorne and Duthie (unreported, 19 December 1985, No. N.S.W. G246 of 1985) the Karumba officer appears to have a discretion, rather than a duty, to approve trials. The adverse exercise of that discretion could result in financial loss to the master and crew of a boat. Where such loss might occur it should not be borne without the opportunity urgently to have the merits of the exemption decision at least reconsidered by another officer, or at best reviewed by an independent Tribunal. An unreviewable exemption discretion which is adversely exercised without reference to binding criteria can result in the loss of competitive equality of opportunity to earn a reasonable livelihood. This appears to place the exemption discretions under scrutiny here in a different category to those described at paragraph 41 of the Eighth Report of the Administrative Review Council, 1983-84.

If the Committee has misinterpreted paragraph (i) and the Mudginberri decision, then the Karumba officer (and other officers in areas operating under similar provisions) had a duty to approve trials subject only to the 24 hour notice proviso. This would be by far the happier outcome.

The Committee would be grateful if you could comment and advise on the foregoing, in particular indicating whether, if the Karumba officer is in fact vested with a discretion, that discretion was exercised adversely to any relevant fishing master.

The Committee is concerned about the matters raised by its scrutiny of this and other Fisheries Notices. This is essentially because the kinds of problems discussed above have arisen in a type of delegated instrument that is an obscure and easily overlooked source of legislative authority affecting the exercise of rights to a livelihood.
The Committee looks forward to hearing from you on these matters.
Yours sincerely
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA: THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
15 April 1986
The Hon. John Kerin, M.P.
Minister for Primary Industry
Parliament House
Canberra ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan being Plan of Management No. 3-Northern Prawn Fishery, made under sub-section 7b (i) of the Fisheries Act 1952 and tabled in the Senate on 11 March 1986. The Committee's security has given rise to a number of queries on which you might be able to advise.
1. Retrospectivity
Paragraph 3 of the Plan is a saving provision in relation to acts done between 1 January 1986 and 1 March 1986 when the Plan came into force. The paragraph provides that:

``Acts or things done on or after 1 January 1986 for the purposes of, or in relation to compliance with this plan in anticipation of its coming into force may be regarded as having been done under this Plan if done in accordance with its provisions''

Thus, the paragraph retrospectively validates acts done since 1 January 1986. If the acts done were merely internal preliminary administrative arrangements it is unlikely that anyone will have been prejudiced by this retrospectivity in delegated legislation. However, if the acts or things done ``in relation to compliance with this Plan'' were, for example, to suspend or cancel a licence under paragraphs 35 or 36 then such retrospective validation will have prejudiced individuals.
The Committee would be grateful if you could comment on this matter and advise whether any individuals might have been prejudiced by the effects of the retrospectivity.
2. Review Rights

As you know, Principle (c) of the Committee's terms of reference provide that the Committee scrutinises delegated legislation to ensure that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent Tribunal.

The Committee notes firstly that reconsideration and A.A.T. review of certain discretionary decisions is provided for by the drafting device in paragraph 41. However, it appears that review of the discretion exercised under paragraph 10.4 has been overlooked. Paragraph 10.4 provides that:

``Subject to paragraph 10.7. if the Secretary is satisfied that an application under paragraph 10.2 satisfied a criteria in that paragraph, the Secretary shall cause that application to be granted . . .''

The criteria described in sub-paragraphs (a) and (b) of paragraph 10.2 involve subjective matters of opinion and potentially disputatious questions of fact (``is entitled to be granted a boat licence''; ``a boat which the person has used for taking prawns at a certain place and time''; ``the person has . . . a substantial financial commitment to build a boat or to purchase a boat''; ``with the intention of using that boat in the fishery''). There is indeed a greater justification for merits review of the discretion in paragraph 10.4 than for that in paragraph 10.3 which is made subject to review.
Secondly, the discretion reflected in sub-paragraph 35.1 (a) is not exercised subject to any criteria, nor is there any right of review to challenge it on the merits. The paragraph provides that:

``Where the Minister or the Secretary has reasonable grounds to believe that the holder of a licence or a person acting on behalf of a holder of a boat licence has contravened, or failed to comply with, a condition to which the licence is subject . . . or has done an act . . . that the person is prohibited from doing by a [fisheries] Notice, the Minister or the Secretary may suspend the licence [depending on whether the holder has previously been convicted of fishing offences]''.

Obviously this discretion is to be exercised on the basis of potentially disputatious questions of fact and opinion which are amenable to A.A.T. review. This paragraph is to be distinguished from paragraph 36.1 where the fact of a first conviction can be relatively easily established.

The Committee may have overlooked the existence in other related legislation of a right of review for the discretion in paragraph 35. The Committee would welcome your comments and advice on this matter.
3. Subordinate Fettering of Primary Discretions
Principle (a) of the Committee's terms of reference provides that the Committee shall scrutinise delegated legislation to ensure that it is in accordance with the Statute.
The Committee notes that there are several provisions in the Plan couched in mandatory terms which appear to fetter a discretion conferred upon the Minister by the Fisheries Act.

Paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 provide that ``it shall be a requirement made pursuant to a notice under sub-section 8 (1) of the (Fisheries) Act'' that certain boat use be prohibited. However sub-section 8 (1) of the Act provides that:
``The Minister may by notice published in the Gazette . . . prohibit etc. . . .

While the paragraphs may have intended to refer to Fisheries Notices already made in bona fide exercise of the discretion, their effect is not limited to existing Notices. It appears therefore that these provisions of a delegated legislative Plan are designed to fetter the exercise of a discretion conferred by the Act under which the Plan was made.

Likewise paragraphs 35 and 36 give rise to similar problems. In this case the Committee notes that sub-section 9a (1) of the Act provides that the Minister or the Secretary may by notice suspend a master fisherman's licence or a boat licence if there are reasonable grounds to believe that:
there has been a contravention of a licence condition;
a licence holder or his or her agent has done a prohibited act; or
a licence application contains knowingly false or misleading information.

Paragraph 7b (2) (b) provides that a Plan of Management shall set out measures by which the objective of the Plan is to be attained. Sub-paragraph 35.1 (b) of the Plan provides that where the Minister or Secretary has reasonable grounds to believe that a licence holder or agent has contravened a condition or done a prohibited act then, if the licence holder has a previous conviction for fisheries offence, the Minister or Secretary ``shall suspend the licence in accordance with sub-section 9a (1) of the Act''. As noted above, sub-section 9a (1) of the Act confers a discretion to suspend a licence. The exercise of such a discretion is subject both at common law and under the A.D.J.R. Act to judicial and administrative review in keeping with the impact which its adverse exercise may have on a person's right to earn a livelihood.
It appears therefore that the terms of sub-paragraph 35.1 (b) of the delegated legislative Plan are designed to fetter the exercise of a discretion conferred by the Act under which the Plan was made.

The Committee notes that the terms of section 7b of the Fisheries Act do not override the discretion in section 9a. Although sub-section 7b (8) provides that while a plan is in force ``the Minister and the Secretary shall perform their functions and exercise their powers under this Act . . . in accordance with the plan . . . and not otherwise,'' power to fetter a discretion is not a ``power under this Act''.
The Committee would be grateful if you could comment and advise on these aspects of the Plan and the possibility that it may have infringed Principle (a) of the Committee's terms of reference.
Yours sincerely
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
15 April 1986
The Hon. John Kerin, M.P.
Minister for Primary Industry
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered Fisheries Notices Nos. 158 and 162 made under the Fisheries Act 1952 and tabled in the Senate on 11 March 1986. The Committee seeks your advice on certain aspects of the Notices.

Sub-section 8a (1) of the Fisheries Act provides for the tabling and disallowance of Fisheries Notices. Paragraph 8 (1) (a) enables the Minister to prohibit the taking of classes of fish without references to times or periods. Paragraph (b) and sub-paragraph (b) (ii) of Notice No. 158 prohibit the taking of certain prawns unless the applicable number of units of fishing capacity have been assigned to the relevant fishing boat. Paragraph (c) of the Notice states that pursuant to paragraph 8 (3c) (a) of the Act, the Minister thereby specifies ``the period commencing on 1 March 1987 as the period during which'' (my emphasis) the prohibitions in paragraph (b) and sub-paragraph b (ii) have effect.

It may be that, in law, specification of a commencement date is not specification of a period. Sub-section 36 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 suggests that a period of time has an identifiable expiry date or ``last day''.
Sub-section 8 (4c) of the Fisheries Act provides that a prohibition contained in a Fisheries Notice ``has effect'':
``(a) if a period is specified in the Notice during which the prohibition is to have effect-during that period; or
(b) in any other case-at all times''.

If the specification of a commencement date only, is not viewed as the specification of a ``period during which'' the prohibition is operative, then paragraph 8 (4c) (b) of the Act may apply, resulting in the prohibition having effect ``at all times''. This would of course be contrary to your obvious wishes. It may be that the purpose and object provisions of section 15aa of the Acts Interpretation Act could result in the expression ``period'' being read down to include a segment of time commencing on a specified future date without reference to any expiry date. On the other hand such a construction may do violence to the meaning of the word ``period'' as it is otherwise used in legislation.

The Committee would be grateful to have your comments and advice on these matters which are drawn to your attention in order to discover if Fisheries Notice No. 158 has in fact been made in accordance with your wishes.
Fisheries Notice No. 162
Paragraph (a) of this Notice revoke Fisheries Notices No. 65 ``OR'' 65a. The Committee is puzzled by this alternative form of revocation and seeks your advice on it.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
Parliament House,
Canberra A.C.T. 2600

Dear Senator Cooney
I refer to your two letters dated 15 April 1986 concerning various aspects of the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan (the plan) and Fisheries Notice No. 158.
On the same day, you wrote concerning aspects of Fisheries Notice No. 160. I set out below my comments on all the matters you have raised in the three letters.

In one of those letters, you have drawn my attention to paragraph (a) of Fisheries Notice No. 162 concerning the alternative expression of revocation. I agree that ``and'' would have been a more appropriate conjunction.
Plan of Management No. 3-Northern Prawn Fishery

The plan and Fisheries Notice No. 158, together with Fisheries Notice No. 159, comprise a co-ordinated package of subordinate legislation for regulating fishing capacity in the northern prawn fishery (the managed fishery). I note that your Committee has neither raised any questions in relation to Fisheries Notice No. 159 nor commented about the provisions of the plan insofar as it regulates the managed fishery.

The purpose of the savings provision (which has now expired through the effluxion of time) in paragraph 3 of the plan was to validate any action taken by prospective unit holders who wished to comply with the plan before it came into force; for example, by applying for registration of units. Any decision to suspend or cancel a licence can be given effect only by exercise of a power in s.9a of the Act, regardless of what the plan provides by way of guidelines to be taken account of in reaching that decision. In the event, no such decisions were made during the pre-commencement period. I refer to cancellation and suspension of licences in more detail below.

With reference to your comments on review of a decision of the Secretary under paragraph 10.4 of the plan, I agree that such a decision should be subject to review and have approved an appropriate amendment to the plan, to come into force in the near future.

Section 16a of the Fisheries Act 1952 (the Act) provides for review of a decision under sub-section 9a (3a) to cancel a licence. In Scrutiny of Bills Digest No. 4 of 1985, the Senate Standing Committee on Scrutiny of Bills drew attention to the absence from the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 of provision for a decision to suspend a licence to be similarly reviewable. A motion by Senator Archer to amend the Bill in that regard was lost. I fully endorse the remarks of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce when speaking against the motion (Hansard, 14 May 1985, pp.1894/5).

Paragraphs 35.1 and 36.1 of the plan set out the criteria to which the Minister is to have regard when making decisions to suspend a master-fisherman's or a boat licence or to cancel a master-fisherman's licence. Those criteria reflect the decision-making powers provided by sub-sections 9a (1) and (3a) respectively of the Act but do not of themselves provide the powers. If the plan did not contain paragraphs 35.1 and 36.1, the Minister would still have the powers in section 9a but without guidelines on which to make decisions about their exercise and to which a review tribunal could have reference.

The Attorney-General's Department has advised that those paragraphs are valid if they are measures for the attainment of the objectives in paragraph 7 of the plan. I am satisfied that the paragraphs accurately describe the desired policy in relation to exercise of the powers in section 9a and are measures for attaining the objectives of the plan. They specify the manner of exercising those powers when a person is suspected of doing, or has been convicted for having done, an act in relation to the managed fishery that is detrimental to the objectives specified in the plan of conserving the prawn stocks in the area of the managed fishery and reducing the fishing pressure on those stocks.

In relation to the Committee's concern that paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 of the plan fetter the Minister's discretion under section 8 of the Act, the combined purpose of those paragraphs is to foreshadow the link between the purpose of assigning units of fishing capacity to boats and the provisions of the Statute that make it an offence to do an act prohibited by a notice under section 8. The Act does not empower the Minister to establish offences and penalties in plans of management. These are matters for the Act itself to deal with.

By paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 of the plan, I have indicated, as an exercise of the discretionary power vested in the Minister by paragraph 7C (2) (a) of the Act, the action I propose to take under the Act to ensure that only boats to which units are assigned in accordance with the plan may validly operate in the managed fishery.

By publishing Fisheries Notice No. 158, I have sought to give effect under the same Act to that intention so indicated. I therefore do not consider that paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 of the plan, which paragraph 7C (2) (a) of the Act expressly authorises, fetter the discretion under sub-section 8 (1) of the Act. Fisheries Notice No. 158 would have been made to give effect to that intention even if those paragraphs did not exist. Without the notice, the plan would have no practical effect in controlling the amount of fishing capacity in the fishery. It is consistent with sub-section 7B (8) of the Act for me to make a notice which I had, in the plan, indicated my intention to make.

The opinion of the Attorney-General's Department is that, because the discretions under the Act which could be affected by a mandatory provision of the plan are exercised by the same person (i.e., the Minister) who has determined the plan and because they are measures by which the objectives of the plan can be attained, paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 are valid.
Fisheries Notice No. 158

I turn now specifically to your comments in relation to Fisheries Notice No. 158, which gives effect to the intention expressed in paragraphs 9, 13 and 17 of the plan. My intention was that paragraph (b) (ii) of the notice (forecast by paragraph 17) should operate after 1 March 1987 for so long as the notice remained in force.

To meet your Committee's concern and consistently with the advice of the Attorney-General's Department, I have approved the replacement of Fisheries Notice No. 158 by two notices, one applicable in sub-area 1 to have immediate effect and the other applicable in sub-area 2, to have effect from 1 March 1987.

I am satisfied that the plan, Fisheries Notices No. 158 and 159 and the Act constitute a total legislative package for managing the managed fishery and that both the plan and the notices have been prepared in accordance with the Statute to give effect to management policies developed in consultation with the State Governments and industry and approved by the Australian Fisheries Council.
Fisheries Notice No. 160

In relation to Fisheries Notice No. 160, I point out that the prohibitions in sub-paragraphs (b) (i) and (b) (ii) are expressed to expire on 7 April 1986 and thus are no longer in force. In addition, neither the review nor retrospectivity aspects of the notice that are of concern to your Committee have effect in relation to sub-paragraph (b) (iii).

With respect to the apparent retrospective operation of Fisheries Notice No. 160, the Committee will note that paragraph (a) revokes Fisheries Notice No. 154, gazetted on 7 November 1985. I enclose a copy of Fisheries Notice No. 154 for your information. In effect, Fisheries Notice No. 160 remakes No. 154 with additional exemptions from the prohibitions therein. No additional prohibitions are retrospectively created. I have recently adopted the practice of revoking and remaking when amending Fisheries Notices so that the position in relation to any prohibition at any time may be ascertained by reference to a single instrument complete of itself rather than to a principal notice and one or more amendments to which the principal notice makes no reference. It is only when endorsements of licences currently in force refer to particular notices that it may not be appropriate to do this, in which case, a principal notice and amendments continue to be necessary.

No person was prosecuted or otherwise punished for any retrospective criminal act in relation to Fisheries Notice No. 160 between 15 December 1985 and 17 February 1986. Had any person been detected during that period in the area of the general prohibition in possession or charge of unstowed or unsecured trawling gear on a boat, the prosecution would have been for breach of Fisheries Notice No. 154, which was in force during that period.

I would also point out that the maximum penalty that a court may order on convicting a person for breach of a fisheries notice with the use of an Australian boat is $5,000, not, as your letter suggests, $250,000 which is the penalty on conviction on indictment of the master of a foreign boat only.

I acknowledge that Fisheries Notice No. 160 would have been better expressed if the prohibition had applied from its coming into force and have noted this in relation to future amendments of notices. I have approved a notice revoking Fisheries Notice No. 160 and re-making the prohibition in sub-paragraph (b) (iii) applying at all times.

The Committee has also raised the question of review rights in the event of a fisheries officer at Karumba refusing approval for the performance of gear trials. Paragraph (d) of Fisheries Notice No. 160 constituted a significant concession by providing a mechanism for exempting trawler masters wishing to test their gear in waters where Fisheries Notice No. 160 would otherwise prohibit them from having possession of unstowed or unsecured trawling gear on the boat. As is often the case in fisheries management, it is necessary to qualify such exemptions with measures to prevent abuse of the concession and consequent damage to the fishery.

For this reason, sub-paragraph (d) (i) of Fisheries No. 160 required the obtaining of approval in the manner specified before a trawler master might take the benefit of the exemption. The paragraph was not intended to vest the fisheries officer with a discretion. The concession was available for any trawler master who wished to take the benefit of it. Fisheries officers at Karumba did approve all applications of which they had the specified period of notice.
`An obscure and easily overlooked source of legislative authority'

While I understand the Committee's concern about matters coming to its attention in its scrutiny of delegated legislation such as Fisheries Notices and plans of management, I also point out that whenever I publish such instruments, I or my Department also issue media statements explaining them. All such statements are published in the magazine ``Australian Fisheries'' which my Department sends free to all holders of Commonwealth fishing boat licences in Australia. In addition, the media in the areas where notices have effect, have a good record of publishing the statements.

Commercial fishermen are thus able quickly to become aware of what delegated legislation provides. More importantly, the consultative processes that take place between government and fishing industry representatives, often over extended periods, mean that fishermen usually become aware of the provisions of delegated legislation in advance of their publication. For these reasons, I cannot agree with your contention that Fisheries Notices (or any other items of delegated legislation under the Commonwealth's fishery laws) are ``an obscure and easily overlooked source of legislative authority . . .''.

Nevertheless, you have my assurance that I and my Department are fully aware of the importance of protecting the rights of individuals when developing delegated legislation, of making the provisions of such legislation widely known and of conforming with Commonwealth legal policy generally in such matters. At the same time, we have a duty to protect the rights of fishermen who conform with the rules, by creating those rules in a climate of practical enforceability.
Yours sincerely
JOHN KERIN

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT BILL 1986AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage, and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Purpose of the Bills
Mr President, these Bills are complementary and are to be considered concurrently.
The first is for an Act which will, in effect convert the Australian Institute of Sport from a public company to a commonwealth statutory authority.

The second is for an Act to provide for the dissolution of the company known as Australian Institute of Sport, in consequence of the establishment of a Statutory Authority by that name and for related purposes, including the transfer of assets to, and the assumption of liabilities by, the Authority.

The main Bill sets out the objects, functions and powers of the Institute and covers a wide range of issues relating to its management and operation. The Bill defines the relationship between the Institute and the Commonwealth within which the Institute will undertake its tasks.

The complementary Bill ensures that there is administrative continuity between the Company and the Authority on the date of the effect of the legislation and ensures that the interests and entitlements of staff are protected.
Background

Mr President, I do not intend to give a detailed address on the background, achievements and future of the Institute. That level of detail is provided in a supplementary statement on the Institute which will be provided to honourable senators in due course.
It is important, however, to reflect briefly on the Institute's development and progress over the last five years.

In that relatively short time, the Institute has become the focus for top-level sports development in Australia and has earned international recognition as a leading Institution for the training and preparation of high performance sportsmen and sportswomen.

It is timely now to review the Institute's objectives and direction after a period of sustained growth, to ensure that its future operations continue to reflect the aspirations and meet the needs of the Australian sporting community.
In assessing the Institute's performance to date and canvassing options for its future development, it is important to review its origins.

Mr President, the Institute bears testimony to the vision of the Whitlam Labor Government, and particularly Australia's first Commonwealth Minister for Tourism and Recreation, the late Frank Stewart. It was that Government, and that man in particular, who conceived and nurtured the Institute concept to the stage where it could be introduced to serve the interests and needs of the Australian sporting community.

As part of its general commitment to improving the quality of life of all Australians, the Whitlam Government was keen to encourage men, women and children throughout Australian to enjoy and enrich their growing hours of leisure. In that context Frank Stewart asked Professor John Bloomfield, of the University of Western Australia, to review the role, scope and development of sport and recreation in Australia.

Professor Bloomfield's report, which became the platform for many Federal initiatives in sport and recreation, recommended-as one of many proposals-the establishment of a National Institute of Sport and Recreation to provide leadership for and co-ordination of National Sport and Recreation programs, services and research. (I should add here, that it is most appropriate that Professor Bloomfield is still involved closely with the Institute, and is currently Chairman of its Board of Management.)

To develop the institute proposal further, Frank Stewart asked Dr Allan Coles, then from the University of Queensland, to lead a study group which would examine the feasibility of a national sports institute in the context of provisions existing in Australia for the adequate preparation and training of sportsmen, sportswomen, coaches and sports medicine personnel, and make recommendations as to the need for a national sports institute.

After extensive consultation in Australia and an inspection of sports institutes overseas, the study group strongly recommended the establishment of such an institute as a major step towards meeting the needs of sport in Australia, with respect to both mass participation and excellence.

Unfortunately for Australian sport, the study group's report was published in November 1975. The political situation at that time meant that it was never formally adopted by government. Nonetheless, the report was the most significant literary contribution to Australian sport of its time and many of its recommendations have subsequently been put into practice by Federal, State and Territory governments.
The momentum generated by the study group's report was dissipated over the following years by the incoming government's initial lack of interest in the Australian Institute of Sport concept.
It was not until 1980 that the then Minister for Home Affairs, Bob Ellicott, to his great credit, took up the proposal and was able to persuade the then government to pursue it.

The Institute was incorporated as a public company, the most expeditious way of commencing the enterprise, on 24 September 1980 and commenced operations on Australia Day 1981. In its first year, 151 athletes in 8 residential sports-athletics, basketball, gymnastics, netball, soccer, swimming, tennis and weightlifting- attended the Institute.

The responsibilities and functions of the Institute have grown considerably since, in keeping with the enhanced level of support and assistance provided by the present government. For instance, whereas $4.5m was made available for the Institute's operation and programs in 1982-83, $13.944m was provided by this Government in 1985-86 including $2.944m for the management of what has in the past been known as the national sports centre-transferred to the portfolio of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism in December 1984. In 1985-86, 297 athletes in 13 residential sports participated in the Institute's programs, and over 2200 athletes in 52 sports attended the institute under the auspices of the national training centre program introduced in 1982.

In addition to fulfilling its own charter as a centre of sports excellence, the Institute has played an important catalytic role in the establishment of similar institutes by State governments in New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania-all of which have become important components of the national sports development network.

The rapid expansion of the institute's services has placed considerable pressure on the institute. It is seen in some parts of Australia as being all things to all sportspeople. Despite its considerable facilities and resources it is not, and can never aspire to being, such a broad and all-encompassing, enterprise.
Government Announcement

By 1985-86 the Institute had grown further, into an enterprise that employed about 150 staff (28 in 1980-81), had a budget of $13.944m and managed facilities costing $77.5m. In this situation, the government felt it was appropriate to consider alternative modes of management and administration to carry the Institute into the future.
As a result, on 18 November 1985 the Government announced its intention to convert the Australian Institute of Sport to a statutory authority.

This move will enable the AIS to operate with, overall, fewer constraints than in the past. At present the Institute, as a company, is subject to two sets of constraints-those normally applicable to a statutory authority which have been imposed by governmental decisions and practices, and those legally imposed by companies legislation, which can involve, for example, additional reporting and special meeting requirements.

The legislation will ensure appropriate accountability to the government of the day and, through it, to the Parliament. Within this framework, it is-and will remain, under clauses 10 and 25-the responsibility of the Institute's Board to ensure the proper and efficient performance of the functions of the institute, determine its policies and direct the conduct of the affairs of the institute by its director.

The new arrangements will bring the institute into line with other national institutions, such as the Australian Sports Commission, the National Library and the Australian National Gallery, which are also largely government-funded.

Under the new arrangements we propose formally transferring ownership of the facilities at the Bruce complex to the institute. However, the community will continue to have substantial access to those facilities, compatible with institute use, including for appropriate non-sporting purposes.
Major features of the Bills

The main Bill, which builds on the experience of the Institute's operations over the last five years, outlines the Institute's objects, which are to provide resources, services and facilities to enable Australians to pursue excellence in sport, to improve sports coaching standards and to foster co-operation in sport between Australia and other countries.

It is intended, in pursuance of clause 5 (b), that there be an added thrust to the institute's coaching efforts-it being widely recognised in sporting circles that broad developments in coaching standards are essential to improving our performance in top-grade sport and in engendering the right attitudes at all levels of sport. In that regard, it is worthwhile reflecting upon the following comments by one of the world's greatest-ever sportsmen, Sir Donald Bradman, when he was the first inductee to the hall of fame at the Australian gallery of sport in Melbourne. ``The Don'' said that the role of coaches ``. . . is not only to encourage and improve athletic skill, but also to mould citizens who will be a credit to society and who will add to our nation's standing and reputation in all parts of the world''.

The Bill also recognises, in clause 5 (a), not only the original concept of achieving excellence in sport while also furthering educational and vocational skills, but also specifically mentions the furthering of a participating sportsperson's personal development. In that regard, it is again worthwhile recounting the thoughts expressed by Sir Donald Bradman, when he said:

. . . whilst I applaud our government's new-found encouragement for the sporting fraternity, I hope nobody gets carried away by the mistaken notion that financial help and good facilities guarantee success.
They merely open the door. Success must still be motivated from within.
Hard work and dedication remain essential for all individuals who must embrace with equal fervour, opportunity and responsibility.

The Bill defines the functions of the Institute, which include program implementation, facility management, the provision of sports medicine and sports science services, and fund raising for Institute purposes. In performing these functions the Institute will consult widely with national and state sporting bodies and persons in the Australian sporting community, as appropriate. Appropriate consultation will also occur between governmental interests at the Federal and State/Territorial levels.

It also specifies the powers that the institute will have to undertake its work. These include the provision of scholarships, the ability to pursue commercial sponsorship of the institute's activities and the distribution of articles bearing the institute's logo. The institute may also charge fees in respect of access to its resources and facilities.

It is important to note that the Bill makes special mention of community access to the Institute's facilities. This has been a feature of the institute's services to date and, as I mentioned earlier, will continue to be so.

Mr President, I would draw the attention of honourable senators to those aspects of the Bill that define the powers and responsibilities of the Minister. The government is anxious to ensure that the Institute operates both within the framework of overall government sports development objectives and policies-in accordance with a strategic plan to be prepared by the Institute for consideration by the minister-and also in the broader context of government objectives concerning the role of statutory authorities. These provisions make it clear that the Institute will be directly responsible to the government. Together with the provisions that allow the Minister to issue directions to the Institute and review its financial estimates, they will ensure a due and proper degree of ministerial overview and responsibility in harmony with the increased size and importance of the Institute.

The Bill contains the usual sorts of provisions related to a range of administrative and operational issues, including the appointment of members to the board, remuneration and financial management. The members of the board will be appointed by the Governor- General. The board itself will appoint the director. I reiterate that the Institute will be required to submit estimates in respect of its proposed budget, will be subject to the scrutiny of the Auditor-General and will be required to publish an annual report, which will be presented to parliament.
The consequential provisions Bill is, as the title implies, required to cover all the ``once-only'' matters that are associated with the conversion of the company to the statutory authority.

Its main effect is to dissolve the company on the commencement of the act. I am advised that this is the most appropriate method of winding up the affairs of the company, in the context of simultaneously establishing the statutory authority.

Honourable senators will note that the statutory authority automatically assumes responsibility for the assets and liabilities of the company, so there will be administrative continuity between the two bodies.

Particular attention is drawn to the various clauses which relate to protection of interests and rights of institute staff. In effect, terms and conditions for transferred staff will be those which exist under the company.

The Statutory Authority will be also required to fulfil the normal financial reporting requirements for 1985-86, on behalf of the company, and the standard arrangements for audit of the Institute's affairs for that year will be effected.
Financial Impact Statement

It is intended that the Statutory Authority be established on 1 July 1986, which is a particularly convenient date in terms of administrative arrangements and financial appropriations. At this stage the Government's allocation to the Institute for 1986-87, its first full year of operation as a statutory authority, is still being considered in the Budget context, and also in the context of a comprehensive review of the Institute's funding and staffing arrangements which is being carried out by the Department of Finance and the Institute.

While it is the Government's concern that the Institute has sufficient funds available to continue its present level of activity, and over time to pursue a number of new sports development initiatives, such issues also need to be considered in the light of the Government's overall economic policy and the allocation of funds for the Australian Sports Commission and the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, each of which have clear and specific responsibilities in the sector of sports development appropriate to their proper roles and structures.

With the formal transfer to the AIS of responsibility for facilities management allied with the establishment of the Institute as a statutory authority, we look to general improvements in management and operational effectiveness including the areas of maintenance and cleaning; purchasing; security; concessions and catering; facility usage and public relations, promotion and marketing activities.

These improvements will be reflected, primarily, in better quality services to the public, AIS athletes and coaches, and commercial entrepreneurs. They should manifest themselves quantitatively in the medium term (2-3 years) through increased revenue resulting from greater usage of the facilities.

To give the AIS the flexibility it needs in the management of the complex, it is proposed that the AIS be funded in a single line appropriation, although the facilities' operating costs will be separately identified for accounting and management purposes.

Mr President, this Bill places the Australian Institute of Sport clearly within the ambit of the Government's commitment to overall management improvement within the public sector. I am confident that the proposed arrangements will enhance the quality of the Institute's functions without themselves leading to extra costs, and have a consequential impact on the standards of sports performance and coaching in this country.
The Future

Honourable senators will note that the Bill provides for the Board of the Institute to prepare a strategic plan, initially for 3 years and then updated regularly. The initial plan, and any variations to it, will need to be approved by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Work on the first plan is currently being done.
As mentioned earlier, a separate statement of the history achievements and possible future directions of the Institute shall be provided.

At this stage I wish to say, however, that the Government has been committed to the consolidation and, subsequently, the extension of Institute programs and activities to ensure that the maximum number of Australians can benefit from them over time.

I am sure that the growing bond between the Institute and State Institutes of Sport will be strengthened over time. Such cooperative arrangements can only enhance the range of opportunities available to our sportspeople and further develop Australian sport.

It is likely that there will be greater opportunities for non-resident athletes to use the Institute's resources through such measures as the National Training Centre program and the Satellite Coaches program.

Although the Institute is located in Canberra we see it servicing the needs of Australia and, as a consequence, will be looking to ensure that its advice, services and resources are readily available to those needing them through the decentralisation program already commenced in Perth and Brisbane.

Mr President, this short overview of the Institute's origins, development and future is intended to demonstrate to honourable senators the significance of its role in Australian sport and sports development.

The Government remains committed to providing the optimum training environment and technical support for our leading athletes. It remains committed to the provision of increased opportunities for Australian sportspeople to reach their potential. It remains committed to the role of the Institute in achieving those objectives.

However, I would remind honourable senators that the Institute does not stand alone as the vehicle for the development of sport in this country. Programs administered by the Australian Sports Commission, which was conceived and developed by the current Government, and established as a statutory authority on 1 July 1985 extend assistance to all levels of the Australian sporting structure and balance the top-level orientation of the Institute.

These initiatives complement and balance the functions of the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism which will continue to provide policy advice on sport and recreation matters, as well as administer major facility development programs and sport and recreation programs for the disabled, and implement recreation, fitness and safety initiatives which will enhance the leisure environment for all Australians.

Mr President, the record of this Government in providing assistance for sport in Australia is unique. Our support has enhanced the capacity and capability of the Australian sporting infrastructure to cope better with the increasing demands placed on it.

The Government firmly believes that the Australian Institute of Sport is vital to sports development in Australia and to Australia's re-emergence on the world's sporting fields. The Government is dedicated to ensuring that its significance and status will not be diminished.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I raised the fact that a number of problems had been brought to my attention regarding this legislation-problems that related in particular to clauses 28 and 33 of the Social Security Amendment Bill 1986 before us today. Clause 28 relates to what is known as the young homeless allowance, and the problems that have been brought to my attention deal with the rather loose definition of what makes up a young person who is defined as being homeless, who decides whether that person is in fact homeless, what proof is required, and what qualifications the people who decide the proof must possess. The problems with regard to the young homeless allowance were, as I said, with the definition of homelessness-the wide range of things, including things such as incestuous harassment at home, domestic violence and so on; who decides what proof is required, and what sort of counselling is going to be provided to those young people who are already suffering from significant psychological and emotional problems. Issues of this sort are vital, considering the potential loss of income and/or income through benefits that some young people are likely to face as a consequence of the legislation. Certainly the people who have come to me and been concerned do not believe that they have been given adequate or appropriate responses from the Ministers or the departmental people they have seen. I hope that the Minister will give assurances that the concerns raised are unfounded.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area of concern brought to our attention relates to clause 33 which is headed `Benefit not payable to full-time students'. As I said yesterday, there has been considerable difficulty in establishing with the Department of Education and with other departments involved in this legislation exactly what the definition of `full-time study' or `full-time student' is. Eligibility for benefits depends on the students' study program and whether they are full time or part time. This will affect not only those who receive some of the benefits we mentioned yesterday but also those, I presume, on supporting parent benefits since the provision talks about benefits not being payable.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it will not.

—The Minister says `No', and I am pleased that items such as supporting benefits will not be picked up. It reinforces the fact that there is some lack of clarity in the legislation which is causing considerable concern among students and young people generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats will not support the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion, for some of the reasons I mentioned yesterday. We do not believe that the amnesty in any way is being directed at people who deliberately defraud the system, and that it is being aimed only at assisting those who have got themselves caught up, unwittingly, in overpayments. They have got themselves on a treadmill and have been too afraid to go to the Department, have stayed in that position and have got beyond the point of no return. Given that many such people are elderly and easily upset, they need the sort of assistance that this kind of amnesty will provide. Frankly, I do not believe that the amnesty undermines the work of departmental field officers or sabotages field investigators' morale. What undermines the work of departmental field officers and the morale of officers in the Department of Social Security is simply that there are not enough of them. In some States field officers are being brought out of the field and placed behind desks because the amount of desk work is increasing. Such officers feel that the work they were originally employed to do is simply not being done and, furthermore, that the work they are now doing is not appropriate to their qualifications or to the value they believe they could have to the Department and indeed to the community generally.

The Opposition argues that the amnesty will give no guarantee that overpayment and fraud will not occur in the future. I do not suppose it will, but I cannot think of too many solutions that will ensure that problems of this kind will not recur. As I pointed out yesterday, the Government has a staffing problem. The very people who complain that there is a certain amount of cheating in areas such as the Department of Social Security or some unintentional overpayments are the same people who raise Cain if the Department's staff ceilings are raised because they are the same people who believe that Government expenditure should be cut. One suggested way of cutting government expenditure is to cut back on the number of public servants, regardless of the departments they are in and regardless of the value that they have to the community.

The final point that the Opposition makes is that the Government's economic policies, such as the capital gains tax and the prohibition on negative gearing, have increased the cost of housing and rent, necessitating extending the rent subsidy to the long term unemployed. Firstly, it was long past time that the rent subsidy was extended to the long term unemployed. Secondly, from the figures that I quoted yesterday, which I obtained from the Real Estate Institute of Australia, there appears to have been no significant cut in monthly vacancy rates in January, February and March of this year as compared to January, February and March of last year in cities other than Perth. I said yesterday that the changes there were more likely to have been due to the run up to the America's Cup and the trials that were going on there than to negative gearing.

The Australian Democrats have supported the principles behind the Government's tax reform package simply because they introduced equity into a system which had previously been highly inequitable, where some people, mostly those on high incomes, were able to avoid tax by certain artificial measures, including negative gearing and getting part of their remuneration package in things such as cars and overseas trips. As far as the principle of that is concerned, the Democrats believe that the principle of equity is an overriding one. We support it and do not agree with the criticism which the Opposition is putting in this attachment to the second reading motion, that the processes of introducing tax equity have had some other sort of deleterious effect on the community generally. Certainly, that is not yet apparent as far as negative gearing is concerned. As to the bleating that is going on in the community about the low number of cars that have been sold this year, I suggest that Opposition members do the sort of graph work which I have done in the last couple of days on car registrations for the last five years. They will find that the variations in car registrations, and hence in new car sales, is a significant one across all years, under all governments that have been in office since I have been in this place. It is highly unlikely that the drop in registrations in the last couple of months has had anything at all to do with the fringe benefits tax and far more to do with the fact that last year there was a massive increase in sales of new cars.

Overall, the Democrats are supporting the Government's social security legislation. I repeat the comment I made yesterday in regard to clause 33. We will oppose that clause if we cannot get some satisfactory answer from the Government on what a full time student is and what full time study means. At the moment, a lot of the students who have come to see us are floundering around in the dark about that, and are unnecessarily being made anxious at a time of year when they ought to be putting most of their energies into study and not into worrying about the contents of a piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate and for not opposing this legislation. It will be no surprise to anybody that the Government does not agree with the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume. The first matter I will deal with is the matter of the amnesty, which is the matter referred to by Senator Peter Baume in the first part of his amendment. I think the amendment itself demonstrates the lack of understanding about what the amnesty is about, a lack of understanding which became prominent on the first day that the amnesty was announced with the almost hysterical reaction from the Australian Federal Police spokesman on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The amnesty came about-it was something we were looking at when I was Minister for Social Security-because there are several groups of people who get caught up in the business of overpayments. First, there are those people who deliberately defraud the Department of Social Security, who set out to do so from day one, the sorts of people referred to by Senator Peter Baume, the sort of person who is getting benefit under 35 different names, the sort of person who is working and still receives a benefit because he or she gives false information. Those people who are deliberately defrauding the Department do not come under the amnesty. They are not supported by anyone in this place. This Government will detect them and prosecute them with as much vigour as would any other government.

However, there is a group of people who get caught up in overpayments for other reasons. The first group is those who initially do not declare changes in circumstances because they do not understand the system. My colleague the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, has been helping them by changing the nature of the letters that we send to social security recipients in these circumstances. They are letters which in future will be more easily understood, letters that are less formal and less stilted in their language so that people will understand them. Another group of people get on what has been described as a treadmill. They receive benefits and sometimes receive small amounts of other income but for all sorts of reasons do not declare it. Gradually this situation gets worse and worse and they get to the stage that, because of a fear of bureaucracy, a fear of facing bureaucracy or a fear of the consequences, they do not declare it. It is that group of people who the amnesty will pick up and is picking up and it is that group of people who departmental field officers and field investigators believe should be specially treated by the Department. They are not the same group of people who deliberately defraud the Department.

I can assure Senator Baume and members of the Opposition that in no way do field officers or field investigators feel that their role has been undermined by this amnesty. In fact the majority of them, if not all of them, believe that the amnesty is reasonable. It is a similar amnesty to the amnesty which has been given in the past to illegal immigrants. It is not the sort of thing one has over and over again. In fact I do not think the Government would ever intend to have it again. The amnesty was conducted to provide a circuit breaker to see whether we can get out of the system that group of people who were stuck there. I think we will find that it will probably succeed. Of course it will not be successful in completely eliminating that group of people but it is a useful attempt to get out of the system that group of people who have received overpayments and who would be quite happy to be out of the system but who, for all sorts of reasons, particularly fear of the bureaucracy, et cetera, are now stuck in it. I do not think it is fair to say that we are trying to establish double standards and disadvantage honest clients. We are dealing with a grey area rather than a black and white area. I will be interested to see how successful the amnesty is.

Senator Baume's and Senator Haines's contributions on the new youth allowance demonstrate very clearly the sorts of dilemmas that all governments face. Senator Baume expressed the very real concern that we do not want to do something which will encourage young people to leave home. We do not want to do something which will encourage emotionally turbulent young people who are having a blue with their parents, like mine always do, to leave home and immediately get benefits and immediately get on another treadmill of receiving a benefit and perhaps even aggravating a situation. We are very conscious of that; I think anyone who has dealt with this area is always very conscious of that.

On the other hand Senator Haines pointed out quite correctly that we do not want to be too tough on those young people who leave home because they are chucked out or who leave home for reasons stated in the legislation-domestic violence, incestuous harassment or other such exceptional circumstances. It is for that reason that the six weeks limit is put on. The reason that the legislation apparently worries some people and some of the people who have approached Senator Haines and others is that they find it not specific enough. They think that in some way we should be able to spell out in very specific terms exactly the circumstances under which someone should receive this allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you actually saying that the six weeks waiting period is not an absolute one, if there are reasons?
—No. What I am saying is that that is why the six weeks was put in. Some people will say that six weeks is too short; others will say that six weeks is far too long.
—But it depends on the circumstances.

—Yes, but what I am getting to is that, if rigid guidelines had been written into this, the criticism would have been that we are far too rigid and too inflexible. So in this area of payments of social security benefits of this kind, of necessity they must be flexible and I am afraid that of necessity there will always be an element of discretion in deciding who will receive an allowance and who will not. The basis of the assessment will inevitably have to be individual assessment. It will come down to individual judgments by individual officers of the Department of Social Security. Therefore training, sensitivity and counselling are absolutely essential.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is establishing the administrative structures to deal with this now. Quite clearly we have to have proof of the fact that the person has not been living at home. We need some proof that the parents are unwilling to or will not continue to support the young person. We have to ensure that the person is not receiving continuous support of other types. I suggest that that will involve a whole series of different forms of investigation in different places. As was quite rightly suggested by the young people's group that wrote to Senator Haines, it would be ludicrous if either the Department of Social Security or the Department of Education just wrote to parents and asked: `Are you supporting this person or not?'. Quite clearly it will involve field officer work, investigations and inquiries not only of parents but also of the young people and of anyone else who can give information. Those administrative structures are being drawn up. It will be difficult and it is a sensitive area. But, as soon as the guidelines are out, I am sure that Senator Haines, Senator Baume and others will be able to look at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the first six weeks is there a capacity to pay special benefit?

—No, I understand that it will be removed altogether. So in some circumstances there will have to be other sources of support through the emergency relief system. People may say that that is hard. I remember well that I was involved in the debate on this. I was not sure what we had come down with finally. But, if there is to be such a benefit which has the potential to do the sorts of things to which Senator Baume referred, one has to be hard and to be pretty rigid.

SPEECH.PARA: People talk about our system being difficult and hard. But, if Senator Haines goes overseas and talks to Ministers in the large social democracies of western Europe, she will find that they are quite amused at our unique unemployment benefit system. Our system pays a benefit which is not generous by international standards. But we pay it for much longer than in any other country. We pay it initially without a waiting period in a way that I believe no other country does.

People in the Scandinavian countries, in West Germany and elsewhere are always amazed that we will pay unemployment benefits to someone who leaves school and has no history in the work force. They are quite fascinated and shattered by this and wonder how on earth we do it. We do it by paying that unemployment benefit at a relatively low rate and paying it for much longer. We have to make hard choices. One hard choice is that there has to be a six-week waiting period. People have to stay out of the system for that six weeks. There are alternative means of support through State governments and emergency relief. They are not satisfactory. I do not pretend that they are. But that is the sort of decision that has to be made. There will be discretions; there will be administrative difficulties. This matter will require sensitivity and considerable skill. It may require some modification in the future; but it is the sensible way to approach this matter.

Senator Haines expresses concern about clause 33 and the problem of the full time student. When I was Minister for Social Security, a phenomenon which was noticeable then and is noticeable now is the number of unemployment benefits paid by social security offices near universities and colleges of advanced education. When I was Minister, one year at Armidale 350 students suddenly applied for the unemployment benefit. Those students make up that group of people who do not qualify for the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance because of the means test and who use the unemployment benefit as an alternative. Those people were assisted-one might even say that they were aided and abetted-by counsellors and others in the CAEs and universities who were very good at adjusting courses and hours of study to enable students in these circumstances to apply for and to get the unemployment benefit as a substitute for TEAS.

We have a system which provides unemployment benefits or TEAS allowance, and students who do not qualify for TEAS because they or their families are better off than other students-that is not making a judgment about whether family income should be included, because it is-are using the social security system, the unemployment benefits system, as an alternative to TEAS. In some cases, I understand, they are supplementing TEAS with the unemployment benefit. Parliament and society have made a judgment that one is either a student or one is not. A full time student is defined in the education legislation for the purposes of applying for TEAS and the other benefits that are described in the legislation before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which education legislation?
—The tertiary education assistance scheme, the adult secondary education assistance scheme, the Aboriginal study grants scheme, the post-graduate award scheme, and the secondary allowance scheme.
—Which legislation?
—I don't know which Act.
—Neither does anybody else, that is the trouble. Nobody can find that definition.

—I will find a definition for the honourable senator. For our purposes and for the purposes of the Department of Social Security, a full time student who cannot make himself available for work because of studies does not qualify for unemployment benefits. I understand the sympathy of honourable senators for students who have managed to work the system so that they get an educational allowance from the social security system.
—That is not fair, and you know it.
—It is fair. It is absolutely accurate.
—It may not be fair but it is true.

—It is certainly true. What we are trying to do and, I believe, what we are doing successfully, is what Senator Haines says we should do-get the unemployment benefits and tertiary allowances into kilter and get down the track towards an allowance which provides support for students and others. We are certainly tidying up a situation which everyone agrees is unsatisfactory. Senator Haines has an urgent need to tidy up everything, believing that in a social security system one can get everything tied down with tight definitions, so that everyone knows where he is, but what one ends up with--
—Just a definition would do. It does not have to be tight. Something that is a definition would be an improvement.
—I understand that a person who qualifies for the tertiary education assistance scheme has to be a full time student. There is a definition there somewhere.
—No, there is not. There is one in the manual.

—There is a definition in the manual; that is in the legislation. The manuals and the guidelines are associated with the legislation. If one wants a rigid and strict definition in this area, one will end up making the system so rigid and inflexible that Senator Haines and Senator Macklin will be the first two honourable senators to get up in the Senate and read us a lecture on inflexibility in the system, saying that we are too heartless and too cruel. We have been through this a million times in regard to the social security system and the education system, and Senator Haines and Senator Macklin know it. It is a very good point to make for people such as Senator Haines and Senator Macklin who can get up and advocate what they like in the absolute certainty that they will never be in government and have to fulfil what they advocate.
—Will we do that on the fringe benefits tax?

—I am sorry that I have upset the Democrats. It is early in the morning and I know that they are a sensitive little group. I know that they are sensitive little souls and I do not want to upset them so early in the morning, but--
—Don't upset the Cabinet. The Bill has not passed yet.

—The Democrats will pass the legislation because, as Senator Haines has said, it is very fair, it is very good and it is introducing a reform into the system which everyone accepts should be introduced. For that reason, I thank honourable senators for supporting the legislation. I am sorry that I cannot accept the extraordinary amendment put forward by Senator Peter Baume, but I used to put up amendments like that all the time when I was in opposition and governments did not accept them then.
