I think the amnesty has been a sensible move, acting as a circuit breaker. I hope that it will be as successful as we thought it might have been when I was the Minister for Social Security. However, even if it is not, it will enable many people to get out of the treadmill of the system.

SPEECH.PARA: If the new youth allowance, as tight and as difficult as the definition in this case may be, is administered with sensitivity, compassion and skill by the officers of the Department of Social Security, as I know it will be, it will enable us to support a group of people in our community who are not being supported now and who are at risk. The change brought about by clause 33 to limit the capacity of certain people in universities and colleges of advanced education to manipulate the system is, despite the problems of Senator Haines and Senator Macklin, a change which has been inevitable because I do not think it is a sensible system if it leaves a loophole which enables people who are better off than others to have a choice between the education system and the social security system as to where they get their income support. For that reason it was important to introduce that change. I thank honourable senators for their contribution and for their support.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 20 contains one of the statements defining a student as homeless. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (A) the parents of the person do not have, or, where the parents of the person are not living at the same home, neither of the parents of the person has, a home at which the parents are, or the parent is, as the case may be, prepared to allow the person to live;

When we plough our way through all of those qualifying clauses we get to the basic point that if the parents do not want their kid in the house the child is defined as homeless. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) was talking about dealing with all this sort of thing sensitively, compassionately and with understanding, which brought a tear to the eyes of most of the honourable senators in the chamber at the time. I wonder, however, what will happen if there is some discrepancy between the parents' version of why the child is not living at home and the child's or student's version of why he or she is not living at home. We all know of instances where parents lay down criteria under which a student or child may live under their roof. Sometimes they are unreasonable criteria; sometimes they only appear to be unreasonable to the child. I just wonder whether the Minister can say under those circumstances what attitude the departmental officials are likely to take if there is some dispute between the parents and the students concerned and some discrepancy in the evidence that is brought before the departmental officers, as to whether the parents are prepared to have the young person living at home.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow up the point that has been made by Senator Haines. Having listened to her speech and having listened to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), it is obvious that there is going to be some administrative difficulty in this area. For example, it seems to me that, if I were a potential applicant of 16 or 17 years of age, the Department of Social Security would first have to ask me to make a declaration of some kind to the effect that I came under one of the categories referred to. The Minister said that there would have to be some administrative procedures, but what procedures will be used to check the declaration? To change roles, if I were a parent who fell into one of the relevant classes, I might be disposed to deny--
—Particularly if incest has been mentioned.

—Particularly so; but, whatever the circumstances, I might be inclined to deny them. There is a question as to how on earth the Department will test these matters. It is very likely that statements made will be in conflict one with the other. There will be certain circumstances in which the youth can call upon independent evidence. That is fine, but often there will be cases where the student cannot do so. I am intrigued to know, in light of what Senator Haines has raised, how on earth we are to determine where the facts of any particular matter lie, particularly where a parent may have a vested interest in putting forward a contrary view, at least in public.

—I wish to deal with the same issue. As the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) will know, we have both been in the thick of this matter on previous committee hearings. On many occasions both sides have been correct in their approach. As viewers of the evidence from both sides, we could not possibly tell which is correct. The parents may say: `There is a bed here; I want the child to come home but the child will not come'. It is really a matter, first, of who we believe and, secondly, of our own feelings-perhaps even moral feelings-on the issue itself. I will give an example. At the tender age of 14 or 15 a child has a right to live his life exactly as he pleases while living at home. What will be the attitude of the officer making the decision-
—It has to be 16 or 17.
—So there is no allowance under the age of 16, is that correct?
—Only the special benefits available now; but that does not come under this homeless youth scheme.

—Fine. When a child reaches the age of 16 and wants to live his own life completely, but at home, he may consider it very unjust if the parent demands that a certain standard should be kept in the home. How does the officer possibly then make a decision because it then relates back to the officer's own sense of moral code of standards that he sees as being applicable? The area is going to be very difficult for the Department.

—On the same issue, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) will be aware that most State governments have laws requiring notification of things such as child abuse, and incest, of course, falls into that area. I would like to know first of all whether those laws, to the Minister's knowledge, cover welfare officers in Federal Government departments who presumably will be dealing with the students who claims homelessness on the grounds of domestic violence or incestuous harassment.
—You are saying they would be required to declare it to the State authorities?

—Yes. There are a number of States where there is a requirement that certain professional groups which become aware of child abuse, and that would include sexual abuse, must notify the authorities that this is happening. This leaves the parents open, and quite rightly so, to legal sanctions. I want to know whether the Federal officers dealing with these young people will be covered by those State requirements or some similar Federal requirements. If they are and if they believe the student who claims that he is homeless because of those unfortunate circumstances will this be taken as prima facie evidence that the activities within the home have taken place? Where does that leave the family as a whole? I think that the Government is right in allowing students the right not to suffer additional penalties if the home environment is appalling, but the student may be rather loath to come forward if in doing so he is going to find suddenly that his parents are subject to all sorts of penalties even though they may deserve it. The relationship between the parent and the child is such that they may feel rather unhappy about it, as has occurred in cases of domestic violence where wives have not wanted to lay charges. They want to be protected, but they do not necessarily want the full force of the law brought in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last matter, most of the State laws do refer to children under the age of 16 and this legislation refers to children under the age of 16 and 17. Secondly, section 17 of the Social Security Act, the secrecy provisions, protects our Federal people under those circumstances. I can appreciate the questions raised by Senator Walters and others and the Government does not run away from the very considerable difficulties that arise here, but I think honourable senators should realise how tough this legislation is. In a situation where parents are prepared and say that they are prepared to have those young people back home then the second situation applies-domestic violence or the incestuous harassment applies. It is difficult. This is a very difficult set of criteria that people have got to overcome to get this allowance. It is deliberately difficult for the reasons that Senator Peter Baume spoke about earlier. It fills a gap for a relatively small group of people in the community. There will inevitably be in some situations discrepancies between the story put by the young person and the story put by the parents. No one is running away from that.

SPEECH.PARA: There are certain things which will assist us. The first is that obviously that six-week waiting period in most cases will eliminate the vexatious or turbulent young person. My experience of my children is that most of it does not last anywhere near six weeks-it recurs all the time, but it does not last six weeks. Secondly, when we have this discrepancy I say no more than that what we must do is use people who have skills. I know this brings tears to the eyes of Senator Haines, but it is a fact: We need skilled social workers, skilled counsellors, who will have to make judgments. They will make these judgments not necessarily by themselves but with others, as they have to do in this area all over the place. They will have to make judgments about taking and using evidence. In many cases there will be obvious evidence, and they will have to make certain judgments in certain groups of cases. Sometimes they will make wrong judgments. But at the moment there is nothing for this group of kids. In most cases it will be pretty clear. In the more difficult cases it will not be clear, and we will certainly have to modify the manuals and the guidelines as we progress. We may even have to modify the legislation, and modify the toughness of this definition. But that is the nature of this area of work. We have people who are trained and who are skilled. If someone here can suggest how we can put into legislation a set of rules and guidelines, or a definition which will cover all cases and which will not leave grey areas, I and others in the Government and the bureaucracy will be very happy to see such a suggestion. I do not think it is possible. We are in a situation in which some very difficult judgments will have to be made. There will be the odd case, as Senator Walters has correctly pointed out, where people will try the system on.

We have thought for a long time about the alternatives available for young people, as I am sure the previous Government did. There have been a couple of cases in Australia already where young people have sued their parents for support. That is very difficult under our system, but it has happened; it has been done successfully. An alternative is to have a system of the type that exists in some western European countries, where the parent is liable no matter what the circumstances. A child literally can decide to leave home but the parent is liable to support that child, and wages are actually garnisheed for that purpose. Under those circumstances a judgment is made by the courts as to how much the parent should use to support the young person. It is taken and given to the young person under supervision by the state. I do not think this country is at that stage; in fact, I think we are a fair way from that.

In the circumstances of community attitudes in this country, I think our legislation is a fair enough approach. I think it will be successful in the vast majority of cases. In the difficult cases there will be problems and we may have to modify things. I do not get away from the fact that it will not be easy, and there will be some difficult decisions to be made, but I do not think that is a reason not to do something like this. Senator Haines correctly pointed out that there is a youth group here in Canberra, particularly, that has considerable complaint about the toughness and difficulty of the legislation. This group is doing what lobby groups always do-a reform is introduced and they talk about the reform as though it has always existed; they say it is not good enough and that it is restricting their capacity to operate. In fact, this is a reform that is being introduced where absolutely nothing worth while now exists. Whatever there is in this legislation is better than the system we have now. If it is not as good as they would like, fair enough.

One point that Senator Haines raised last night which I meant to answer today concerns the complaint of this group in Canberra that we have not consulted them. I assure Senator Haines that in fact the present Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), the Minister for Social Security before him-which was me-and the Minister for Social Security before me, Senator Chaney, have spent a considerable time discussing with the various youth representatives in this country this problem and many other problems. The difficulty is that there is a plethora of groups and all these groups, and sometimes all the individuals in these groups, want to be consulted every week. We cannot do it. In this area, in the women's refuge area and in the child care area there has been plenty of consultation by people on both sides of the Parliament for a very long time. To suggest that we have not been willing to talk and consult is unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree with Senator Grimes that the provisions in this legislation are a lot better than nothing at all, as is presently the case, particularly for students, because with a little bit of luck we might encourage them to stay at school-something that was virtually impossible under the previous system, as they had to be unemployed to get any assistance. I ask the Minister what sort of appeal mechanism there would be for the parents if they considered that a completely unjust decision had been made against them and their child had been, in effect, lured away from home as a result of being given financial independence. I am sure that is how it will be described.
—Parents will be able to appeal through the existing administrative appeals system and through the courts. There is no specific appeals provision built into the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 33 of the Bill. The problem here is not that it is the intention of the Government to avoid a double dipping operation-let us take it for granted that everybody is opposed to that-but the problem that student bodies find with the clause in the breadth of its drafting. It may in many ways pick up unintended consequences that the Government has not thought about, or has not thought through correctly. I refer the Minister to the tertiary education assistance scheme as an example. If a person becomes ill and remains ill for more than eight weeks, the assistance will continue only up to the point that the person cannot show that he is able to remain enrolled in the course. The difficulty arising with the drafting of this is that if a student has a three-year course and a TEAS allowance is paid on a monthly basis, that includes vacation periods. On my reading of it, the person would be ineligible for any benefit during those holiday periods, no matter what happened to him. I will be interested to see whether or not the person is actively excluded from sickness benefits during that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a second example. Paragraph 15.741 of the Unemployment and Special Benefits Manual, which contains an interminable discussion with regard to what anybody might require to be a full time student, states:

Where the time spent in employment exceeds 25 hours a week, it is not normally accepted that the child is a full time student unless it can be established that the work being performed is not a bar to full time studies . . .

I take the Minister's point but I would be interested to know of the types of abuses the Department of Social Security has picked up, because in paragraph 2.922 it appears that the Department is already applying these criteria-that a person be unemployed, be capable of undertaking suitable paid work, be willing to undertake suitable paid work and have taken reasonable steps to obtain such work. I refer to that because paragraph 15.741 then goes on to give a very interesting example. That example is:

. . . unless it can be established that the work being performed is not a bar to full time studies, e.g. a student works from 5 p.m. to 10 p.m. four days a week and then more than five hours on a weekend. Nevertheless, each case should be treated on its merits as the `25 hours' guideline is not a hard and fast rule.

It is not only people who receive TEAS who are affected by this but also people who are ruled ineligible to receive TEAS for two reasons. The first reason is that their parents have sufficient income to exclude them from receiving TEAS-that is, income starting at $14,000-odd going up to $24,000, or up to $30,000 if the person is living away from home. Under those types of circumstances a person may be ruled out for TEAS but not ruled out for unemployment benefit. In a move to try to make sure that the person is eligible for unemployment benefit the Government has managed to say that the person has actually to sit at home and do nothing, then it knows he is eligible for unemployment benefit. I should have thought a better way would be to encourage people to study. I should have thought that a better expenditure of government money all round, and the community's money, would be to have no bar on people trying to better or improve themselves in some way. I am only interested in those legitimate cases where there is not a double dipping and where the second reason for exclusion occurs-that is, a person is actually ruled out because his parents' income is above the level and he is now trying to support himself through studies. The Minister knows that there are plenty of people in those circumstances, difficult though it is in our community to do that.

Secondly, a person may be barred because he has failed the previous year and decided to keep going and study. Such persons may have a job during the day and rearrange their full time study. But they cannot under the Minister's application of the rules up to now, by the way. It does not have to be full time because, if one takes the other definition that the Commonwealth is currently using of full time studies, it only has to be 75 per cent of the amount of work prescribed by the institution as a year's work. That is in the definition given of the statistics that the Department of Education uses to allocate money to universities, which is different from the 25-hour rule. Under those circumstances I give the example of a person who is working, who has arranged for his full time studies to take place in the evenings and who falls into unemployment. He was employed and he was a full time student. There are plenty of people in our community who have two full time jobs. That person now has to give up his studies because he cannot get unemployment benefit during the day. He can work and be a full time student but he cannot be unemployed and be a full time student. That is what the Government is now saying. That person who wished to work and put himself through the full time course at night is deprived of doing so, under my reading of this provision, if he becomes unemployed. What the Government is saying is that if that person sits at home, that is fine.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you propose fixing it?

—If one looks at the rules that the Department is already applying under its unemployment and special benefits manual, one finds that it is in fact employing the case by case situation that the Minister was lauding before as being the way to deal with these matters. There is a very explicit operation in the manual as to how this whole thing takes place. It goes into a very detailed operation in terms of the verification of full time status-that is, that the case is looked at first of all, the institution is approached as to what is its classification of the course that the person is undertaking and the institution is approached as to when that particular operation takes place and whether it is a full evening course. If that is not successful in determining the status of the dependant, the officer who is using this manual has to go to the Commonwealth Department of Education to see whether that course is registered as a full time course for the purposes of TEAS. Before people even get to there the officer has to apply those four previous criteria. Two of those criteria are that a person has to be available for full employment and has to be able to be seeking work. He has to fulfil all of those criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just wondering whether this is another one of those excesses of caution on the part of the Department to make sure that the person is sitting at home and not doing anything so that the Government can be assured that that person really is eligible for unemployment benefit. I would have thought that it is far better to proceed in the way that the Department already has proceeded. I am interested in the types of abuses that the Minister raised in terms of numbers and why the particular procedures set out in the manual have not succeeded in stopping those abuses, where precisely those abuses are, and whether clause 33 is drafted in such a way as to be so wide as to run foul of problems in terms of sickness and supporting benefits. The Minister shook his head during the second reading stage and indicated that that was not the case. I would be interested to know why that is so.

Lastly, I make a comment on the gratuitous comment that the Minister made. If his comment holds up and we are about populist causes, I presume it means we can vote against the fringe benefits tax. The Minister was saying before that we do not have to take any responsibility for our vote, in which case there is really no problem with regard to the discussions that are currently going on elsewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I used the word `populist' at all. In fact, I remember hearing part of a debate yesterday afternoon when Senator Robert Ray, I think, pointed out that Senator Haines, for instance, does not just follow populist causes; that if she did, she would have supported the plastic Australia Card.
—What you said was that he made a mistake because he thought we did.

—He thought the honour-able senator did. I am not saying that the Australian Democrats accept populist causes. I just made the comment that it is sometimes easy for one to advocate things in the certainty that one will not have to introduce them or to administer them. Senator Macklin made some point about people who are no longer eligible for the tertiary education assistance scheme because of sickness. They are not affected by this and they are not affected by anything else. They are certainly eligible for sickness benefit. That is the situation that exists now and that situation will continue to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the problems that Senator Macklin sees or that particularly the student bodies see in this sort of legislation. I can even understand Senator Macklin's suspicion that what the Department of Social Security is about is trying to take a broad brush to overcome some difficulties that have faced it in the past. I think it is fair enough to be suspicious in that way. He asked me for some details of the numbers and the situations where this occurs. I am afraid that I do not have them here now but I will certainly try to get some. I can give him some anecdotal evidence about what has happened in the past and, I am sure, what happens now. This came up frequently when I was Minister for Social Security. I do not think Senator Macklin would deny for a minute that the brotherhood and sisterhood of student counsellors in tertiary ins-titutions in this country in fact kept themselves very well informed on the best ways to fix courses and to fix hours of courses to enable people to qualify for unemployment benefit when they could not qualify for TEAS because of the income test on TEAS.

That may be fair enough from their point of view but it is not fair enough from the point of view of what this Parliament and what governments in this place have decided about the differences between the social security systems and the method of supporting the education system. Honourable senators opposite may disagree with it. In fact, in many ways I disagree with it. I would like to see the situation where we did not make the distinctions that we make now. But we do and we make them for economic and social reasons and for other sorts of reasons. We do make those distinctions and I believe we should not allow people to get round the system in the way that people have tried to do so. I mentioned the case at Armidale where, I think, 350 students-it may have been more-led by the President of the students' union, all registered for unemployment benefit and got very annoyed when we did not allow them to have unemployment benefit, especially the President of the students' union at the time, who, it turned out, had a full time job anyhow. Some of the situations Senator Macklin put forward, if I understood him correctly, clearly will not apply. A student who has a full-time job and takes a full-time course at night, clearly will not qualify for unemployment benefit. If he then becomes unemployed, one wonders why he is not on TEAS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the example I gave was where he failed the previous year.

—So Senator Macklin is suggesting that somebody who does not qualify for TEAS because he has failed the previous year should then be able to be picked up as a full time student by the social security system. That is a judgment Senator Macklin makes. It is a judgment I cannot make as a Minister in the Government administering the system as it now exists.
—In the system that is there now the Government has not been able to provide for the types of problems this is supposed to be addressing.

—The system that is there now enables people who otherwise would fail to get TEAS because of income tests and everything else to get around that by getting into the social security system. That is what this exercise is aimed at. I think that is a fair aim of the exercise and a fair aim of the Department-to overcome the difficulty which exists now administratively, in terms of the man hours or person hours, however one likes to put it, spent by officers of the Department and by counsellors in tertiary institutions trying to manipulate the system as it exists now. That difficulty had to be overcome and this is an attempt to overcome it. I dare say that people will try to work out methods of overcoming this system. I, like Senator Macklin, think that eventually we will get to a stage-we are moving towards it now-where we have youth allowances which are dependent on the young person doing something, be it training or whatever. We are not there yet; it is a fair way down the track.

—Following Senator Macklin's intervention, will the Minister clarify one point? Clause 33 seeks to insert a new section 133 into Part VII of the principal Act. Part VII deals not only with unemployment benefit but also with sickness and special benefits. Am I correct that the main thrust of the Minister's argument and his main justification for it relate to the inappropriate use of the unemployment benefit by students? If one looks at the wording on page 13 of the Bill, one sees that it merely says that `a benefit' will not be payable. Am I correct that that says that an unemployment benefit will not be payable, a sickness benefit will not be payable and a special benefit will not be payable? Is that the Government's intention? If the argument is that unemployment benefit has been gained inappropriately, is it not a fact that the special benefit is discretionary and a benefit that the Director-General has available to cover special circumstances? Would it not have been more appropriate to say that unemployment benefit will not be payable in respect of all these conditions? Some of Senator Macklin's argument might still stand, but it would not be quite as sweeping in the exclusions it seems to place which seem also to cover sickness and special benefits. It is the special benefit provision that gives me some concern.

—It does not cover supporting parents benefit. I said that the supporting parents benefit is excluded. That is not in the legislation. It certainly covers sickness and special benefits. Special benefit at the moment is not supposed to be available for full time students. If it is being argued that it should be, that is an argument.
—The AAT did. Presumably this is why you have the secondary allowances.
—The AAT did in one case certainly.
—Not one case, but for a number of students.

—The AAT said that if something was to be done about it, there would have to be legislation. That is one of the things that are being legislated for here. It becomes an argument, Senator Macklin: Should one use the social security system, be it through sickness benefit, special benefit or anything else, to apply to a special group of people different rules than one applies in the income support system in the education system? We say no, and that is what this legislation is about. Senator Macklin may say that judgment is wrong, and there are good and valid arguments why he may consider that judgment is wrong. But if we are to use special benefit as a discretion in these circumstances, one may well, to take a ridiculous example, justify using special benefit to support people in a business that is not making money, and one may use it in all sorts of circumstances like that. It is a judgment we have to make. We may not be very popular in making it, but I think that it is a fair judgment.

—May I go back to the first example. It was not based on the TEAS proposition, but on those people who do not get TEAS and who are now being said to operate under the same rules. I am talking about somebody who falls sick during the vacation period and who is not getting TEAS. Presumably, the Minister is now saying that, by virtue of the fact he is a full time student, he will not be able to get sickness benefit.
—If the person has lost TEAS--

—In my first example they did not even have TEAS. It is people who, for a number of other reasons, are not eligible. To clarify the example, it might be the income test operation. They may not be eligible, for whatever reasons. I am talking about the sickness benefit operation, which is not means tested.

—Their situation does not change. They are precluded from getting sickness benefit in the vacation now. I think I see what Senator Macklin is saying-that somebody who would otherwise qualify for TEAS but who does not qualify because of parental income and who falls ill in a university vacation, will not be eligible for sickness benefit. That is the case now. In fact, such a person will not be eligible under this legislation.

—I turn to Part III of the Bill dealing with the amnesty. Yesterday I asked the Minister for some figures which he assured me that he would obtain for me. I was wondering whether they are available. The question I asked was: To date how much has the amnesty brought back to the Government, and, secondly, what advertising costs have been incurred for the amnesty to date or are expected to be incurred under the additional amnesty period proposed by the Bill?

—As for the advertising costs, I have asked Mr Howe's office for that information. I was hoping to provide it in Question Time today. I will certainly obtain it. As for the figures on the amnesty, I heard a figure of $10m, which I think was brought up in the Estimates Committee when the officers of the Department thought it might be that. Mr Howe has said that, rather than making any predictions at the moment, as soon as the amnesty is over, which will be very soon, he will make a statement to the Parliament about what has happened and how much the Department has gained from this exercise. He is not willing to make estimates or guesstimates now. As for the advertising figures, I will get those for Senator Walters.

—I thank the Minister for that answer. Will the amnesty provision be advertised further-the fact it is to be extended-and to what extent will that advertising go on? Can the Minister give me an estimate?
—No. Yesterday I was asked whether the amnesty is to be extended. It is not. It finishes on 31 May, so there will be no more advertising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate that the Australian Democrats do not believe clause 33 should be included, because we believe there has not been sufficient information provided to the Committee with regard to that matter. Since we do not have support we do not intend to press that point, but we want to register our opposition to clause 33.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986TAXATION (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1986 which we are addressing today are the start of the journey through the major part of the Government's tax package which was announced on 19 September 1985. These Bills put into legislative form the details of the enactment of the so-called negative gearing legislation and certain other matters that touch particularly on self-assessment, the new procedure which the Government is introducing in the Australian Taxation Office. Before addressing that aspect and because this is part of a rather long debate, which will probably go into the next week or so in this chamber, on various matters such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, I would like, for the record, to set down at the outset a few fundamental tests which the Go-vernment itself set when it moved down the road of taxation reform some 13 months ago; at each stage along the way the Opposition will be testing the Government's performance against those criteria. I refer, of course, to the so-called nine commandments on taxation reform which were laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he called the so-called National Taxation Summit about a year ago, something, no doubt, which he has regretted doing ever since. With your concurrence, Mr Deputy President, I read into the record those nine so-called commandments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1: THERE must be no increase during Labor's term of office of the overall tax burden as measured by the share of the gross domestic product taken by the Government in tax revenues.
2: ANY tax reform must continue the process of providing cuts in personal income tax.
3: CHANGES must help smash tax avoidance and evasion.
4: ANY reform must simplify the system so that all Australians can understand it more easily, and therefore make avoidance and evasion more difficult.
5: A REFORMED system must be fairer and progressive, so that Australians are only required to pay tax according to their capacity.
6: ANY reform must not disadvantage welfare recipients and should reduce and remove poverty traps.
7: ANY changes in indirect taxation must be acceptable to community groups whose response will determine whether the Government can maintain moderation in wage movements.
8: ANY reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment.
9: ANY reform package must have widespread community support at a widely representative national tax summit of economic organisations and community groups.
They are the nine commandments on which we will be calling in the course of the debate over the next several days in respect of the Government's performance on its tax package.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986 covers a number of matters, two of which I have already mentioned. I will deal with several of the matters with which the Opposition has no complaint. Firstly, there is the anti-avoidance measure in the Bill which seeks to overcome the decision in the Myer case and which seeks to tax as a lump sum any payments for rights to income forgone. We concur with the decision of the Government to enact legislation against that particular decision, and we have no objection to it. There is a clause in this Bill which provides for an airline profits agreement with the People's Republic of China. So, as I understand it, airline profits earned by the Chinese airline in Australia will not be subject to Australian tax. In return for that, and by agreement with the Chinese Government, the reverse will occur with Australian airlines earning profits in China. We have no objection to that. The next item is the adjustment and amendments to the Pay-roll Tax (Territories) Assessment Act which seeks to outlaw the avoidance device of grouping parts of various subsidiaries and other legal entities of one particular company, wholly owned or partly owned groups for that matter, in such a way as maximum exemptions can be obtained for the payroll tax legislation which applies in the Australian Capital Territory. We have no objection to that anti-avoidance device.

I turn to perhaps the major part of the legislation which attempts to outlaw and abolish for taxation purposes the practice of negative gearing. At the outset I make the point that it seems to me that there is in the Government ranks a basic misunderstanding of what negative gearing is all about. That misunderstanding is based on the assumption that there is no economic benefit which stems from people applying income earned from sources other than that which might be attributable to real estate in order to further develop real estate investment. Quite clearly, if a person who earns money from normal trading profits and allocates some part of that profit to pay for the interest which might be necessarily incurred in respect of borrowings in order to erect new premises or a new set of flats, for instance, there is no reason on earth why that does not suit an economic objective which should be well and truly recognised by the Government. I do not blame the Australian Taxation Office for advising the Government that it sees that as some kind of tax shelter-that is a reasonable point for the department to put. But it is for the Government to see that there are other reasons why it should not accept that advice, that, in fact, there are economic objectives involved in developing the capacity of the country to house its people, to provide low cost housing to the population of Australia, and that this is one way of doing it. So it is the Government's fault that it has seen fit to implement advice which basically was given, I take it, on the grounds of avoidance or anti-avoidance measures but which, of course, it has seen fit not to accept on the grounds of wider advice that that advice was wrong in the context of the economic needs of the country.

If we now start to examine what is actually happening in the real estate development and in the housing industry, we can see quite clearly what a silly decision the Government has made. I picked up today the insert in the Australian Financial Review which is the so-called `Property Review'. On the front page of that insert it says: `Building bubble to burst'. It says that all kinds of changes are occurring in the housing industry at present. On page 8 of this publication I read that property consultants, known as Property and Building Advisory Services Pty Ltd, believe that a slump in the residential building sector has started. I do not think one has to be Mandrake to work that out at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only because Bob's bubble has burst.

—Exactly. Bob's bubble will burst faster. The article goes on to state that there were only 2,044 approvals of residential dwellings, other than houses, in February. This is the lowest February figure since 1979, when the figure was 2,077.
—Who was in office then?

—What has that got to do with it? The point is that the number of approvals has declined to the same level as it was in 1979. This comes at a time when the Government is now imposing a taxation restriction which will drive down that number even further. Obviously, there will continue to be a growing demand for low income housing in the community. We have to turn only to the public housing list figures for the last few years to demonstrate that point. Let us look at-Senator Maguire might be able to answer his own question in a moment-the number of applications outstanding for public rental housing on 31 December 1982 which was just some eight or nine weeks before the Hawke Government was elected in 1983. Something like 109,000 people were on public housing lists. What was the figure at the end of December 1985 under this magnificent Hawke Labor Government? The figure was 156,000. The number of people who are waiting for cheap public housing has grown by nearly 50 per cent under the Hawke Labor Government. There are 50,000 people more on the lists now than there were under the Fraser Government and this has occurred as a direct result of the policies of this Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: One has only to survey other factors. Think about interest rates. At this time, under this Government, we have the highest interest rates that this country has seen since the Depression in the 1930s. Is it any wonder that there is a restriction on low cost housing in this country and that people are flocking to State housing commissions in order to seek cheap rental housing. No wonder 50,000 people more are waiting for that kind of housing.

Let me look at some of the States. Senator Maguire might be very interested to find out that in South Australia-his State and mine-at 31 December 1982, under the then Tonkin State Liberal Government and the Fraser Federal Li-beral Government, the number of people waiting for housing was 24,000. Today, under the Bannon State Labor Government and under the Hawke Federal Labor Government, the figure is 36,000, a 50 per cent increase. Let me look at the socialist Utopia of Victoria. At the same time 15,000 people were waiting for housing from the State Housing Commission of Victoria. That figure is now 29,000. Through the list of States one can find the same kinds of conditions applying. Why is it that this Government has sought to take such a harsh tax measure, to make it even harder for Australians generally to be able to get cheaper housing? It seems incredible that the Government should have accepted that advice from the Australian Taxation Office because clearly it is not the time to be implementing that kind of proposal.

I mentioned earlier that interest rates in real terms are the highest that they have been since the Depression. Automatically, if anybody is looking at developing a new property, developing a new residential property, by definition almost it is impossible-because of high interest rates-to do other than to negatively gear that property. If one has to borrow money at an interest rate of 18, 19 or 20 per cent-the pro-perty will yield only 6 per cent by virtue of the rent one can charge because that is all the market will be able to pay-it is impossible not to negatively gear under the definition of the tax Bill that is before us. Again it is absolute nonsense to put this legislation into place at this time. This Government will deserve everything that it gets from the electors when they find out what it is doing to the housing market in this country as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —The electors don't deserve getting what they are getting from this Government.

—They certainly do not and in the not too distant future they will have an opportunity to express their view on that. The other side I would like to mention is that this measure must drive rents higher and we have already seen this happen in Sydney and Melbourne.
—What about Adelaide?

—And in Adelaide too. We are seeing a great growth in rentals all over the Sydney metropolitan area. There are huge rises, such as 25, 30 and 40 per cent, in rentals. This is occurring because of the shortage that is developing in the unit market and in residential dwellings generally. This is also being heightened by the Government's stupid capital gains tax which is restricting development as well. Obviously people are suffering because they cannot get housing in the first place and now they will pay far more for it. This is incredible and this Government seems to think that it is a great idea.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what the Government will get out of this legislation. It will raise $55m in the first year in which it applies. It says that this figure will rise to $100m in a couple of year's time. We have to wait until 1991 before the figure gets anywhere near $200m, so the Government says. The first question I would like to ask the Government is: `Please tell us how you calculated those figures?' Did the Government take into account the drop in income for property developers as a result of this measure? Did it take into account other factors in the market-place that will have an impact? The fact I bet the Government did not take into account is what this measure will cost in social security payments by its being forced to meet increased supplementary rent assistance for those pensioners and low income earners who will have to go to the Department of Social Security to find extra rental assistance to pay the increased rents that this legislation will drive up. One does not have to be too clever to work it out. When half a million people are on social security rental assistance now all one needs is another $5 a week increase in rents on average-that is all-and that means that the total cost of welfare for that group will go up by $136m a year compared with what this Government expects to get from negative gearing-the abolition of something like $55m. The Government will lose money if this measure is introduced. It is absolutely crazy that it is adopting such a silly measure at this time. However, I guess it is just typical of the rest of the package which the Government has in train to implement.

There are lots of details in the legislation which I will come to in the Committee stage of the debate but let me turn to other clauses of the Bill which deal with the amendment of assessments. First of all let me outline to honourable senators the present system which applies to the amendment of assessments. As all honourable senators will know, the Government is proposing to introduce a system of self-assessment by taxpayers and follow up orders. Of course we have very little information about what that actually entails.

However, let us look at the present system. Firstly, if a taxpayer has not made a full and true disclosure of all material facts necessary to make an assessment, if any tax has been avoided and if the Commissioner of Taxation considers the avoidance to be due to fraud or to evasion, he may amend the assessment at any time by making such alterations or additions as he considers necessary to correct an error in calculation, a mistake in fact or to prevent the avoidance of tax. Even where there has been an avoidance of tax due to fraud or evasion, the Commissioner's power to amend, although unlimited in time, is limited in extent. It is not a general power of amendment. For example, he could not amend an assessment to reflect a changed interpretation of the law but is limited to correction of errors of calculation and mistakes of fact and prevention of loss of revenue through tax avoidance.

Secondly, when there has been an avoidance of tax not due to fraud or evasion, an amended assessment increasing liability can be validly made to correct an error of calculation or mistake of fact or to prevent the tax being avoided, at any time within six years from the due date of payment of tax under the assessment which is the subject of amendment. However, as in the case of avoidance through fraud or evasion, no amendment increasing liability can be made unless at the time of its making there has not been full and true disclosure of all the material facts necessary for the taxpayer's proper assessment.

Thirdly, where a full and true disclosure of all the material facts necessary for his assessment has been made by the taxpayer at any time before an assessment, original or amended, is issued to him, any subsequent amended assessment increasing his liability is competent only if it is made to correct an error in calculation or a mistake in fact and, of course, if it comes out within three years from the due date for payment of the tax under the original or previous amended assessment.

Fourthly, ordinarily an amendment reducing liability may be made only within three years of the due date for payment of the tax under the assessment being amended. Moreover, only an amendment by way of correction of an error in calculation or mistake of fact is permitted. In addition, a taxpayer may make application for an amendment to his assessment. Such an application would have to be made within three years from the due date for payment of the tax due under the assessment. Any information necessary for deciding the application must be supplied to the Commissioner within that time. If these conditions are satisfied, the Commissioner may amend the assessment at any time. The Commissioner's power to amend an assessment to reduce liability, and particularly his power to amend on the taxpayer's application, is discretionary and not mandatory. There is no power to amend to reduce liability in order to correct a mistake of law as such.

Basically, it seems to us that the changes that are proposed in this Bill apply within those same time frames. The Commissioner is to have the power to amend an assessment for any reason, which appears to include the correction of an error in law. Considerable disquiet has been expressed at the extension of the powers of the Commissioner in this regard. Most of this criticism concerns the lack of certainty that will result from not knowing, even if a full and true disclosure has been made in the return, the taxpayer's final tax liability. A fundamental aspect of our assessment procedure until now has been that, if a full and true disclosure has been made, no amendment to increase the tax liability can be made to reflect a changed interpretation of the law-only to correct an error of calculation or a mistake of fact. It appears that the changes could well empower the Commissioner of Taxation to amend assessments to increase a tax liability due to a change in the interpretation of the law.

The Liberal and National parties take strong exception to this point. We believe that what has been brought upon people is a major change in the way in which they will have their taxation liabilities incurred, with very little public debate or exposure of the issues. We have seen nothing of this until the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill was brought into the House of Representatives only about a fortnight ago. Concern and disquiet has been expressed on a wide front across industrial and professional areas. Indeed, we are very concerned about it, basically for the reason that, simply, we do not know enough about the self-assessment procedures that are being introduced by the Tax Commissioner from 1 July 1986. That is another area that deserves a major review in the public arena so that people can properly understand what is about to occur.

I am sure that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who is in the chamber, knows that already in the community there is very widespread concern at the actions of the Taxation Commissioner in dealing with taxpayers and assessing penalties, and at the so-called harshness of the Taxation Commissioner in hearing out disputes and dealing with them. That is before us in the background of this particular matter, and we believe that this matter requires the widest exposure to the community for public debate. For that reason we intend at the Committee stage to move that this matter and those parts of the Bill relevant to this matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations so that it can undertake a full review of that part of the legislation, bring before the Committee officers of the Department of the Treasury and of the Australian Taxation Office to give evidence and to demonstrate to us what these measures are really all about and what safeguards, if any, should be written into the law in order to protect the rights of taxpayers, and, of course, to find out in far greater detail what the Government has in mind with regard to the new system of self-assessment and audit and in what way that will affect the day to day operations of business and of the community generally.

Certainly, the new system of audit has a lot of thorny questions attached to it to which we would like to have answers. For that reason we will appeal to the Australian Democrats to support us in seeking to take this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for a thorough review. It seems to me that this is quite reasonable in the circumstances since the Government has failed adequately to demonstrate its arguments for this and certainly has given us no time for public debate on the matter. In the light of that, we feel quite justified on this point in delaying the passage of this Government's legislation. We will come more to that in the course of the Committee stage debate.

Finally, I would like just to refer to the one other matter that I forgot to mention earlier-that of gifts being allowable as donations to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation under clause 10 of the Bill. That will be dealt with by my colleague Senator Collard in his capacity as our Senate spokesman on sport and recreation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986 and the Taxation (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1986. In addressing the issue of taxation reform, the basic proposition that we put is that the Opposition has no credibility on tax reform. Despite its eight years in office, it did not deliver any major tax reforms in our country. Despite all of those years in office, it squibbed taxation reform. In the five Budgets from 1978 to 1982 brought down by Mr Howard, the present Opposition Leader who was then Treasurer, there was no major reform of the pressing problems of the Australian taxation system. The only legacy left to the Australian people in the taxation field from Mr Howard's five Budgets was a 66 per cent rise in sales tax collections. The only thing that can be said to have been a major taxation aspect of Mr Howard's five Budgets was a massive shift in the taxation burden in this country towards sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party and its National Party allies for years protected tax avoidance and tax avoiders whenever possible. They did nothing to reform the tax system to boost the economic efficiency of the Australian economy or to improve resource allocation. The Opposition has absolutely no credibility on taxation matters following its position on the so-called business lunches. Last year, in November and December, the Australian people and this chamber were barraged by claims by Opposition spokespersons about the likely impact on the restaurant industry of removing subsidies for business lunches. There were claims of losses of jobs in that industry which varied from 11,000 to 80,000 jobs. In view of those sorts of claims and misleading arguments about the impact of this Government's tax reform measures, we simply cannot accept the sorts of claims made today by Senator Messner.

I will address one specific point on public housing that was made this morning by Senator Messner. He made all kinds of claims about public housing in my State of South Australia and in other States. He claimed that the public housing system was not working properly. The point remains that the Liberals for years and years when in office starved public housing of funds. They gave it a low priority. Looking at their record nationally, it can be said that the Liberals do not support public housing as a proposition when we consider the money voted by them for it. I point out that in the last financial year for which information is available South Australia, which is the fifth State of Australia in terms of population, spent the second largest amount in dollar terms on public housing. It was second only to New South Wales in total outlays on public housing despite having the fifth largest population. It is on the record that, while nationally about $54 per head of population is spent on public rental assistance, expenditure in South Australia is well over $100 a year per head. Our expenditure on public rental housing is twice the national average and compares favourably with the very meagre $29 per head in Queensland.

The Hawke Government's tax package announced on 19 September last year is a far-reaching reform of the taxation system. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made it clear repeatedly that overall there is to be no tax rise as a result of this package. The proportion of taxation in relation to gross domestic product will not rise. The tax reforms contained in the package will create a fairer and more equitable tax system and will reduce the tax burden on ordinary taxpayers. I am pleased to say that the tax system, following the tax package, will be based more on the very important principle of the ability to pay. Those who have the ability should pay more tax. Not only that but the tax system will help to make the economy more efficient. It will result in better resource allocation by removing artificial schemes which inflate the value of particular assets. It will help reduce over-investment in property. As a result of this tax reform package a typical taxpayer will receive an income tax cut of about $6 a week from later this year and a further reduction from July next year. It has to be borne in mind that that is an addition to the average tax reduction of $7.60 a week from November 1984.

All marginal income tax rates will be reduced as a result of this package. The top rate will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. That will be the same rate as the company tax rate. The result will be that no Australian will have to pay more than half his extra income in income tax. The double taxation of company dividends will be largely eliminated. Poverty traps for social welfare recipients will be eased so that they will be able to earn more outside income if they choose without losing part of their social welfare payment. The tax free threshold will be increased. Sales taxes will be rationalised so that they will be fairer and simpler. Provisional taxpayers will be able to pay their tax in quarterly instalments so that the burden of seasonal interest rate fluctuations will even out over the year. A mild capital gains tax will ensure that those who choose to increase their wealth through increased asset values rather than extra income will pay their fair share of tax. On the great majority of Australian taxpayers the capital gains tax will have no impact.

By introducing a capital gains tax this Government has helped drag Australian taxation law into the twentieth century. We will now have a taxation system more in line with that of the other developed countries which are members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Following this move of all the developed countries only the Netherlands will not have a capital gains tax. This tax package also will levy tax on non-cash fringe benefits to ensure that the proliferation of remuneration packages with substantial fringe benefits will be brought under control and no longer be a means to escape tax. The rate of company tax will be lifted to the same level as the top rate of personal income tax to eliminate the incentive for tax avoidance.

When fully implemented the Government's tax package will raise an extra $1,500m annually but will return $4,500m annually to taxpayers. Marginal tax rates will be cut across the board. I have mentioned the reduction in the top rate from 60c in the dollar to 49c. It is very important to note that these rate reductions clearly demonstrate that the Australian Labor Party is the low tax Party. The bottom marginal tax rate under this Government will be reduced to 24c in the dollar. The best that the Liberals under Mr Howard as Treasurer could do in five Budgets was leave Australia with a bottom marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar. All Australians should pay their fair share of tax. Under the old system some high income earners were able to minimise or avoid paying tax. This meant that pay as you earn taxpayers, low income earners and honest taxpayers were forced to shoulder an ever-increasing tax burden. No responsible government could tolerate a tax system which forced low and average income earners to subsidise the lurks and perks of the well to do. By closing loopholes and broadening the income tax base the Government's tax reform package will ensure that those high income earners--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I ask you to rule on the matter of relevance. The honourable senator is talking about everything but the Bill before us. There is certainly no reference in the Bill, as I read it, to anything like fringe benefits, perks or whatever. The Bill concerns negative gearing of property and some other matters.

—I draw to the attention of the honourable senator that it is a good idea from time to time at least in a second reading debate to acknowledge the matters within the ambit of the legislation. I ask the honourable senator not to draw on his imagination too much.

—Thank you for that advice, Madam Acting Deputy President. Unfortunately, Senator Messner does not have the patience to wait for the delivery I am about to proceed with on the impact of negative gearing. I simply go back to my original point that Senator Messner, in purporting to debate negative gearing, got on to the subject of the waiting lists for public housing authorities. He spoke for five minutes about public housing. I fail to see the relevance of that to this debate on negative gearing for rental properties. It was a very far removed subject, indeed. By closing loopholes and broadening the income tax base, the Government's tax reform package will ensure that high income earners who receive considerable tax free income in the form of fringe benefits and various allowances will now meet their proper tax obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the previous coalition Government the Australian tax system was nearing the point of collapse. The Fraser Government lacked the determination or the will to reform an increasingly unjust tax system. Mr Howard and Mr Fraser were prepared to license the great Australian tax rip off. Tax avoidance and tax evasion were among the few growth industries under that Government. Through various rorts, evasion schemes and tax shelters, tens of thousands of high income earners were able to avoid paying their fair share of tax. The old tax system cultivated a petty criminal mentality instead of rewarding effort and achievement. When Mr Howard was Treasurer, income tax was a voluntary tax for the wealthy. The criterion for a fair and equitable tax system should be the capacity to pay rather than the propensity to cheat.

This legislation implements two of the Government's tax reform measures. It removes the income tax advantage associated with the negative gearing of rental property investments and provides for a new depreciation allowance of 4 per cent per annum in respect of residential income producing buildings. Negative gearing has been a popular form of tax minimisation. It occurs when interest payments on borrowings used to finance rental property investments exceed net rental income from that property. It has been done deliberately. It is a contrived arrangement. Under the old tax law the taxpayer was able to offset these losses against income from other sources, thereby sheltering that income from tax. In fact, many Australians use negative gearing to shelter their main incomes-their incomes from exertion-from income tax by using the negative gearing device in regard to rental properties. High income earners have exploited this feature of the tax law to minimise their tax liability while increasing their wealth by accruing tax free, capital gains. This Government does not intend to tolerate a situation where ordinary taxpayers effectively subsidise property speculation and tax minimisation by a number of high income earners.

The amendments proposed by this legislation will place a limit on the income tax deduction allowed for interest on borrowings used to finance rental investments made after 17 July 1985. The deduction limit will now be an amount equal to the net rental income from those investments. Net rental income is defined as the aggregate of gross rental income from all such investments, less related deductions other than building depreciation and interest. Interest payments in excess of the deduction limit in any year will be carried forward and treated as expenses incurred in the next income year. It can then be offset against the net rental income of that year or of later years. The legislation will apply to rental investments made after 17 July 1985 and will include land and buildings acquired under contracts entered into after that date. That means that assets previously owned will not be affected by this measure. Any assets owned before 18 July will not be affected by the negative gearing arrangements for rental properties.

The annual revenue yield from this measure will be negligible this financial year, rising to some $55m next financial year and an estimated $100m in 1987-88. So in revenue terms, the negative gearing arrangements are significant. They are an important part of the Government's tax package and a significant way in which the Government is financing income tax cuts for other Australians. They are a very important part of the revenue side of the tax package. At present, negative gearing is a significant tax concession to the wealthy. Ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers cannot take advantage of negative gearing because they do not have sufficient income for a second property loan. In our type of society, the ability to borrow is a key advantage of the wealthy. Ordinary taxpayers were forced to shoulder an increasing tax burden to make up for the subsidy gained by wealthy property investors from the tax system.

The Government's move against negative gearing is far from draconian. Existing negative gearing arrangements, as I have pointed out, are in no way affected. People who entered into arrangements before 18 July are not affected by the measure. The new rules continue to allow investors to negatively gear property, but their losses will have to be stored up and set off against future profits from property investments. It will not prevent them from entering into these arrangements; it just determines when they can make the deductions against their incomes.

The legislation will also amend the income tax law to allow depreciation deductions on residential buildings used for the purpose of producing assessable income. This is a new arrangement. A fixed annual deduction of 4 per cent of capital expenditure on the construction of an eligible building, extension, alteration or improvement will be available over a 25-year period. The depreciation allowance will apply where construction commenced or commences after 17 July 1985-the date on which the proposal was announced. The Government believes that this measure will help stimulate new building for rental housing purposes, thus increasing the supply of rental accommodation. The cost to revenue of the 4 per cent annual depreciation allowance is estimated at some $7m in 1987-88.

The Opposition's hysterical reaction to the Government's move against negative gearing is all too predictable. As I pointed out initially, Opposition members have no credibility on taxation measures. They have no credibility after the outrageous claims they made about the impact of removing the subsidy for business lunches. They have no credibility after the outrageous claims made about the impact of fringe benefits taxation on the car industry. The coalition's bleatings that the capital gains tax and the removal of the negative gearing tax shelter will curtail new investment in property and real estate are, as usual, at variance with expert opinion. I quote Mr Richard Bird, the New South Wales sales manager of what is perhaps the largest real estate company in Australia, L. J. Hooker. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 September last year he said that, generally speaking, his company was not concerned by the impact on prices in the Sydney market-place of the removal of the negative gearing arrangements. I quote in more detail Mr Frank Charnock, the Federal President of the Building Owners and Managers Association, from the Australian Financial Review of 31 October last. He said:

. . . so far as the upper levels of the commercial, industrial and retail property markets are concerned, the proposed tax changes only impact in a peripheral way, if at all, upon the main participants in the market. Hence there is no reason to assume tax-induced change in investment strategy or behaviour.

That was the Federal President of the Building Owners and Managers Association, not a member of the Australian Labor Party or a trade union official, but the President of the largest building owners association in this country. Mr Charnock also went on to say that, even with the abolition of the negative gearing tax shelter, property investment would still remain attractive to the small investor. He said:

So far as further investment is concerned, investors will tend initially to think there is less future in property for them. More accurately, the extreme tax attraction previously held by property will be brought more into line with most other avenues of investment.
He continued:

In due course they will realise that while the special taxation advantages may have gone, the fundamentals of property-approached on its merits and not just for the perceived tax advantage-is still the best medium for investment at this level.

That was the Federal President of the Building Owners and Managers Association, quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 31 October 1985. Among the more specious of the Opposition claims about the impact of the removal of negative gearing arrangements are Mr Howard's claims that the end of negative gearing and the tax subsidy for it will somehow force up rents and hurt low income earners. I would like to quote from this week's Adelaide Advertiser. Madam Acting Deputy President, you may have seen it yourself. Mr Don Howell, the new President of the Real Estate Institute of South Australia Inc., was quoted in the Adelaide Advertiser of Tuesday of this week as saying:
Surprisingly, the rental market had not been squeezed and there was plenty of rental accommodation available.

That was the State President of the Real Estate Institute of South Australia speaking as recently as this week. I point out to the Senate that people should not be fooled for one moment by Mr Howard's crocodile tears about the alleged impact of removal of negative gearing arrangements on public housing and private housing rents. What Mr Howard is really saying and trying to convince the community is that the poor and the less well off in this country can be best helped by giving tax concessions to the rich. That is really what the argument boils down to. The Liberal attitude is that the wealthy should be allowed to hang on to their assets because in that way they may do something to help the needy in Australia. This is the so-called trickle-down effect allowing the wealthy to hang on to their assets because they may just feel motivated in some way to pass on some of their benefits to help lower and middle income earners in our country. The fact is that the negative gearing arrangements as they apply in Australia were not designed to help increase the availability of rental housing. They were simply designed to reduce the tax liabilities of a select group in the community. They had absolutely no linkage to the availability of rental accommodation. They were simply taxation devices designed to reduce the tax liabilities of the most well off sections of the community.

The exploitation of negative gearing as a tax shelter has had explosive growth in the past few years, but this has not produced a strong supply of rental accommodation for low income families. It has had rapid growth as a tax avoidance device, but it really has not created a massive increase in the supply of rental housing for low income earners. In fact, negative gearing arrangements have not been associated with the low end of the property market, they have been associated with the luxury end of the property market where the prospect of capital gains in respect of those properties seemed greatest. Furthermore, as negative gearing arrangements made before 18 July this year are unaffected by this legislation, landlords and the Opposition cannot use the Government's tax changes to justify claims about increased rents.

It should be pointed out that the Government's new 4 per cent depreciation allowance for residential accommodation will encourage investors to build new dwellings for rent, adding to the supply of accommodation. In contrast, negative gearing arrangements-this is a very important point-which encourage investors to compete with each other, simply have the economic effect of bidding up the price of existing dwellings. Under these kinds of tax arrangements, one simply encourages potential investors to go out into the market-place, to bid against each other and in that way force up property values and, therefore, force up rents. I think that really does nail the lie being put around by Opposition spokespersons about these particular measures. The fact is that under present tax arrangements in Australia the value of a number of assets, including rental properties, probably has reflected their value as a tax avoidance mechanism to some extent and not their true value as income-producing assets. The values have been artificially increased because of the tax minimisation advantages of those properties.

I have canvassed the arguments in favour of the Government's tax package generally. I have canvassed the arguments in favour of the Government's moves in regard to the negative gearing of rental properties. I have pointed out the many claimed disadvantages, drawbacks and economic side effects of such proposals as claimed by the Opposition and shown that they have absolutely no foundation. Basically what is happening in this country at present in regard to tax reform is that the wealthy and the well to do want to have a reduction in the top marginal tax rates from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar, and they want to have the other major reforms in the tax package, but they do not want to be affected by the measures which generate the revenue to provide for those reductions in tax rates. The Government's tax reform package is based on the principles of fairness and equity. No truly progressive tax system can allow a minority to avoid paying taxes at the expense of the majority of taxpayers. The tax changes contained in these Bills before us are part of the Government's policy to redistribute the burden of taxation and to ensure that all Australians pay their fair share of tax. As a result of these Bills and others to come before this place shortly the tax system in Australia will be based more on the principle of ability to pay. I am very pleased to say that as a result of these particular tax measures income tax in Australia will no longer be a voluntary tax for the rich in our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1986. This Bill relates to two very important areas: Firstly, it relates to the banning of negative gearing for property developments which was part of the Government's tax package and which was discussed at some length at the National Taxation Summit. The Australian Democrats have indicated that it is a principle we are prepared to support. As compensation, the Government has allowed a 4 per cent depreciation allowance on income-producing residential properties. There was a lot of discussion at the Tax Summit and subsequently, that the elimination of negative gearing on property developments would have a disastrous effect on home building and welfare housing. If honourable senators look at the figures, this has not occurred and we believe that it is right and proper for the Government to move in on this area because there is no doubt that negative gearing of property development had developed into a tax rort. We believe it is proper that the Government should clamp down on it. However, the Government has not clamped down on an even larger tax rort; that is, it is allowing negative gearing for corporate raiders and billions of dollars are going into stock market speculation rather than into developing our productive capacity. I will talk more about that matter later.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Bill introduces necessary changes for the adoption of self-assessment. Self-assessment essentially means that each taxpayer works out his or her own position each year. The Department will take the taxpayer's return on face value and will issue a refund or a bill on the basis of the taxpayer's return. Scrupulous checking of every return will be replaced by a random audit. People caught carrying out tax fraud will be penalised. Of course self-assessment achieves one significant thing: It relieves staff of mundane clerical duties and allows investigative areas to be beefed up. We can only say that this is a good thing. Trying to assess every tax return routinely, every year, must be a soul destroying task. Senator Messner indicated in his speech that the Liberals are unhappy about this aspect of self-assessment and that they would like the Bill to go to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are unhappy about the amendment to the assessments part of it. We want to see how that relates to it.

—I may have misunderstood the honourable senator. I can only say that the Democrats feel that to delay this legislation unduly would be to create uncertainty in the community. There has been great uncertainty in the community about the whole of the tax legislation. They are dramatic changes to the tax law.
