As I have said before, they are probably the most dramatic changes for 40 years. The legislation has created great community uncertainty and the sooner we get it through the Senate and the Parliament the better for all concerned. It will at least lift the great veil of uncertainty in the community at the moment. So we are not in principle sympathetic to putting this legislation to a committee, or even a part of it, because that would delay it. However, we will be moving an amendment and I will speak on that shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The controversial area of the legislation is this: The Commissioner of Taxation has always had the right to amend assessments already issued. In the past his right has been restricted to the correction of errors in calculations, mistakes of fact and deliberate avoidance. This right is to be extended to all situations. This is significant because the Commissioner will now be able to amend assessments to account for errors in law. In other words, if we make a mistake in the application of the tax law and pay less tax than we otherwise should and this is picked up later on, we will be made to pay the back tax. Where a taxpayer is engaged in wilful evasion, a penalty is to be levied on the back tax payment. The Bill also allows for interest payments to be levied where a person makes a mistake in calculations, either in fact or in law. The Commission has discretion as to whether he will levy interest. Under the Bill the Commissioner must pay interest if the taxpayer has in fact made an overpayment.

The Democrats believe there is a grave danger here. The responsibility is on the taxpayer to interpret the tax law, to put in his return. This may not be audited for some years-five years or even longer-and it may then be drawn to the taxpayer's attention that he has made a mistake and will be up for a considerable amount of back tax, when, in all fairness, he has attempted to fill in a return as he or she understood the law. We believe that there should be some requirement on the Commissioner to answer genuine queries. I have discussed this at some length with the Taxation Office. The Democrats were originally hoping to move an amendment to make it necessary for the Commissioner on receiving a query from a taxpayer to give a ruling on the matter, and that ruling would then be binding. We looked into this in a little depth and the Taxation Office indicated that it is often difficult for the Commissioner to give a firm ruling because frequently he is not in possession of all the facts. Often, also, the facts that he is given are deliberately put in a way that makes his ruling very difficult. He may also have to make a ruling on incorrect or insufficient information.

The tax law operates at the moment on a case by case basis. When the law is transgressed the matter goes before the courts and the case is assessed and ruled on on its particular merits. We agree that if we were to turn that system upside down at this stage we would be asking too much of the Taxation Office. It would be difficult for the Commissioner to give a definitive ruling on cases brought to his attention. However, we have an assurance that the Taxation Office is prepared to answer genuine queries from taxpayers and to indicate the principle involved in that particular query. This means that there will not be a definitive ruling but there will certainly be a response from the Taxation Office to clarify areas of uncertainty. We believe that this is probably as far as we can go with this piece of legislation, so in the Committee stage we will be moving an amendment which simply says that the Taxation Office will be required to reply in principle to the queries of taxpayers, but we will not attempt to incorporate in our amendment anything along the lines that the Taxation Office's response will be in any way in the nature of a ruling on that particular case. It will reply in principle only; a decision on the merits or otherwise of the case would have to come from the courts.

We believe that with that requirement this legislation achieves what it sets out to do. It does introduce the adoption of self-assessment and it does ban negative gearing for property developments. But we cannot let the opportunity pass without criticising the Government strongly for again introducing legislation that is inconsistent. The Government has steadfastly refused to move on the question of the negative gearing of corporate raiders. The Government wants to abolish negative gearing for developers but it refuses to tackle the problem of negative gearing for takeovers. The amount of money involved in successful takeovers in 1984 was a mere $1.9 billion. That jumped to $4.2 billion in 1985, and already this year in excess of $4 billion has been put into Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd alone in bids for the control and defence of that company.

We have also seen the Repco company, an important company in the automotive parts supply business, raided, taken over and then split up and sold off, no doubt to the great benefit of the raider. Investment is being subverted. Figures released today show that real productive investment is falling. During the March quarter it fell by no less than 2.1 per cent. We cannot create jobs and overcome balance of payments problems unless the incentive to invest in productive activities, in productive capacity, within this country is restored. As I have said before, total new fixed capital expenditure in March totalled $2.7 billion. If half the money invested in the takeover of BHP had gone into fixed capital, this figure would have rocketed from $2.7 billion to $4.7 billion and that would have created an enormous number of additional jobs.

Takeovers are increasingly being successfully undertaken by small raiding companies, which take over large and successful companies with partial takeovers and the like purely to get access to the cash flow of the larger companies. This is not increasing our productive capacity. Companies can engage in takeovers simply because of a tax rort which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) so far has refused to address. The facts are that tax laws presently exist which could control this. Section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, if it were applied, would overcome the negative gearing of corporate raiders, but the Treasurer has refused to act. He recently released a White Paper on the tax effect of takeovers which was nothing but an enormous whitewash. He did not address the problem at all.

The facts on tax and takeovers are very simple. Dividends are tax free in the hands of companies. If a company borrows money to buy shares it must offset its interest payments against the tax free dividend income. This naturally assures that there is no double dipping in the tax system by getting tax free dividends before writing off the interest rate against other income. The facts of the matter are that companies are circumventing this law. By being allowed to do that it means that a company raider is in a better position than a legitimate company which is trying to develop its assets base and its productive capacity. A company which borrows money to buy real assets gets a tax write-off on the interest but the income produced by the assets is taxable. A raider, on the other hand, gets a tax write-off on interest and a tax free income from the shares it buys. therefore, it can afford to pay a higher price for the shares than the market value. So legitimate companies that are developing their productive resources are always at risk while the negative gearing of corporate raiders is allowed to persist.

The Treasurer has said: `Do not worry, imputation will cure this problem'. Incidentally, he says it will cure this problem but he steadfastly denies that a problem exists. The fact of the matter is that imputation will not cure the problem. Company tax will still be levied on retained earnings under imputation so that companies will seek to minimise their tax and, therefore, takeovers will still be advantaged over productive investment. It will continue unless the Government applies section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Some years ago tax frauds in relation to personal income tax became a very hot political issue. In this place some years ago we debated bottom of the harbour schemes and so on and so forth. I put it to the Senate that the tax rorts that are taking place right now in respect of company raids and stock market speculation are every bit of the magnitude of the tax rorts we had to face up to some years ago in the personal income tax area. If the Government continues to refuse to act on this, it certainly will not be able to control the economy as the economy should be controlled and it certainly will not be able to encourage the export oriented industries that should be encouraged right now. But, apart from that, it is putting enormous tax free profits into the pockets of company raiders. In the case of the Holmes a Court raid on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, he was offered a profit on the value of the shares he bought on the stock market of no less than $400m. What right has an individual-he is essentially an individual because he controls the Bell Resources group of companies-to make a $400m tax free profit in a period of some months? That is essentially what we have seen happen. It is happening because the Government refuses to make the existing company tax laws work. It is allowing the most blatant rorts to continue so that, first of all, the raiders are able to write off their interest charges over a whole variety of companies and are able to make interest free loans of billions of dollars from one company to another. This simply means that section 50 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is supposed to stop this happening, is not being applied.

It is very difficult for the Democrats to support a Bill which bans negative gearing in one area of the economy but not in another. There is a grave inconsistency here and we again say that if the Government does not act on this, it will be subject to the criticism of the community in no less a way than the previous Government was over the income tax rorts that applied during its term in government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter in this public interest debate with regard to the problems of food irradiation. Over recent weeks it has come to light that the Federal Government has been involved in confidential meetings with various State and Federal departments, including the Departments of Health and Primary Industry, and with various commercial interests and nuclear energy authorities to discuss the prospects of irradiation of certain foodstuffs in Australia. As part of this process the National Health and Medical Research Council has drawn up a document entitled `Model Food Standards Regulation for the Irradiation of Foods', dated March 1986. Discussions at the State level, notably in Queensland, my own State, have also been held between the Queensland Government authorities and certain United States companies, among them a company called Radiation Technology, incorporated in New Jersey.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the irradiation process involves the treatment of certain foodstuffs. The model food standard regulation produced by the National Health and Medical Research Council restricts food irradiation to the following: Cereals, fruit and dried fruits, poultry, herbs and spices and vegetables and dehydrated vegetables. We should note that most of these foods-for example, cereals, fruit and vegetables and white meats-are those which nutritionists are constantly telling us are necessary for good health and diet. The purpose of food irradiation, we are told, is to increase the shelf life of food and to destroy bacteria and insects which can cause disease or food spoilage.

Let us look at what else food irradiation can do for our food and our health. A March 1984 report prepared for the United States Department of Agriculture showed that mice fed irradiated foods showed an increase in testicle tumours, lesions and kidney disease and had a remarkably reduced lifespan. In another study there was found to be an increase in deaths in the tested animals, again fed irradiated food. In a further test there was a marked decrease in the weight of the animals and in the number of offspring of the animals being tested.

Studies have also showed that vitamins A, C and E, and especially vitamin B, may be destroyed by the irradiation of food. With the loss of vitamins and nutritional value in food, the potential also certainly seems to be there for genetic damage and cancer resulting from eating irradiated food. There seems to be also a possibility of increased growth of naturally occurring alpha toxins, which are very potent cancer-causing agents. Some of the latest research seems to have produced some evidence pointing to the creation of new chemicals in the food which is irradiated called radiolytic products, and in recent times some evidence has been produced of increased risk of food poisoning because of radiation-resistant bacteria. Since certain bacteria have been killed off by the radiation, other bacteria are allowed to reproduce at a much greater rate than they would normally. Further studies have found bruising and spotting in citrus fruit in particular, abnormal ripening and browning of fruit.

The process is one which is fairly obviously involved with the rural products area, and it is interesting that in a current publication there is some disquiet being felt in rural circles in Australia about the type of damage it may do to our rural products if we proceed down this line. I refer to our trade with other countries and allowing an Australian market to open up if, in fact, we accept irradiated foods.

These types of damages, of course, concentrate on the food itself. Setting up such mechanisms would provide-outside a further increase in terms of the types of companies and establishments concerned-an increase in the transport of radioactive materials and further possibilities of exposure to radiation for food processing workers. For example, the Health and Energy Institute in the United States of America states that one average-sized United States food irradiation plant could generate as much low level radioactive waste in a year as the total volume of such waste produced in the United States from all other sources.

The National Health and Medical Research Council's model regulations have recommended that the radiation doses be limited to a maximum of one million rads. However, this is 10 times more than allowed under regulations which recently came into effect in the United States. Further, Australia's own research establishment-the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-which has involved itself in this matter to a considerable extent, has found marked changes in cell membranes where red blood cells have been irradiated at not the 10-kilograys, or the one million rads level, but 0.1 kilograys, and changes in taste and smell at the level of 2.5 to 3 kilograys. It would seem-at least on that material-that the National Health and Medical Research Council's recommendations would seem to be extreme.

Something which causes me in particular great concern with the model regulations is paragraph 9, which deals with the labelling of irradiated food. In an earlier draft, in December 1985, the NHMRC recommended that irradiated food be labelled clearly as such. For some reason, this has been altered in the March recommendations to the following:

There shall be written in the label the words `treated with ionised radiation' or `radiated' (here insert the name of the food), or words having the same or similar effect to clearly indicate to the consumer that the food has been irradiated.

I would have thought that the first two descriptions spelt out clearly that the food was irradiated. Why include `or words having the same or similar effect'? What has happened in some other countries is that new words and symbols have been invented-for example, in the United States the word `peco-wave', and the use of the Netherlands' Year of the Flower symbol. These are supposed to indicate that the food has been irradiated. If indeed there is no problem, if people feel quite relaxed about the matter, there would seem to be no reason to go for these euphemisms and symbols. I think they in themselves indicate the concerns that people in the community have about this matter and hence the fact that people obviously feel they may affect the commercial viability of the products involved.

Another aspect of the labelling process is also of concern to me. This is the practicality of labelling fruit and vegetables. Does one, for example, label the individual orange, pumpkin or passionfruit, or do we rely on the fruiterer to ensure that the correctly labelled fruit and vegetable boxes are clearly visible to customers? I would have thought the commodity with which we are dealing is one which in fact is rarely packaged and only packaged in the supermarket context. It would seem that in the normal way in which these foods are sold, within the Australian context at least, most customers would probably not find out what in fact is occurring.

Turning now to the company which wishes to operate a food irradiation plant in Queensland, Radiation Technology Inc. of New Jersey, we find that this company has been before the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission for a number of violations. Among these violations are the following: In September 1975, Radiation Technology failed to advise the Commissioner of contamination of the plant's research and development pool water; secondly, the company failed to notify the Commission of a shut-down of its research and development pool; thirdly, the company failed to comply with an NRC regulation which requires that all individuals working within a restricted area be instructed in the precautions used to minimise radioactive expose; fourthly, when NRC inspectors monitored radiation levels in unrestricted areas of the plant in October 1976, levels in excess of those permitted were discovered; fifthly, the company violated an NRC regulation which requires that licensed materials, stored in an unrestricted area, be secured against unauthorised removal from the place of storage; sixthly, the company failed to signpost areas of radiation; seventhly, Radiation Technology did not label the containers of radioactive materials located in the receiving pool room and the containers material located in the unrestricted area in order to identify their radioactive content; eighthly, the company failed to make certain surveys or evaluations relating to the contaminated water incident, as is required by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission; and, ninthly, Radiation Technology failed to comply with an NRC regulation which restricts the use of by-product material to designated individuals only.

This is the very same company that wants to set up a food irradiation plant in my own State of Queensland, a company whose President has been quoted as saying that he was `very impressed with the gung-ho, can-do Queenslanders who are able to cut through the red tape'. In dealing with bureaucratic controls over radioactive materials, I believe that the action of red tape is supported by all senators and an area about which we are all greatly concerned. I think it is an area where there cannot be any cutting through of red tape. I suppose it is the new version of `better red than dead'.

Radiation Technology's abandoned waste dump at Rockaway township in New Jersey was in 1985 added to the United States Environmental Protection Agency's list of 133 hazardous waste sites and the company has been fined thousands of dollars for questionable chemical disposal practices and severe groundwater contamination. It worries me that such a company is proposing to operate such a type of plant in my State.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the name of the company again?

—It is Radiation Technology of New Jersey. There are a large number of questions on the practice of fruit irradiation which I believe need to be answered. I have mentioned some of those concerns, for example, health issues, transport and storage issues and incidents involving radioactive material. More questions have been placed on notice and asked of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) by a member of the other place. These include the critical questions relating to the importation of radioactive cobalt 60 and caesium 137.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk on a very important matter. It concerns the question whether there are in Australia nazi war criminals who have as yet escaped justice. In recent weeks the Australian Jewish Board of Deputies has asked the Federal Government to set up an independent inquiry, free of partisanship, to look at this question. The matter has come before the Jewish Board of Deputies primarily because in February last year the Canadian Government set up the Canadian Commission of Inquiry on War Criminals, the terms of reference for which I have before me. Equally, the Jewish Board of Deputies is concerned because of evidence that is coming out of the United States of America, where individual case are dealt with episodically.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been assertions in these inquiries that Australia was, to use a phrase, a dumping ground for nazi war criminals. Those assertions, if true of course, ought to be identified and the people concerned brought to justice. In two other directions, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, twice in the past six years, has run a series of programs making a series of allegations; and the Minister for Housing in the Wran Labor Government has made a series of very serious allegations in the Parliament calling for a specific kind of investigation. If any of these allegations are true, they should be investigated.

I want to make it clear that members of the Opposition-the Liberal Party and the National Party-are firm in their minds that we have an absolute abhorrence of the holocaust. We are determined that the world shall never forget it, that it must never occur again and that anyone who is clearly identified and proven to be a nazi war criminal should be brought to justice no matter how long it is since the end of the war. I want to make it equally clear that it would be utterly wrong and detestable if we undertook unjustified witch hunts. The Australian Jewish Board of Deputies has protested about that kind of partisanship and stressed that any investigation must be completely non-partisan.

There has also been a request by the chief Israeli delegate to the United Nations that the secret files compiled by the United Nations War Crimes Commission for 1943 to 1948 be released for scrutiny, and that is a matter that I invite the Federal Government to look at. I emphasise that we in the Liberal and National parties want to bring to justice any persons who can be properly identified against whom accurate evidence has been collated and who have been given a fair trial. We have gone much further than that. Over the years a number of our members, including senior members, have searched the world to get evidence in this regard. A number of times our members have called upon the Jewish Documentation Centre in Vienna where that very distinguished investigator, Simon Wiesenthal, holds responsibility. We have invited a search of the files to let us have any information. We are eager to pursue investigations in this regard.

The fact of the matter is, though, that so far, whilst we have ample evidence of numbers of people who have come to Australia who are, however much we detest it, strongly anti-semitic and have written anti-semitic words and articles, we have no evidence of our own, and nor, I think, does the Federal Government at this moment, of nazi criminality. We must differentiate between criminality and statements that are abhorrent to us. Above everything else, we must never repeat what happened in this place in, I think, 1973 when a whole ethnic group-the Croatian people-was condemned and some 2,000 names were publicised without the slightest indication at all that there was any evidence against them. That must never happen again. It is, indeed, to some extent happening in the kinds of allegations that Mr Walker has made.

I welcomed very much the statement made in this chamber several days ago by Senator Grimes representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford). He was asked by Senator Chipp about the progress of an inter- departmental committee on this matter and said that it had not yet finalised its report. He went on to say:

I can say, however, that to date the Department has uncovered no evidence to support allegations that there was a conspiracy to admit, as migrants to Australia, known war criminals, nor has an examination of the records of the Department unearthed any evidence of war criminality of persons who figured prominently in recent media programs.
The Department is not aware of any Australian material held overseas which relates to this matter.

I commend Senator Grimes for his moderation. He went on to say that we must not witch hunt. Indeed the whole substance of his answer is one that the Opposition would accept totally. But, of course, we cannot leave the matter here. If it is left here and if an interdepartmental committee simply finds something in similar words, there will always be the chance that somebody or some media organisation such as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, or some Minister of some political party wanting a cheap trick, will pursue it again, and that great damage will be done to individuals and to races of people.

A number of people were named by Mr Walker in the New South Wales Parliament. He made very grave statements indeed. I am not in a position to adjudicate in this regard. It is true that, like members of the Labor Party, I have met these people a number of times. But let me just take the following simple statement by Mr Walker:

Constandin Untarou migrated to Australia in 1950. He was a member of the Iron Guard of Romania and Treasurer of the Romanian National Government in Vienna from 1944 to the end of the war. Members of the Iron Guard participated in murderous attacks on the Jewish community in Bucharest in 1941.

I have asked the Government to agree to the incorporation of a number of documents. That, I understand, has been agreed to. It so happens that one of the documents, unless forged, is a certificate of incarceration of Dr Untaru in Buchenwald Concentration Camp from 1 January 1943. How can a Labor Minister, a member of the Party to which this Government belongs, put this label on a person when that documentation must be known? I also seek to have incorporated a statement and two letters from the Romanian National Council. I take it that the Government and Mr Walker do not say that the Romanian National Council is a nazi organisation and is hiding nazis. It says that nothing that Mr Walker says is true, that Dr Untaru was never a member of the Iron Guard, never a nazi, never a war criminal, and, indeed-in case Mr Walker wants another epithet, having said that Dr Untaru was a member of the Liberal Party-never a member of the Liberal Party. One of the two letters is directed by that Council to Mr Wran as Premier and the other to Mr Greiner as Opposition Leader. I also seek to incorporate a statement in Dr Untaru's own words, which he invited me to edit. That I have not done, and honourable senators will note the footnote. I seek leave to have those documents incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

Sir,

This Council takes the strongest objection to the campaign of character assassination conducted by Mr Frank Walker New South Wales Minister for Housing against, inter allios, Doctor Constantin Ion Untaru, our Australian Branch President.

We join our voices to those of Mr Michael Danby of the Australia Israel Review who is quoted (SMH 18.4.86) as saying, ``That the Jewish Community was disquieted by the way Parliamentary Privilege had been used to make unproven allegations against individuals''.

We urge Mr Walker to reveal publicly the source of his information and the evidence, if any, supporting it so that the Australian Public may gauge the veracity both of the persons making the allegations and of the allegations themselves.
We assert that Doctor Untaru was never a member of the Iron Guard or a Nazi and that on the contrary he was himself an inmate of The Buchenwald Concentration Camp.

During the events which occurred in Romania in the late 1940 and early 1941 years Doctor Untaru was doing his military service in the Royal Romania Army and on his discharge he was sent abroad by the Romanian Government to undertake a survey and study in economics on its behalf. Since that time he was never to return to Romania.
Doctor Untaru had as much to do with the events which occurred in Bucharest at that time as Mr Walker.

To be a Member of the Liberal Party of Australia is as much an honour as to be a Member of the Labor Party. Doctor Untaru however cannot claim the honour of having been a member of either. A search of the membership records of both parties will confirm this.

It is true however that during his activity on behalf of immigrants Doctor Untaru had met personally a succession of Prime Ministers including Sir Robert Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Gough Whitlam. He had met personally Ministers and other distinguished parliamentarians both Labor and Liberal not least of which was Arthur Calwell, the initiator of the Post War Migration.
Why was Mr Walker silent about Doctor Untaru's contacts with the Labor personalities.
We know Doctor Untaru as a former President of the Captive Nations Week Committee and as a President of the United Council of Immigrants, the forerunner of the Ethnic Communities Council.

He appeared in the latter capacity on the same platform as Mr Gough Whitlam MP in trying to convince the Government to adopt the principle of portability of pensions, Doctor Untaru's idea, since then implemented.

We known Doctor Untaru as President of the Anti-Bolshevik Bloc of Nations and as Member of the Romanian American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was and is, in spite of his age, a tireless worker for people in distress mostly migrants bewildered by problems.

The fact that he was in the forefront of those protesting against the iniquities besetting the countries lost to the Soviet Union is due also to his concern that Australia should be spared the same fate.
It comes as no surprise to him and to us that he was congratulated for his work and at one time he was accorded the accolade of ``Migrant of the Month''.

His activities have targeted him for attacks prompted both by the Soviet and the Romanian Communist Governments who would dearly love to silence this 79 year old Australian for Doctor Untaru had been and is fearless and articulate in denouncing those Governments' contemptuous disregard for human rights.

We know Doctor Constantin Ion Untaru for his selfless unstinted and long activity of intercession on behalf of generations of migrants, have the greatest admiration and affection for him and feel that the Order of Australia would be a proper recognition for his contributions to Australia's Post War Immigration efforts.
Yours faithfully,

COMMENTS AND ADDITIONAL INFORMATION TO THE DOCUMENTS ATTACHED CONCERNING THE WAR YEARS

(1) From 1926-1941, I was for the most time, studying overseas, and during the short periods, in between, spent in Romania, I was professionally engaged in activities, having no time for domestic politics.
My father and his friends were all members of the Liberal Party of Romania, and close associates of the Bratianus' family, who were the architects of modern Romania.

I did not meet, nor been associated with Romanian National Movement, known firstly under the name of ``Iron Guard''; then disbanded and reformed under the name of ``Legionary Movement''. As a legal political party, with representatives in Parliament, it was very popular especially among young people, peasants and workers, its programme having a rather religious character, based on a) Christianity, b) Monarchism, c) Anti-communism, d) Honesty and Public Affairs, e) The right of the overwhelming Romanian population to have a decisive say in the affairs and destiny of the country.
The first time, I came face to face with members of the Legionary Movement, it was in the Concentration Camp Buchenwald, Germany; but I did not become a member of their organization.

(2) The motive of my incarceration in Buchenwald is not given by the Gestapo, but I assume that it was requested by Marshal Antonescu of Romania. I believe that the reason for it, might have been the following fact. When I arrived in Germany, February 1941, on my mission to study the economic organization of Germany, on a war footing-some newspapers in Vienna published short articles about my mission. This drew the attention of the son-in-law of Alfred Krupp, the well-known German armaments manufacturer, who invited me to a private dinner in Berlin, at which were also present the Romanian Minister Pleni potentiary to Germany, Raoul Bossi, and the German Ambassador, Chef of the Romanian Desk, in the German Department of Foreign Affairs. The main discussion by the Germans was to convince me, not to recommend to the Romanian Government the introduction of a similar legislation as in Germany, for the mobilisation of Romanian heavy industry on a war footing, because it would be not good for business, as the dividends for the capital investers would be drastically curtailed. Among other items of discussion concerning the conduct of the war, I expressed the view, that Romania should not march into Russia, after reconquering the lost territories in the East (Bassarabia and North Bucovina), but should stop at the frontier, the river Dniester, consolidating their defences. So did also the Finns, under Marshal Mannerheim, after defeating the invading Soviet troops, and throwing them out of their country, but not following them inside Russia. Such views at that time were not only mine, but also shared also by veteran Romanian politicians as Maniu and Bratianu.

I believe that such views in this matter, which were not in accord neither with Hitler's nor Antonescu's war plans-were brought to the attention of the Gestapo, who sent me to the Buchenwald concentration camp, and allocated me to the Romanian Legionary's group, who were already there, before my arrival.

(3) It is true, that we were not incancerated in the same compound with the other common criminals or political prisoners, mostly communists, but had a separate accommodation behind barbed wire, consisting of primitive wooden barracks. In the same quarter of the Buchenwald concentration camp, but in better housing, were accommodated other VIPs, as the former Prime Minister of France, Leon Blum, or a daughter of King Emmanuel of Italy, married to a German Aristocrat, who politically disagreed with Hitler; and many others, whose names I did not know.
(4) On 23 August, 1944, when Romania capitulated to the Russians, we had a terrible air bombardment by the Americans, our barracks being totally destroyed and some of us killed.

Consequently, we were transported by the Germans to Vienna, where a Romanian National Government was in the making. This was a coalition Government, in which participated, besides Legionaries, also Romanian personalities, at that time, refugees in Germany, as e.g. the former Metropolitan Puiu Visarien of Bucovina and Bassarabia; an active General Chirnoaga; Cristis, a former member of the Bassarabian State Council, who voted in 1918, for the re-union of that province to Romania, etc. I was also invited to participate, as an economist, in the post of treasurer, the Finance Minister being a Legionary, by the name of Cenger. We all accepted to take part in this coalition Government, out of a patriotic duty, as our country was invaded by foreign troops, and the Head of State, King Michael could not act, being a prisoner of the Soviets. It was rather an academic gesture on our part, because we knew that we would not be able to change the course of a war, which was already lost and in which our country never fought against the Western Allies.
(5) After getting in touch with Lord Dalton, he helped me to get a job with a ``Displaced Persons Assembly Centre'' in Germany, which was an Agency of the British Military Forces of Occupation.
With other words, I was a former British Public Servant, not a ``nazi'', a war criminal before emigrating to Australia (see attached document).

(6) Actually, the term ``nazi'' did not exist before or during the war; it was cooked up afterwards, in order to smear people. In Europe at that time, there were: ``National Socialism'' in Germany; ``Fascisme'' in Italy; ``Falangisme'' in Spain, and similar nationalist movements in Great Britain, Norway, Belgium and France.

The Romanian Legionary Movement was none of these; it did not participate in any Government in the last war, and as such it was completely exonerated of any political responsibility, by the Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal in November, 1945.
(7) Not later than 4 years ago, I won a Defamation process in the Supreme Court of N.S.W. against a defendant, who accused me of being a Communist Agent! (see Document attached)
I would advise my detractors to make up their minds, before smearing me, because I can't be a ``communist'' and a ``nazi'' at the same time!
(Dr C. I. Untaru)
P.S. Kindly retype this in good English, as my memory of the English language is no more good-before presenting my notes to Senator Carrick.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot adjudicate on this matter, but if this kind of information is being traipsed around it has to be nailed down. If there is anything wrong with it let it be proven and let it come out. I can only say that the man Dr Untaru whom I and many members of the Australian Labor Party have known, because he was very active in good neighbour councils and migrant councils over the years, is held in very high respect indeed and, until we can prove otherwise, we are here to defend him.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take another case, although I do not want to take them all. Mr Walker, who uses a tar brush with great effect, in an attempt to talk of nazi war criminals, the subject of a motion in the New South Wales Parliament, said:

Fabijan Lovokovic is a name well known in New South Wales ethnic circles. He was a subject of lengthy investigations by ASIO concerning his activities with Croatian terrorist groups particularly the Croatian Liberation Movement or HOP.

He went on to comment. I happen to know Mr Lovokovic. I happen to have had a lot of information about him during the time that a Labor Attorney-General wickedly raided the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and then produced a pile of names but did not attempt in any way to support the allegations. But when Mr Walker said this Mr Lovokovic, rightly or wrongly, said: `I was 14 years of age at the end of the war'. Now, was he or was he not? That question is easy enough to answer. In any case, everybody knows the basic background of Mr Lovokovic.

Mr Lovokovic is one of those people who believe that a communist Yugoslavia is wrong and who want a non-communist Yugoslavia. He wants that, but not as a nazi. He is entitled to his views, but he is not entitled to use vigorous actions in that regard. But what we have done is terrible. We have put a taint on the Croatian people, a people who wanted to be free. Croatians had a dreadful choice during the war years. They could either be the chetniks with Mihailovich, the royalists, the non-communists, the King Peter people that Britain supported for quite a while, communists under Tito, pro-German or Ustashi without being nazi war criminals. They were entitled to be anyone of those things. Indeed, if we are looking for blame, it was the allies who, having looked towards the King Peter group, turned towards Tito and watched Tito slaughter some hundreds of thousands of Mihailovich's chetniks and execute Mihailovich. Is there not a case for Croats to feel a taste for freedom?

I just hope that we will never taint people with a tar brush like that. It is an outrageous kind of situation. It was easy for Mr Walker, who perpetually brings up a man named Lyenko Urbanchich whom I oppose in virtually every view he has. He certainly is anti-semitic. The whole aim is to say that the Menzies Government brought him into Australia. I say, and I do not say it invidiously, that the Chifley Government had Mr Urbanchich screened, as it did so many of these people. Indeed, they came in in the 1950s and 1951 in particular.

It is the duty of this Government either to hold an independent inquiry to the last degree and put these people out of their misery, or get up and say to governments and to broadcasting corporations: `You are committing a terrible crime if you continue to make these accusations against people and races when you have no proof'. I invite the Government, with all the force I can command, to hold an independent inquiry, completely non-partisan, completely free of tit-for-tat. Every political party will have within it remnants of displaced people. Every party will have within it people whose names could be bandied around like that of Mr Urbanchich. There will be none that we support, but indeed it is wrong if we go on a witch hunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The nazi regime was defeated and officially ended in May 1945 and suddenly no one was a nazi and no one had ever been a nazi. No one had ever supported the nazis from that day on. The issues have been raised, as my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick says, not only by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, and not only by the Hon. Frank Walker under the protection of parliamentary privilege in New South Wales. We also have the issue of Dr Kurt Waldheim, who is now a candidate for the most senior position in Austria. Senator Sir John Carrick has already referred to some of the accusations made in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs and, indeed, has had incorporated the letters from the Romanian Australian Cultural Society over the signatures of its President Stefan Verisan and its Vice-President, Micheal Vincenz, which deal with the matter of Dr Untaru. He has also cleared up the position of Mr Lovokovic and has made the point that Mr Lovokovic was 14 years old at the end of the war. If people wish to accuse him of having been a war criminal, they will have to do it against the background that he was 14 years old at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer again to Mr Walker. Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned the name of Lyenko Urbanchich. I make no bones about where I stand on the position of Mr Urbanchich. I sought with others to have Mr Urbanchich expelled from the Liberal Party of Australia. I would vote again for his expulsion.

TALK.START.PARA: —And I.

—And Senator Sir John Carrick would vote for his expulsion. I have no evidence that he was a nazi war criminal, but I believe that he was a nazi collaborator. They are very different matters. I believe that Lyenko Urbanchich was a nazi collaborator and for that reason I do not want to be in a political party with him, but we have not succeeded in having him expelled from the Party. That does not mean that our desire is any less; it does not mean that we endorse or accept anything that he stands for, I will not, in fact, endorse anything he stands for.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Dr Waldheim, we have a problem of a different kind. Its resolution, of course, rests with the people of Austria, but it has been revealed now that there are a number of questions in his own background. It is clear that he did serve in the German Army in a way which he had not made clear in his biographies. It is clear that he had served in the Balkans, when he said that he had not. It is clear that he has served in units which undertook some very doubtful activities and units which were probably involved in some atrocities. It is clear that Dr Waldheim has lied to the people of Austria in the run-up to the election, and he must stand branded as a liar. I do not know whether Dr Waldheim was a nazi or a nazi war criminal, although I know he belonged to nazi youth groups. Anyway, the more that seems to be revealed about him, the more his support on popularity polls seems to increase. I have no doubt that he will be elected President of his country and all I can say is that, with the background he has, it is a pity, but it is a matter not for my concern but for the people of that country.

I was concerned when this matter was first publicised that I should find some of the old documents about which much was being said in the Press. For example, did the British Government approach the Government of Australia, that is, the Chifley Government, asking it to go easy on nazi war criminals? What was the response of the Chifley Government? What other documents existed? I accordingly sought, under the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, the release to me of certain documents. I sought this from the Department of Foreign Affairs and from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I also made approaches to the Australian Archives.

The initial advice I received from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was that it did hold some documents but that they were prior documents in terms of the Freedom of Information Act and it therefore proposed to deny access to them. We phoned the Department, pointed out to it that that was a perfectly legal course of action and asked whether we were then free to announce publicly that it did not wish to reveal these documents because of a loophole in the FOI law. The position was rethought and the Department of Foreign Affairs has made certain material available to me. I must say that it is available as a result of the FOI requests.

It is clear from these documents that the Australian Government was approached by the British Government in 1948. I have here a rather poor copy of a document dated 13 July 1948, deciphered from the British Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations in London and received in Australia on 14 July 1948. It was declassified in Australia on 10 April 1986, just over one month ago. The document, which appears to bear a file number which I think reads HN0295, reads as follows:
Trials of Suspected War Criminals. We have been considering the question of final date for completing trials in the United Kingdom zone of Germans who are suspected of war crimes.
2. It is now proposed that:
(a) As many as possible of cases which are still awaiting trial should be disposed of by 31 August 1948 (uncompleted trials which began before that date would continue).
(b) In general no fresh trials should be started after 31 August 1948.

The British Government is suggesting that no fresh war trials should be contemplated after 31 August 1948. I take it that is irrespective of the crimes which were the subject of the charge. The document continues:
This would particularly affect cases of alleged war criminals not now in custody who might subsequently come into our hands.
I take it that that would include people such as Adolph Eichmann, Klaus Barbie and a whole range of people who subsequently were discovered. The document goes on:

3. In our view punishment of war criminals is more a matter of discouraging future generations than of meting out retribution to every guilty individual. Moreover, in view of future political developments in Germany envisaged by recent Tripartite talks we are convinced that it is now necessary to dispose of the past as soon as possible.
4. If Commonwealth Governments have any comments on arrangements proposed we should be glad to receive these by 28 of July.
Then follow some official abbreviations which I cannot read. Just to ensure that I have that accurate, I seek leave to have the full text of that document incorporated in the Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Dated: 13th July 1948
DECIPHER FROM SECRETARY OF STATE FOR COMMONWEALTH RELATIONS LONDON
Rec'd: 14th July 1948
HNO 295
1. Trials of suspected German War criminals. We have been considering question of final date for completing trials in United Kingdom Zone of Germans who are suspected of war crimes.
2. It is now proposed that
(a) As many as possible of cases which are still awaiting trial should be disposed of by 31st August 1948 (uncompleted trials which began before the date would continue).
(b) In general no fresh trials should be started after 31st August 1948. This would particularly effect cases of alleged war criminals not now in custody who might subsequently come into our hands.

3. In our view punishment of war criminals is more a matter of discouraging future generations than of meting our retribution to every guilty individual. Moreover in view of future political developments in Germany envisaged by recent Tripartite talks we are convinced that it is now necessary to dispose of the past as soon as possible.
4. If Commonwealth Governments have any comments on arrangements proposed we should be glad to receive these by 28 July.
Min & Dept E.A. (att)
Min & Dept Defence
A.G.'s Dept.
14th July 1948

TALK.START.PARA: —To the best of my knowledge and from the documents I have received, it appears that no reply was ever sent by the Commonwealth of Australia to that request from the British Government-the Labour Government in Britain-to the Labor Government in Australia, asking it to cease all prosecutions of war criminals after a date in 1948. One of the documents released to me under FOI is a hand-written note, which I take it is an internal file document, saying that no response has been discovered.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter does not end there, because the question of Klaus Barbie comes up. Klaus Barbie is, I believe, a Frenchman who is at present awaiting trial on certain charges relating to his activities during the war. It appears that there was some question of Klaus Barbie coming to Australia, and some of the documents which have been released to me suggest that this is so. I refer first to a document from the Department of the Army, Office of the Assistant Chief of Staff for Intelligence, Washington, DC-that is, the United States Army-received on 15 August 1983. It was addressed to the Office of the Army Attache, Embassy of Australia, and it reads as follows:
1. In processing the Army-orginated records concerned Klaus Barbie, the attached classified document information originating with the Australian Government, was located.
2. Request you review the Australian Government information contained in the document and determine whether there is any objection to the release of this information to the general public.

It goes on to say that any questions are to be referred to certain people. The document, which apparently refers to Barbie, talks about a new form of processing of German nationals who may wish to come to Australia. I have in my possession as well a Department of Foreign Affairs minute dated 25 October 1983 which carries the heading `War Crimes-Klaus Barbie'. It refers to the attached letter dated 7 October from Washington concerning the United States Army inquiry and is over the signature of Brian Matthews of the General Legal Section. It says:

I agree with Washington that on its own the letter appears innocuous. Seen in the context of its existence on a US Army Intelligence file on Klaus Barbie, however, the letter suggests the Australian Government was, at the request of the United States, giving consideration to the re-settlement of Klaus Barbie in Australia. Paragraph 6, set out below, is quite specific on this point.
Paragraph 6 reads as follows:
Cases such as those you proposed in our discussion would come under a special category.
this is the document talking about a new way of processing migrants to Australia--

In this connection, representations have been made to Australia, the special conditions mentioned by you being placed before them. I will now await a decision and you will be informed when it is known.
The minute then goes on to say:
The use of the plural `cases such as those . . .' implies that the inquiry was not restricted to just Klaus Barbie.

It appears that the Australian Government has indicated that it did not agree to the public release of these documents to the United States Army. I believe they should be released and, in if they were not public, they certainly are now. Anyone who wants them can get them from me.

I come back to the points made by Senate Sir John Carrick. I believe that Australian governments-whether it was the Chiefly Government or the Liberal governments that followed-acted in good faith to try to resettle people in this country. I believe that they tried to screen people. I believe that it is outrageous that the British Government should have sought to impose upon the Commonwealth countries in 1948 the proposal that they should cease any pursuit or prosecution of war criminals. It displays a selective kind of morality which I find it impossible to understand or to accept. I suppose it is the same kind of morality which caused the chetniks to be sent back to Marshal Tito after the war, after we had supported King Peter while it was in our interests so to do.

I do not support for one moment that the search for nazis should ever end and that those who were war criminals should not be brought to justice if there is evidence against them, and for as long as they live. In saying that, I know that I echo the views of many people who share my sense of right and wrong. I put on record the fact that we are appalled that the British Government should have acted this way. We are not saying that the Australian Government responded inappropriately, because I do not know that it did, but I know that many of the approvals for people who entered this country were made in those years from 1945 to 1950, including approval for Mr Urbanchich. For that approval, of course, we still have to bear the consequences. I hope that this country will try to get the facts clear to avoid witch hunts of different communities, and that if we do find any war criminals in this country they will be dealt with firmly and appropriately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments about an article in today's Courier-Mail headed `Phone taps save drug addicts' lives-police'. In this article the Vice-President of the Queensland Police Union, Detective Sergeant John O'Gorman, was quoted as saying that he was disgusted by Australian Labor Party Caucus moves to block plans to give telephone tapping powers to State police forces. I believe that Sergeant O'Gorman has every right in a democratic country to be disgusted. Whether he has a reason to be disgusted is another matter. But his disgust will not sway those who also have a strong belief that civil liberties in Australian society are worth preserving. Sergeant O'Gorman should not be surprised to know that there are still some people who do not want to see our country become a police State. Quite frankly, I would find it difficult to trust some police officers with telephone tapping powers.

SPEECH.PARA: The abortive, and in some ways frightening, raid on a rural property in Queensland in real swat style, as outlined in the National Times last week is an indication of how inept the police organisation can be in Queensland. I spent three years in the Queensland Police Department as a public servant. During that time I met many fine police officers whose professional judgment I would trust. I have met similar officers in the visits that I have had to provincial cities and rural areas in Queensland since I have been a member of this place. But in my time as a public servant in the Queensland Police Department, I saw some things that almost made my hair curl. I do not think it would be proper for me to go any further than that, but suffice it to say that I do not want to see phone tapping powers given to State police. The dangers to our liberties are far too high. The Queensland Police Department should have the investigative skill to track down drug dealers, drug pushers and addicts without listening to the telephone conversations of the State citizens.

When everything is fair and above board in the Queensland Police Department Sergeant O'Gorman may have reason to be disgusted, but things are not fair and above board. For example, just how long has an illegal casino been operating in Wickham Street, Fortitude Valley, in Brisbane? Perhaps the police force does not know about it. Perhaps it does know and someone or some people are on the take. I presume it is the latter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a young person these days, attempting to obtain employment can be quite traumatic, especially for a young person with some form of a problem which makes it more difficult than average. It has been difficult for young people to obtain jobs, and I wish to refer to two in my electorate who have had particular difficulties, each with different areas of the Public Service, which I would ask to be looked into. One concerns a young man who applied to the Public Service Board for an opportunity to take part in the examination system on 4 November 1985. The letter which I will seek to have incorporated indicates that he made phone calls to try to find out what was happening. He then sent another copy in February 1986 and made phone calls. He subsequently sent a third similar letter on 21 March 1986, and the Public Service Board in a letter which has the reference 86/3649 indicates that it received the letter `late last month'. That letter was dated 23 April 1986 and would undoubtedly refer to the third letter sent in March.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not really know what happened, but it would seem that the phone calls that this young man made to the Board were not adequately followed up. It may well be that both the previous letters did not get there for some reason. But surely the phone calls would have prompted somebody with some diligence to follow up what had occurred. It seems that just nothing was done until the date in March 1986 to which I have referred. In the letter to which I have referred it was said that he would be able to sit for the examination as speedily as possible. It is traumatic looking for a job, especially when one has a handicap, and this lack of apparent interest is discouraging indeed. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of a letter which I have received and which sets out in more detail the story that I have briefly referred to.
Leave granted.
The document reads as follows-
26 March 1986
Senator Margaret Reid
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Reid,
I am writing to you to seek your assistance in the case of my son, , who is trying to obtain permanent employment in the Australian Public Service.

Briefly, the history of the case is that during October 1985, my son heard through a third person that there were special testing facilities available in the Public Service for applicants with recognised disabilities and other special groups. He therefore contacted the Special Placements Officer in the Office of the Public Service Board by telephone, and was advised to submit an application in writing, together with a medical certificate. This he did on 4 November 1985.

Because he had not received an acknowledgement of receipt of his application, he phoned the Special Placements Officer after about a month had elapsed. He was advised that his letter had been received and was being processed. It was expected that a test would be held about the end of January 1986.

About the middle of January 1986 when he had received no advice, either written or by phone, he again contacted the Special Placements Officer by telephone, who reaffirmed that the next test was to be held at the end of January, 1986 and that he would be advised in writing of the necessary details.

When an advertisement appeared in ``The Canberra Times'' towards the end of January 1986, advising that a Clerical Assistants Test was to be held on 8 February 1986, my son, having heard nothing from the Board, again contacted the Special Placements Officer, and was advised that a special test would be held on a different date in February, and that he would be advised accordingly.

By the middle of February, when Michael had not been contacted by the Board, he again wrote to the Special Placements Officer. When he received no acknowledgement of his letter by the end of February 1986, he telephoned the Special Placements Officer once again. This officer advised him that neither his original application, nor his February letter could be located. However, every effort would be made to find the two letters and he would be contacted. No contact was made.

After more phone calls and more fobbing off, Michael was advised by the Special Placements Officer on 14 March 1986 that the search for the letters had been unsuccessful, and to submit a fresh application together with another medical certificate, and to bring them to him at 9.30 a.m. on Friday, 21 March 1986.

Michael kept the appointment, armed with the new application and medical certificate. To his surprise the Special Placements Officer said he had found the original application and the February letter. The Medical Certificate was still missing. The Officer advised Michael that he ``thought'' that a Test would be held in April, but could not give any definite date.

You will agree, I am sure, that this situation is most unsatisfactory, and is an example of bureaucratic incompetence at its worst. I am therefore seeking your assistance in obtaining written acknowledgement of his application, and his eligibility to avail himself of the Board's special testing facilities. Also I would like assurance that the original medical certificate has been sighted only by those entitled to see it in the course of their duties, and that a thorough search of the Board's records has been undertaken.

The ``missing'' Medical Certificate contained information of a highly confidential nature, and I am most concerned that this information does not fall into the hands of anyone, who may use it against Michael at some future date.
Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: —The other, a young lady, applied to the Department of Territories for a job in one of the hospitals. Again I will seek leave to incorporate the history of what had occurred. It is a similar type of story of a young person having great difficulty in getting an answer as to what was occurring, of being told that things were being posted and not receiving them when she expected them. I say to those who are responsible for the administration of the Public Service: Please try to see that these areas function smoothly and with great compassion because it is important. It is all very well to spend vast sums of money in what might be called `self-promotion' with the Priority One scheme, but where young people are actually interfacing with the Public Service it is important, as I said, that compassion and some diligence apply. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter to the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) and a summary of the submission to which referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
The Minister for Territories
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T. 2600.
Dear Minister,

I wish to protest most strongly at the apathy shown by the School of Nursing at Royal Canberra Hospital, to my daughter Elizabeth, aged 17, who was an unsuccessful candidate for the current Enrolled Nurses course being conducted by the above School.

I must emphasise at the outset that the fact that Elizabeth was an unsuccessful is not the basis of this complaint. The total lack of professionalism is evidenced by the administrative bungling, which appears to be endemic in the Canberra Health system, and is borne out by the facts appended herewith, in chronological order at Appendix A.

All too often there are those of my generation who hasten to label the unemployed young people of this country as `Dole Bludgers', `Layabouts', etc. If other young people seeking a career have been treated with the same insensitivity and apathy encountered by my daughter, then not only are the labels attached to these people unfair to say the least, but I can well understand why so many people throw themselves upon the Social Security system in order to avoid further disillusionment, brought on by shattered expectations by incompetent and impassive prospective employers.

Surely it is not asking too much to expect a prospective employer to notify an applicant of their application being unsuccessful in order that that person may at least, without undue delay, look to new horizons.
I will not labour the points which are appended, but I pose the following questions and await your reply:
1. If an inexperienced person of 17 years can competently administer the requirements of recruitment, why cannot the staff of the School of Nursing at the Royal Canberra Hospital do likewise.
2. Why was not Elizabeth informed of the requirement to sit an examination in order that she could have been prepared.
NB:-A recent advertisement for a similar course conducted by the Queanbeyan and Cooma hospitals clearly set out this requirement in their advertisement.
3. When might Elizabeth expect to receive the letter, and requested documents which she was told over one week ago, were `being posted'
4. What steps will you take to ensure that future applicants will not be treated with the same apathy encountered in this case.
I await your reply.
Yours sincerely
MINISTERIAL SUBMISSION-MALADMINISTRATION, SCHOOL OF NURSING, ROYAL CANBERRA HOSPITAL
(1) Applications for an Enrolled Nurses Course were called for by advertisement in the Canberra Times on 15.2.86.
(2) On 20.2.86 my daughter, Elizabeth, handed in her application having completed the requirement for her to have a dental examination prior to application.
(3) On 21.3.86 RCH advised of date of interview, i.e. 26.3.86.

(4) Immediately prior to interview Elizabeth was asked to complete some questions, which turned out to be an English Comprehension examination, with no apparent time limit, and no forewarning of this requirement.
(5) At interview Elizabeth asked whether she would be informed if her application was unsuccessful, and she was advised that she would be informed by telephone either way.

(6) In the subsequent weeks from 26.3.86 there ensued a period of absolute silence on the part of RCH, and a period of confinement to the home for Elizabeth awaiting the expected phone call. (The expected phone call, as you may well have guessed did not and has not to date of writing, arrived).

(7) On 18.4.86 (5 working days before Course starting date) Elizabeth phoned RCH and was told she had been unsuccessful. She queried which part of the Selection Criteria she had failed to meet and was advised to ring RCH on the following Monday and speak to someone from the School of Nursing.
(8) On 21.4.86 Elizabeth phone RCH and was asked to ring the next day to speak with a Mrs Walters.

(9) On 22.4.86 Elizabeth again phoned RCH to be told Mrs Walters was in conference and to phone back. This she did. Mrs Walters was again in conference and the employee asked if she could be of any help. When the query was raised as to the Selection Criteria Elizabeth was miraculously connected with Mrs Walters who advised her:
(i) she had not met the communication requirements;
(ii) she was on the reserve list;
(iii) she would be notified by letter, which was being posted; and
(iv) in reply to a request, that her curriculum vitae, etc. would be returned.
(10) On 30.4.86 I rang to speak with Mrs Walters and was advised she was unavailable. I then:
(a) enquired as to the whereabouts of the expected letter said by Mrs Walters to have been `being posted';
(b) indicated my intention to protest at Ministerial level over the apathy and inefficiency shown;

(c) pointed out the difficulties associated with young people endeavouring to establish their careers, and the necessity to inform them promptly of interview results in order that they may seek alternative employment;
(d) was asked to:
(i) `put this in writing';
(ii) phone back to speak with the elusive Mrs Walters;
(iii) give my phone number in order that Walters may contact me.
(in the light of previously detailed facts, I felt (iii) above would have been futile), and was advised that:
(e) 160 letters had to be sent out to unsuccessful applicants and there was only one person to carry out this task.
As previously mentioned in the covering letter hereto, the letter advising Elizabeth she had been unsuccessful is still awaited.
Sitting suspended from 1.38 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, leaves for official duty in the Republic of Korea, Canada and the United States of America today. He will return to Australia on 8 June. During his absence the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, will be Acting Minister for Trade. I also inform the Senate that the Deputy Leader in the Senate, Senator Grimes, will be a few minutes late for Question Time today. Will those senators who, for some reason that I cannot for the life of me understand, are anxious to pursue welfare matters today hold those questions for a little while until Senator Grimes returns?

—My question, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, concerns the economic mess disclosed by the national accounts which have just been issued. I remind the Minister that some time ago he indicated that he was quite happy to accept the credit for the good things that happen in the economy and he understood that that would mean that he would have to take the blame for the bad things that happen. I refer him to the national accounts which show negative real growth in the economy for the second quarter in succession and a significant drop in real private investment for the third quarter in succession. I refer also to yesterday's statistics which showed no evidence of a production pick-up last month and the fact that the national accounts confirm the depressed level of private investment and expectations revealed in yesterday's Australian Bureau of Statistics survey. In light of all this evidence, will the Minister now acknowledge the need for fundamental change to Government economic policy settings, and in particular will the Government alter its policies to get interest rates down so that investment and economic growth can resume?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board Senator Chaney's angst displayed in the question and the concern about the national accounts figures and the investment figures published yesterday. I remind Senator Chaney of two things. The terms of trade turned very sharply against Australia, particularly in the December quarter last year and in the March quarter this year. That has been a significant factor in itself.
—It was all forecast in the Budget; look at page 73 of the Budget Papers.

—Senator Michael Baume is on the Waste Watch Committee. He should look at his own waste sometimes, instead of interjecting here with silly comments. The terms of trade figures for the two quarters are of course very bad and the Government has acknowledged that fact. The second point is one about which honourable senators do not need to be reminded because they have been reminding us for six months, but in October the Government took a quite deliberate decision to slow down the rate of growth in the Australian economy. It is a matter of which the Opposition has been complaining for the last six months and trying to make hay about. That was a deliberate decision which has clearly taken effect in the two quarters in question.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney rightly said that the figures for the quarter show a negative growth rate. I would remind him in respect of these two quarters, having regard to the very strong performance in the September quarter, that if the June quarter is the same as March-that is, a weak quarter-we will still record a 4.5 per cent GDP growth for the financial year. I was asked whether the Government would change its policies in respect of interest rates in particular. I do not know whether there is any other aspect of that part of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you alter all those policies which will then enable you to get interest rates down?

—We are asked to alter all those polices which will enable us to get interest rates down. I remind Senator Chaney again that monetary policy has been eased slightly and interest rates are coming down. Compared with two months ago, when Opposition senators were making complaints, interest rates have come down considerably. There are of course other factors relating to interest rates which concern fiscal policy particularly, which the Government will be addressing in the context of the forthcoming Budget. I summarise by saying that the figures are disappointing. They look disappointing and they look bad, particularly in the light of the national account figures which have been published in every quarter since the end of 1983 after this Government came to power.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Leader of the Government for his answer and refer to his comment that in October the Government took a deliberate decision to slow down the rate of economic growth. Is it still the Government's intention to slow down the rate of economic growth?
—The answer to that question is, in terms of the application of rigorous monetary policies as applied earlier, no.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw the Minister's attention to an advertisement in a recent issue of the Australian Financial Review. The advertisement features Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and his wife blatantly promoting the services of a real estate company. What does the Minister make of this obvious abuse by the Premier and his good wife of their positions? Does the Minister see any similarity between being found between the pages of the Financial Review and being found between the sheets of the Australian Women's Weekly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I personally would be quite incapable of commenting on the last part of Senator Crowley's question; I have no expertise in those matters, and I will not make any comment. The advertisement in question has been drawn to my attention and anything I say is said more in sorrow than in anger. It is a source of great regret to see prominent Australians in positions of public life taking part in advertisements for private concerns. The advertisement in question is for Jones Lang Wootton, the real estate agents. I thought that in public life we had disposed of the notion that politicians should lend themselves to advertising campaigns for private companies at the time of the extraordinary incident with the Sheridan sheets, which involved the former leader of the Liberal Party some years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: I very much regret that the Premier of Queensland and his wife have participated in advertisements of this kind, because I regard it as a departure from the appropriate standards of public life. It is to me in sharp contrast with the Premier's persistent attempts to cajole or incite people to break the law in respect of taxation measures introduced in this Parliament. I find the double standard associated with that unusual and extraordinary. I also find the advertisement itself extraordinary. The heading of the advertisement is `Great teams of our time' and the text reads:
Parents of four children, grandparents of eight, the Bjelke-Petersens epitomise teamwork in its purest form, practised to perfection to produce outstanding results.

I do not know what all that means, but it seems to suggest that perhaps it is a beautiful thing after all. I find it extraordinary that the Bjelke-Petersens should have lent themselves to that advertisement without at least having perused the text and understanding what they were being put in for. I am sorry about the advertisement, but it is not for me to pass judgment about other people's conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to repeated claims by the Treasurer that despite the serious current account situation the domestic economy has remained healthy. In the light of today's national accounts, and in particular the fact that for two successive quarters there has been a decline in real non-farm product, does the Minister agree that Australia is now on the brink of recession?

—No, I do not. This is clearly one of those questions which have been put forward and prepared by what I euphemistically call the `Liberal Party think tank' before Question Time. Having regard to the answer which I gave to Senator Chaney's question I find it surprising that it is asked. Of course, the Treasurer has been correct in saying that on the basis of all published figures, the broad range of economic indicators, growth rates, et cetera, the domestic economy in Australia has been very healthy since this Government came to office, particularly in regard to the bits we had to pick up after the Opposition's mess of seven years in government.
—Where are you now?

—The honourable member asks where are we now. I do not know what he would do if he were in government. I suppose he would send the Prime Minister off to a royal wedding or something in order that the wages policy could collapse while he was away. That would be a brilliant suggestion which would emanate from the Liberals no doubt. Yes, the domestic economy has remained healthy, but the downturn in the terms of trade has been very significant in the domestic economy effects. As Senator Messner knows, and as I answered Senator Chaney, the effect of high interest rates which has been designed to decelerate the rate of growth in the Australian economy was a quite deliberate decision of the Government and, of course, that will have adverse effects on many of those economic indicators. We recognised that at the time and we do not retreat from that in any way. I have been given a variety of fairly mindless interjections such as: `Where are you now'. My answer to `where are you now' is, in a period of some difficulty which is a matter of national importance. I have absolute confidence that this Government with the economic management skills it has displayed will be able to resolve those difficulties over time. Wait and see.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Was it part of the Government's deliberate intention to bring the economy to the brink of recession?
