—I do not really regard that as a supplementary question. These flamboyant phrases do not mean anything. I would think that Senator Messner has been bordering on the brink of depression for a very long time. Anything this Government does might make him topple over. I ask him to wait a while.

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs would be aware of a Press release by the Opposition spokesman on veterans' affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, alleging that the Minister improperly used the Australian War Memorial for a ceremony associated with the proclamation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Is there any substance to this claim?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the Press statement put out by Mr Tim Fischer, my shadow opponent. I am very surprised and disgusted at the statement which he issued and also at the tenor of the question that he asked of my representative Mr Clyde Holding in the House of Represenatives last Thursday. The fact is that the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in the Parliament, now known as the Veterans' Entitlements Act, was the most significant piece of repatriation legislation in post-war years. As such, it was determined in a discussion with my Department that there should be a ceremony for the actual proclamation of the legislation with invitations extended to the veteran community. The Department, therefore, took steps to itemise suitable venues for the holding of such a function. The Department then made the decision that the suitable place for the proclamation ceremony would be the Australian War Memorial. That event took place last Thursday.

ANSWER.PARA: The reasons advanced were that it was significant legislation, that it was a matter of some importance to the veteran community, and that the War Memorial had the facilities and the venue suitable for such a function. However, the function was a non-political function, and it causes me some concern that a member of the Opposition parties would take the position which Mr Tim Fischer took. The function was opened by the Director of the Memorial. The Chairperson of the Memorial then spoke, followed by the President of the Repatriation Commission, Mr Derek Volker. I then spoke as the Minister and I was then supported by Sir William Keys on behalf of the veteran community. The only reference to politics which was expressed at the function was made by Sir William Keys when he thanked the Parliament and the Government. He thanked the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats for their co-operation, following extensive consultations for the passage of the legislation. That was the only time there were any sorts of party-political references made.

This is not the first time that Mr Tim Fischer has departed from what I regard as the normal behaviour between Government and Opposition. For example, he requested information from my Department some time ago, and due to a typographical error on the assets test, he was given a figure of 4.3 per cent instead of 3.4 per cent. That error was discovered within 24 hours and he was subsequently advised. Nevertheless, he circularised a great number of organisations and persons with the original figure and not the amended figure, causing a greater degree of concern than was otherwise occasioned. He also claimed credit for 40 of the 42 amendments which the Government accepted in the Senate arising from the debate in the Senate. As he knows, and as we well know, many of those amendments were put forward by the Government, by the Democrats, as well as by the Opposition. Again, he got very very close to misconstruing and misrepresenting the Opposition's political position. One then has to wonder whether the facilities which are normally available to shadow Ministers should be continued if Mr Tim Fischer is going to play politics the hard way as he did in respect of this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of a report in this month's issues of Vetaffairs noting that a nation-wide training campaign is currently being held for departmental staff to familiarise them with the new guide to assessment of rates of veterans' pensions? Can the Minister confirm that under the recently passed Veterans' Entitlements Act, this guide must be tabled in Parliament and is subject to disallowance. Can the Minister explain why copies of the guide have not been laid before Parliament, whereas they have already been given to departmental officers and are being widely distributed in the community?
—I have not seen the particular article to which Senator Macklin refers, but I will certainly check out that information and give him a very early reply.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Minister answer the second part of my question which is that this guide must be tabled and why it is now available widely within the community and to departmental officers when it has not been tabled in this place?
—I have nothing further to add.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Has he seen an article in this morning's Canberra Times reporting that an Australian Capital Territory solicitor, Mr Gary Humphries, who is apparently also a vice-president of the Australian Capital Territory division of the Liberal Party, had received a cheque from the Department of Finance for $2,929 and a computer print-out showing various deductions from 34 New South Wales Federal Labor parliamentarians' salaries adding up to that figure, which he imputed was an attempt to bribe him? Can he advise the Senate of the circumstances in which Mr Humphries received the cheque? Will the Minister consider setting up a royal commission into these allegations to give all of those New South Wales parliamentarians an attempt to clear their name?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in charge of royal commissions but I certainly would not recommend that a royal commission investigate this matter, although I would recommend an investigation by the relevant law society into the unprofessional behaviour of Mr Humphries. However, that is not a matter which the Government per se can take up. The cheque in question was mistakenly posted to a firm of solicitors, Elringtons, instead of to the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party. My office was told yesterday afternoon by a journalist from Capital 7 that this had happened. The matter was then investigated and the journalist was advised according to the Press release which was issued later yesterday. It explained that a coding error had caused the cheque to be misdirected. The Press release is already a public document.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Humphries had apparently taken the cheque to the television station rather than returning it to the Department of Finance, as one would have expected any honest person to do. I was surprised by the allegations of bribery in the release distributed by Mr Humphries in the Press Gallery last night. It is a silly political stunt of the type that should qualify him for membership of the Liberal Party's Waste Watch Committee. It seems that there is a clear case of libel against some senior Cabinet Ministers in Mr Humphies's Press statement. I do not know whether they want to take up the matter.

Finally, Mr Humphries' behaviour was certainly questionable and, in my view, unethical. I would hope that the Law Society and Mr Humphries' colleagues at Elringtons will advise him that his conduct was unprofessional and take action accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, relates to the management skills of the Government which he has recently claimed. I refer the Leader to the recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report on labour market flexibility, which argues in favour of a tripartite approach to economic and labour market policy formulation. Does he support the view expressed in that report that full automatic wage indexation should be halted, or at least modified, as in all other countries? Will the Government seek to extract increased flexibility from the trade union movement at next week's mini-summit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular OECD report to which Senator Durack referred; he did not identify it. I do know that several OECD reports have commented very favourably on the success of this Government in producing a prices and incomes policy in Australia which worked. There is no doubt that some OECD reports have stated that a greater degree of flexibility in that system would be more desirable. They have also stated, I repeat, that we have been successful in providing a prices and incomes policy which worked. That has been the essential comment contained in the OECD reports.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know the particular reference to which Senator Durack referred. He asked me whether, on the basis of some OECD recommendation, full automatic wage indexation should be halted. I think that was the expression that he used. He went on to ask what the Government would be putting to the trade unions at the Advisory Committee on Prices and Incomes meeting next week. All I am able to say at this stage-it is public knowledge-is that the question of wages will be on the agenda. I suppose curiosity is a great thing, but the process of discussion and negotiation about these issues is not helped by my saying publicly in the Senate what approach the Government will be taking on those issues. Let me say that the issue of wages will be on the agenda.

As for Senator Durack's gratuitous piece of sarcasm at the beginning of his question about this Government's management skills, I find it extraordinary that the suggestion should be made by an Attorney-General in a former Liberal government whose management skills were displayed when he left files in drawers at the bottom of his desk for several years. It is a matter of public knowledge that I do not agree with the Treasurer in the present Government on everything. Nobody would with any Minister in any government. But one thing on which I do agree with him to the utmost is that members of the Opposition could not manage a tart shop.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to Press reports today that the Reagan Administration has served notice that it tends to end observance of the provisions of the SALT II Treaty in the near future. Inasmuch as the Australian Government's position on nuclear weapons is based on support for arms control measures and that the SALT II Treaty, despite not being ratified by the United States of America, is commonly recognised as the most effective arms control agreement existing, will the Government express its complete rejection of this unilateral action by the United States?

—The Government's position on this matter is in the following terms: In a recent exchange of letters with President Reagan, the Prime Minister informed him of the Australian Government's views on the issues of United States and Soviet compliance with the SALT II Treaty. The Australian Government attaches great importance to the existing regime of nuclear arms control, including the SALT II Treaty, because of the important degree of predictability it establishes and because it provides a basis for negotiating new agreements to reduce the level of armaments, both nuclear and conventional. The Government understands the United States concerns about Soviet compliance with particular provisions of the SALT agreements. It has made clear Australia's view that the Soviets have a case to answer on specific issues and this view was conveyed directly to the Soviet Government in a recent letter from the Prime Minister to General Secretary Gorbachev. President Reagan's decision, announced a couple of days ago, that the United States will, in future, no longer necessarily be bound by SALT II limits underlines the grave situation which has now arisen for the arms control process. The situation demands close and careful analysis, which the Government is undertaking as a matter of urgency.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Given the importance of establishing within the new and permanent Parliament House significant national identification of the Australian way of life, its history and its resources, I ask: Why was Australian produced wool carpet excluded in favour of a product from New Zealand? Could not at least a portion of the contract have been reserved for Australian industry?
—I have no advice on that matter from the Department of Territories. I will seek an early response for Senator Watson.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: PROCESSING OF CLAIMS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be aware of often repeated criticisms of the Department of Veterans' Affairs that delays in the processing of claims are unsatisfactory and that the situation in recent times has worsened. Would the Minister care to comment on these allegations, particularly as he is on public record as having defended these delays?

—On several occasions I have answered questions in respect of outstanding applications for pensions and variations of pensions. The most recent information I have is that the number of entitlement applications has decreased as a result of the improved system that has been operating since 1 January 1985. It decreased from 28,000 to 20,000 in round figures. Similarly, the number of assessment cases dropped from about 13,700 to about 8,500 over the same period, which would be a drop of approximately 41,000 to 28,000. Several days ago my Department advised me that there has been a steady reduction in the number of cases outstanding. The only State in which a peak position is still to be reached is Western Australia. Special steps have been taken in my State of New South Wales to maintain the very improved position that has taken place, in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. We are hopeful that we will be on target by about the end of this year.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of the leaked confidential Treasury forecasts which claim that by June 1987 Australia's gross external debt could total $100 billion or $6,330 for every man, woman and child in Australia? Do the April balance of payments figures confirm to the Government that our ability to pay our way in the world is decreasing rather than increasing? Does the Minister believe that the introduction of new taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, the Australian Council of Trade Unions-Government sponsored 3 per cent productivity claim and the maintenance of the inflexible accord will help to reduce our growing debt problem?

—The answer to the first part of the question is no. The second part of the question relates to the April balance of trade figures and whether they indicate a decreasing rather than a rising standard of living. If one were to leap to conclusions based on a month's figures the answer to that part of the question would be yes. Then Senator Parer cranked up his old ideological machine and asked me about the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and all that stuff. We have been through that before. When he can come into the chamber and tell me why the Opposition has compared for many years the growth rates and economic performance of this country with other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, all of which have had a more stringent capital gains tax than has Australia, and when he can cite some respectable arguments as to why they have been so successful and we have not--
—They are friends of the tax dodgers; that is why.

—As Senator Elstob points out, that is largely because the Opposition has been dedicated to supporting tax avoidance. When Senator Parer can put some respectable arguments about those things, I will endeavour to answer that part of his question more seriously. When he can work out some alternative policies on some of these issues, again I will be prepared to answer those questions more seriously.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHILDREN'S SERVICES IN THE NORTHERN TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Community Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to media reports that claim that the Northern Territory is not receiving its appropriate share of Commonwealth children's services and is suffering because of its remoteness and isolation? If so, will the Minister comment on these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have seen such reports. They usually emanate from a couple of groups in the Northern Territory which have vested interests, namely, the people who are running and those who are employed by two of the child care centres in the Northern Territory who seem to believe that the rest of the community has a duty to support them. In the main, the main centres of population in the Northern Territory-Alice Springs, Katherine, Gove, Tennant Creek and Darwin-have funding programs for children's services comparable with those in all the States. In fact the Northern Territory is pretty well off in those centres for children's services when compared with the other States. However, in remote areas and remote communities there are problems that create planning difficulties and this means that we have to take a different approach. While I was in the Territory last week I offered the Northern Territory Minister for Community Development a plan whereby, if he would contribute $120,000 on a dollar for dollar basis, we could provide a remote area children's services program. Over a three-year period we would be able to provide funds to assist people in remote areas where there are small numbers of children and in which there are very special and particular problems such as isolation, a high percentage of Aboriginals, et cetera. We could assist them in determining what their needs are and how best to fulfil them.

ANSWER.PARA: This follows a pilot program which was run in the Northern Territory in 1983 and 1984 and which was directed primarily towards the needs of Aboriginal children. Under the proposed program that I have put forward we would look after the needs of both Aboriginal and white children. During the pilot program we put funds into a range of projects, including community recreation programs and the construction of things like basketball courts and playgrounds. These assisted very much in meeting the recreational needs of children in those areas. We also confirmed the wisdom of employing Aboriginal staff wherever possible to deliver these services to Aboriginal children. If we can develop a program which benefits both communities in the Northern Territory, through a joint Territory-Commonwealth program of this type, we will have a better planning method and we will ensure that the needs of the community and the very special needs of those remote areas are best met. But in the large population areas of the Northern Territory the services provided are on the same basis as for the rest of the community and at a level equal to the rest of the community. In fact the Northern Territory, with some very efficient and innovative children's services programs, is doing very well in this regard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Did the Minister see the article in today's Australian headed `Up to 14,000 students barred from uni places'? It states:

QUESTION.PARA: Between 9,000 and 14,000 Australian students eligible for entry and willing to accept an offer of a place were unable to start studies in higher education at the beginning of this year.
That number represents a medium-sized university.

Does the Minister agree with those figures? What action is to be taken to correct the situation and so utilise the abilities of our young and not so young people who wish to pursue university studies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the newspaper report. More to the point, I am aware of the survey which was carried out by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education to try to measure the extent of unmet demand in the higher education sector. I have that report available to me. If Senator Townley would like to see it he is welcome to do so. It qualifies very heavily the range of 9,000 to 14,000 places because it is very difficult to take into account things like students applying to more than one institution, students deciding to defer so that they can go into the work force and so on. However, there is a level of unmet demand and it is probably in the vicinity of 9,000 to 10,000, which is similar to what it was last year. However, there are some factors explaining it and I will draw Senator Townley's attention to the quotation of the Chairman of the New South Wales Universities and Colleges Admissions Centre which was quoted in today's Sydney Morning Herald. New South Wales is a State which has shown an increase in the number of people unable to get places. The Chairman, Mr Schroder, said:

ANSWER.PARA: I'd guess in the main they--
that is, those who did not get offers-
did not perform very highly. Then there are a certain number who have performed well and not applied at all . . .

Mr Schroder said the unmet demand did not mean all places at institutions were filled. He said that in NSW there were more places available in nursing courses in CAEs and the same might apply to education courses at CAEs.

That sort of comment demonstrates that some students apply for particular courses and, when they cannot get into those courses, they make other arrangements such as returning to school in order to try to get a higher pass or they get some work experience and intend to apply again. So the situation is better than the growth statistics suggest, although it is not a satisfactory situation; I agree with that. The Tertiary Education Commission has pointed in the same article to the growth of higher education enrolments which increased from 265,000 in 1983 to 292,000 in 1986. So certainly there has been a significant growth in places available, partly because of our success in getting students to complete secondary schooling, partly because of the increased student allowances and, of course, because of the increased funding available to higher education institutions. The Government is intent on continuing to build up the number of places available. At the same time, we recognise that not all students will be successful in gaining places. We hope that many who do apply will reapply next year in a stronger position and will be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, refers to the national drug offensive. Can the Minister say where the offensive's anti-drug information campaign is likely to include a more direct and hard-hitting exposure of the dreadful effects of drug abuse? Is the Minister able to say whether the Government is satisfied with the present coverage given to drug abuse in schools' health education programs?

—I am not able to give a meticulously detailed answer. It requires an answer at two levels. One is related to the drug offensive which is a joint initiative of State and Federal governments. There is significant evidence that the level of debate and discussion about the danger of drug abuse generated by that campaign has been very substantial. That is particularly seen in responses to surveys about the recall of television-provided information and so on. That level of recall is considerably higher than it normally is for transmitted television information. The drug offensive has had more than 5.4 million booklets distributed to Australian households.
—Just getting yourselves re-elected.
—A great number of information kits have been distributed and there have been hours of electronic media coverage.
—And advertising of the Labor Party. Was there anything else? There was television advertising selling you and your Government.

—In spite of all that campaigning, Senator Lewis still interjects as if he has been smoking pot for a week-silly, pot-headed interjections from Senator Lewis in spite of that campaign conducted in Australian households. The only real hop-head it has missed is Senator Lewis. There has been general exposure of the information which has been sought to be purveyed in the drug offensive. The second part of Senator Elstob's question relates to the schools program on drug abuse. A number of projects have been set under way in various schools by Commonwealth and State governments. Many millions of dollars have been spent. About 138 on-the-ground programs have been placed in line at a cost of $24m. One million dollars has been devoted to educative programs in Western Australia, $5.6m in New South Wales and $360,000 is Tasmania. All are school-based projects. In Victoria, $3m has been allocated and in South Australia, Senator Elstob's State, $800,000 has been allocated. This education funding is organised through a variety of mechanisms not school-based alone but spreading into the community. Of course, there can never be satisfaction with the results of a campaign of this kind because no such campaign can be successful in eradicating abuses of drugs or perhaps in making more than a reasonable impression on the abuse of drugs.
—You are trying to sell yourselves to the kids of Australia. You should do something decent about it.

—The process has been going very well so far. To that extent, the Government is pleased with the program. I say again that the only progress that has not been made is by Senator Lewis who is mumbling away-perhaps I was unkind to him-under the influence of alcohol probably.

—I take a point of order. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate to withdraw the comment which he made about Senator Lewis at the end of his answer. The comment was thoroughly objectionable and should be withdrawn.
—Order! I did not hear the statement. If Senator Button said something that was offensive, I am sure that he will withdraw it.
—Perhaps it should be repeated, Mr President.

—I take a point of order. The Leader of the Government's desire to amuse the Press Gallery is no doubt very noble but I suggest that he ought to show a little dignity and a little respect for senators. He ought to withdraw the remark without any further messing about.
—Order! Again I say that the Chair did not hear the remarks of Senator Button at the end of his answer. If he said something outside the Standing Orders I ask him to withdraw it.

—Mr President, I made about five remarks which might be regarded as being offensive to Senator Lewis. He was interjecting repeatedly throughout my answer. Senator Chaney took a point of order about the last part of my answer, but I withdraw all those remarks. I wish that Senator Lewis would withdraw his interjections at the same time.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. It concerns changes to the calculation of air navigation charges which will become effective as at 1 July 1986. Is the Minister aware that one airline operating in regional Queensland will face an increase in charges of about $310,000? Can the Minister appreciate that regional airlines should not be compared with the major airlines for these charges as they do not require long runways, primary control zones and fire services for their operation? What is the Minister's reaction to the fact that any increases in air navigation charges will have to be passed on to the travelling public-in this instance, the regional commuters of Queensland-probably resulting in a significant decline in passenger numbers and, more worrying, in employment? Is the Minister prepared to look at regional services in a more sympathetic light, taking into account their dissimilarities with major airlines and the fact that they provide a much needed communication service for people already disadvantaged by isolation?

—Senator Bjelke- Petersen has raised a specific problem dealing with regional commuter services in Queensland. I imagine that this would have the same application in some of the other large States. As the honourable senator understands and accepts, the charges will commence on 1 July. It is a part of the cost recovery program that has been approved and agreed to by the Parliament and will continue the substantial progress towards cost recovery which has been synonymous with that of previous governments and of this Government. The honourable senator raised some specific concerns about some of the smaller airlines in the more outlying areas. She asks whether the Minister for Aviation is aware of the implications. I only represent the Minister in this place and cannot say whether he is aware, but I imagine that he would be aware, of the difficulties created by the cost recovery program. I will take steps to draw the Minister's attention to that matter to see whether there is any discretionary power in the legislation that may temporarily at least alleviate some of the concerns expressed by the honourable senator. I will ask for an early response to her question.

—Is the Minister for Education aware of the lack of progress in transferring nurse education to colleges of advanced education in Queensland? What steps can be taken to give Queensland nurses the same professional opportunities as are being developed in other States? Does the Minister consider that the latest 7 per cent drop in the Queensland Premier's already low approval rating is related in any way to his Government's persistent refusal to negotiate and co-operate with the Federal Government on this important issue and so many other issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our Government is very concerned that the Queensland Government refuses to act and co-operate in respect of the transfer of nurse education to colleges of advanced education in Queensland. I am sure that our concern is shared and perhaps felt even more keenly by the nurses of Queensland. The policy of transferring nurse education to colleges of advanced education, and thus giving nurses professional qualifications equivalent to those of many other professionals working in the health area, was very energetically supported for many years by nurses throughout Australia, including nurse organisations of Queensland. Their disappointment is very great that the Queensland Government has refused to take up the Commonwealth's offer of making 450 places available in higher education institutions. I should add that the Queensland Minister for Education often likes to complain that Queensland is being badly done by in terms of higher education places. The Commonwealth is now offering 450 places to Queensland which the colleges wish to implement and which nurses and the nursing profession generally wish to see transferred but which the Queensland Government, for reasons best know to itself, refuses to act on.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in terms of what the Commonwealth can do, we can make clear to the Queensland Government and to the public in Queensland, who I know are also very interested in this matter, that our offer still stands. We are making the same offer we have made to other States throughout Australia which is that we will add to the nurse training funds, already made available to the States through the States health grants, additional funds which will provide an additional $1,500 for each student going into a college place. We will pay a tertiary education assistance scheme allowance to all eligible students and we have also made several million dollars available for the retraining of nurses who wish to re-enter the profession, to ease the shortage which may come about partly as a result of the reduction in hospital-based training.

I remind honourable senators that nurse training has always been the responsibility of the States. They have received funds for that function through the States health grants. We are making no deduction in those grants to the States. Instead, we are providing the additional per capita amount of $1,500, the TEAS payment to eligible students and the retraining amount. As a result of this package the States have a net gain in the funds available to them for nurse training. In those States where transfers have taken place-every other State except Tasmania-the health authorities have facilities and resources freed up to use for health purposes. So the deal is a fair one. It was painstakingly worked out in co-operation with nurses throughout Australia. If it is carried through by the States it will mean that the transfer will be complete by 1990, a goal which, as I said, has long been sought by nurses and their supporters throughout Australia. The delay in Queensland is entirely the fault of the Queensland Government but, should the Queensland Government decide, as a result of Senator Reynolds's representations and the representations of nurses throughout the States, to take a more constructive view, our offer still stands, and I certainly hope that that will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Has the Minister seen reports indicating that the United States intends to sell 500,000 tonnes of barley to Saudi Arabia? Is the Minister aware that such a sale represents a loss equivalent to one-quarter of our market in Saudi Arabia and approximately one-tenth of Australia's total barley exports-about $48m? What information does the Government have on the matter and what action does it intend to take? Finally, as Australian farmers are now facing possible United States competition for wheat in North Yemen, rice in Papua New Guinea and now barley in Saudi Arabia, does the Government still stand by the view put by its Prime Minister that the Government has the `wholehearted co-operation of the United States Administration' in relation to agriculture?

—I have with me a note from Mr Kerin on this matter. I do not know whether I should do a deal with Senator Crichton-Browne and offer to supply him with this information if he will tell me what is going on inside the Liberal Party in Western Australia and the power struggle--
—Order! The Minister will answer the question.

—Anyway, we do know that Senator Chaney and Senator Crichton-Browne are on opposite sides of the power struggle. I am told that Saudi Arabia is the most important export market for Australian barley and that traditionally the United States has supplied only very small quantities to Saudi Arabia. The United States move to sell under concessional terms up to half a million tonnes is viewed with great concern by Mr Kerin who will be taking up that concern with the United States through all the appropriate avenues. Consistent with the assurances received from the United States during the Prime Minister's visit, we expect Australian sales to the Saudi market to continue at normal levels of around two million tonnes per annum.

—Is the Minister for Education aware of concern about the level of tertiary education assistance and of the criticism of the recent Government decision that full time students ineligible for TEAS should not receive alternative forms of assistance from the Department of Social Security? If so, does the Minister consider that these concerns and criticisms are justified?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that there has been some criticism from student organisations recently arising from the decision to clarify what has always been the position, namely that full time students are entitled to student allowances and not to welfare allowances. That was always the intention of the program but there has been some departure from it over the years. There have been cases where students who were judged ineligible for TEAS were able to draw on other welfare benefits. That is not appropriate in the view of the Government and there will be a clarification of the position in legislation. I do not think complaints about that are justified. It is our Government's intention to treat students fairly as a group. We have taken a number of steps to improve the allowances available to students. However, for students who fail to meet the TEAS requirement to be able to go off and take a welfare benefit certainly undermines the intention of the TEAS scheme which is to assist needy students in their tertiary studies and is unfair in its effects on welfare beneficiaries who are generally not in a position to avail themselves of the benefits of full time tertiary study.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that in the students' comments there has been some misunderstanding of the Priority One package for increasing student allowances. Students also seem not to be aware of the fact that there has been a growth in the number of students receiving TEAS, for example, from 74,691 in 1982 to an estimated 101,600 this year. This represents an increase from 36.7 per cent of full time enrolments to something over 40 per cent. So, over 40 per cent of full time enrolled students are now eligible for TEAS.

TALK.START.PARA: —Full TEAS?

—Not for full TEAS, but for part of TEAS. In 1985, 37 per cent of TEAS beneficiaries received allowances at the independent rate. The Government's initiatives for income support arrangements across the tertiary and secondary sectors will involve considerable additional expenditure. The costs are being estimated at $35m in 1985-86, $86m in 1986-87, $170m in 1987-88 and $251m in 1988-89. These figures will represent an increase in the individual allowances until they all reach the equivalent unemployment benefit rate for the age group and will also involve indexation of the allowances. I stress that, because there was a criticism from student groups that the package did not include indexation. It does include indexation and is a considerable improvement on any previous student allowance scheme. It will enable more students to take advantage of the scheme, as the statistics show is already happening. It is on line with our Government's intention to increase participation in higher education and tertiary studies, particularly by low income groups.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Education. It follows the question of Senator Townley to her earlier in Question Time. Why was the Minister so complacent in her answer earlier today about the 9,000 to 14,000 Australian students refused entry this year to higher education courses? Will she acknowledge that the figures have the authority of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals in Advanced Education? Will she acknowledge that they are determined after duplicate applications and withdrawals have been accounted for? The Minister should be aware that, in total, the gross figure of applicants refused is 33,000-that is, 22.7 per cent of all applicants were refused entry to higher education this year, a figure that is 4,000 greater than that of last year. When these increasing figures in higher education are added to refusals for technical and further education courses, does this not amount to a massive failure of Government policy? What is the Government proposing as an answer to this failure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Teague had listened to the answer that I gave to Senator Townley, he could have saved himself a lot of breath. I not only acknowledged the source of the statistics; I offered to make available to Senator Townley the full report which I had had made available to me from the vice-chancellors and the college principals. Senator Teague would do well to pay attention to answers that are given at Question Time if he wants to try to score points off them. I am not complacent about this situation, but I am satisfied that our Government has made significant progress in increasing the number of higher education places available, in increasing the number of technical and further education places available--
—What about Queensland?

—Oh, what about Queensland! This must be a dorothy dixer. Queensland is the State which has benefited most from the growth in higher education implemented by our Government. Queensland is experiencing a growth in higher education places of 9 per cent, whereas the national average figure is between 5 per cent and 6 per cent. We have been positively discriminating in favour of Queensland in higher education growth--
—Why?

—Why? To rectify the past neglect by a series of State governments in Queensland and by the Fraser Government. When we came to office the disproportion in relation to Queensland was very much worse than it is now. We are assisting Queensland to catch up by positively discriminating in favour of Queensland. It is about time the Queensland Government and Queensland Opposition senators acknowledged the very good deal that Queensland higher education is getting from our Government.

ANSWER.PARA: To return to Senator Teague's question, of course we regret the fact that there is significant unmet demand. Of course we wish that we could make faster progress towards overcoming the backlog in tertiary education funding that we inherited from the Fraser Government. In the period of the Fraser Government there was a real decline-not just a decline in dollar terms but a real decline-in funds made available to higher education institutions. There was a recession, so to speak, in higher education institutions. Funding was cut; staff were put off; and students lost confidence in the higher education system. There were empty place in universities and colleges during the late 1970s and early 1980s because students were so despondent about the state of the economy under the Fraser Government that they did not even bother to seek places.

As a result of our success in creating jobs-over a half a million in three years-in stimulating the economy, and in boosting morale in universities and colleges by enrolment growth and growth in capital funds, there has been a renewed enthusiasm for higher education studies by young people. As a result, many young people who under the Fraser regime would have just gone on to the dole and waited for something to turn up are now trying very hard to get into higher education and are taking their studies very seriously. We have dramatically increased secondary participation rates. We have many more students working to qualify themselves for higher education places. As a result, the competition for higher education places is very fierce, and we expect that it will continue to be so. But, at the same time, there has been significant growth, as I cited to Senator Townley in my previous answer, in the number of places available for higher education throughout Australia, particularly in Queensland but in all States and Territories, and that growth will continue in a sustained and steady way, so that students who perhaps did not achieve the required entry standards this year may have another opportunity to do so. I conclude by saying that our record stands absolutely in contrast with the record of despair and depression that was the case under the Fraser Administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the second part of my question. Does she acknowledge that 33,000 Australian students were turned away from universities and colleges of advanced education this year? That is, 22.7 per cent of all applicants were, in the first instance, turned away from universities and colleges this year.

—I made clear to Senator Teague that I had the report available to me. It refers to 33,000, but not in the way that he has just suggested. The gross number of rejections was not 33,000. Senator Teague does not understand it. In that 33,000, as the report acknowledged, there are many cases of students applying to five or six institutions, many cases of students withdrawing applications, and many cases of students applying but not having a sufficient score to be eligible for the course for which they have applied. So that is a gross figure and it is acknowledged as such, and it is of very little statistical use, as the report makes clear. Even the estimate of 9,000 to 14,000 has been qualified by the vice-chancellors and college principals as needing further modification in terms of multiple applications and so forth. Our data collection processes are as yet not precise enough for us to arrive at a precise figure, but I agree with the report's conclusion that unmet demand is in the vicinity of what it was last year, which is about 10,000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the early part of Question Time today Senator Macklin asked me about an article that appears in the current issue of Vetaffairs. First, I have to inform him that the publication Vetaffairs is a publication from the Department of Veterans' Affairs but has no input by the Minister, except his own personal column in each of its issues. I had not seen the article referred to by Senator Macklin at the time of his question. I have subsequently looked at the article, and I understand his reason for raising the matter. Obviously, Senator Macklin had an earlier opportunity to look at the paper than I did.

ANSWER.PARA: However, the facts are that next Tuesday I shall be presenting the guide to assessment to the Parliament for its ratification or otherwise. Disallowance opportunities will be available. The guide to assessment has been in draft form until very recently and it is very much related to the passage of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The legislation provides that the guide will stand until such time as it is set aside, if at all, and the Parliament may amend it as it so desires. Consequently, because it is an integral part of the operation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Department, naturally, has taken steps to inform its officers as to how that guide will operate. It stands until such time as decisions of the Parliament amend it or otherwise. I am expecting that it will be tabled in the Parliament early next week. However, I remind Senator Macklin that until it is amended in any way it exists as a working document. After a great deal of consultation with the veterans' community, a final document has now been determined, and it is on that basis that it will be presented to the Senate and to the House of Representatives next week.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The amendments contained in this Bill are consequent upon the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1986.

The Citizenship Bill, which was passed by the House on 13 March 1986, proposed amongst other things that children born in Australia to visitors, temporary residents and illegal immigrants would no longer automatically acquire citizenship by birth unless they would otherwise be stateless.

I said during my second reading speech to the Citizenship Bill that an amendment to the Migration Act would be introduced to regularise the immigration status of these children by conferring upon them the same immigration status as their parents. If their parents' immigrant status differs, the children would be given the status of the parent with the longer non-expired period of permitted stay in Australia.
The amendments proposed in this Bill will give effect to that undertaking.

This Bill will insert a new section 6aaa into the Migration Act which will determine the status of children born in Australia who, once the Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1986 commences, will not be Australian citizens because neither of their parents is an Australian citizen or permanent resident. Under the amendment these children will be deemed to be included in the entry permit or to have the same immigration status as their parents or, if the entry permits or status of the parents differs, the children will be deemed to be included in the entry permit of the parent that is authorised to stay here the longest.
The amendment carries with it no financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill I am introducing today is to amend the Copyright Act 1968 to
significantly strengthen the `anti-piracy' provisions of the Act;
increase access to copyright materials for the handicapped, and for libraries, archives and their clients;
extend fair dealing;
make clear that broadcasts via satellite are subject to the Act; and
provide for costs in Copyright Tribunal matters to be taxed on the Federal Court scale.
Background

Most of the amendments are the outcome of a review by the Attorney-General's Department of the provisions of the Act dealing with audiovisual items. This term means sound recordings, including compact discs and audio cassettes, as well as vinyl records; cinematograph films, including videos; and radio and television broadcasts. Audiovisual items contain works, such as lyrics, music and scripts, which are also subject to copyright.

Copyright owners submit that their rights are threatened by new communication technologies, in particular readily available, low cost equipment, much of which can also copy at high speed. New technologies have made audiovisual items an increasingly important part of entertainment and education in the community.

Extensive consultations took place in the course of the review, not only with record, film and broadcasting interests, and representatives of writers and publishers, but also with representatives of users of audiovisual items, including consumers, schools, universities, institutions assisting the handicapped, libraries and archives.

As a result of continuing technological innovations in Australia, there is a need to review and update copyright law to ensure the benefits of this technology are fully realized. In so doing it is necessary to have regard to the laws of other countries, and to the Berne and the Universal Copyright Conventions which govern copyright internationally.

It is important to remember, when considering the laws in other countries, that Australia-unlike, for example, the US or the UK-tends to be a net importer of audiovisual materials. For example, during the review it was estimated that the sale of Australian records (by which I mean recordings by Australians or of Australian material) was, on average, 20% or less of all retail sales. That situation is gradually changing, not the least in part because of the support the Government gives to the Australian arts, through measures such as the Australian content requirement in broadcasting, and tax assistance to film makers.

Clearly we need copyright laws which support Australian artists and producers and which take account of the significant position of overseas materials in the market, consistent with our international convention commitments.
CONTENT OF BILL
Anti-Piracy Provisions

The unauthorised copying of records and videos for commercial purposes, more commonly known as `piracy', appears to be a growing problem worldwide for the legitimate record and film industries. Australia is clearly not one of those countries in which pirate products represent the majority of the material available on the market. Nevertheless, industry representatives inform me that piracy, particularly of video material, is increasing in Australia, and could represent as much as 10%-20% of material available.
When the audiovisual review was commenced in 1981, copyright piracy was not one of the major issues. It only became important towards the end of the review largely because
the spread of home videos resulted in a huge demand for new titles; and
new technology enabled unauthorised commercial copying to meet that demand.
I refer now to the specific anti-piracy amendments in the Bill, which will combat this growing and serious problem.
As many copyright owners have said, the proof of subsistence and ownership of copyright is an expensive and technical procedure. Some defendants unfairly take advantage of this.

Suggestions have been made that subsistence and ownership of copyright should, in all cases, be presumed to exist as claimed by the plaintiff or prosecution in affidavit evidence. This would, in effect, place the burden of proof on the defendant in these issues.

Suggestions have also been made for introduction of a copyright registration system to enable the relevant proof by certified copy of the registration record. There is an argument that such a registration system may, technically, breach our commitments under the Berne Copyright Convention. In any case, it would seem to undermine a basic principle of the Convention that the effective operation of copyright should not require any formality. Another proposal for an amendment to give `full faith and credit' to certificates of registration from countries which do have registration systems, would clearly discriminate against Australian copyright owners.

The solution in clause 18 of the Bill is proof by affidavit of subsistence and ownership of copyright, with discretion remaining with the court as to whether or not the deponent to the affidavit should be called to be cross-examined before the affidavit becomes admissible. This provision should make copyright proceedings easier, without the disadvantages of the alternative proposals.

Copyright owners have also submitted, with some justification, that the current `knowledge' element in copyright offences is too difficult to prove, as it requires a court to be satisfied, beyond reasonable doubt, that the accused knew he was dealing with infringing copies.

It has been suggested that accused persons should be presumed to have known they were dealing in infringing copies, unless they could prove they did not. This would involve a shift of the burden of proof to the accused, which cannot be justified in offences of this nature, particularly given the proposed new high penalties. In circumstances where pirates are making copies which look very much like the real thing, so that even those who are experienced in dealing with the product are not easily able to recognise a pirate copy, it would be unfair to require a lay accused to prove he or she did not know it was a pirate copy.

Nevertheless, the Government wishes to ensure that unscrupulous dealers are not able to rely upon technical arguments to avoid proper liability. The proposed introduction of the words `or ought reasonably to know' is intended to make clear that a person will not escape criminal liability by disregarding circumstances which would lead any reasonable person to conclude that the copies with which he or she is dealing are pirate copies. The new knowledge test will also apply in the new offences created by the amendments: clauses 15 and 18.

The Government has been concerned that the Copyright Act offences do not afford owners protection at each point at which they are vulnerable to commercial piracy. The new offence of possession of an infringing copy for commercial purposes, and the new and restructured offences of causing infringing public performances of copyright material, are intended to meet this deficiency: clause 15.

Finally, on the topic of the anti-piracy amendments, I refer to the proposed significant increases in penalties. The penalty structure set out in clause 16 of the Bill is summarised in the Explanatory Memorandum. Those penalties have the following important features:
a person who commits an offence involving video piracy runs the risk of going to goal for a period of up to 2 years for a first offence;
the same person, on a subsequent offence, could go to gaol for up to 5 years;

the maximum penalty payable per offence involving more than one infringing copy is significantly increased from $1500, in a court other than the Federal Court, to $10,000 in the case of a natural person, and $50,000 in a case of a body corporate;
a body corporate could pay up to $7500 per infringing copy when films are involved and $2500 otherwise;

it will be possible to charge a body corporate in the Federal Court and obtain a maximum penalty, in relation to a single offence comprising the appropriate number of infringing copies, of $250,000; and

the current uncertainty as to when maximum penalties are payable will be removed, and clear provision will be made that the maximum penalty is payable, as is usual, per offence and not in relation to a group of offences.
The amendments do not alter the position in the Act that penalties are paid per infringing copy, not per title copied.

In deciding upon the new penalty structure, the numerous submissions of the video industry, in particular, were carefully considered. The penalties proposed in the Bill were determined having regard to:
the nature of these offences under the Copyright Act;
penalties for like offences in other countries;
penalties payable for other `commercial practice' offences in Australia, such as those under the Trade Practices legislation;
the need to limit penalties which can be imposed by lower summary courts;
the desirability of structuring penalties so as to reflect the status of the defendant as a natural person or a body corporate, and whether there are any prior convictions; and
the fact that a gaol sentence is more likely to be a meaningful deterrent where the primary threat of monetary loss through civil action apparently is not.

Taking into account the range of penalties proposed, the new rates will be up to 33 times higher than those introduced in 1981. Although it is difficult to make any direct comparisons with rates in other countries because of the different penalty structures applying, the new penalties are, on the whole, more than comparable with other countries, including the US.

In addition to the loss suffered by the copyright owner, piracy activities cause harm to the community by undermining the work of creators and innovators. There is also lost tax revenue when copyright material is traded in an underground market. Further, it is often not in consumers' interests to obtain pirate copies-the pirate is unlikely to be willing to comply with normal commercial rules concerning warranties and so on.
I should draw attention to one implication which could be seen to arise from the introduction of these amendments at this stage.

In September 1983, the Copyright Law Review Committee, chaired by His Honour Mr Justice Sheppard of the Federal Court, was established. One of the matters which the Committee was asked to enquire into is the prohibition in the Act against `parallel importing'. This term refers to the importation for commercial purposes of legitimate copies of, for example, books or records, by someone other than the Australian `territory' exclusive licensee.

Under the civil remedy provisions of the Act which are being considered by the Committee, a copyright owner or the exclusive licensee of an owner may take legal action against unlicensed importers, and against people who sell or otherwise deal in parallel imports, as well as against unlicensed copying and dealing in unlicensed copies. The importers and dealers may also be liable under section 132 of the Act for a criminal offence. Parallel importing is treated, under the Act, in the same way as importing a copy made without the copyright owner's permission-the so called pirate copy.

Parallel imports are, however, clearly very different from pirate copies. In the case of parallel imports the copyright owner has received royalty payments from the licensed manufacturer and dealer in the territory from which the copies are imported. In the case of pirate copies, imported or made in Australia, of course the owner has not received such a royalty.

The Committee was asked to look at parallel importing because of this difference, and because it had been submitted that some local licensees do not exercise their exclusive rights, and so deprive the Australian public of overseas material which others would be willing to import.
These and other issues were set out by the Committee in its paper on this topic, released earlier this year.

The Government has not adopted any position in relation to those issues and will only do so after the Committee has completed its report. The Committee recently conducted public hearings in Sydney and Melbourne on this issue and expects to complete its report by late this year.

In order not to cut across the Committee's work, none of the civil remedy provisions which it is examining will be amended by this Bill. However, the Government is concerned to take action quickly to stem the recent growth in illegal commercial copying and trading in pirate copies.

For this reason it was decided to proceed with amendments to the criminal offences, and reforms on proof of subsistence and ownership of copyright, without drawing any new distinction between parallel imports and pirate copies. These amendments do not change the provisions now being considered by the Committee.

The amendments will result in it being easier to prove in a criminal than in a civil case, that the person knew he was dealing in infringing copies. The higher standard of proof required in criminal cases will still make civil actions preferable. Nevertheless, I emphasize that as soon as the Committee's parallel importation report has been received, urgent consideration will be given to it. Subject to any overall reforms which the Government may decide are necessary as a result of the Committee's report, it is intended to take early action to bring the knowledge test in the civil infringement sections, so far as they relate to piracy, into line with the criminal offence amendments in this Bill.

I emphasize that the central issue before the Committee does not relate to the issue of knowledge but, as I have mentioned, only to the question whether the prohibition against importation of otherwise legitimate material should be relaxed for the benefit of Australian consumers.

From what I have said about the Committee's reference it should be clear that, whilst the parallel importing issue remains unresolved, copyright licensees should not take the amendments in this Bill directed at piracy as an endorsement for prosecution action in relation to parallel imports.
INCREASED ACCESS TO COPYRIGHT MATERIALS FOR THE HANDICAPPED

The United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) and the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) have been concerned with the issue of access by handicapped persons to copyright materials since 1981. The new statutory licences proposed in the Bill for operators of radio stations for the print-handicapped and for institutions assisting the intellectually handicapped are consistent with this concern, which the Government shares.
The new statutory licences set out in clauses 6 and 26 of the Bill are based, to the extent appropriate, on existing statutory licences introduced in the Copyright Act in 1980.

These licences already enable educational institutions to photocopy works (section 53B of the Act) and institutions assisting the print-handicapped to make braille, large-print copies, and `talking book' versions of works (section 53D of the Act).

In order to take advantage of the statutory licences, the beneficiaries need to make certain records of copies taken and to comply with other regulatory requirements in the legislation. Some educational representatives have complained that the record-keeping requirements they must meet under the existing section 53B statutory licence are onerous, particularly given that copyright owners have not, to date, in some cases, inspected the records kept. It would seem that the requirements to inspect may be a costly burden for copyright owners.

These complaints are a matter of concern, although it should be noted that the existing provisions of the Act allow owners and users to agree on less onerous terms and conditions, and provide for the sending of records to a central authority, so avoiding the burden of retaining records for the prescribed period of 4 years.
Representatives of the handicapped institutions have indicated that, in return for the access they will acquire, they do not mind keeping records.

In addition, given the very limited market for the materials which would be broadcast or copied under the new licences for the handicapped, indications are that the cost to the institutions of their new licences is likely to be minimal. In these circumstances it seems appropriate to continue the existing basic structure for the new statutory licences.

Many of the onerous aspects of statutory licensing could be overcome if the beneficiaries did not have the possibility of dealing with every single copyright owner whose material is subject to the statutory licence. In practice, at the moment, a claim for equitable remuneration from Copyright Agency Limited (CAL)- which was established as a collecting society by some copyright owners for the purpose of the sections 53B and 53D statutory licences-is very likely to be the only claim made. Nevertheless, the institution cannot assume this. CAL has no statutory authority to represent all copyright owners who have the right to seek remuneration under the licence.

As CAL has now commenced inspections and claims for remuneration it would not be appropriate to alter the statutory licensing structure at this stage. In the event of a continuing failure by the relevant parties to agree on less onerous arrangements, it may be necessary to consider providing statutory recognition for only one collecting society to make claims based on copying and to which all records of copying would be sent.
INCREASED ACCESS FOR LIBRARIES, ARCHIVES AND THEIR CLIENTS, AND FOR THE PURPOSES OF CRITICISM AND REVIEW AND FOR REPORTING NEWS

The Act currently provides certain limitations on copyright control of works, for the benefit of libraries, archives and their users, and for the purposes of criticism or review and for reporting news. The Bill will extend these limitations to include audiovisual items: clauses 10, 11 and 12.

It is intended to allow libraries and archives to copy unpublished records and films for the purposes of research or study or with a view to publication, and to copy records and films for preservation, provided certain conditions are met. The new provisions are not, of course, intended to limit the copying rights which a library or archives may negotiate with particular copyright owners. The provisions are intended only to set the minimum which libraries and archives may do, without seeking the permission of copyright owners or paying any fees.

The fair dealing provisions proposed in the Bill for the limited purposes of criticism or review and of reporting news, are in the Government's view appropriate limitations on copyright control. As is the case with the existing provisions in relation to literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works in sections 41 and 42, no attempt is made in the proposed amendments to define what would constitute a `fair dealing' in an audiovisual item. The purpose of the provisions is to ensure that people who, in the community's interests, disseminate news and provide legitimate criticism and review for the benefit of consumers and audiences, may use copyright material without risking infringement action.
Satellite Broadcasting
Clause 5 of the Bill is intended to ensure that broadcasts via satellite are broadcasts under the Copyright Act.

Under section 91 of the Act, copyright subsists only in broadcasts made from a place in Australia. A point-to-point transmission, under the present provisions, whether originating from a terrestrial transmitter and received by a satellite (an `uplink') or made from satellite to satellite, is arguably not a `broadcast'. Whilst the `downlink' from a `direct broadcasting satellite' is a broadcast, it is not apparently from a place in Australia within the meaning of the Act. The result is that a broadcast which would otherwise be subject to the Copyright Act, but which goes via satellite, does not enjoy copyright protection.

In addition, owners of copyright in a work or audiovisual material may not be able to enforce their exclusive right to broadcast against a person who makes an unauthorised broadcast via satellite because presently only acts done or authorised to be done in Australia may constitute infringements. Consistent with international opinion in relation to this issue, which was set out most recently in the report of the WIPO/UNESCO Group of Experts on the Copyright Aspects of Direct Broadcasting by Satellite, broadcasting via satellite ought to be dealt with under the Copyright Act in the same way as other broadcasts.
Costs in the Copyright Tribunal

Proceedings in the Copyright Tribunal have significant commercial impact on the parties, and are often lengthy and involve considerable cost. At present, the Act provides, in most cases, that the Tribunal may make an order for costs.
The Bill will amend the Act by making it clear that, in taxing those costs, a taxing officer shall have regard to the Federal Court Rules (including its scale of costs).
Other Matters
The impetus for the review by the Attorney-General's Department was home taping, but during the course of the review it became clear that commercial piracy was also a problem.

Home taping remains an important issue. The remedy most favoured by copyright owners-namely a levy on blank recording media in return for a right to copy audiovisual material-would seem appropriate from a copyright policy point of view, because it would be a payment for use of copyright owners' exclusive right to copy. Whether a levy would be the most appropriate solution to the problem in the Australian context remains to be seen.

Several countries do have such a levy: West Germany, France, Austria, Portugal, Hungary, Finland, Norway, Iceland and Sweden. In some of those countries the levy is collected as a tax, with only part of the proceeds going directly to the copyright owners, the remainder going either into general revenue, or to the general welfare of copyright artists. In its April 1986 White Paper, the United Kingdom Government announced its intention to introduce a levy on blank audio tape in return for unrestricted home taping. It was also stated in the White Paper that a levy on blank video tape was not justified at this stage. Both the House of Representatives and the Senate in the United States are considering Bills which propose a levy on blank audio tape.

The Attorney-General's consideration of this issue to date has been on the basis that a blank tape levy would be a tax. If this proves to be the case, there are problems for Government taxation policy including the costs and structure of such a scheme.

One other matter deserves close consideration in this context. It may be that the losses suffered by copyright owners through home taping could in some way be offset by a rental right. Both the U.S.A. and Japan have such a right for records and cassettes. A rental right could become increasingly important with the advent of compact discs, which may be a highly viable rental proposition because of their durability and high quality sound.
The Attorney-General's Department is continuing to examine all these issues, in the light of international developments.

Another reason for the commencement of the Department's review was the call by educational institutions for increased access to audiovisual items, in particular to non-commercially available material broadcast on television. Last year the Department developed a proposal for a statutory licensing system, in return for equitable remuneration, which would have provided that access, on terms arguably more favourable than those of the existing photocopying licence. The proposal was supported by tertiary institutions and copyright owners, but opposed by schools' representatives largely on the basis that there would be an increase in costs which, they considered, was not justified. In these circumstances, the Government decided not to proceed at this stage with any reforms in the area of educational use until further consultations and work can be undertaken.

Educational institutions need to negotiate copying rights privately-either on a one-off basis, or by blanket licensing arrangements. Given that copyright owners are often not in a position to voluntarily grant such rights, even when they want to do so, it would be desirable for the difficulties with a statutory scheme to be overcome.

It seems from recent discussions with schools representatives that common ground is being found. I am pleased to say that schools have acknowledged that the use of that material does require payment. This follows on the important concession from most copyright owners that, because of the social importance of education, they are prepared for their right to withhold their material to be removed and not to have the benefits of payment under a statutory scheme without joining an approved collecting society.

In the course of the review, submissions were made to the effect that the term `performance in public' ought to be defined in the Act to take account of the fact that new technologies enable performances before small groups of the public. These `performances', which are usually film or video showings in motels, are to the commercial advantage of the person holding the performance. The decision of the Supreme Court of New South Wales in the Rank case in 1983 clarifies the issue.

As the dissemination and use of copyright material becomes easier because of innovations in communications technology, both owners and users may have to accept a greater degree of orderly collective administration, perhaps via statutory schemes, subject to Copyright Tribunal review. Such trends appear to be evident overseas and increasingly appear relevant also in Australia.
Financial and Regulatory Impact Statement

The Copyright Amendment Bill will have no direct impact on Commonwealth revenue of expenditure. Any indirect impact on expenditure which may occur will be minimal, and will depend on applications being made to the Attorney-General or to the Copyright Tribunal to exercise powers under sections 10a and 149a respectively, which this Bill will slightly extend.

A favourable indirect impact on Commonwealth tax revenue may be expected, as the strengthened anti-piracy provisions reduce untaxed illegal dealings in copyright materials, and encourage sales in legitimate product on which sales tax is payable.
The position of the copyright industry can, therefore, be expected to improve as a result of the anti-piracy provisions, though the extent of this is difficult to quantify.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Childs, I table further additional information received by Estimates Committee C and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 247th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, entitled `Expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance-Appropriation Act 1984-85'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Report 247 examines the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance in 1984-85. Honourable senators will be aware that each year the Committee examines expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance to ascertain whether or not expenditure from the Advance has been confined to urgent and unforseeable requirements for which provision could not have been made in the original or Additional Estimates. The Committee also seeks to ascertain whether or not the departments concerned have maintained efficient administration in the expenditure of funds under the items examined. Under current arrangements, the Committee receives copies of all approved applications for funds from the Advance where they would remain a final charge to the Advance at the close of the financial year. All these applications for funds must be accompanied by adequate supporting detail. The Committee received statements relating to 103 items of expenditure remaining a final charge to the Advance in 1984-85. Supplementary material was obtained concerning 22 items.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite clear instruction some departments did not offer sufficient explanation with their applications. The Committee would have expected the Department of Finance to have insisted upon sufficient documentary material for it to be satisfied that an urgent and unforeseeable requirement for funds from the Advance was warranted, prior to approval being finalised. While the Committee is satisfied that, in all cases of expenditure remaining a final charge to the Advance in 1984-85, the requirements were urgent, it is not convinced that all were unforeseeable. In several cases, the requirement for additional funds should have been foreseen before the cut-off date for changes to Additional Estimates on 25 March.

In particular the Committee is not satisfied that the criteria for the use of the Advance to reimburse a revenue shortfall in the Williamstown Dockyard trust account were satisfied. The fact that the central office of the Department of Defence was unaware of the likelihood of a very large shortfall until May 1985, although the dockyard had been implementing measures aimed at eliminating the shortfall since late in 1984, indicated a disturbing lack of liaison between the dockyard, the Office of Defence Production and the central office of the Department. The Committee will be inquiring further into the operation of the Williamstown Dockyard trust account when it reviews the Auditor-General's report of March 1986. The Committee will particularly be looking to examine the proposed 1985-86 financial statements of the dockyard, which the Department has advised will conform to the `Guidelines for the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings'. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986TAXATION (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.
