TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was commenting on the taxation legislation before the Senate which introduces self-assessment as a new principle in our taxation system. While the Australian Democrats generally are in favour of this, as it is a more efficient system, we are nevertheless concerned that it does place a very heavy responsibility on ordinary taxpayers, in particular ordinary taxpayers who may not have available tax consultants to assist them in the filling in of their returns. Because of that we are of the opinion that at least some of the responsibility for informing the public should rest with the Commissioner of Taxation and his Department. Precisely how that should be achieved is a question about which we have a fairly open mind, but we do believe that the Government has been remiss in not addressing this very important problem of informing the ordinary taxpayer and that an amendment, which I have already foreshadowed, should be passed in the Committee stage to put some responsibility on the Commissioner at least to reply in principle, and in principle only, to taxpayers' queries. We do not believe this would be an onerous responsibility on the Australian Taxation Office. Of course, we are anxious not to alter the law in a way which might lead to tax avoidance or evasion or which would defer the completion of taxation returns. All these matters have been raised by the Commissioner, and we have had a look at them. We believe that the amendment we will move in the Committee stage will be reasonable, having regard to all the matters that have been discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that because of time constraints the Senate is under a lot of pressure at the moment and I do not wish to extend my remarks unnecessarily. We do support this legislation; we do believe that it is important to clamp down on negative gearing for developers. We believe the Government, having done that, has a very urgent responsibility to clamp down on the negative gearing of corporate raiders so that productive investment can flow into the business sector, the manufacturing sector, rather than be sloshed around the stock markets. We believe self-assessment is a better way to go and for that reason, in principle, we support that part of the legislation as well. In the Committee stage I will be talking to our foreshadowed amendment, which states:
. . . where a taxpayer furnishing a return raises, in writing signed by him or her . . .

That implies, of course, that it does not apply to companies, partnerships or co-operatives. Presumably they can get advice, but the individual taxpayer may not be in a position to get advice. The amendment continues:
. . . and furnished with that return, a question of fact or law affecting the taxpayer's liability to tax, the Commissioner shall give attention to that question.
It does not stipulate a time limit; it just says that the Commissioner shall give attention to the question. I look forward to elaborating on that amendment in the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be reasonably brief. As Senator Messner indicated, I will be discussing clause 10 in my role as representing the shadow Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism in this chamber. First of all, I pick up one remark that Senator Maguire made when he used figures to compare Queensland with South Australia. I guess in this day and age if an honourable senator thinks that his State has arrived as a State, the thing is to prove it by using some figures, albeit selectively on many occasions, to prove that that State is better than Queensland. Mr Acting Deputy President, I have you at a disadvantage. Because you are sitting in the Chair you are struck dumb as far as the debate is concerned. Even you have given Queenslanders a backhanded compliment by indicating on many occasions that if some other State wants to prove it is better, it has to beat the State that you and I belong to.

SPEECH.PARA: In this instance Senator Maguire used figures to say that South Australia spent more money than Queensland on public housing. That is very easy to say and, indeed, he was probably right on the money that is spent. But if one takes those figures further, there have been less applications for public housing in Queensland than in South Australia. Indeed, from 31 December 1982 to 31 December 1985 the number of applications for public rental housing has dropped by 564 in Queensland. In Queensland it has actually dropped but in South Australia, the State that Senator Maguire represents and from which base he seeks to criticise Queensland all the time, public rental housing applications have increased by 12,106. I suggest that Senator Crowley wait a minute longer before she leaves the chamber. Obviously there are different bases from which they operate. We are operating on a time basis and the bases on which South Australia has operated have not changed over that period. So we see this selective quotation of figures from South Australia, which has had an increase-I say it again-of applications for public rental housing of 12,106. Really, are there any more people in South Australia than that? Queensland has had a decrease of 564. Quite obviously more money would be spent on public rental housing in South Australia because more people are in the market for it there than in Queensland.
Having said that, and feeling a lot better for having said it, I will go on to the brief section I said I would talk about, which is clause 10, which states:
Section 78 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after sub-paragraph (1) (a) (1xxxiii) the following sub-paragraph:
``; (1xxxiv) the Australian Sports Aid Foundation,''.

This means that the Australian Sports Aid Foundation is added to the list of charities which are recognised under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for deduction purposes. The Sports Aid Foundation will be able to act as a mechanism for channelling donations to the various sports bodies. The Opposition does not oppose this. Indeed, it welcomes this addition to that list of accepted charities. But I must say that there seems to be an abundance of bodies being introduced into the sports scene in Australia. As I understand it, there will be legislation later on concerning the Australian Institute of Sport. We already have the Australian Sports Commission and now we have the Australian Sports Aid Foundation. In reality one-certainly two at the most-could do the job that is necessary. Be that as it may, the Government, I suppose on the patronage system on which it operates, by setting up these commissions, institutes and foundations is able to pat some of its good friends on the shoulder and say: `We would like you to come along and do this job for us'. Having said that, the people who have been appointed to the Board of the Australian Sports Aid Foundation are eminently suitable for that job. I think the job of the Sports Commission and the Sports Aid Foundation could all be handled by the one group of people; however, those people are eminently suitable, they are quite notable Australians and I am quite sure that in that capacity they will make a great contribution to sport within Australia.

The Sports Aid Foundation, I can say from my personal knowledge, is set up a bit like the Elizabethan Theatre Trust Fund. In Queensland, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you would know, we have the Warana festival. If one wants to channel donations to the Warana festival and receive tax deductibility, one channels it through the Elizabethan Theatre Fund and indicates it is to go to the Warana festival. As I understand it, that is how the Sports Aid Foundation will operate. Mr Peter White, my colleague in the other place, asked for four guarantees from the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) in respect of the Sports Aid Foundation. The first guarantee was that donations to the Foundation would go to those sporting clubs or organisations that were nominated by the donor, providing they were bona fide organisations. The second guarantee was that there would be no deductions from the Foundation for handling charges as the money passed through the Foundation. The third guarantee was that there would be no interference in the existing system of direct sponsorship-in other words, there would be no interference where large firms use section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to claim tax deductibility for advertising, and in that way firms would still be able to help our various sports. The fourth guarantee was that money donated to the Foundation which has no specified recipient at the time it is given would be used to benefit sports which at present receive little or no help.

Even though there is nothing in the legislation to indicate any of those things, I think it is worthy to have in Hansard, in addition to clause 10, which amends section 78, the Minister's reply to those four guarantees. I will briefly read that response into Hansard. I will not go through the whole lot. At page 3297 of the Hansard of the House of Representatives of 7 May 1986, in response to the first guarantee, the Hon. J. J. Brown said:

One of the other constraints that applies is the necessity for the Australian Sports Commission to ensure that any money channelled through the Foundation to any particular body, specified or otherwise, is audited in exactly the same way as are grants given by the Sports Commission through the sports development fund. This ensures that the money is spent for the purposes for which it is given.
The second guarantee was that there be no deduction for handling charges. At page 3298 of Hansard the Hon. J. J. Brown was once again addressing Mr Peter White. He said:
The honourable member for McPherson may rest assured of that. The specified regulations say that there will be no deduction at all for handling charges.
The third guarantee was that there be no interference in the system of direct sponsorship. The Minister said:

I simply point out that there has been a very different method by which firms, corporations and individuals sponsor sporting bodies, often using section 51 of the tax Act and claiming tax relief under advertisements. No money will attract tax deductibility as a gift to sport unless it is directed through the Sports Aid Foundation, except in the existing situation where corporations or individuals claim tax relief under section 51.
The fourth guarantee was that the money would not necessarily go to sports which were well off. The Hon. J. J. Brown said in respect of that guarantee:

The fourth guarantee that the honourable member seeks is that money donated to the Foundation for an unspecified purpose would not be used to prop up what are already very rich sports. The honourable member has not only my personal assurance on that but also the assurance of the Chairman of the Sports Aid Foundation, Mr Harris, to whom I think the honourable member issued this request in the first place.

Having said all that, the Opposition welcomes the creation of Australian Sports Aid Foundation. We do take issue with the fact that there are now three bodies when in actual fact one, or at the most two, could do this job. We accept that the people who have been appointed to it are honourable and well known citizens of this nation and will do a good job. We support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill is to make a number of changes in the taxation regime, the most significant of which is the change to arrangements on negative gearing which, according to the Minister's second reading speech, will eventually yield $195m a year in additional revenue. I pause to note that that money will be gained to revenue without the necessity to issue anybody with an Australia Card, or pursue all the ghastly paraphernalia which the Government seems intent on doing in that regard. I see my friend Second Commissioner McDermott in the gallery smiling wryly at the mention of the Australia Card. I think we can be assured that debates about the Australian Taxation Office and the Australia Card will come to occupy a certain amount of time in this chamber in due course, but I regret to say that today is not the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I do, however, propose to take up a number of matters to which Senator Collard has referred in relation to the Australian Sports Aid Foundation, and in particular to be a little less generous than he was about what is being done to sport in this regard. I congratulate the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) on the appointments to the Sports Aid Foundation. The seven gentlemen whom he has appointed to the Board of the Foundation bring to 100 exactly the number of patronage appointments that the Minister has made under his portfolio since he became Minister. They represent the last batch to bring the number to 100, and I shall have something to say about that in due course.

Clause 10 of the Bill seeks to give effect to the proposal which was originally announced on 10 December 1985 to admit the Australian Sports Aid Foundation to those provisions of the income tax law which authorised deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more made to certain specified organisations. Gifts made to the Foundation on or after its date of incorporation-that is 18 February 1986-will qualify for deduction. Therefore, the Australian Sports Aid Foundation becomes No. 84 on the list of organisations approved for that deductibility status under section 78 of the Income Tax Act and now fits in neatly behind the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists.

It is also indicative, as I shall recall in a moment, of the selective nature of the way in which organisations are admitted to tax deductible status and the reason that that occurs. I want to deal more generally with the purpose of the legislation in seeking to raise and channel funds for sporting activities through the Sports Aid Foundation. It has by and large been assumed in the wider community that this Government has somehow developed a reputation for outstanding generosity towards the funding of a sport. That does not coincide with the facts. For instance, on 27 March this year I received a letter from Mr Leslie J. Martyn, President of the Confederation of Australian Sport, in which, among other things, he said:

Given the optimism generated by the Hawke Labor Government when it came into power and the increase in sports development funding it initally provided, national sporting associations approached their developmental tasks with considerable enthusiasm. The reductions in the 1985-86 grants have tended to dampen this enthusiasm.

If one looks at the hype that has gone on, for instance, over fund-raising activities for the Commonwealth Games participation-the Games are to take place in Edinburgh in July-one sees that the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Games Association, Mr Arthur Tunstall, has been quoted as saying that the Association is still $700,000 short in its fund raising. The Australian on 23 May this year reported that the money crisis may force a cut in the teams for the games.

Despite all the hype and denials by the Minister for Sport, Mr John Brown, it is quite apparent that in this area at least that hype has not been matched by the appropriate provision of revenue. The Government has, both subtly and more directly, put the squeeze on organisations over such matters as the broadcasting of sporting activities. Part of the problem of the shortfall in Commonwealth Games fund-raising activities has been that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has rights to broadcast the Games. I do not object to that in the least, but it means that the capacity of the sponsors to raise additional money for Australian sporting activities, because of the sponsorship opportunities that would have been available had the telecaster of the games been a commercial station, has meant that by putting the squeeze on sporting organisations to favour the national broadcaster the downside of that has been that sporting organisations have less capacity to generate funds to support the sporting activity because of the prohibition on any form of corporate sponsorship of the ABC. That itself is a live issue in terms of the future of the ABC, one which this Parliament has not had the opportunity to debate at any great length.

One of the things one is concerned about is the extent to which under the power of ministerial persuasion or direction we shall see the Minister playing favourites in this regard. I take, for example, the particularly difficult position of cycling in Australia. Australian cyclists in recent years at international competitive level have made their mark. At the last Olympics the Australian team's four did extraordinarily well and came away with a gold medal. We were all aware of the prowess of cyclists like Phil Andersen. It was therefore discouraging to see that on 12 March this year the Daily Telegraph in a statement under the heading `Minister back- pedalling says coach' reported:
National cycling coach Charlie Walsh has hit out at Federal Sports Minister John Brown's failure to include cycling in the Australian Institute of Sport.

It goes on to indicate the promises made by Mr Brown in that regard which have since been dishonoured. The Sports Aid Foundation per se is a very admirable concept. It was initially announced and developed by Mr Ellicott when he was the Minister for Home Affairs in the Fraser Administration. Had Mr Ellicott and had a Liberal-National Party Government been in the process of establishing the Foundation, it would have been established on very different lines from those currently put forward by the Government. Nevertheless, we have to deal with the legislation as it is and with the Foundation as it has been set up.

I do not in the least criticise what the Government has said or has acted to do in terms of sporting relationships with South Africa. In fact, I support what the Minister has said on this issue, and there has been a bipartisan degree of support. But one wants to be aware of the extent to which this particular Minister has been prepared to intervene in a financial sense in this regard. For instance, the Minister issued a Press release on 25 September 1985 headed `Government grant withdrawn from Australian squash player'. Mr Ross Thorne, who was ranked in the top 10 squash players in the world, had been allocated support under the Government's national athlete award scheme. The grant was withdrawn because Mr Thorne had competed in the South African Open competition. In the current dispute in regard to the invitation issues to the Wallabies for a potential tour of South Africa, one saw a report in the Weekend Australian of 17-18 May 1986 as follows:
Mr Brown said the Government would `withdraw all support for rugby union' if the tour went ahead.

That is not just support for individual players or for a team potentially going to South Africa, but involves the withdrawal of all support for a particular code of football on the basis that the action is contrary to government policy. One wonders the extent to which the Sports Aid Foundation will have the degree of independence which it ought to have to make decisions sufficiently at arm's length for a ministerial direction in this regard.

Despite the assurances given by the Minister to my colleague Mr White in the other place, which have been repeated today by Senator Collard, I am not persuaded that the effect of making donations to the Foundation tax deductible will not lead to the drying up of independent corporate sponsorship of sport in Australia. One thing that will happen is that direct relationships between the corporate sponsor and the receiving sporting organisation will be put in peril because there will not be the same degree of tax attractiveness, financial attractiveness, as giving the money through the Sports Aid Foundation. Although the assurance is given that the money will be directed to a particular sport, there are also contradictory assurances; the assurance, for instance, that the money would not be passed on to an already wealthy and favoured sporting code organisation.

How are we going to balance the two? How will we be able to direct the money to a particular organisation or a particular code of sport and, on the other hand, not allow the continued subsidisation of sports which are already wealthy if, in fact, the money is directed towards a sporting code or organisation regarded as falling within that category? I believe that the direct breakdown in relationships is something which the sporting organisations take very much at their peril. I regret to say that I think that in the long run many of the codes and sporting organisations throughout Australia will suffer a reduction in the level of direct corporate sponsorship.

The other point to be made as far as that is concerned is that the Minister, of course, has a directive power over the Foundation. I would be very suspicious of attempts to build up sports because they happen to be seen by the Minister as relevant to a particular area of the State. We know the amount of expenditure which has taken place out of total funds purely within the Minister's own electorate in Sydney. I would be very suspicious of large sums of money being under ministerial sway as far as the Foundation is concerned. It seems to me that, if the Minister were really serious about doing something significant in the taxation area for Australian sport, the most important thing that he could do would be to persuade his colleagues to provide some form of tax averaging for professional sportsmen. I would have thought that if there was anything of real financial benefit which the Minister ought to be concentrating on, the idea of tax averaging for professional sportsmen is one that he should be looking at.

The final two points I want to make relate to the questions I raised about patronage. The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism-I am glad a friend and colleague, Senator Michael Baume, is here as the watch dog of the Coalition Waste Watch Committee-has it within his power to make appointments to the Australian Institute of Sport, the National Committee on Sport and Recreation for the Disabled, the Australian Tourist Commission, the Tourist Advisory Council, the Australian Sports Commission, the National Australia Day Council, the Working Group on Women in Sport, and now the Board of the Sports Aid Foundation. Of those positions of patronage there are 15 on the Australia Day Council, 31 in the tourist area and 47 in sport. When we add the seven that are now appointed, it brings the Minister up to a nice round 100. The Minister is to be congratulated on now having had the capacity to make his 100th appointment of patronage. At some later stage when we come to the legislation on the Australian Institute of Sport one hopes to be able to develop a little more fully the extent to which political favouritism-the ducks and drakes syndrome-has taken place.

TALK.START.PARA: —That task is a heavy load to carry.

—Indeed. For instance, as I consider the seven persons appointed to the Board of the Australian Institute of Sport, worthy gentlemen as they all are, I am intrigued as to the particular contribution that Sir Peter Abeles is going to make to the whole thing, the particular contribution that Mr Nicholas Whitlam is going to make to the whole thing, and the particular contribution that Mr Kerry Packer is going to make to the whole thing. I was talking the other day about regional television and who is whose mate, big or little, particularly in the media. I am intrigued at the extent to which the relationship between the Government and the owners of, in particular, major broadcasting and publishing institutions in this country is reinforced, essentially at the public's cost, by these patronage appointments to which, when we come to the Australian Institute of Sport, we will have a little more time to devote our attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I make is this: Without in any sense seeking to derogate from the value of making contributions to the Sports Aid Foundation tax deductible, it is extraordinary when one considers the representations that I expect every member of the Parliament receives from people seeking tax deductibility for their organisation, and the extent to which they are knocked back regularly by the Government for inclusion as a prescribed body under section 78 of the principal Act. For instance, without naming names or without naming specific organisations, I know that in the course of the last year or so I sought to make representations to the Government on behalf of a number of organisations which are, for instance, involved in raising and spending money in an attempt to assist victims of the disease acquired immune deficiency syndrome-organisations which have sought to raise money for medical purposes, for research purposes, for rehabilitation purposes, for care purposes and for counselling purposes, which have been regularly and systematically knocked back in terms of their capacity to have a tax deductible status.

I expect that every member of this chamber has a list of people and organisations on whose behalf he or she has made representation. Many of those are extremely worthy and extremely significant community-based groups, but they are knocked back. Because there happens to be real politics and there happens to be real votes in doing something or in being seen to be doing something about sport it gets preferential treatment. As I said, I do not object to sport having the Sports Aid Foundation. We, in government, promised that we would establish such an organisation. But it is not without significance that the politics of sport has become one of the most intriguing areas of politics developed to a fine art by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, whose concern to use sport and to use sports men and women in Australia as promoters, supporters and, indeed, campaigners for the Australian Labor Party leaves a very great deal to be desired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise in this debate the matter of negative gearing as it relates to the property industry, the home building industry. I state at the beginning that the Opposition, naturally, is opposing these negative gearing provisions which, in effect, mean that any interest burden that is in excess of the revenue that emerges from the ownership and leasing of a home, of a dwelling, should not be deductible for tax to the extent that it exceeds the revenue. The simple consequence of that is, of course, that it is an enormous disincentive for people to invest in rental properties. This may not interest or excite the Government. In fact, it has not in the debate so far in the House of Representatives and here. The Government speakers have expressed no concern whatsoever for the consequences that will inevitably flow from this disastrous change in the tax law, disastrous insofar as it is diminishing already the flow of accommodation available, particularly to people in lower income groups.

SPEECH.PARA: This may not have been so bad-it would have been bad anyway-had it not been in the context of an overwhelming governmental assault on the home building industry. We are all aware of the fact that the Government decided, as a matter of economic policy, not to cut its own spending, not to follow the sort of economic policy which had been advised for a long time by the Opposition and most expert commentators and not to show restraint or responsibility. Instead, the Government determined that it would regulate the economy almost solely by means of interest rate policy. It is that reason and basically that reason alone that determined Government policy. We have seen record real interest rates and the disastrous impact which that has had on investment overall let alone on housing and, of course, there has been the general inflationary consequence of this kind of economic policy.

However, let us concentrate on the impact of this deliberate governmental policy which the Government had to impose in order to try to preserve some value in the Australian dollar and to establish some kind of interest rate differential between interest rates existing overseas and interest rates locally so that overseas people would still invest in the Australian dollar even though it was clearly weak. The maintenance of this deliberate and determined high interest rate policy by the Government has resulted in a disastrous impact on home building. We have seen the figures over recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Investment is going down.

—As my friend Senator Watson says, investment has been continually going down. However, that is only part of the story. The Government, through this high interest rate regimen, has been knocking the home building industry which, when it came to office, it set out to improve significantly. It boasted of its record of success. There was something like a 15 to 16 per cent average interest rate cost if one wanted to buy a home. Of course interests rates have now been increased as a result of the Government's belated recognition that market forces required it to increase the limit on savings bank housing loans.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of this incredible squeeze on the housing industry, as a result of interest rate problems, we have now had two further deliberate, determined policy attacks on home building and the opportunity for people to own their own home in Australia. They have been deliberate acts of Government policy. The first was the announcement on 17 July last year-almost a year ago-of negative gearing proposals with which we are dealing in this legislation and the second was the capital gains tax which was announced on 19 September last year and which we will be dealing with later.

Let us forget that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had promised not to introduce a capital gains tax. Generally with this Government one would expect that the more vehement the protest that something will not happen the more likely it is that it will eventuate. However, let us forget that. We have to look very seriously indeed at the consequence of the negative gearing proposal not simply on the industry as a whole, not simply on home seekers as a whole but particularly on the poorest families who rely on the housing industry to provide them with accommodation either through the purchase of a home, hopefully at the lower end of the range, or through rental accommodation.

The consequence of the negative gearing legislation is that it basically hits those people who are least able to get accommodation by purchasing a home. They do not have the capital or the capacity to borrow and therefore they are obliged to rent. Where will the rental properties come from if it is no longer financially rewarding for people to invest in property or to build new rental accommodation if the negative gearing proposals which the Government has introduced apply? In other words the Government, because of its own incompetence in cutting government spending which is absolutely essential, has decided to solve the problem in its usual way. It is belting the victims, it is belting the Australian people because it does not have the intestinal fortitude to cut its own spending.

I will give an example. In the rental housing area the direct and inevitable consequence of this mean and offensive tax will not be to disadvantage the investors. They will find other ways to get a return. They can buy Commonwealth bonds and get a far higher rate of return because of the excessive interest rate policies that this Government has introduced. They can have other sources of investment. The people who have benefited from the capacity to deduct interest costs from income other than rental income are not the investors so much as those people who have been able to rent at less than the economic cost for this very reason. In other words, the owner of the property would not depend simply on rents for a return; he would also hope for capital appreciation which, in many instances, may never be realised because he may hold on to it until his death. But the fact is that his asset is appreciating; so he would not seek deliberately to make a capital gain. If he had other income he could naturally increase the benefit to him by claiming a tax deduction against his other income.

These matters together-the capital gains tax and the ability to negatively gear-meant that the rent that would provide an economic return to an owner was far below the sort of return that that owner would seek if he had bought Commonwealth bonds or had made any other investment. In Sydney the average rental return has been something like 5 to 6 per cent. That is outstanding, as my friend Senator Watson says. This recognises that the people doing well, in general, were the poorer people who could not afford to buy their own home and who were obliged to rent. For a return of something like 6 per cent to the owner renters could have accommodation; but under this tax law, allied with the capital gains tax law, the poorer end of the housing market would simply be forced to do two things. They would be forced either to pay an economic return-in other words, pay whatever the owner had to charge to get a reasonable return on his income which would be something like 14 per cent and that would mean rents would go up enormously-or to seek public housing simply because owners would not build accommodation, whether it be flats or houses, for rental purposes if they could not get an adequate return. This legislation ensures that they will not get an adequate return. So in this legislation we are not only pushing up the rents of those people who basically are at the lower end of the income scale but also depriving them of the opportunity to get even a place to rent because we are destroying the market.

Today we heard, I think, Senator Maguire, or some other leading intellect on the Government side, say that we were talking scare talk, that this was all scaremongering and that it was not really happening. Well, I have news for Senator Maguire or whoever it was, because today the national income figures for the March quarter came out; that is, the quarterly estimates of national income and expenditure from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Of course, they are disastrous and they show that for the second consecutive quarter we have had negative growth. National income has in fact fallen by 0.3 per cent for the March quarter and, after revisions, by the same amount for the December quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Watson is right to say: `Oh'. This is one of the most serious developments among the many serious developments we have struck in the last month. This is one of the most serious developments affecting every Australian to have happened under this Government. We have warned and forecast that this would be the consequence of the Government's irresponsible attitudes, ratbag economics and extraordinary reliance on high interest rates as its only instrument of economic policy. Now it is all happening. Investment is collapsing. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, is running around the place saying: `You have to cut government spending because otherwise investment will collapse even further'. We have record balance of payments deficits and, quite frankly, if the present wage case is not resolved in a way that limits any rise in labour costs to a minimum and unless suggestions of productivity gains are scotched, these figures demonstrate that the economy is well into a recession which started six months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look specifically at the figures as they relate to housing. We have been told that what we have been saying and the warnings that we have been giving are all bunkum and nonsense. But let us look at the percentage changes for dwellings in real money terms, that is, after taking into account inflation and seasonal adjustment, over the last few quarters. The figures show that in the December quarter there was a 2.6 per cent fall, after adjusting for inflation, in fixed capital expenditure on dwellings. I am not quite certain why it is called fixed capital expenditure because in effect it is a consumption expenditure, but it is classified as capital. Expenditure on dwellings by the private sector was down 2.6 per cent and in the March quarter down another 2.4 per cent. So, so far in the last 12 months there has been an overall decline of something like 1.4 per cent. No doubt this will continue further in the next quarter.

So the forecast in the Budget figures of a slight decline in dwelling expenditure is certain to be massively exceeded. Of course, that is disastrous enough. But then we find, when we look at the inflation factor in the dwelling industry, that not only is there the increased interest rate cost, the increased rental cost, the increased costs that will emerge from negative gearing and from the capital gains tax but also already an increase in the actual inflation rate as it relates to dwellings. These statistics reveal that over the last 12 months there has been something like a 9.2 per cent inflation rate in respect of dwellings. That is another element to discourage investors from putting their money into this area. The cost of doing so is increasing and the returns naturally will also have to increase simply to keep pace with inflation.

Apart from dwellings, we see in the statistics that came out yesterday for new fixed capital expenditure for selected industries by type of asset, seasonally adjusted and in constant dollar terms, that spending on new buildings and structures in the March quarter was stagnant at $755m in 1979-80 prices. In fact, in current dollar terms it was about $1.39 billion. That stagnation is a matter of major concern because it is in the investment area. So not only do we have a disaster in dwellings; we now have stagnation in new buildings and structures in terms of industry investment in commercial operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry predicted it.

—As Senator Watson said, the industry predicted it. But it is interesting because in fact the only bright point in the national income figures in the whole area of gross fixed capital expenditure was in non-dwelling construction. In the latest quarter there was supposed to have been a 14 per cent increase, seasonally adjusted. So it seems to me that, if the latest figures for selected industries are an indication of what is to come, and I believe they are, even in the one area that looked moderately bright in the national income figures, we are about to see a collapse. The only reason we saw some increase in non-dwelling construction was as a result of the expenditure on quite a few casinos and other tourist accommodation which developed as a result of the collapse of the Australian dollar, making Australia a much more attractive place for tourists but at the same time making it far less attractive for Australians, particularly those seeking a home. I want to stress that one of the reasons that we are strongly opposed to this legislation is the impact it will have on Australians, particularly those seeking a home and who are in the lower income bracket.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are a couple of other matters I want to raise in relation to this legislation which have emerged from the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills of which I am a member. This Committee has some concerns about clause 25 and retrospectivity that I would like to draw to the attention of the Senate. As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee reports:

By virtue of sub-clauses 25 (4) and (5) the amendments made by clause 11 limiting deductions for interest on money borrowed to finance rental property investments and the amendments made by clauses 12, 13, 14 and 15 deeming consideration received for the transfer of rights to receive income from property to be assessable income (rather than a capital receipt) will have effect from 17 July 1985 and 9 October 1985 respectively. The Explanatory Memorandum indicates that these were the dates on which the changes were first announced. In neither case was this announcement made to the Parliament.

The Committee is critical of the practice, which is becoming increasingly prevalent in the field of taxation law, whereby changes to the law are made retrospective to the date of a Ministerial announcement. The Committee recognises the special conventions associated with changes to the taxation laws announced in the Budget or in similar statements to the Parliament and the practical necessity that changes to taxation laws be made retrospective to the date of the introduction of the amending Bill into the Parliament. However, these conventions aside--
I want to stress this-
the Committee deplores--
it does not just criticise-

the practice of making changes to the law retrospective to the date of a Ministerial announcement, for example to a press conference, which carries with it the assumption that people should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament. The practice treats the passage of the necessary retrospective legislation `ratifying' the Minister's announcement, in the present case 9 months and 6 months respectively after the event, as a pure formality.

That holds the Senate in contempt. This Government has done this consistently. It is not acceptable; not only that, it is misleading and disgraceful when, many months after the announcement, we find deals going on with the Australian Democrats behind closed doors which in fact change that announcement. So for nine months people have proceeded on the basis that the law will change when in fact it simply will not change in the manner announced back in September, or in one case July, of last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government by fear.

—This is absolutely government by fear and fiat and government by Press conference but not government by parliamentary democracy. It is about time that this Government woke up to the fact that if it continues to treat the Parliament with contempt the people of this nation will not tolerate it. This contempt of the Senate and of the whole Parliament is a far more serious matter than the people have so far recognised. I hope that we will continue to draw it to their attention.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say in all fairness that there were examples under the previous Government when announcements were made relating to tax matters which were followed by legislation many months later in some instances. I remind the Senate that in those instances the announcements simply were to close off loopholes in existing law. They were not creating totally new directions, new laws, new attempts to do totally new things. For this Government to try to use that specific measure, that we were forced to adopt when in government, as a precedent for this disgraceful behaviour now is equally intolerable. It involves a kind of intellectual agility which is inappropriate for a serious chamber and certainly inappropriate for a democratic government. I am unaware-perhaps the Government could point it out-of any instance other than the closing of a loophole in an existing Bill or tax law in which our Government in tax matters acted in the way that this Government is doing. I do not think that anyone on the Government side would criticise us for coming out with announcements to close loopholes-in fact they were critical that we did not do that more often-and then finding out how to write the legislation to effectively block the loophole without doing damage to existing and proper commercial activity.

That is not what this Government is doing. It is setting out a new set of taxation changes. The Government calls them reforms. Reform is the phoney word that is supposed to represent change-often change for the worse. That is the situation in this case. To regard this ragbag of Bills as reform is to abuse the English language. This legislation was part of the bribe that the Government offered to the trade union movement to allow the Treasurer to introduce some genuine improvement in the tax arrangements involving a switch from an over-reliance on direct income tax to a greater dependence on indirect tax, which had general community support. That, however, did not have the support of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and some elements of the big business cabal which surrounds the Prime Minister and to which he appears to limit his detailed conversations on such matters. As a result, Mr Keating's proposals were rolled. We do not have any genuine reform of the tax system. All we have now is the bribe that was offered-this ragbag of legislation-which, as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee says, has been introduced in a manner which it deplores. We have to put up with the bribe without getting the benefit of genuine tax reform. I strongly oppose this.

I look forward to being able to test the attitude of the Australian Democrats in the Committee stage when some amendments will be moved. I encourage the Senate strongly to resist this legislation. I hope that those people who find that they cannot afford accommodation, that rents are out of their reach, that they have no prospect of getting a deposit or of being able to pay the interest bill if they want to buy a house, will recognise-there are many thousands of such people judging from the latest falls in housing approval figures-that it is not just bad luck or not simply bad fortune that has deprived them of the opportunity to have accommodation either rental or owned but is the direct result of deliberate government policy. The Government has chosen in endeavouring to solve its economic problems not to cut its own self-indulgences but to hit the home seeker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill contains two major elements: The removal of negative gearing on rental property investment, and the self- assessment of taxation. Both of these provisions are inept attempts by the Government to tidy up Australia's increasingly cumbersome income tax system. Unfortunately, the Government has neglected to acknowledge the detrimental effects that its social taxation reform package will have on the economy. The Bill proposes that negative gearing be abolished. It is incredibly short-sighted legislation. The Government objects to negative gearing operations when money is borrowed on rental investment property which is subsequently sold for a capital profit. There is some substance and justification in that argument but what it actually has done is hit all negative gearing proposals, even those that are not subsequently sold.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government attacks such schemes from two sides; namely, by abolishing the negative gearing aspects and by introducing a capital gains tax. In equity, in philosophy, one may be able to justify one proposal but not the double-edged sword approach that this Government is using. In an effort to track down a minority of individuals-even the minority use the mechanisms provided by the law to reduce their tax burden-the Government has placed in jeopardy the welfare of the very people whom it claims to represent. In 1983 the Government gave assurances that housing would be given a high priority. When there is already a housing rental crisis the Government proposes to exacerbate the situation by squeezing the rental market even further.

The private sector plays a vital role in providing accommodation. It is clear that the abrogation of negative gearing will result in a reduction of property investment for rental purposes. The ability to off-set excess interest costs on a rental property against other income has to a certain extent afforded the community with rental accommodation at a lower price than the market would normally provide. These negative gearing provisions in the Bill will have a very adverse effect on the housing situation. They will remove incentives for individuals to buy properties for rental purposes. They will receive less income in the short term in rent than the cost of the interest on their borrowings. I emphasise that that is in the short term. As the availability of rental accommodation decreases basic economics tell us that according to the law of supply and demand rents will be forced upwards until the market reaches a new and higher equilibrium. Also, present rent levels will not provide sufficient after tax returns to the investor. This is a second factor which will tend to inflate prices. Clearly, rents must increase for this type of investment to remain viable.

I believe that the timing of the legislation is terrible, as my colleague Senator Michael Baume has already described to the Senate. With private sector approvals continuing to fall, the Government cannot afford to place more pressure on an already critical housing situation. It is the low income earners who find it most difficult nowadays to qualify for a loan. Consequently, this legislation is further evidence that the Government is placing home ownership beyond the reach of ordinary people, particularly the poor. If rents are forced to rise, poor people, the category of people most in need, will be the real losers. This legislation has even more far-reaching consequences. When the rental market dries up, the demand for housing commission homes will also be intensified and people will turn to government, clamouring for more funds for Commonwealth housing. The abolition of negative gearing will merely tamper with an already distorted market, gaining the Government little and destroying a system which has worked reasonably well in the past.

The new depreciation allowance of 4 per cent per annum on residential, income-producing buildings included in this package has been offered as an illusory olive branch to the property investor. In effect, it will do very little to overcome the damage that the negative gearing provisions will cause to the housing situation today. The Government claims that the building depreciation provisions will somehow offset the effect of the removal of negative gearing. However, the compensation is not significant. The provision applies only to new buildings, not to all buildings. This means that a substantial number of property investors will not benefit as most of the houses which are rented out are old, rather than new.

The legislation before us today is another example of the tardiness of the Government in putting into legislative form its earlier undertakings. A Bill which is intended to operate from July 1985 is not introduced until late May 1986 and in the dying stages of the parliamentary session. It is then rushed through the House of Representatives.

The self-assessment provisions, likewise, give the Taxation Commissioner an inordinate amount of authority. Therefore, the provisions have the capacity to be particularly inequitable. Under the new proposals, a taxpayer's return goes to the Australian Taxation Office but will not be routinely assessed and given the full scrutiny it currently receives. The object of self-assessment is to reallocate work within the Taxation Office so that more staff will work on selected post-assessment assignments. This concept is quite sound in theory but in practice it has many problems. The scheme will impose great costs on the taxpayer as he is presumed to have a very intricate knowledge of the taxation Act in order to claim fairly and correctly. So that he can have some degree of assurance that he can claim properly he would need to have the services of a super-reliable tax agent. The system of self-assessment is unfair because it singles out and places costs on certain categories of taxpayers, together with the responsibility of knowing an increasingly complex taxation system. I believe that the Government Whip, Senator Robertson, will be aware of the sorts of problems that will be placed on people in these circumstances.

The most blatantly unfair aspect of this tax relates to the Commissioner's powers. At present if a full and true disclosure has been made, no amendment to increase the tax liability can be made to reflect a changed interpretation of the law. Only if there has been a mistake in calculation or an error in fact can liability be changed. However, under this new legislation the Commissioner has the power to increase or reduce liability if the law is reinterpreted or changed in some way. This will apply to tax assessments made in the previous three years. Although returns may be accepted by the Commissioner, he can decide that assessments made earlier are not satisfactory and require them to be audited. Past commitments can then be called up and a backtracking process undertaken. One of the most unjust aspects of the proposed legislation is that, whilst the Commissioner has the power to reopen a case to increase liability, the request of the taxpayer to reopen a case to decrease liability is at the Commissioner's discretion. I believe that this leaves the taxpayer powerless while the Taxation Office calls all the shots.

The fact that any assessment can be audited and liability increased has very serious implications for small business. Even if a full and true disclosure has been made and is accepted by the Taxation Office, there is no way of knowing whether the taxpayer's liability is finalised. This will create dreadful uncertainty within the private sector. Taxation laws are not black and white. They are always under debate as to what is the correct way of interpreting them. Not even experts in the field agree fully as to the real meaning of the many different and complex laws. Therefore, when assessments are made, they may be made on the basis of one meaning, yet be audited at some stage in the future when the law has been reinterpreted. If this happens it leaves taxpayers in dire straits. There is nothing binding in the tax laws that will give individuals some degree of confidence in the liability they have to pay. It will be up to the Commissioner as to how he interprets the legislation before the Senate. He has a disturbingly wide range of discretionary powers.

Furthermore, if the taxpayer is uncertain about his assessment, he does not have the option to get the Taxation Office to scrutinise his assessment rather than do it himself. Therefore, even if he wishes to do so, the taxpayer cannot make certain of his standing in relation to his tax liability. Instead he must wait, perhaps up to three years, to see whether he will be audited and the matter subsequently disputed. He has no protection whatsoever. Given this length of time, problems must be created for the Taxation Office in relation to changes in the situation of each taxpayer. That is what will occur, for example, in the case of bankruptcy, insolvency, company liquidation and changes in the formal construction of a business.

There are other anomalies which I particularly would like to comment on. The first relates to what I can see only as being the double standards which could occur due to this Bill. If a person receives interest paid by the Commissioner because the Commissioner owes to him a disputed claim or decreased liability, the individual must pay tax on that interest as assessable income. However, if the person has to pay the Commissioner tax, he cannot claim it to be tax deductible. In my mind this seems to be somewhat questionable.

I am also particularly concerned about another anomaly which relates to tax audits under these new provisions. Under this legislation the expense of complying with a tax audit is not classified as a business expense and, therefore, is not deductible in the normal sense of running a company. Therefore, the very high costs that will be imposed on companies and individuals by tax audits are not tax deductible. Even worse, the costs of mounting a successful appeal against the Taxation Office are also not tax deductible. I believe that this is grossly unjust and a typical example of the unfair way the Government is now treating the private sector.

Let me give honourable senators an example. In regard to the heavy construction industry, the road construction industry or forest harvesting, if an engine blows up on a major plant item and the engine is replaced, but on replacement it is found that the replacement engine is of a slightly greater horsepower, technically this means that it is a capital improvement, even though it involves the replacement of a subsidiary part of a whole asset. Most contractors would write this off as a repair item, it being deductible under section 51: It blew up in the normal course of conducting the business and a new engine was put in. However, down the track the Commissioner of Taxation, on one of his post audits, comes along, and three years later the contractor is up for about 40-odd per cent interest, back payment, and on $50,000 that could be sufficient to bankrupt a harvesting contractor. By removing the element of certainty by changing the provisions of section 170, these provisions will result in the bankruptcy of many small businesses. They just will not be able to carry these interest costs for three or four years down the track. The self-assessment provisions of the Bill must be condemned. They will do little to foster growth in the economy and will result in massive uncertainty in the private sector.

Overall, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill can have only a negative effect. The Australian tax system is far too complex. Grafting bits and pieces on here and there in an effort to reduce tax avoidance will simply make it more and more complicated and more and more inequitable to the individual. Ultimately, the benefits will be nullified by the costs. The level of taxation avoidance will continue to increase, with individuals trying to shelter from their existing very high levels of taxation. The higher the rate of tax, the more that taxpayers are likely to exploit the mechanisms that can be found to provide ways and means of minimising tax liabilities. The present measures will not guarantee a reduction in tax avoidance. More and more leaks will keep appearing in the system, and they will have to be blocked off. I conclude by expressing my extreme concern at the extension of the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation and by pointing out the grave implications that the Bills will have on the continuation of investment opportunities in the community and the problems that they will pose for small business.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (APPLICATION TO THE COMMONWEALTH) BILL 1986FRINGE BENEFITS TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the commencement of the debate on the fringe benefits tax, the second part of the Government's so-called tax reform package. It has come before us some eight months after the initial announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last year. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 represents a giant step forward in tax law to prove that there is absolutely no logic in taxation; it is merely the figment of the imagination of an avaricious government which finds itself enmeshed in an impenetrable net, locking itself in with the Australian Council of Trade Unions through that so-called sacred document, the accord. It is, appropriately, a purple document that has been produced to be circulated amongst employers-the colour of mourning. And mourn we might for Australia as a result of this stupid tax measure. Mourn we might for the jobs of Australians as a result of it. But one thing we will not mourn is the passing of the Australian Labor Party out of government as a result of the introduction of this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's formal position in relation to this legislation is that we shall be opposing it at all stages. Furthermore, upon election to government, we will repeal the legislation. I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of the news release issued today by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, stating his intention to repeal this legislation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LEADER OF THE OPPOSITION
News Release by John Howard, MP
Coalition will Repeal Fringe Benefits Tax
The Opposition has considered in detail the Keating Fringe Benefits Tax.
This legislation is anti-business, enormously bureaucratic and will do great harm to the productive sector of the Australian economy.
On election to government the Coalition will repeal the Keating Fringe Benefits Tax.
It is economic insanity for the Hawke Government to be introducing wide-ranging anti-business taxes at a time when Australia has a balance of payments crisis.
The Government should be doing everything in its power to encourage investment and export earnings.
Instead Mr Keating has decided to mug Australian businesses and farmers with an enormously complex fringe benefits tax.
This is a costly, unfair and punitive way of tackling areas of undoubted abuse that do exist in relation to certain fringe benefits.
In the name of tackling these abuses there is not justification for the method adopted by Mr Keating that will:
cripple many small businesses and farming enterprises; and
put thousands out of work in the motor vehicle industry and in rural areas.

There are alternative ways of tackling those fringe benefits abuses which are an obvious form of tax avoidance. This will be addressed in detail when the Coalition's taxation policy is released prior to the next election. The Coalition's approach will address the abuses which do exist without the unfair and costly burdens involved in the Keating Fringe Benefits Tax.
CANBERRA

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This tax represents an insult to all Australians. It breaches the National Taxation Summit principles which were outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) some time ago. There are at least three principles which it obviously breaches. Let us look at the fourth great Hawke tax principle: Any reform must lead to a simpler system, which, therefore, all Australians can understand easily. Certainly this legislation will lead not to any simpler system but only to a more complicated one. The eighth principle was that any reform must provide the best possible climate for investment, growth and employment. Obviously, this tax will destroy jobs and destroy incentive for investment and growth, all coming on top of the most disastrous national account figures that we have seen for three years announced today. The ninth principle also was stated by Prime Minister Hawke to be that any reform package must have widespread community support. I have never seen a tax measure more roundly condemned by the community than the fringe benefits tax, so it has no support in the community whatsoever. As a result, it fails on that ground as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only does this tax breach those principles; it taxes the employer for the benefits obtained by others. It is a capricious piece of legislation in its impact on the various categories of employment. For instance, it singles out farmers, motor cars, and meals for employees; but it allows people to eat in in-house canteens and in other in-house facilities, which are given exemption from this tax. The tax imposes a double penalty. For example, even where a tax deduction to an employer is denied or limited, the fringe benefits tax on the employee's benefit is imposed. Let us just take the classic case of the so-called executive who receives, as part of his remuneration package, the use of a motor car which might be worth more than $26,660. The Australian Taxation Office will not allow a depreciation deduction on values in excess of that figure. To that extent, no tax allowance is made to the employer for the use of that motor vehicle; and yet notwithstanding that there is no tax benefit to the company, a second tax is imposed through the fringe benefits tax on the company as a result. It is absolutely ludicrous and is an insult to the intelligence of all Australians.

There are other insults. The Treasurer expects us to believe that his famous tax cuts which are coming up this year and next are dependent upon this measure. Yet for every $6 of tax cuts that will be implemented by the Government's proposals, only $1 will come from the fringe benefits tax. We all know that the balance-some $3 billion in the overhang over a two-year period-will be paid for by inflation and by the taxpayer moving into higher and higher tax brackets. That is where the payment will come from. It will not come from the fringe benefits tax by any means.

The Treasurer also expects us to believe that rorts are rampant and that the rich are getting the benefits. Let us look at what benefits they are getting. I mentioned earlier the case of the executive car. Suppose there is a $80,000 Mercedes owned by an executive; but the company that is employing that person gets a deduction for the depreciation on it only up to $26,660. There is no deduction against taxable income beyond that level. Yet we impose a second tax on the company in the form of a fringe benefit tax as a double penalty in that situation.

It is interesting to note that 65 per cent of the work force receive fringe benefits, and among the kinds of benefits that they get, under the definition of this law, is, say, where they take home the car provided by the employer for garaging, because, frequently, the company, the employer or the charity, or whatever it is, has no room for garaging. It is therefore to the benefit of the employer that the employee takes the car home. Let us just consider that there are, say, a number of benefits to employees in that category, who might be in the lower level of income. Let us say that a company provides cars to 500 employees. We might find that, say, 10 people at the executive level of income have a somewhat grander vehicle than the other employees who take cars home, so only a minimal number, perhaps two per cent, of a company's employees may be caught under that category.

While we are on that point we should note the statement in the Senate the other night by Senator Walsh who acknowledged that it was the Government's firm intention to force employers to cash up benefits-that is, instead of paying fringe benefits in the form of kind, pay them in cash. Logically, that means that it will be not the employer but the employee who will be paying the tax because in the future the employer will of course get a tax deduction for the cashed-up value of those benefits. The benefit will be received in the hands of the employee and he or she will be paying the tax as part of the pay as you earn system. Just to demonstrate this point I would like to incorporate in Hansard a table which sets out the situation as the tax applies to varying levels of income. The table quite clearly shows that in relation to benefits being cashed-up, as Senator Walsh wants employers to cash them up, there will be an incentive for employers to do that in the case of lower income earners and not, as he would have us believe, in the case of upper income earners. Therefore it is the lower income earners who, in the long run, will find that their benefits will be subject to tax in their hands. They will be paying the tax, not the upper income earners. As a result, the Government's measure fails on that very important ground. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other point that the Treasurer would have us believe is that the tax is being imposed on 700,000 employers across the country because of efficiency of collection; that it is cheaper and better to impose it on the employers rather than on the employees. That is absolute nonsense. As we have now seen, Senator Walsh wants employees to pay the tax. But even if that were so, obviously that is not the reason why employers are having this tax pushed on them. Obviously it is politically easier for the Government to do that and, of course, the trade union movement would not allow it to happen any other way. Absolutely no thought has been given to the cost to business of the regulation associated with the fringe benefits tax, which is fantastically complex and difficult and which is generating amazing concern amongst employer groups. The Government seems to have ignored entirely the fact that it is adding to the regulation of business at a time when it is claiming that it is trying to deregulate industry and provide a more competitive industrial base.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, this tax represents nothing more than a new form of payroll tax, as it is being levied in exactly the same way as the States levy their taxes. Of course it is different from those taxes levied by the States because there is no exemption for small business in the same way as there is in the State arena. It is therefore destructive of jobs, of enterprise and of incentive. Small business has already reacted to payroll taxes. It knows what they are all about, and it knows how they destroy jobs. The only positions we can see being created in the job department as a result of this new fringe benefits tax are for accountants and public servants. We know that in my State, for instance, the car industry could well suffer a loss of 4,500 jobs. We have also the new uranium, gold and copper development at Olympic Dam. The Western Mining Corporation proposal to establish 650 houses there is in jeopardy because of the imposition of the tax. Instead of establishing a town of 650 houses, Western Mining Corporation is now actively looking at flying people on a regular cycle basis between Andamooka and Adelaide, rotating jobs so that its employees can keep their houses in Adelaide.

Perhaps the most callous part of this whole fringe benefits tax is the impact it will have on charities and voluntary groups, and in some cases on religious organisations as well. People who are providing a genuine community service-people involved in groups such as the Red Cross Society, the Salvation Army, the Australian Cancer Society and so on-and who drive charity vehicles, or non-profit organisation vehicles, as part of the 24-hour service that they give the community, or who take them home in order the save the charity or body involved the cost of garaging, will now find that those organisations will be forced to pay a fringe benefits tax, so reducing the amount of money available to the disadvantaged.

One other area of great concern came to my attention only yesterday. The new consulting industry, which is developing rapidly overseas, consulting with governments in other countries, and which is competing on a very large market that is now worth some $160m a year, will have problems with the tax. Consultants overseas are provided with houses, and in those parts of the world where there are no English-speaking schools and children have to go to special schools, the extra cost of fees associated with that have to be paid for and they will all be taxed at these new rates under the fringe benefits tax. Consequently that industry will be thrown into jeopardy because it is competing against the rest of the world on a very tightly-priced market.

Let us look at some of the detailed provisions of the legislation. The fundamental problem with it is the broad potential application of its provisions. The crux of the legislation is the provision of a fringe benefit in respect of the employment of an employee. An employee is defined as a person being a former, a current or a future employee. So a company, an employer, can never avoid being caught for the fringe benefits tax. Basically, to be considered an employee a person must have received salary or wages as defined in section 221a (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Of course, that definition includes directors fees. As the definition of an employee includes a future or former employee, it is only necessary to have received or to receive such a payment at any time in the past or in the future, with no linkage of the benefit to any current employment. In fact, section 137 states that if a benefit is provided not in respect of employment but is paid in cash, it is salaries or wages. It will be deemed to be salaries or wages to ensure that an employee's relationship is preserved, or created. Thus the concept of an employee is very broad indeed.

Once the extended concept of an employee is established, a benefit must be provided in respect of employment. Section 148 extends the meaning of what constitutes `in respect of the employment of an employee', which is the crux of the whole Bill, and states that it is also included whether or not the benefit is also provided in respect of any other matter or thing, whether or not employment will occur, is occurring or has occurred, whether or not the benefit is offset by any disadvantage or inconvenience, whether or not the benefit is provided in connection with that employment and whether or not the benefit is provided as a reward for services rendered or to be rendered.

So the extraordinary breadth of this legislation catches virtually any kind of condition. To make my point I take the common example of a teenage lad of 16 working in his parents' greengrocer shop after school and who receives a salary. When he gets married at the age of 23 or 24 and gets a wedding present, that wedding present will be a fringe benefit. I will take this a step further. The father might give his son and future daughter-in-law a loan for a house on an interest free basis or on perhaps a concessional interest basis. That is a fringe benefit and will be taxed in the hands of the father. So on it will go right through the life of that child until he dies. This is absolutely incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will encourage them to work for dad!

—That is obviously going to kill that business. There are a number of other examples that perhaps we ought to run through at this point. Let us look at the farming industry. The value of a dead tree chopped up by a farm worker and used for heating a farm cottage for his family is going to be subject to the tax. The mere use of a farm vehicle by a worker living on the farm to drive his children to the school bus stop will be subject to the tax. As private use is defined to mean `use not exclusively for producing assessable income', if a farmer drives into town to pick up a spare part for a tractor and takes his wife to do some shopping, the use of that car is a private use and will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. Senator Grimes laughs, but he should read the law. I bet that he has not addressed his mind to it. A four-wheel drive vehicle used exclusively on the farm each day will be required to substantiate business use in order to obtain exemption from the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The example of the farmer's son, which we have just covered in another instance in relation to small business, is a similar problem. The provisions are so broad that if a farmer had a son who worked on a farm property, who lived with the farmer and his wife in their house and received a salary while he worked, of course, the rental value of that house is taxable as a fringe benefit to the employer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not fair dinkum.

—Yes, I am fair dinkum. We return to the situation of the small business where a child employee is working and he is given a bicycle by his parents as a birthday present. This will constitute a fringe benefit under these situations.
—That is disgusting.
—That is the way this Government operates. One can see the breadth of this legislation. The Minister laughs, but I ask him to tell us where this legislation does not cover these circumstances.
—You know it doesn't.
—Will the Minister tell us or point to the Act?
—It is just the same as you said about charities. You were lying then, and you are lying now.
—Order!

—I do not take exception to what Senator Grimes has said. We all understand him. But the point about it is that it is exactly the misleading situation we had in the House of Representatives yesterday or the day before when Mr Keating, the Treasurer, said that people in farm houses would not be subject to this tax. That is absurd. If a person under this law is an employee of a company which owns a house that is on a farm property, the value of that house will be subject to a fringe benefits tax. That is the situation that will apply in those circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us pass to other problems in industry. Safety awards will be made subject to the fringe benefits tax. Road safety awards given to people for good road safety habits will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. The gold watch given to the retiring employee will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. Relocation expenses paid for the transfer of an employee and the family will be subject to the full to the fringe benefits tax. This will be so, as the taxable fringe benefit is generally reduced by the amount that would have been deductible to the employee had the employee incurred the expenditure. But, as the Minister would know, that expenditure is of a private nature and is not deductible for the employee, therefore it will be caught up. The air fares paid by the company for a job applicant travelling from one city to another for an interview will be subject to the fringe benefits tax if that person becomes an employee of that company.

It goes on and on, but let us just turn to religious bodies and charities. The private use of a car by a minister of religion will be subject to fringe benefits tax when he takes his car to visit his mother or to do some shopping. A proportion of the value of the house attached to the church will be subject to the fringe benefits tax. The value of a live-in school teacher or housekeeper will also be subject to a fringe benefits tax. As we have seen quoted so often in the media, a field worker for a charity who takes a car home because there is nowhere to garage it on the charity's property, will find that it is subject to the fringe benefits tax. These cases just roll on and on and we keep hearing more and more of these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —All out of your mind.

—If Senator Grimes can ask his offsiders to give him advice as to where we are wrong on these points, we would be only too pleased to hear about it, but these are clearly interpretations based on the law and have been scrutinised by people who understand that law and who apply it every day.
—The Treasurer has denied that repeatedly. Senator Walters is lying now like you lied about the assets test and she will get her staff to do the same again.

—I really do object to the fact that the Minister calls lies those issues that were raised at the time under the assets test because quite clearly when they were raised they were proven to be right and the Government was forced to back off and adjust its legislation and its thinking.
—The gold teeth?
—I never mentioned gold teeth, and the Minister knows that.
