—You mentioned that on the program in Hobart. I will get the date for you and I will get the transcript. See if you can deny that.

—The Minister is only trying to take my time. The point is that we should look at some of the other stupidities in this legislation. Governments are going to be forced to pay fringe benefits tax on that part of its employees' benefits. We talk there of State and local governments. Some 16 per cent-about $100m-of this new tax is going to be raised from local and State governments. Who is going to reimburse them? Is the Federal Government going to have to rob Peter to pay Paul? That is one solution. Another solution is that local governments will be forced to put up rates or State governments will be forced to put up the cost of water supply, water rates and so on. How else are they going to do it? Is it any wonder now that the Premiers of the States, such as Mr John Bannon in South Australia and Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland, have said that they will have to consider very carefully whether they can pay this or not?

SPEECH.PARA: The attack on charities, as I say, is probably the most outrageous attack of all. Now we come to a matter even more serious-the letter sent to business houses in the last few weeks by the Commissioner of Taxation which incorporated the purple booklet and which included a questionnaire asking for information from employers. This letter is unprecedented in its political nature. I cannot believe that the Commissioner of Taxation did this off his own bat without some kind of duress from the Government because incorporated in this letter is the following statement:

The Fringe Benefits Tax is an integral part of the Government's tax reform package, the overall aim of which is to cut personal marginal income tax rates and finance other benefits for the Australian community.

If that is not a political statement, I do not know what is. I can only assume that it was the duress from the Treasurer on the Commissioner of Taxation which produced that kind of statement. Apart from being wrong, it is outrageously political as uttered by a civil servant in this situation. One can only say that that would be unprecedented in its breadth.

When I started my comments on this Bill I made the point that the Opposition will be opposing it at all stages right down the line and that it is our commitment to repeal it upon election to government. I believe that we are thoroughly justified in that position. This Bill is dangerous. It is wrong in its principle in so many ways. It is certainly very onerous, it is burdensome, and it will add considerably to the cost of doing business in the community. It comes at a time when we are struggling to get the economy moving to bring about increased output in future to provide job opportunities for Australians. Clearly, this tax is destructive of jobs in the community, it is destructive of incentive for investment, and it will lead to the disemployment of many people in a wide sector of industry. It will force people who are unequipped to handle these things to keep records in such detail that they will find themselves in error, and no doubt subject to prosecution by the Australian Taxation Office as a result.

In order to avoid those errors people will be forced to take advice from lawyers and accountants. One wonders what is in the Government's mind. We know that the accounting profession is under pressure in meeting its own obligations to the Taxation Office in the way of lodgment of returns by the end of October each year and the profession will be forced to answer queries and prepare returns on behalf of employers at about the same time in this financial year. One wonders how the industry will cope with this difficulty.

The Opposition opposes this legislation. It is thoroughly bad and should be withdrawn now. That is a positive step that could be taken by this Government to retrieve this country's economic position. The legislation should be withdrawn now before the Government is embarrassed any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the Government's legislation to impose a tax on specified fringe benefits. The fringe benefits tax Bills introduce provisions which continue the Government's attack on tax avoidance and tax evasion practices. These Bills will ensure that a whole range of fringe benefits previously received tax free by a privileged minority of the work force will now be subject to taxation. Importantly, the extra revenue raised by these tax reform measures will be used to finance personal taxation reductions for other Australians. I make the point that this is part of a tax package which is designed to create tax cuts for many Australians. It is not a package which will result in overall taxation increases across the board but will result in tax reductions for many Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The revenue raised by this tax on fringe benefits will be used to reduce personal income tax scales and marginal tax rates. I instance the reduction in the top marginal tax rate from 60c to 49c in the dollar under this Government and the reduction in the current rate of 46c to 40c in the dollar. It is important to bear in mind that those reductions will enable many Australians to buy new motor vehicles and new products. One of the dishonest aspects of the campaign waged by the Opposition and by certain groups in the community against this legislation is that they will not acknowledge the effect of the tax cuts which will be financed by these measures and which will enable a number of Australians to make major consumer purchases and in many cases to buy new motor vehicles for the first time. That is a very important point that should be put on the record.

The Government's crackdown on fringe benefits will make the tax system more equitable by distributing the taxation burden more in accordance with each individual's capacity to pay. As a result of the measures contained in the Bills and the Government's overall taxation package, there will be no increase in the total level of taxation in the community. That was spelt out in the Prime Minister's nine principles of tax reform-namely, that there should be no increase in taxation collections in relation to gross domestic product. There will be no overall increase in taxation as a result of the tax package.

The provision of fringe benefits as a form of non-taxable remuneration to employees has escalated rapidly in recent years. Often it has constituted nothing less than outright tax avoidance. It has led to a serious deterioration in the direct tax base as upper income earners in particular have been receiving large slices of their remuneration in the form of non-taxable fringe benefits. Of course, fringe benefits have always existed as additional incentives provided by employers to attract employees. However, in recent years the use of fringe benefits has been abused. When one looks at the official surveys covering employees who have received fringe benefits one sees that there has been a very explosive growth indeed in the spread of fringe benefits in recent years. In fact, they can no longer be labelled as fringe benefits if one is to describe them correctly. In many cases such non-taxable benefits account for up to 40 per cent of an employee's remuneration package. So strictly speaking the term `fringe benefit' is a misnomer. In such cases 40 per cent of some remuneration is being received tax free. This practice had to be stopped if Australia is to have a fair and equitable tax system.

The measures introduced in this Bill will ensure that the value of all major fringe benefits, whether received in cash or otherwise, are made subject to taxation. The fringe benefits tax will apply to all employers, including Commonwealth State and local governments and their agencies. Types of benefits to be taxed include employer provided motor vehicles, free or low interest loans, residential accommodation, board and excessive living away from home allowances, goods and services provided free or sold at or below cost, and expenses paid on behalf of employees. The tax will not apply to benefits associated with contributions to superannuation funds and employee share acquisition plans. Also exempt is free or discounted use of commuter transport systems by employees. No tax will be applied on goods consumed at work, nor on the first $200 in value in a year of free or discounted goods or services provided to an employee, including discounted air fares to airline and travel agency employees.

It was previously announced that the taxable value of free or subsidised rental accommodation would be discounted by one-third. The Government has decided to increase that discount to 40 per cent. This concession is in recognition of the cost disadvantages of constructing accommodation in remote areas. That means that only 60 per cent of the value of subsidised rental accommodation will be taxed; initially at the 46c in the dollar rate, then at 27.6 per cent of the value.

The Bill makes further allowance for the position of remotely located employees. One of these is to discount by half the value of holiday travel subsidised or paid for by employers. The system will be one of self-assessment. Responsibility will be placed on employers to lodge an annual return and to calculate the amount of fringe benefits tax payable. For the transitional year of the new arrangements tax will be imposed at the rate of 46c in the dollar on the taxable value of those fringe benefits subject to the tax. Thereafter, the rate will rise to 49c in the dollar, which equates with the maximum rate of income tax to apply from 1 July next year and the company tax rate to apply to corporate incomes derived in the financial year 1987-88.

Revenue gains from the fringe benefits tax originally were estimated at $320m in 1986-87 and $515m in 1987-88. They are very large sums of money indeed-large amounts of revenue to be obtained by the Commonwealth. They indicate very tangibly the extent of tax avoidance through these avenues in the past. The fact that we are able to raise hundreds of millions of dollars by taxing fringe benefits indicates what has been going on in Australian society and those revenue figures underline the extent of tax avoidance through the use of fringe benefits in recent years. The revenue collected from the fringe benefits tax will be a major means of financing income tax cuts for many pay as you earn taxpayers in the next 18 months. That is a very important factor that has to be borne in mind in this debate.

Since the announcement of the Government's fringe benefits tax measures in September last year, the Australian public has been bombarded with misleading and even false information about their likely effects. Much of this misinformation has originated from members of the Federal Opposition, and at other times, I regret to say, it has been the result of concerted scare campaigns by disaffected industry groups. For example, in South Australia Mr Olsen, the continuing State Liberal Opposition Leader, and a small section of the car industry late last year based the whole of the State election campaign on the so-called car tax. It is very important to note that this so-called car tax has already been tested once at the ballot box. Mr Olsen and a small section of disaffected industry groups made the fringe benefits tax on cars a major issue at the South Australian elections on 7 December last year. They invested thousands of dollars in full page newspaper advertisement telling us that the car industry was about to collapse. They told South Australian voters to send a message to Canberra. That is what they did. Rallies were held to give Mr Olsen a public platform. The organisers tried to confuse and mislead the South Australian electorate. They made it a big issue in the election and look where it got them-complete rejection by the South Australian electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of 20 speakers only two of you were willing to speak on this.

—It is the quality that counts. Today I will present some concrete facts about fringe benefits and about the likely effects of the new taxation measures. I intend to spend some time discussing the fringe benefits tax as it applies to employer-provided motor vehicles, since it is in this area that most of the scare tactics have been directed. First, it has to be made clear that the Government has not introduced a new tax on cars. The Government is not levying a new tax on the car industry as claimed in the full page, highly unsuccessful election advertisements at the time of the South Australian elections. The fact is that the Government simply is removing a tax lurk, a tax avoidance mechanism that has been available to a privileged few in the community for too long.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very encouraging to note that the Government's proposals in regard to fringe benefits taxation is very heavily supported by the electorate. Opinion polls are showing overwhelmingly that these measures are very heavily supported by the electorate. As I pointed out in the debate on business lunches we had last November and December, it underlines the good common sense of the Australian electorate. The attitudes, which are coming through in opinion polls, show that an overwhelming majority are in favour of this legislation proposed by the Government. In fact, the fringe benefits tax element of the tax package is seen as the best feature of the overall tax package. It is overwhelmingly supported by the community. The Government is not placing a new tax on cars. It is simply subjecting to taxation the assessed value of the private benefit received by that minority of Australians who are given the use of employer- provided motor vehicles.

The Government is simply making sure that remuneration, whether received in cash or otherwise, is made subject to taxation. We are trying to stamp out tax avoidance in this country, the scourge of tax avoidance which continued for years and years when Mr Howard was Treasurer. This Government is trying to stamp it out and this proposal to tax fringe benefits is an important aspect of that strategy. The fact that the benefits of using an employer-provided car for private purposes has been flowing to a privileged few can be seen clearly from an analysis of relevant Australian Bureau of Statistics information.

The latest Bureau of Statistics survey of employment benefits conducted in August last year details the incidence of a whole range of fringe benefits in the community. For example, that official survey shows that some 7.7 per cent of all employees received some form of transport fringe benefits. They are the people the Opposition supports-the mere 7.7 per cent who receive some form of transport fringe benefits. Over 92 per cent of employees do not receive any form of employer concession or benefit related to transport costs. Clearly, once again, the Opposition has jumped into bed with the privileged minority in the community.

What is even more revealing in the Bureau of Statistics figures are those which show the number of employees in each income bracket who receive particular fringe benefits. For example, of those earning less than $200 a week, which is the lowest income bracket in the survey, only 3.3 per cent received some form of transport fringe benefit. The 3.3 per cent in the lowest bracket compares with an average figure for all employees of 7.7 per cent. Yet of those employees earning greater than $560 a week, the highest income bracket, 18.8 per cent received a transport fringe benefit. That is more than double the average of 7.7 per cent for the entire community. In other words, fringe benefits are heavily skewed in favour of upper-income earners. Those figures clearly demonstrate that. No doubt, that is why the Liberal Party and the National Party have made such a fuss about this legislation. These are lurks and perks which are available to the most privileged income earners in our community.

Often the intention of employer provided motor cars is outright private use. One only has to walk through a few corporate garages in the capital cities-I invite honourable senators to do so-to see the company cars with towbars. It is a very illuminating experience to see all these so-called company cars which are clearly fitted out as private vehicles. If anything, the figures provided by the Bureau of Statistics on fringe benefits fail to reveal the full extent of the inequitable distribution of those benefits.

Some quite revealing figures on executive salary packages are contained in a report by the accounting firm Price Waterhouse entitled `Top 5 Plus-Executives Compensation Report'. A table from that report is included on page 88 of the Government's tax White Paper. It shows that an employer provided motor vehicle to a chief executive officer is worth over 15 per cent of that officer's salary. The relevant figure for a sales executive is over 14 per cent. So privileged employees are not only receiving the free use of a motor vehicle, worth up to 15 per cent of their actual salary, but also receiving it tax free. By contrast, average pay as you earn Australians receive almost all of their income in the form of taxed wages and salaries. They do not get company cars or lurks. They receive all of their income, or most of it, in the form of wages and salaries and every dollar of that income is taxed, except those dollars below the threshold. For those persons buying a motor vehicle is a major purchase, probably the second largest purchase they ever make after their home. These average Australians pay tax on all of their income and purchase their motor vehicle from their after tax income. It is relevant to ask: Why should a small privileged group of Australians receive a motor vehicle free as untaxed income while other Australians pay the full price out of their own wages and salaries after tax? Where is the fairness in that situation? The lurk of avoiding tax through the payment of income in kind rather than in cash had to be stopped. These Bills are designed to do just that; to bring some fairness and equity back into the Australian tax system.

We have heard a lot recently of the claimed effects of these tax measures on the Australian motor vehicle industry. Naturally, as a South Australian member of parliament, as a South Australian senator, I am concerned that the effect of this legislation on the car industry is minimised. We have two major producers, General Motors-Holden's Ltd and Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd, in Adelaide, and I am concerned that the effect of this legislation on those companies and on their employees is minimised. I have been monitoring the position, as have my colleagues from South Australia, and we have raised the matter repeatedly within the Government party. Certainly, there may be some effects on the motor vehicle industry from a fringe benefits tax, but it will be nowhere near as drastic as some people would have us believe. Also, the effects of the fringe benefits tax on locally produced motor vehicles will be far less, I believe, than the impact on expensive imported motor vehicles, and that is a very relevant consideration in this debate.

At present the Australian car industry is going through a period of change, a period of rationalisation. After all, the industry is made up of a number of firms producing a large number of models. There are probably more producers in Australia than there are in the United States of America where the market is 17 times as large as the Australian market. We certainly have five producers and I think that is a larger number than there are in the United States of America. There may well be a reduction in motor vehicles sales this year. I will go as far as to say that there will almost certainly be a reduction in sales in 1986, but this reduction will be partly one of the industry's own making.

We only need to consider some recent facts about the performance of the Australian motor vehicle industry. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, has indicated in this place, 1985 was a record year for car sales in this country. I have an article from the Adelaide News, a newspaper which has been making a lot of noise about the effect of the car fringe benefits tax. In a major article on 20 September last year, the Adelaide News had a headline `New cars in bonanza sales rush'. This is the newspaper that is stirring up all the fuss about the car fringe benefits tax. It reported that the threat of a tax on company vehicles has had little effect on the market. This is the newspaper which is now stirring up confusion in the community about this tax. However, as recently as last September it carried an article which stated that the threat of a tax on company vehicles had had little effect on the market. The article went on to state that many people were buying motor vehicles in September in anticipation of the end of the year introduction of models fitted with catalytic converters. In other words, people were buying early to try to obtain cheaper motor vehicles. That is one of the reasons why, in 1985, records were broken in the car industry. Some 695,000 new motor vehicles were registered. Partly a reason for that was the drawing forward of car purchases which would normally have been made this year-in 1986. The industry actually encouraged that. As a result of the fear of car price rises, due to the depreciation of the dollar and to the introduction of unleaded petrol, some consumers were encouraged to bring their purchases forward to 1985. The car dealers, through their own advertising, encouraged this drawing forward. One only needs to look at the many articles that appeared in newspapers last year under the heading `Buy now and beat the price rises'. There were many articles of that ilk and they were designed to stampede people into buying motor vehicles in 1985.

There is no doubt that the Australian car industry is facing some real pressures in 1986 which could reduce sales but the Government's fringe benefits tax by no means is the major one. There are two major sources of pressures working to lift car prices and to hold down sales. The first is the need for catalytic converters for pollution reasons and the second-I have referred to it already-is the effect of the devaluation of the Australian dollar and the cost pressures resulting from that. However, there are some offsetting benefits. Local car makers should become more competitive as a result of the depreciation of the Australian dollar since the prices of fully imported cars have risen quite dramatically. Those are some of the facts about the Australian car industry. There will be changes ahead and a rationalisation of existing models, but there is certainly no cause for predictions of doom and gloom.

Of course some members of the Opposition would have us believe that the measures contained in these Bills will sound the death knell of the Australian car industry. They are telling us that car sales will plummet as a result of the measures. I suppose one could argue the proposition that, to the extent that new motor vehicle sales fall as a result of this tax package and the fringe benefits tax, it simply demonstrates that the vehicles were not essential for business purposes. One could argue that proposition. If there is a fall in sales as a result of the fringe benefits tax, one could validly argue that the motor vehicles were not at all essential for business purposes. It is a very difficult argument for the Opposition to sustain because it has to admit that the vehicles were used for private purposes. The intention of this legislation is to tax that aspect of vehicle use which is of a private nature.

I would also like to point out that even after this legislation is introduced it is highly likely that more new motor vehicles will be registered in Australia this year than were sold in the last year when Mr Howard was Treasurer. I think that is a very likely outcome.

On 3 March the Melbourne Age cited industry sources predicting that car sales would fall by 80,000 units in 1986. The very same day the Adelaide News-I have referred to the campaign waged by the Adelaide News-also cited industry sources claiming that car sales would fall by not 80,000 units, but 120,000 units. So there is a 50 per cent variation in the claims being made by those opposed to the fringe benefits tax. Who are we to believe? Mysterious industry sources are putting about figures which are not so much rubbery as decidedly elastic. The claims about the industry impact of this measure are rather like having a hole in the muffler of one's car; the hole tends to get larger and larger and noisier and noisier and that is what has been happening with the claims being made by Opposition spokespersons about this legislation.

Some more alleged facts emanating from the motor industry have come from the South Australian Automobile Chamber of Commerce. In one of its newsletters it claimed that over 50 per cent of all cars sold are fleet cars or corporate cars. Yet according to the data provided to the Government by the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries-it represents essentially the same industry-the proportion of fleet registrations is not 50 per cent but 38 per cent. However, these inaccuracies are overshadowed by the Opposition parties' deceit and manifest hypocrisy on this legislation. I instance as an example of that hypocrisy a recent Press release issued by Senator Chaney in which he called on South Australian Labor Party senators to vote against the fringe benefits tax on company cars. It was a classic example of kiddie car politics by Senator Chaney.

I refer him to Mr Howard's first Budget in 1978 which contained savage tax rises and were disastrous for the South Australian brandy industry. At that time my State, South Australia, contributed some 92 per cent of Australia's total brandy production. In one Budget Mr Howard, who is now the Opposition Leader of this country, wanted to virtually double the excise on brandy from $10.21 per litre of alcohol to $18.75 per litre of alcohol. The punishing effects of that impost on an important South Australian industry can be seen in the Treasury's revenue collections. The impact of that measure on the South Australian economy will be far greater than the effect of this car fringe benefits tax and that is a very important point to bear in mind.

There was clear evidence that the South Australian brandy industry suffered major dislocation as a result of Mr Howard's 1978 Budget; but did Senator Chaney, who was a Minister in the Fraser Government, call on South Australian Liberal Party senators to put the interests of their State first? Of course he certainly did not. Did the South Australian Liberal Party senators vote against the brandy excise? No, they did not. South Australian Senators Messner, Jessop and Teague were all members of the Parliament at the time, as was Senator Chaney, and they all voted for the brandy excise which created absolutely disastrous problems for the South Australian brandy industry. Did South Australian Liberal Party senators voice any concern over the politically disastrous effects of Mr Howard's tax on the brandy industry? Not once in their speeches on the 1978 Budget did Senators Messner and Jessop refer to the brandy excise. We now find Senator Chaney issuing statements calling on Labor Party senators to vote against their Party and to vote against the Government's proposal to tax fringe benefits. Yet, he did not have the guts to vote against the brandy excise when the 1978 Budget was debated. This excise has wrecked the South Australian brandy industry. It has had far worse effects on the South Australian economy than the fringe benefits tax on motor vehicles could ever have. They are some of the facts and a real demonstration of the hypocrisy of the Opposition with regard to the tax on motor vehicle fringe benefits.

Let us look at the details of the fringe benefits tax when applied to employer provided motor vehicles. First, the fringe benefits tax applies only to cars used privately by employees. If the vehicle is used solely for business and not for private purposes the employer will not be liable for any tax. The fringe benefits tax will be levied only on the assessed private benefit that the employee gains from using a vehicle. Secondly, the fringe benefits tax will not apply to self-employed people. Thirdly, existing tax deductions claimed for vehicle costs will continue to be deductible in full. It is quite incorrect to label the fringe benefits tax as a tax on cars. It is simply a tax on the value of the private benefit derived by an employee from the use of a company provided car.

For too long the provision of motor vehicles and other items as part of an employee's remuneration package have been a major source of tax avoidance in this country. It has led to a serious deterioration in the direct tax base and has meant that a privileged few have received a large part of their income free of tax. The Government could no longer tolerate this rip-off. This inequity had to be cleaned up and that is what the fringe benefits tax is designed to do. Contrary to the Opposition's claims, the Government's tax package does not lift overall tax levels in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last we have come to the debate on the fringe benefits tax. This government initiative has been the subject of intense speculation in the community for over six months. In the last week or so it has intensified to a crescendo which hopefully will be resolved once and for all once this legislation passes the Senate. I cannot help but draw a distinction between the attitude of the Australian Democrats on this matter and the attitude of the Opposition. The Opposition still says that it opposes this tax, that there is no need for such a tax and that, if it becomes the government in the future, it will repeal such a tax. I believe that any reasonable thinking Australian has to accept that there is a need to crack down on fringe benefit lurks. Without doubt it has become a very serious method of tax avoidance in the community. Worst of all, it has been a method of tax avoidance available to the upper levels of our society and certainly not applicable to those on a weekly wage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 are designed to clamp down on the use of private motor cars, free or low interest loans, the release of debts, the payment of private expenses, free or subsidised residential accommodation and free or discounted goods and services. All of these fringe benefits undoubtedly have been offered to employees and undoubtedly it has become a rort. There was no doubt that something had to be done. The Democrats recognised that and adopted an attitude that we would negotiate with the Government, slug it out with the Government and try to get the worst features, the unfair features, of the tax modified.

Essentially the need for a clamp-down on a fringe benefit rort was there and something had to be done. It would have been very easy for us to have joined with the Opposition and said: `Right. We will just flatly oppose this tax'. Then the inequities of fringe benefits would have persisted in the community. But we did not adopt that attitude. We negotiated with the Government, and I believe the Australian Democrats can be very proud of the very considerable concessions made by the Government as a result of our negotiations with it. For instance, our negotiations with the Government on fringe benefits on motor cars, concluded only last night, will result in that tax being reduced by about one-third. About $200m is involved in a very simple reduction of the percentages. The Government argued that it wanted to raise $370m through the car fringe benefits tax. If one looked at the way the tax was to apply, realistically it would not have raised $370m but something more like $500m. It was very difficult to convince the Government that its figures were wrong; in fact it has not yet conceded that its figures were wrong.

What did we do? We got together all the motor car manufacturers and the trade unions, discussed the matter with various State Labor governments and came up with a formula with which all of those bodies agreed. We put it to the Government and the Government has finally been prepared to concede our point of view. As a result of that the scale will be reduced. The rate on motor cars travelling between 0 and 15,000 kilometres a year will be maintained at 24 per cent. For cars travelling between 15,000 and 25,000 kilometres a year, the tax will be reduced to 18 per cent of the value of the motor car. For cars travelling between 25,000 and 40,000 kilometres a year, the tax will be 10 per cent; and for cars travelling over 40,000 kilometres a year, the tax will be 6 per cent. That is pretty much in line with the agreement reached with the motor car industry as a whole, that is, what it thought was reasonable. It asked for three categories of tax-one at 16 per cent, one at 12 per cent and one at 8 per cent.

If one looks at the proposal in detail, one finds that what has finally been agreed to by the Government is pretty much in line with what the industry said was reasonable under all the circumstances. The industry was prepared to concede that a rort was going on with company cars being supplied to employees who were not using those motor cars for business purposes but purely to drive to and from work. That was a very considerable concession by the Government and a considerable victory for the Democrats. It was achieved by getting in there, getting the various parties together and negotiating.

The Government can reasonably be criticised on the ground that the fringe benefits legislation is extremely complex; it is. We would have liked it to have been less so, and I believe that could have been done. For instance, on the motor car tax it was not impossible to have applied a flat rate of tax on one or two categories of motor car and to have raised quite easily the same amount of revenue of $370m. On 500,000 motor cars it represents a tax of about $730 per car per year. The Government could have adopted an approach of applying a flat tax on one or two categories. However, the Government was anxious not to change its approach. It believes that delineating all the different uses for company cars will be a fairer way of doing it. It will certainly be a more expensive way of doing it. But when it was all considered we felt that we could push the matter so far and no further. It was probably not in our province to change substantially the philosophy that the Government used to levy these various taxes.

There were other inequities which were very obvious to us and which have been addressed by the Government. For instance, when we first discussed this matter with the Government late last year, in September or October, we said that it was very unfair that the Government should impose additional fringe benefit taxes on charitable institutions, non-profit institutions. The Government agreed and said that it would look into the matter. When the legislation came through we found that the Government had not honoured its commitment in this area. Discussions over the last two days have resulted in the Government's agreeing to an amendment so that existing genuine charitable organisations will not be disadvantaged. That amendment will be moved during the Committee stage, as will the amendment relating to the percentage taxes on the value of new cars to which I have already alluded. That amendment has already been circulated.

The Opposition has said that it would have been fairer if this fringe benefits tax had been levied on the employee rather than the employer. The argument goes that it is a benefit to the employee and that therefore he or she should be subject to the tax. I pointed that out in the Senate six or eight months ago as being a fairer way to apply the tax. It undoubtedly is. However, it suffers from the practical problem that it is very difficult to police such a tax. In fact, the existing tax law says that fringe benefits in the hands of employees should be taxed. That is clearly spelled out in section 26c of the Act. The problem is that the present system simply has not worked. People have ignored the value of fringe benefits.

The Commissioner of Taxation has been unwilling or unable to catch up with people ignoring the tax. In most cases there has been no formal valuation and no one checking the system. It has been left to people's better natures to comply with the law. I was interested to learn only today when talking to various ministers of religion who were concerned about the way this tax will impinge on them that they are one of the few sections of the community who make clear what their fringe benefits are. Unfortunately, the bulk of the community has not been doing that and the system of taxing the employee has not worked. In practical politics, to clamp down on the rorts in the fringe benefit area the Government has resorted to taxing the employer and leaving it to the employer to recoup the value of that tax from the employee to the extent that the employer feels that that should be done. In the short term probably it will not involve the employee in any great additional tax. The employer probably will not bother to take the value of the tax from the salary or wages of the employee. However, in the long term this tax undoubtedly will have the effect of making it very unlikely that employers will indiscriminately hand out fringe benefits which are taxable.

There is a long list of speakers on this matter. I do not wish to take up any more time than is necessary to go through the details of the taxes. Lots of points still need clarification. They can be debated in the Committee stage. For instance, how does the tax apply to free accommodation for farm labourers, to cases of people living on the premises of a business, and so forth? All these areas are of concern to various sectors of the community. We have discussed them with the Government. A letter from the Commissioner of Taxation clarifies many of these matters. The facts are that in opposition one can only amend legislation and try to reduce the worst effects of it where they are seen to apply.

Fundamentally, one cannot change the philosophy of the legislation. We believe that the fringe benefit tax, particularly with the modifications on taxes on motor cars, is fairly reasonable. It is complicated, but at least it addresses the unfairness and various inequities that were applying in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you table the letter from the Commissioner? That would be very helpful.
—The letter has already been circulated. It is available.
—We have not seen it.
—I am afraid that I do not have the letter with me but it can be made available. It is for publication.

SPEECH.PARA: In opposition we cannot force the Government to change its policies. Particularly, we cannot force the Government to change policies in critical areas of the balance of payments problem and our investment policy. The Democrats are very concerned about the direction the economy is taking and the present Government policies in these areas. The Government's reaction to the problems with the balance of payments and the huge foreign debt has been to cut expenditure, slow growth, and increase interest rates. We are very critical of these policies as being absolutely the wrong approach to the problem. We would have preferred to see the Government directing resources into developing industries rather than simply cutting expenses, which will have the inevitable effect of placing the burden of the problems of the economy on the backs of working Australians rather than where it should be-in the area of development-and stopping the enormous profits that are being made on the stock exchange at the moment. These are fundamental matters of Government policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is profit a dirty word?

—It is not a dirty word but it is very unfair that one person, namely, Mr Holmes a Court, can make $400m on share speculations over a few months, mainly tax free. If the Government is to place additional burdens on the community as a whole, as it is threatening to do with its cutbacks in expenditure and in slowing down growth generally, it has to at least stop the enormous tax free profits that are being made right now through speculation on the stock exchange, which benefits nobody and creates not one additional job. These are important and fundamental matters. I mention them only because there is no doubt that this is an additional tax on employers and as such will have its effect on the economy as a whole. As I said, we agree with and support the tax that had to be applied. With the changes that we have been able to wring from the Government-I think that that is the right expression as this has been an extremely difficult period for us in negotiating with the Government, which has not given in easily but has been at least prepared to talk-we now support the legislation with the amendments to be moved at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of the debate on the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill the Senate should recall that it is now about eight months since the Government announced this tax package. It is only in the last three weeks that some of the crucial legislation has been introduced into the Parliament by the Australian Labor Party tax junkies. While we could quite well accept that there are some delays between policy announcements and the introduction of legislation a delay of eight months amounts to contempt not only of the Parliament but also of the business community. The business community is trying very hard to make crucial decisions in the light of not knowing the basic details of what this Government is all about. It is bad enough to inflict this essentially anti-business legislation on the private sector without at the same time subjecting it to uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: It is becoming fair to say that the delay of these taxation Bills until the closing weeks of this parliamentary session is a deliberate ploy by the Government to ensure that they receive minimum exposure and public scrutiny and that is absolutely disgraceful. The public of Australia deserves to be able to assess every bit of legislation at length. It should not be rammed through the House of Representatives, as the Government has done, and then rammed through this place. This is particularly true of the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986 and its companion Bills, which effectively visit the employers of this country with a Federal version of a payroll tax that is far more complex and damaging than any other form of tax. It will take employers more than a couple of weeks to assess the likely costs they will incur under this tax. It is very hard for us to evaluate in the debate now the damaging aspects of this tax.

The fringe benefits tax would have to be one of the most dishonest and cowardly taxation measures introduced into the Parliament. This is because the tax is not levied on the recipients. It is levied on their employers, the providers of the benefits. That, too, is disgraceful. The Government may talk about administrative convenience, but the fact remains that it is levying the tax in this way for the crudest of political reasons. Let us not forget what this Government is doing to the employers of this country and what it has done to the farmers and other people who are less likely to vote for it. It is simply homing in on the people who are less likely to vote for it. The Hawke Government has made a judgment that the direct taxing of the benefits in the hands of employees would cause a massive voter backlash and infuriate the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Let us not forget the ACTU which, hand in hand with the Government, runs this country.

The last time a government attempted to tax fringe benefits in respect of both housing and the private use of company vehicles was in the disastrous 1974 Budget of the Whitlam Government. That Government soon experienced the political backlash of the imposition of that tax and withdrew the tax on company cars the very next year. The Hawke Government is now treading the same path, but with more guile and far less honesty. It was estimated by K. M. G. Hungerfords in April that the most likely cost of the fringe benefits tax to the corporate sector would be an extra 12 per cent in costs at a time when company profitability is faltering. We have just heard Senator Siddons say in effect that profit is a dirty word. He picked on the more affluent in our country, giving them as examples. We are not talking purely about the affluent. We are talking about everyone who is to be affected by this iniquitous tax-many of the small business people, farmers, charities and all those who are not at the higher end of the scale. Too often it is forgotten that this tax will fall on some unprofitable companies.

There has also been a lack of consideration of the employment effects that will flow from the tax. In Western Australia, initial estimates of the fringe benefits tax by the Confederation of Western Australian Industry put the annual full year cost to employers at $80m. In anyone's language that is a large amount to take from a local economy. It is equally important to remember that the direct cost of the tax is only one aspect of the additional costs that will be imposed on the private sector. A tax that is assessed and payable quarterly-and within six weeks of the end of each quarter-will provide an absolute administrative nightmare. To substantiate the nightmare, the Government has had to send out 700,000 to 800,000 fifty-six page booklets to explain the tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one can understand it.

—Exactly. That is the feedback coming back to all of us. People cannot understand it. Let us consider the costs that have been incurred just by sending out these booklets. We cannot find out the exact costs, but let us just take postage. The cost of postage to send out between 700,000 and 800,000 booklets is nearly half a million dollars. What is the administrative cost on top of that?
—Walsh said $3m the other night.

—I thank the honourable senator. It has cost $3m to send out a booklet that people cannot understand and that will be an absolute rock around their necks anyway. The comedy is that last year the Prime Minister was proclaiming that simplicity in taxation was the objective of his Government. That is an absolute laugh when we realise that the Bills before us today, together with certain parts of the tax package passed at the end of last year, have simply created another 350 pages of tax legislation to add to the 1,100 pages of the Income Tax Assessment Act as it stood last September. Tax legislation has become more simple, if we are to believe the Prime Minister. Yet we have an additional 350 pages of legislation. With legislation of this kind, no wonder it is estimated that some 54,000 people employed in the private sector are devoting their time solely to compliance with government regulation, and that was prior to the imposition of this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government should consider that the administrative burdens placed on the private sector contribute nothing to revenue, but diminish the capacity of businesses to pay their taxes. The whole concept of the fringe benefits tax takes no account of the capacity of employers to pay and the serious effect the tax will have on profit and employment levels. Such insensitivity falls very heavily on the motor vehicle industry. The Government has chosen repeatedly to ignore the problems that are being experienced by the motor vehicle industry. Even Senator Button, at Question Time this week, repeatedly said that the motor vehicle industry is overstating the facts. That is quite wrong, because independent people have said that the motor vehicle industry has already been affected by the impending imposition of this tax. I was, at least, pleased to hear Senator Maguire say in his speech that the industry had been affected by the depreciation of the dollar, forcing up the price of imports. It has also been affected by the high interest rates and the costs associated with the introduction of unleaded petrol. Does the industry really need an additional tax that will cost it more?

Even without the fringe benefits tax, the motor vehicle industry is confronted with the fact that the average motorist will now retain his existing car longer in the face of increasing replacement costs. Clearly, the announcement of the fringe benefits tax has already had an adverse effect on car purchases by employers. The industry has had the worst March quarter for eight years, with a 22 per cent decline in total sales, a 33 per cent decline in registrations and a 40 per cent decline in the sale of commercial vehicles. Yet the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has said that the decline in figures has been caused by an extra good sales year last year. If that is not absurd, what is? Given the dramatic slump in sales in recent months it appears more than likely that 35,000 sales will be lost to the car industry in the course of this year, a proposition which, quite frankly, this Government is treating flippantly.

On a conservative estimate, 10,000 jobs stand to be lost in the car industry. We should also remember the forecast of 25,000 job losses in the car industry, a forecast made not by employers but by the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia. This Government continually says that our estimates regarding the effect on employment of the entertainment tax last year are incorrect, yet the Minister lumps together all employment figures regarding the hospitality industry, including hotel staffs and everything else. The Government is still saying that our figures are wrong. They have been proven to be absolutely accurate. Do we really have to prove these figures relating to the decrease in jobs as well? When a car costing $15,000 is assessed at a value of $1,500, providing that it has travelled 30,000 kilometres, the incentive for employers to buy smaller and cheaper cars is quite obvious. This, in turn, makes a mockery of the local content policy of the Government as it is the larger models which achieve 85 per cent local content and which will be avoided in fleet purchases where a long term decline of between 12 and 15 per cent is anticipated.

It is interesting that the Government, of course, is also very generously offering two methods of assessment for the calculation of the fringe benefits tax on company-owned vehicles-the need to keep a daily log-book, or the option of assessment by operating costs. Of course, this is an absolutely dubious and very costly proposition. But such an assessment system as keeping a daily log-book requires careful paper work from employees, who, quite frankly, in some cases, are too jolly busy to do that, and, in other cases, might not even have the capacity to do it in terms of knowledge of how to go about it. This Government seems to forget that company cars are not merely made available to the higher echelons and executives as part of salary packages but are often supplied to low paid employees for simple reasons of convenience. But once again, like trying to define legitimate entertainment expenses and trying to define this tax, this Government does not care to draw any distinction whatsoever: Lump them all in together and hope for the best. But the larger the fleet the more likely it will be that employers will adopt the statutory formula of between 10 per cent and 24 per cent of cost according to mileage. It defies logic to deny that the imposition of this tax will damage the car industry, and it is worth considering that with the consequent loss of sales tax, company tax and income tax paid by employers and employees alike in this industry, together with the increased social security payments to those who lose their jobs, instead of the $350m that the Government expects to recoup from the car industry it may, in fact, net about $49m if it is lucky.

This tax junkie Government has sought to imply that the fringe benefits tax applies mainly to executives avoiding high marginal rates of tax through generous allowances and the use or concessional purchases of expensive vehicles. In truth, the fringe benefits as defined in this legislation cover a far wider spectrum of the work force. It was estimated last year that as many as 175,000 employees in Western Australia could be affected, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Altogether, 44,000 employees receive assistance for private travel; 49,000 receive a payment for their private phone; 34,000 receive accommodation; 26,000 enjoy an employer contribution for medical expenses or health insurance; 25,000 get subsidised or paid electricity; 23,000 obtain free or discounted holiday travel; 21,000 receive entertainment allowances; and 14,000 have low interest loans, usually for housing, and 3,000 of them are, of course, bank employees. It is inevitable that thousands of these people will ultimately have to pay more tax when employers can no longer afford some of these benefits, and a smaller number may well lose their jobs as a direct consequence of this tax.

It has been said on a number of occasions but, unfortunately, never publicly by Government members that what they are hoping is that, in the final analysis, perhaps, many of the private companies will simply not be able to afford to continue paying the fringe benefits tax, so, therefore, it will be put on to the employees. Is that their final aim and ambition through this tax-to put it on to the employees so that they are paying more tax?

The mining industry is a major employer within Western Australia and will be a major payer of the new tax. This is worth considering, especially at a time when declining export returns are already threatening profitability, and of course, let us not forget about the threat of a gold tax as well. The Australia-wide cost of fringe benefits tax to the mining industry is likely to be $30m, half of which will be levied on mining operations within my State of Western Australia. The isolation and climatic extremes of major mining centres have required companies to offer subsidised accommodation and other benefits, such as holiday travel, or return travel to capital cities. They are essential inducements to getting employees to go into these far away places; they are not part of any scheme for tax minimisation. Once again, the offer of alternative methods of assessment for subsidised housing, in practical terms, gives little choice to employers.

The second method of a statutory formula, applying a proportion of adult full-time earnings in the mining industry to each unit of accommodation, fails to take into account the great range of quality in the accommodation provided. The individual method of 60 per cent of the market value of the right to occupy accommodation creates the difficulty of assessing this market value. But it should not, however, be assumed that the cost of employee housing is a problem for only the mining industry and remote regions of Western Australia. It is, of course, equally of concern for a major employer in the south-west of the State, the Bunnings timber company. A firm of this size supplies 200 of its employees with vehicles, on the basis of administrative convenience rather than employment packages, and it has over 400 housing units for employees engaged in timber milling. At a very rough estimate, a company in this position could find itself paying $200,000 on the value of the vehicles and $300,000 on that of the housing. Even a well-managed and profitable company would find it very difficult to absorb a sudden increase without a major decline in profits or price rises.

The Government has failed to consider important questions of equity in the calculation of the value of this kind of company housing. For example, housing provided in an isolated mill settlement such as Deanmill would have absolutely no practical market value if the company mill did not exist in the same area. Equally, there is a major question mark as to the value of housing in a centre such as Walpole on the south coast, where the rental value of a fairly basic home is of considerable value in the summer months and of little value in the winter months. There is no guarantee under this legislation, however, that these factors will receive proper consideration in the assessment of the value of employee housing. Why? It is because, like so many other pieces of legislation that this Government is putting forward, it is all too difficult. Should the timber industry suffer a general downturn, the effects of the tax will, of course, continue to apply to the detriment of the whole economy in the south-west of Western Australia.

Of course, let us not forget the 200,000 Australians who are employed in the finance industry. Perhaps half of these receive some sort of subsidised loan. People might well and truly say: `That's fine. Why should they receive a subsidised loan when I don't?' But in the case of bank employees, a fringe benefit of this kind merely compensates for the fact that even after 13 years of service a bank officer will still receive 6 per cent below average weekly earnings. This again illustrates the point that the tax will have a major effect on the employment conditions of ordinary Australians. The impact of this tax on a bank the size of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd will be at least $10m to $15m-exclusive of administration costs, which will be very heavy indeed.

The magnitude of administrative costs will result from the number of employees and the variety of benefits, with varying allowances for non-metropolitan areas. The quarterly calculation of this iniquitous tax will absorb an enormous amount of computer time, as the experience of a similar tax in New Zealand has already shown. In New Zealand, when this type of tax was introduced, it meant that a team of five to 10 data processors worked flat out for three weeks changing all the computer systems. Of course, to do that also required extra staff to back them up. But this quarterly payment, within six weeks of the end of the quarter, has once again not been given any consideration, in view of what we already know about similar taxes. Even again, in New Zealand, consideration is being given to making it an annual payment and not a quarterly payment. Indeed, banks may, in effect, choose to pay extra tax rather than claim possible deductions and allowances, because of that administrative cost. We should also be considering this point: If the banking industry, with its sophisticated computers and accounting expertise, foresees this kind of problem, the impact of the fringe benefits tax on less expert and less profitable firms will surely be more damaging, with calculations to be made within six weeks.

The Government has overlooked the fact that the tax will be levied on bank employees living overseas in the first year of such a transfer, when they will be counted as Australian residents for tax purposes, and this tax will, therefore, be levied on expense allowances for locations such as New York and Japan, where they are necessarily high because of local living costs. Double taxation agreements provide no protection here, since they cover income tax rather than indirect taxes. Whilst the banks may attempt to maintain existing benefits, it is surely inevitable that their employees will suffer in the long term, when such benefits will not be available.

Only in recent days have many of the small business enterprises begun to realise the true impact of this tax and the bureaucratic nightmare that it will involve. Any small business enterprise-farms are included-organised as a company faces a fringe benefits tax bill on the private use of cars by family members held in the name of the company. Small businessmen and farmers are often employers on a casual basis only, and what this Government is offering is purely and simply the removal of a benefit which applied in cases where employers could not afford to pay higher wages. They are sufficiently hampered already by government paperwork, at Federal and State levels, and this new quarterly imposition will really be another millstone around their necks when, as we are already well aware, they are paying enough to their accountants and tax consultants. In short, they will find that they can afford neither the cashing up of employees in lieu of benefits nor the direct or indirect cost of the tax. Their solution will be to cease employing other than family members.

It is important for us to remember that this Hawke socialist Government has been very courageous this time. It has broken new ground with this legislation by extending the fringe benefits tax to charities and non-profit organisations, which of course hitherto have been exempt from other forms of taxation. It is hardly a major concession to exempt from the tax the accommodation benefits supposedly enjoyed by staff living in to care for the aged and handicapped, but it has, as I say, reached new depths by now deciding that it will also levy a tax on the presbyteries, rectories and manses of Australia. A large number of welfare organisations and charitable institutions with modest administrative budgets will find themselves paying the tax, but of course their donors will be very comforted to know that the Federal Government will be receiving a little portion of each gift that they make. It was stated on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television on Friday 23 May that the Salvation Army in each State could be paying $50,000 in tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is disgusting.

—It is disgusting, Senator Boswell, when it affects groups such as the Salvation Army and also organisations such as the Jesus People in Perth who provide accommodation and outreach for homeless youth. When we think that these groups will also be hit by this tax, it is nothing short of a disgrace. Employees in such organisations need vehicles at home to answer calls at all hours of the day and night, and they so often need to garage them simply because it is unsafe to leave them on the premises. Yet the tax will be payable on these vehicles and on the value of accommodation provided to resident hostel managers. We might also ask why the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) assented to the levying of the tax on National Trust accommodation provided to wardens of the historic properties that it maintains and opens to the public. As a voluntary organisation the Trust cannot afford, for example, to pay full salaries to the 14 wardens at its Western Australian properties.
—They are going to close down four in Queensland.

—Heaven knows how many the Trust will have to close down in Western Australia, too, because it simply cannot afford to pay the tax. It will be impossible for it to continue with 14 properties if this tax is allowed to go through. This Government may not know or care that the charter of the Trust excludes it from deriving income from its properties and thereby gaining rental income. If the National Trust in Western Australia alone has to pay a fringe benefits tax bill of $18,000 each year, it will be forced to reduce the advisory services it provides to government, including local government. It would be a tragedy if the stupidity of this Government put our heritage at risk of vandalism or forced the National Trust to cease restoring historic buildings and maintaining them for public enjoyment.

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes we are led to conclude that, at bottom, this Government has limited respect for voluntary organisations anyway. It will be of very little value to the Government to try to repair the damage to the voluntary sector by increasing its direct grants. This would be a classic illustration of bureaucratic fatuity-giving with one hand and taking with the other-to the ultimate administrative expense of the taxpayer. It would make no more sense than the supposed taxing of government departments who provide fringe benefits-an exercise, of course, that we could call fancy bookkeeping. The only solution to these injustices is to scrap the fringe benefits tax. It gives me great comfort to know that even if this tax is passed, with the aid of the Australian Democrats who have been doing a soft shoe shuffle on this issue for weeks, at least a future Liberal Government will repeal it. It is absolutely iniquitous and it should be rejected at all costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has heard some arguments put-very forcefully, may I say-by those who are opposed to the fringe benefits tax, but many speeches have been directed not so much against the fringe benefits tax as against taxation at all. Of course nobody likes paying tax, and why should we? There are some great free spirits around. I see Senator Boswell over there; he is a free spirit; as is Senator Robertson over here. They are men from the north, pioneers who do not like to be restrained by government; who would like, as it were, to live in the style of Crocodile Dundee. They may consider they need no government, no services, and therefore need pay no tax. The difficulty is that many of us live in what I might say are less pristine-some people would say more civilised--
—Less desirable.

—That is right, Senator Robertson; we live in less desirable parts of the world. As a result of that we have to have government, and we have to have roads, electric light and all those sorts of things because we live in society. As a result, we have to have taxes to pay for those services. We even have to have taxes to pay for the eminent people in this chamber.
—We have to pay for your light and your roads.

—The Leader of the National Party in the Senate is a very eminent figure and it is proper that the people of Australia pay to have him in this chamber. So there is really no question that taxes are needed, and the real question is who will pay the taxes. That is what the debate on this legislation centres on. It is clear that no more tax will be raised as a result of this measure. To use an expression I heard used recently, rather clumsily, though perhaps it indicates what it is all about, this measure is revenue neutral. In other words, it is not a question of raising more taxes; really it is a question of redistributing the burden amongst those people who have to pay them. Of course those who will have to pay more, who do not get what they used to get, will complain. I think we have to put up with that; why should not a person complain if he is going to lose a benefit? Was it not the Great Wobblies who said: `What's we got we hold'. That is really what this is about. Members of the Opposition quite eloquently and robustly have put an argument for those who presently have benefits as far as taxpaying goes which they want to hold on to.

SPEECH.PARA: Should they be allowed to hold onto those benefits, having enjoyed them for many years while other people have not enjoyed similar benefits? Is it not time for a redistribution of the tax burden towards those who have had a good go in the past and away from those who have had a poor go, in particular the pay as you earn people who now, under this general tax package, of which this fringe benefits measure is a part, will get a considerable reduction in the rate of tax they pay upon their income?

We have heard Senator Messner and Senator Knowles quite properly put forward arguments on behalf of charitable groups, but do those arguments hold water? The Director of the Australian Catholic Family Welfare Bureau in South Australia, the State from which Senator Messner comes, does not think so. I read from a Press clipping from the Australian Associated Press service of 28 May 1986. The headline is `Church group in favour of fringe tax', and it states:

Adelaide, May 28 AAP-The Federal Government should take an even tougher stand than the proposed fringe benefits tax if it was really serious about confronting social injustice, the South Australian Catholic Family Welfare Bureau said today.

Bureau Director Joseph O'Neill, who supports the proposed benefits tax, said it was generally the rich who enjoyed fringe benefits while the perks for the poor and low income earners were few and far between.
He said fringe benefits were just a way for high income earners to avoid paying tax, and that was manifestly unjust.
Mr O'Neill said the Government should get tougher and be prepared to tax the person who received the fringe benefit in every case and not the employer.

Let me make it quite clear that he says that the fringe benefits tax is more than justifiable. He says that in his capacity as the Director of the Australian Catholic Family Welfare Bureau. He does not think that this is an iniquitous tax. He does not think that charities are suffering as a result of all this. He puts his view forward, and puts it forward strongly. Let us be clear about this question of charities while we are on it. Everybody seems to have assumed that the charities are going to be taxed on the vehicles they use in the course of carrying out their charitable work, but, if the use of any vehicle is to be taxed, it is only the private use component that is to be so taxed. If people are making donations to charities for the cars and other things that are available as fringe benefits, should that not be revealed? Is it right that charities should get donations from the public and then use those donations to buy articles which are then used for private purposes? It is a matter of real concern and, from the sort of debate we have had so far about this it seems that there is an extensive use by charities of cars, and perhaps of other things, for private purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only some.

—Senator Grimes, in his usual charitable fashion, has raced to the aid of the poor and the charities of this country and said that only some charities do that. Let us hope that he is correct. If funds given to charities by donors are used extensively for the purchase of cars, which in turn are used for private purposes, something certainly ought to be done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Act is now a massive volume. It has come out in many editions over the years. It has perhaps been reprinted more often than the works of Shakespeare. Be that as it may, section 25 says, if I can paraphrase it, that people who earn income have to pay tax on it. Section 51 says that, in considering the income that people have earned, the losses and outgoings ought to be taken into account. It might be worthwhile reading section 51 (1). It states:

All losses and outgoings to the extent to which they are incurred in gaining or producing the assessable income or are necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for the purpose of gaining or producing such income, shall be allowable deductions except to the extent to which they are losses or outgoings of capital, or of a capital, private or domestic nature, or are incurred in relation to the gaining of production or exempt income.
We are soon to hear from Senator Boswell in this debate. He will make his usual quite brilliant contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Glad you recognise it.

—I certainly recognise that. Senator Boswell will no doubt deal with this point, but throughout this debate it should be remembered that anything that is expended on earning income is deductible. The whole argument is about whether or not elements which are not used in production ought to gain the same status as those elements which are used in gaining that income. In other words, the argument from those who oppose the fringe benefits Bills must be that expenditure on things not used in earning income should bear the same status as expenditure to earn income. Is that fair? A person can get sweat upon his brow, corns upon his hands and callouses upon his knees out there expending himself and expending all sorts of other things on earning income, yet the person who does not bear those marks of work and trade can gather the same benefits. In other words, there is no reward at all for the person who earns his bread by the sweat of his brow because he gets no more in deductions than the person who sits back and enjoys the benefits of a luxury car--
—What a stupid statement.

—Let us go through that. Senator Boswell says it is a stupid statement. It is very good that Senator Boswell is following me in this debate because he can explain why that is a stupid statement. Senator Boswell says it is a stupid statement but that is the situation. This shows that even amongst the great intellectuals of this world-I put Senator Boswell amongst them-there is a misconception of what this is all about because to say that that is stupid means that he cannot see that the items and goods being taxed here are items and goods which are not expended in the earning of income and which do not fall within section 51 of the Act. If they do fall within section 51 of the Act they are tax deductible and do not even have to be dealt with under the fringe benefits tax Bills. Unlike the fringe benefits tax Bills, no records are required to be kept. The person simply states that he had to buy a vehicle and that it is being used by his employees to carry coal to Newcastle or whatever else he wants to do. I was almost going to say to carry bananas to Queensland but I certainly will not do that. Nevertheless, if it is expended in doing that, it is deductible.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems that have arisen in this debate is that people think that what this legislation does is to tax items that are used in producing income, but quite clearly it does not. What we are talking about here are the fringe benefits as such-the person who gets the low rent, the free use of a car for his own purposes, low interest rates on his loan and those sorts of things which are not part of the employer's expenditure in earning income. Up until now the employer has used those to gain tax deductions. Honourable senators opposite have talked about the tax being unfair on the employer, but employers across the board have created this situation over the years. They are the ones who have come up with this scheme and have said to the employee: `I will not pay you $300 or $500 a week. I will pay you half of that and I will throw in the use of a car or give you a low rent home or a loan at low interest rates. That is what I will toss in'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or pay for your kids' schooling.

—Pay for the kids' schooling. I will get off that subject. In any event, that is what the employer says. He then claims that as a tax deductible item because he has expended it, he says, in earning income, but nobody pays tax on that, whereas if the person was paid his proper wage, he would have to pay tax. It is the employers who have created this whole scheme for avoiding taxes which would otherwise have to be paid on remuneration, so why should they not have to unravel that scheme? It is within their power to do that. That has been brought up in debate already. People have said that what is going to happen here is that there will be renegotiation of remuneration packages. What is wrong with that if that is the result that is going to come about? If one looks at the history of this matter, it was not the employees who said: `Give us $150 plus the use of a car and this and that'. The whole scheme was created by those employers who practise these sorts of things. All these Bills do is to say to these employers: `If you want to do it that way, if you want to create that scheme, good luck to you; but you will have to pay tax on it'. If they want to go back to the way that most people in this community are remunerated-that is, in terms of cash payments-the employees would pay tax. That is a matter for them. People have said that that is going to be hard on the employers, and so it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was talking about fringe benefits tax and seeking to demonstrate that the concept behind the tax was that of fairness.
—Use a bit of honesty. You're not in the legal profession now.

—I hear an interjection to the effect that the tax is not fair. Having heard the comments of Opposition members, led by the redoubtable Senator Boswell, who will be followed by other eminent speakers, it will be interesting to hear them justify why it is not fair for remuneration which includes fringe benefits to bear the same tax as remuneration which does not. What is wrong with a remuneration that consists of $400 a week, plus $100 in fringe benefits, bearing the same tax as would an unsupplemented sum of $500 a week?
—Under this system that will not happen because you're applying a flat rate to it.

—That is not quite right. The whole purpose of the tax is to this effect: If an employer wants to pay remuneration in such a way that up to now has obtained a tax benefit, from now on if that system is followed the employer has to see that the proper tax is paid on that remuneration. Until now the employer has paid out the remuneration by way of cash and by way of fringe benefits. He has discounted all that off his earnings because under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act he has attributed all of it as being expended in the earning of income. That position will still remain except insofar as the payments include fringe benefits which have not been expended for the purposes of earning income but expended to give somebody an advantage over other people who have their remuneration paid simply in cash.

SPEECH.PARA: What is unfair about that? Why should people who until now have had an advantage because they have their remuneration paid by way of a car, or a low rent home, or by obtaining a loan at a low rate of interest, be advantaged by way of remuneration over those who receive their remuneration in cash?

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have your heart in it, do you?
—Of course I have my heart in it because it is a matter of justice and morality.
—How much is your fee for this one?

—The fee for this one is the satisfaction of knowing that I am talking on a matter which will introduce a great deal of fairness and will bring a great deal of equity into the taxation system. It will mean that people who up until now have missed out will be advantaged. Those who have had the free kick in front of goal will have to take their place in the ruck and earn their kicks from now on.
—Are you referring to the farmers who are finding themselves in a difficult situation?

—If we are talking about small business, it is interesting to see that the average income of proprietors of unincorporated non-farm businesses increased by two per cent in real terms between 1982-83 to 1984-85, and in the same period wages have fallen by two per cent in real terms.
