When one talks about the impact on small businesses other than farms, one must bear in mind that their income has increased by two per cent in real terms over that period and that their overheads have fallen in that wages in the same period have fallen by two per cent in real terms. If one looks at the whole economy-this is almost a cultural rather than an economic question when one thinks about it-it is a matter of whether we as a nation, as a group of people pulling together as a country, are willing to say that everybody should be given a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us deal with the concept of a fair go. People are saying that the car industry will be affected by what we do in this legislation. For the purposes of the argument, if we want to give an advantage to the car industry why not give the industry a bounty and pass that provision through the Parliament? That would be a matter of expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who pays the tax on that?

—Senator Boswell would allow the car industry to take advantage of an unfair tax system. If he wants to give the industry an advantage, which obviously he wants to do when one considers his argument, why not do it out in the open by giving the industry a bounty? Why not do that, rather than going about it by an elaborate and labyrinthine mechanism by saying that we will give the car industry an advantage by allowing people to gain an unfair advantage in the payment of their income tax? In other words, the matter should be put out on the table. If the industry is so fragile and so unable to stand a system in which people pay according to what is earned, let us make some accommodation for the industry, if that is what the Parliament thinks, but let that be done through the Parliament rather than through a backdoor method of allowing fringe benefits to be tax deductible.

SPEECH.PARA: If one follows that through, one could apply it to people who obtain benefits by way of low housing rents or low interest loans. If people are to be subsidised and dealt with in that way let Parliament debate it on that basis rather than on the basis that the taxation system is unfair because allegedly some people are being disadvantaged in some way. Of course, they will be disadvantaged by those provisions because they will be less well-off than they were before. But the people who were less well-off before will find themselves a lot better off because they will enjoy tax reductions. Furthermore, an advantage will flow to the very people Opposition members are now trying to protect by the backdoor method of giving them an advantage they do not deserve. By the way, they are the very people who will have a lower rate of tax imposed upon them. The Opposition is saying that not only should people get advantages by being able to drive cars, obtain free travel above everybody else and obtain advantages in the sort of house in which they live by free loans or other means, but they should in addition have tax reductions. The Opposition wishes those people to be advantaged to the disadvantage of the very poor and the less well-off in the community. The difficulty about the Opposition's proposition is that it wants the system to go one way. The Opposition should listen to the man who was mentioned before--

TALK.START.PARA: —From Snowy River?

—No, the man from the Australian Catholic Family Welfare Bureau-somebody who should be dear to the heart of Senator Parer, who professes a strong and firm belief in social justice. He should listen to that man who takes the Government to task for not imposing a greater fringe benefits tax than at present. He takes the view that the poor and lower income earners are very disadvantaged under the present system. The Opposition, through Senator Parer, Senator Boswell and Senator Brownhill, shows that it is misguided. It wants to give double advantage to those people who elected Opposition members to this chamber. They are proposing a double advantage again and again through the position they are taking on fringe benefits. When those opposite rise to speak in this debate I want to hear from them the answer to this question: Why should people who get an advantage-which does not come from the fact that they are working and producing income, but rather from the fact that employers want to give them a benefit which other people do not have-not have those advantages taxed and paid for by those who are on a lower rate of interest?

SPEECH.PARA: This is part of a package which this Government has most successfully put forward. It includes the accord, which has kept wages at a low rate-perhaps lower than they should be. This is something which the previous government was unable to do. If one looks at the evidence and at the record of how this legislation came before the Parliament one can see that a great advantage has been given to business by the fact that wages have fallen where profits have been at record heights since this Government has been in office. When some sacrifice is asked for from that sector, which that sector is prepared to make, or at least the better part of it, honourable senators opposite unfortunately expend time and effort on a brief which I do not think they can-if they look in their heart of hearts-put forward and agree is a reasonable proposition. How do we overcome-we will hear this from honourable senators opposite when they get up-the annual growth rate of over 5 per cent in the three years since this Government came to office? This is not the first time this has been put. It has been put ad nauseam in this place since I have been here, but has never been answered. Perhaps this is the night when we will hear the question answered. How do those opposite explain that for three years Australia has had a real economic growth of around 5 per cent per annum? How do they explain the fact that unemployment has fallen and that employment has risen? How do we overcome the fact that industry has boomed? How do we overcome the fact that the car plan and the steel industry plan are accepted by industry? How do those opposite answer all those questions? They really cannot answer. In return for what this Government has done they have offered what could only be described as a scheme which would have been put to Alice in Wonderland at the Mad Hatter's tea party, and with about as much chance of success.

The fringe benefits tax is a tax which is part not only of an overall taxation plan but also of an overall plan to re-establish Australia, its industry, and its people, people who are confident that a tax system is working very fairly in their favour, and to ensure that industry will continue to expand. The low level of industrial disputes is an indication that people now feel that they have some sort of stake in this community and that they can go forward under the leadership of this Government, confident that they will all be looked after by both business and unions, to ensure that the poor and the rich, those who are advantaged and those who are disadvantaged, can go forward as a nation instead of under the opposite prescription which is down on a particular section, down on the unions, down on the people at work, and down particularly on those who have borne the burden of taxation until now. The proposition put forward by those opposite indicates that there will be no relief in taxation for those who have suffered for so long under the present system. A rejection of this fringe benefits tax is an affirmation that the two nations of which Disraeli used to speak will be established well and truly in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to an incredible contribution by Senator Cooney who has tried to defend the fringe benefits tax. He has certainly convinced no one in Parliament-certainly not on this side, and there was no one on the other side to listen to his contribution. Not one honourable senator from the other side had the interest in the fringe benefits tax legislation to come in and listen to his speech. The fringe benefits tax will affect the farmers, the graziers, the car industry, local governments and State governments, mining companies, and charities. They have all been frantically worried about this fringe benefits tax since it was proposed eight or nine months ago. They are more worried since the little purple booklet went out to 750,000 frantically worried business people who keep ringing my office. I am sure that other senators have had the same sort of telephone calls. No one has been able to make head or tail out of it. To my way of thinking this shows that this is a government in disarray.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a country which, in the Government's own words, is becoming a banana republic. That is correct; the overseas debt hit $80 billion. We are overspending by $1.5 billion a month. Of course, the socialist answer to this is to tax heavily the productive sector-the small business person, the farmer, the miner, the exporter. The Australian Labor Party has really scraped the bottom of the barrel this time. It will tax the blind, the cripple, the mentally retarded, and every charity which is trying to raise money to provide facilities for its own people. Fringe benefits tax is nothing short of a tax on an employer who has already paid tax. Even Senator Cooney must be able to see that. A business produces wealth; to produce more wealth it has to have a car, or it has to provide a house, in the case of a miner. So the business or the mining company is doubly taxed, once when it pays income tax and the second time when it provides a tool or item of equipment to produce wealth. Even Senator Cooney must realise that. I do not have his way with words; he is an eminent barrister, but one only has to be a man of the people to understand that one is paying tax twice.

At a time when Australia is crying out for leadership, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) once again showed how he caved in to the Australian Council of Trade Union pressure last year at the National Taxation Summit when the unions told the Government that they wanted a fringe benefits tax but that they did not want their workers to pay for it. I suppose that that is a reasonable response from the unions but it is certainly not a reasonable response from the Government which is not here to give the unions everything they want. It is here to govern in the best interests of Australia. It is failing miserably to do that. The fringe benefits tax is short sighted. It will result in a massive loss of jobs. Already, the car industry is in dire straits with massive sackings taking place. In Queensland car registrations are down 28 per cent; in most other States they are down 30 per cent. That is resulting in the loss of many thousands of jobs. While the registrations are down 30 per cent, interest rates are going through the roof,

Many honourable senators would have had representations from car dealers who say that they are in dire straits, in financial trouble. A lot of them are saying that there is no future for them in the long term. We must bring the Australian Democrats into this because they are doing the usual thing and making the usual grandstand play about the car industry. They have told the Government that unless it agrees to some minor amendments they will not pass the fringe benefits tax legislation. But in the next breath they say that if the Government really does not get enough revenue they will guarantee that they will put extra revenue legislation through. They are having two bob each way, the way they usually do. They are offering absolutely nothing. We are becoming used to the Democrats doing this sort of thing. The amendments they put through are not worth the paper they are written on.

I say to Senator Macklin, who is sitting next to me, that we saw a classic example of the Democrats' concern regarding the capital gains tax when they said that they would reduce a capital gains tax on the goodwill component of farms. That is useless because there is no goodwill component of a farm. I asked the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, whether he had ever heard of goodwill relating to a farm and he had not. I asked the National Farmers Federation and it had never heard of it either.

The Queensland Country Life newspaper exposed the Democrats' offer on the capital gains tax and the goodwill component of a farm, saying that it was not worth the paper it was written on. It advised its readers that the only way they could defeat a fringe benefits tax and a capital gains tax was to vote for the National and Liberal parties and that is the best bit of advice it has ever offered its readers. I commend Queensland Country Life for giving that advice, and that advice cost only 50c. Everyone should subscribe to that paper if that is the sort of good, sound economic advice it offers its readers.

The Australian Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries estimates that 90,000 fewer cars will be sold in 1986 than were sold in 1985 and a further 25,000 fewer will be sold in each subsequent year. At this stage I believe that we should look at what revenue the Government will lose if the fringe benefits tax on cars is applied. I point out that I am referring to motor vehicle registrations only, not to houses or any other item to which the fringe benefits tax applies. Let us just look at cars. At the rate of car registrations, sales tax will be down $82m, import duty will be down $15m, the loss of company tax will be $49m and the loss of income tax due to the retrenchment of workers will be $70m. The total Commonwealth revenue loss will be $276m. Then, of course, there is the loss to State revenue. The loss in payroll tax will be $8m, stamp duty $11m, registration $3m, making a total loss of $298m. Even if that claim is an ambit one and even if we halve it, it is still a considerable amount of money. However, that is what the Australian Federal Chamber of Automobile Industries estimates the Government will lose in revenue.

I point out that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) said in his second reading speech that the revenue raised in the first year would be $330m. I ask members of the Australian Labor Party-Senator Cooney is in the chamber, as is Senator Maguire from South Australia, the scourge of Queensland; he is a good man on figures-to tell me whether it is worth the pain to raise $30m, $60m or whatever if the result puts workers on the dole, destroys factories that manufacture motor vehicles components and causes misery and family breakdowns due to the pressure of people going out of work. The fringe benefits tax will affect many areas. State governments will be forced to pay tax on every policeman's house, every school teacher's house and every hospital employee's home.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an uncaring Party.

—The Government does not care about the worker. I think that Senator Jones is of the Australian Workers Union faction. I know Senator Black is. I would like to know what they are doing to represent their union members.
—Wrong one.

—I can never keep up with the factions; I would need to be given a sheet of paper every day telling me of the changes. I would like to know what the AWU is going to do about all the benefits and jobs that will be lost to its members. Honourable senators opposite are now springing to action to defend the cause.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I would like to correct Senator Boswell. I do not belong to the AWU faction. I think that he ought to get his facts correct.
—That is not a point of order.
—I apologise to Senator Jones if I have offended him by associating him with the AWU.
—Don't spoil a good speech by worrying about facts.

—Let me get back to my speech because I know that Senator Cooney is terribly interested in this matter. He is hearing from a man who has been in business rather than one who has an academic background like most ALP senators. I have actually been there and done that, which is more than Senator Cooney has done. He has been locked away in the courtrooms of this country. If he listens to me he may even learn something. It will cost the Queensland Government alone $80m to $100m to continue to provide services in the rural areas of Queensland where most of the houses for the public servants-the teachers, the policemen, the hospital workers; one could continue ad infinitum-are based. No government creates money; it only collects it. It would be necessary for it either to collect more taxes-that should be obvious-or to reduce the benefits that a State government is expected to provide by closing schools and police stations and shutting down hospitals. If that is what the ALP and the Democrats want, I suggest that they vote for this legislation because that is definitely what will happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Every State government, irrespective of its political persuasion, runs on a tight budget. Every department works within the constraints of a budget and there will be no alternative but to reduce services. As I have said, most fringe benefits that are provided by governments are provided in the western areas of Queensland, the northern areas of Victoria or the western areas of New South Wales; they are provided in the primary industry areas. Those areas will bear the brunt of the tax due to the loss of services. They will also bear the brunt in a more direct way. Once again primary industry has been singled out by this ALP Government.

After four years rural people have come to expect it. There has been one continued assault after the other on the primary industries of Australia. A fringe benefits tax will be charged on the fuel, food, telephones, vehicles and accommodation provided by the farmer and the grazier. A farmer will even have to pay fringe benefits tax on his son's or daughter's residence on the farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about wedding presents?

—I do not know about wedding presents but if my colleague says that they will be affected, I should recognise his expertise in this area. The Government expects primary producers to employ people. Does it expect a farm worker to live up a hollow log? Is that what the AWU wants for its members? Does the Government expect a farm worker to live in a home in a town 20, 30 or 40 kilometres from where he works and trek 50, 60 or 70 kilometres to and from home? There is no alternative for a farmer but to provide a cottage or accommodation for farm workers. Telephones are also essential in country areas, particularly if a farmer has a worker on another block or who is living away from the main homestead. He must communicate with his farm workers or manager. It has got to the ridiculous stage that even if one offered a farm worker a cup of tea on the verandah and a piece of cake one would have to pay $2 in fringe benefits tax. Is that the egalitarian society that the ALP wants? Is that the one class society that it is aiming for? That shows honourable senators how ridiculous the ALP is.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take, for example, the benefits an average stationhand would receive. Let us put down $40 for the use of a cottage, which is a fairly low figure, and $14 for electricity and gas and let us say that we give him $10 worth of meat, which is not unreasonable. A dog would probably eat more than that. I will not throw in any phone bills or petrol. I come up with a figure of $64 a week. He will have to pay income tax at the company tax rate of 49c in the dollar on that $64 a week. That is at the absolute minimum but that works out at $31 a week added on to the costs to every farmer for every employee. Senator Grimes shakes his head. I do not know whether he does so in disgust or in shame. He is probably absolutely disgusted because I do not believe that Senator Grimes-I consider him a reasonable person-would ever fall for this type of legislation. The Government is asking every farmer who employs a worker to pay 49c in the dollar and then an additional $31 a week in tax per employee. I say to Senator Cooney that that is most unreasonable because the average farm income is around $7,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wheat farmers have minus incomes.

—Senator Crichton-Browne speaks up for the Western Australian wheat farmers, as he should. There are many wheat farmers and farmers in Australia on a minus income. The Government is asking those people with an income of $7,000 a year-let us talk about an average income-to take $1,500 off that $7,000. How can Senator Cooney defend that? He cannot defend it because it is indefensible. There is no alternative for farmers but to provide accommodation for people who work on their farms. The workers cannot physically own their own houses on the farms. Farmers cannot expect workers to travel from a town that is 50 or 100 kilometres away. Therefore, the Government is expecting farmers to pay $31 per employee.

SPEECH.PARA: It is predicted by rural organisations that up to one-third of rural workers will lose their jobs. Between 10,000 and 20,000 Australian Workers Union members will have their working conditions eroded. Senator Black is not prepared even to come into the chamber. I do not know to which faction the AWU belongs but I would like the AWU to defend the position of its members who pay $80 or $90 a year for the benefit of union membership. It is a complete sell-out. I will put out a Press release calling for all rural workers to resign from the AWU and to seek some other union that will defend their rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the National Party?

—The National Party of Australia would certainly never sell anyone down the drain like that. But at the end of the day let us look at what will happen to rural Australia. Up to 20,000 people will lose employment on farms. Families on those farms are already overstretched. Husbands are trying to make ends meet now and will have to do extra work. They already work 80 or 90 hours a week. But I suppose that the Australian Labor Party would not mind if they did another 10 to make it an even 100 hours a week. The wives of the tractor drivers, the mothers and the accountants will not let their properties go. They are great survivors. They will work a little harder and put a little more pressure on their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members do not like the farmers. They have never liked them. The farmers do not vote for the ALP so the ALP has never given them a fair go. But it is not only the farmers who oppose this. The National Farmers Federation has passed a unanimous resolution requesting farmers to ignore both paying and filling out the forms for the fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —You support the breaking of the law.
—If I support it, so do Premier Bannon, Premier Burke and Premier Bjelke-Petersen.
—Are you urging people to break the law?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek some protection from your colleague. I am continually being interjected upon.

—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. My point of order is that Senator Boswell has reflected on a member of another parliament. He named the Premier of Western Australia, Brian Burke, as being in support of not paying fringe benefits tax. Premier Burke has never made any threats to that degree and I ask the honourable senator to withdraw.
—There is no point of order.

—Premiers Burke, Bannon and Bjelke-Petersen are all on record as saying that they will not pay the tax. Rural producer associations have not been invited to the mini-conference that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is putting on. He has disregarded the NFF and has refused to send it an invitation. Once again he has completely ignored its members.

SPEECH.PARA: When speaking about the fringe benefits tax we should not let pass the plight of the mining industries. They make a great contribution to overseas trade. The fringe benefits tax will cost the mining industries in Australia $61m per year-$46m for housing, $5m for travel and $10m for electricity allowances. In Queensland the tax will cost $13m. The housing, travel and power benefits are essential to the mining industry because of its remoteness. They are not tax evasion measures; they are recognised in tax legislation. The contribution of the mining industry to Australia's development, decentralisation and export earnings cannot ever be overestimated. Since 1967 the mining industry in Australia has build 24 new towns, 12 new ports, 20 airfields and 1,900 kilometres of heavy duty railway lines. In Queensland alone $362m has been spent on employee housing.

The fringe benefits tax is a retrospective tax because it has changed the rules after projects have been established. Because 78 per cent of our coal is exported, prices are determined by the market. The industry is not able to pass on new domestic taxes. This tax can only cost jobs, stop mining industries from expanding and stop the growth of new towns. There is only one Labor senator still to speak on this legislation. Only three Government senators are making some effort by speaking on this fringe benefits tax. I must admit that the two previous Government speakers did an exceedingly shocking job. They have not convinced anyone.

The fringe benefits tax will reduce all business in Australia. The Government is trying to recreate the wheel but it will pull down the whole system of business. In the last 10 years we have seen 360,000 jobs lost in manufacturing industry. This fringe benefits tax legislation will not create one real job. On the contrary, it will send many thousands more to the dole queues, particularly in the car industry. It will help the Government with its numbers of people employed under the community employment program. Many thousands more people will line up for the CEP jobs. As the dollar falls, because our mining and rural exports will become increasingly uncompetitive due to the fringe benefits tax, we will go further into debt internationally, with reduced income to service overseas borrowings, the J-curve will race off into the sunset and we will all remember the words of the best Treasurer in the world-that Australia will become a banana republic. I say to the Australian Democrats and to members of the Labor Party: If this fringe benefits tax comes through, you will all have made your contribution to ensuring that the best Treasurer's prophecy comes true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start to debate the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986, I want to record my absolute abhorrence for the manner in which this Government has gone about this legislation. Even before the legislation had reached the Senate and barely after it was passed in the House of Representatives, as an employer I was sent three things-a copy of a booklet, which I believe cost some $3m to produce, a form and accompanying letter. The booklet told me clause by clause what was in the legislation. The letter told me that the fringe benefits tax would become effective on 1 July and that from that date I would be liable to pay fringe benefits tax on a range of benefits. Basically, the form asked me to dob myself in and to admit liability under legislation that does not yet exist in law. The form further required me to sign and swear the information to be true and correct. How on earth is anyone supposed to sign that without knowing for what he is liable? What sort of Government are we running in this country that forces people to sign blank pieces of paper?

SPEECH.PARA: The whole thing is atrocious. The history of this taxation legislation is a fascinating study of how governments can operate at the most inefficient level. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his statement on 19 September, observed:
Today's measures will achieve a return to fairness in the Australian tax system not seen for decades. Australian society will be much the stronger for it.
In November 1985 the Treasurer said:
The Government has today concluded its discussions with the Australian Democrats concerning the tax reform package.

It would appear that the Federal Treasurer has of late got nothing right, because neither of those statements has turned out to be correct. It all means that the tax summit or, perhaps more accurately, the Treasurer's tax rort and all the consultations, deals and pay-backs that went with it have amounted to an absolute waste of time. For three years we have had to suffer the Government's claims that it was working on the greatest reform of the taxation system ever attempted. We have been told time and time again that everyone in the community would contribute-unions, businessmen and employers. That is so much rot.

The Democrats have taken their role of keeping us all honest to new heights. If I did not know better, I would have thought that the discussions over the past few days between the Democrats and the Government were scenes from a Cecil B. De Mille epic, with everyone taking turns at playing God. I do not need to outline what the various fringe benefits tax Bills will cover. Other speakers have documented their entire scope. I will concentrate on what I consider to be appalling inconsistencies and discriminations in the Bills.

Before someone on the other side claims I am protecting some people, I had better say that I am not talking about those very few businessmen who live in cities such as Sydney or Melbourne, who have large incomes and very good accountants and who have for years been able to manipulate the income tax laws no matter how they are amended. I do not condone the actions of those people, nor do I wish to protect them. We all know the sorts of rorts to which I am referring-the absurdly concessional loans to people well able to afford full interest rates, and fringe benefits packages of $50,000 to $100,000 on top of their salaries. What I am concerned about and what the National Party and the Liberal Party are concerned about are the hundreds of thousands of other Australians who will be so much worse off after these tax changes are brought in. I want especially to talk about what is happening to the employers in small business in rural areas.

Perhaps the most basic absurdity in this legislation is that of a tax imposed on employers on the total taxable value of non-cash fringe benefits provided. As the President of the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales, Mr Michael Tooth, said only last week:

The principle that tax should be paid by the recipient of wages and other benefits is well established in the western world. This new tax completely overturns that principle and in fact it becomes a tax on incentive and employment.

It also contravenes the principles of tax reform of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His fifth commandment claims that Australians should pay tax only at the rate commensurate with their ability to pay. This legislation will apply to employers even if they have a negative or nil assessable income, as Senator Boswell said earlier. In the rural sector, a rural employer who provides residential accommodation and charges rent at a rate less than what the Commissioner of Taxation considers fair market rent will be up for additional costs. Any additional costs of employment will simply reduce the number of people employed in the rural sector. Alternatively, the employee will be asked to pay the full market rent. Currently 110,000 wage and salary earners are employed in agriculture and related services. It has been estimated that this tax will cost the rural industry about $150m. This will be avoided if the employee is sacked. Either way, agriculture is to be slugged. The Government and the people of Australia must be made aware of this.

This legislation deals not in cents but in dollars-hundreds of millions of them. It will hurt not just the rich tax dodgers whom Senator Walsh is so fond of talking about but the people who simply cannot afford to pay. Companies in my area are facing costs of $12,000 per employee. The alternatives for these or other people will be to pay it, pass it on, sack the employee or put the price of goods and services up to cover the extra costs. For those dealing in export commodities, that is just not possible. Either way, the economy suffers. If the employee is forced to pay, he will push for higher wages to bring him back to where he was before FBT. If the employer pays, his profitability slumps. If he passes on the costs, the prices of goods go up and so does the consumer price index. The merry-go-round starts spinning. Where does that leave the pensioner and others with little income?

Another absurdity created by this tax is the timing of the year over which it applies. It will run from 1 April to 31 March with the tax payable in quarterly instalments. I know that the argument for this is that the timing will not interfere with other tax requirements. What it means in effect is that the businessman or farmer will not work on his tax just once each year or visit his accountant once a year; he will just about be living with his accountant. Already taxation accountants have been inundated with inquiries. Meetings of accountants have been held across the country. They have been trying to unravel this appalling accountancy nightmare. The accountancy profession is concerned about legal liability. The penalties for incorrect assessments are high, yet with the tax applicable in just a few weeks' time we still do not know the answers. We must all await the pleasure of the Democrats. Several accountants and businessmen near my home town have rung me and told me that they have rung the Taxation Office. They have spoken to people in the Treasurer's office. Some have even been desperate enough to phone the Democrats. All of them have called back--

TALK.START.PARA: —The last card in the pack.

—That is definitely the last card in the pack. None of these people can answer the questions. For example, a staffer in Senator Siddons's office assured one of my constituents that most farm workers lived off the farm and would travel to work, so the question of fringe benefits tax on accommodation for farm workers would not apply. I doubt whether that tax expert has been on a farm which is more than five kilometres from the centre of Melbourne. I also hope that Senator Siddons, as the Democrats' economic spokesman, receives better advice than that provided by that officer. Treasurer Keating's office fared no better. Someone in that office told my constituent that all he would need to do was put a nominal charge on the farm cottage and then `just increase his wages by the same amount'. If the Treasurer wants to find tax loopholes, perhaps he should talk to his own staff. The Taxation Office was far more honest, if unenlightening. People there just said that they did not know.
—This is like the Mad Hatter's tea party.

—That is right. They have supposedly supervised the compilation of this legislation, and they do not know how it works. Accountants have already started up a fighting fund to protect their members against law suits likely to arise from late or incorrect returns. Businessmen will now spend many more hours and dollars sorting out the mountain of paperwork generated by these Bills. One part of this legislation has confused me and angered me even more than does the whole concept of fringe benefits taxes. In the White Paper published last year it was proposed that fringe benefits provided by an employer to an employee under a trade union award would not be taxable. If it still applied that benefits provided or won under an industrial award did not attract fringe benefits tax, that would have been one of the most blatant forms of discrimination perpetrated on the Australian community. It would have meant that trade unions could negotiate a most extraordinary range of fringe benefits using as a lever the fact that the employer would not have had to pay the fringe benefits tax on it. The private businessman, on the other hand, who similarly chose to provide a car, dining facilities or some other form of benefit or bonus would have been penalised, and at the full company rate of taxation. If that still applies under this legislation it will be the most extraordinary deal ever cooked up by the real pawnbrokers of this country-the trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: The unions still have some employers over the proverbial barrel. In New South Wales, for example, some farmhands are employed under the New South Wales Rural Workers Accommodation Act which requires that where residential accommodation is provided for a rural employee it shall be free of charge to the worker. In other words, there is no way the farm owner can avoid paying the fringe benefits tax irrespective-I emphasise this-of his ability to pay. It gets worse. If the children of a family live on a farm under a company arrangement or under the terms of an estate of the parents or live on a property owned by the parents, they are deemed to be employees, and the owners of the company-the owners of the property-will have to pay the fringe benefits tax on their own family. Yet Treasurer Keating had the nerve to tell the Parliament today that this tax would not unduly hurt farmers. What a lot of rubbish! Where has he been for the last 12 months?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is being deceitful.
—`Deceitful' is quite correct. Is he not aware that there is a rural depression on and that farmers just cannot take any more costs?
—Why does the Government hate the farmers?

—I am trying to find out why it hates the farmers. It is not giving much help to the farmers anywhere along the line. What was the point of the 15 April rural package which gave a measly $103m to farmers when this legislation is estimated to take back $150m? How much will it cost to do that? I have heard estimates that 450 additional staff will be employed to administer the legislation. I bet that, as large as that figure is, it is a mere drop in the bucket. The legislative formula is so appallingly complex that I believe it will take more than 450 people just to unravel it. I agree with Senator Chipp's comment that the legislation looks as if it was written by the same person who wrote the telephone book, but if Senator Chipp believes that it is so appalling why does he not join the Opposition and kick the legislation out? He knows as well as everyone else that the existing legislation has more than enough provisions to tighten up any lurks that should be wiped out. How, for example, does one value the rent on a house which has been on a property for 80 years or more and which has never been commercially rented out? Will the Government apply the same unfair dictatorial standards to this situation as it did to the assets tests valuations in which absurdly high values were placed on rural dwellings?

SPEECH.PARA: The anomalies and the blatant discrimination are not restricted to the rural sector. Let me give some examples. Let us take a garage proprietor who employs his son as an apprentice. The son lives at home with his parents and currently pays no board because his parents choose not to charge him. Under this legislation the apprentice is not his father's son-which makes him something that I could not mention in this chamber-but rather he is his employee and is receiving fringe benefits. The father will have to pay for his son living under the family roof and sharing the family car. Does the garage employer father throw out or sack his apprentice employee son? Is that what this Government is all about? Is it trying to break up the family?

An even more astounding example is that of a motel manager who has a wife and family. Like all motel managers they live on the job. They eat and sleep at the motel. Under this legislation their employer will be liable for tax on 60 per cent of the assessed value of rent, food and furniture. Food, for example, would cost some $4000 a year in fringe benefits tax. Rent would cost another $4000, and that is even before electricity is calculated. What about the beds and bed clothes? Where does it stop and who is to calculate it? Who is going to come and look between the sheets? Who is going to knock on the door late at night to see what sort of sheets the family is sleeping between? Where do retired employees go if, until now, they have been allowed to remain on a property rent free in exchange for the odd caretaker role? What happens if those retired employees are one's parents?

The Government has been working on the tax reform package for three years. Frankly, it has been a phantom pregnancy because it has achieved absolutely nothing worthwhile and beneficial for this country. It has singled out the employer to pay for benefits he does not receive. In fact, he provides them and he is now to be charged tax for the gesture. The legislation will create bitterness between employer and employee. If employees are not sacked or charged for the benefit they will be quizzed at length as to how they use the company car. The employee will be challenged about the use of his telephone or electricity. Not just one industry has been hit. This tax will hit the big industries such as mining, which I am sure Senator Parer will mention later in this debate. It will hit the motor vehicle industry which Senator Messner has mentioned already. It will affect little people equally as hard. There has been no attempt to determine the ability of those affected to pay. The Government appears to have forgotten that the recovery of the economy depends on private enterprise, especially our export industries. If, on top of all the other economic ills, business has to cope with a further tax impost, we will be sending many businesses to the wall. In some cases both employer and employee will lose their jobs. The Government should take heed of the saying: `The levying of taxes and the shearing of sheep are very alike; they should both stop at the skin'. This tax is already well into the hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986. Senator Messner pointed out the Government parameters for tax reform. I will mention a few of them again. Before the Government began the tax reform process last year, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will simplify the system so that all Australians will understand it. It will be based on capacity to pay. Any changes will be acceptable to community groups and it will provide the best climate for investment and employment.

I repeat: The Government will simplify the system so that all Australians will understand it. We have a Bill of 139 pages, an explanatory memorandum of 176 pages, and every person who is liable for the fringe benefits tax has received a 56-page guidebook from the Australian Taxation Office. That is what the Government means when it says that it will simplify the system so that every Australian will understand it.

The fringe benefits tax has prompted an unprecedented revolt across Australia and the more the effect of the legislation is felt by every Australian, the more antipathy it will generate. There is no doubt that unacceptably high taxation brought about by grotesquely excessive government expenditure spawned a grocery list approach to salary packages. No one would disagree that in a minority of cases the system was abused. No one would disagree that these people should pay tax on blatant evasion. The existing provisions of the taxation legislation are such that these evasions could have been attacked.

The fringe benefits tax, however, is part of an obscene package conceived late at night in a motel room between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Is it any wonder that the progeny is a gross monstrosity? The National Taxation Summit, agreed to by the Prime Minister on a pre-election talkback program, was supposed to simplify and make more equitable the taxation system. Following the sell-out by the Prime Minister of his Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Government has produced a horrible piece of socialist, ideological nonsense which purports to aim at the few who have abused the system but which will succeed only in shooting the innocent bystander. When this legislation bites, it will adversely affect every taxpayer in Australia. This is not an income tax. It is a new payroll tax which applies to charities, ratepayers, farmers, tourist operators, small business, schools, religious institutions and miners. It is a tax on labour costs and not on tall poppy fringe benefits which, to be kind, was the original intent.

The effect on the car industry is horrendous and is already being felt. While the rest of Australia was engaged in stop work meetings or strikes on 28 May to force the phoney 3 per cent productivity/union superannuation case, the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia was also on strike to protest about the effect of the fringe benefits tax on their industry. The language used by the secretary of the Vehicle Builders Federation to describe the tax was unparliamentary and therefore cannot be quoted. Even though the tax on vehicles may be watered down the Federation and Senator Button know that the jobs of these people are at stake. This aspect has already been covered to some extent by Senator Messner, and no doubt it will be covered by other senators in more detail.

The tourist industry, one of the few growth industries in Australia today, will be particularly affected. Senator Jones should know this, coming from Queensland. This growth has occurred despite outdated and idiotic penalty rates. The industry is now confronted with a new and totally unwarranted and inequitable tax which will of course be paid for by the consumer. Because of the 24-hour nature of the industry, managers and staff live in many cases at their place of work. Staff must be accommodated on island resorts; there is no other form of accommodation. As the new tax is non-deductible and the measure is counter to section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the industry will need to derive an additional $150m a year in order to meet the tax. Tariffs and charges will need to increase by 9.5 per cent across the board to cover the cost. This, with the increase in labour and other costs of operations, will result in a massive inflationary increase in accommodation and hospitality costs of some 20 per cent over the next 12 months.

I turn to regional and remote areas. My State of Queensland is the most decentralised State in Australia-an end which at one time was a priority for government. To attract shire clerks, engineers, nurses, teachers and others to remote areas special provisions such as housing, return air fares once a year and perhaps boarding school allowances have been and have to be provided. We recently had the Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland telling the people of Mount Isa, Cloncurry and other regional towns and cities in Queensland that he had negotiated special tax concessions with the Treasurer for people in those areas. This claim is nothing more than a flagrant abuse of the truth by an embarrassed Labor leader looking at an election. How on earth could these people be receiving a concession when before the legislation they were not paying the tax and after 1 July they will be? Those councils and shires will still have to provide the package to retain the services of these people, and who will pay? The ratepayers will pay, of course. They cannot afford to cash out, as Senator Walsh has suggested, as the cost to ratepayers would be even higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the highest charged State. It has the highest charges of any State in Australia.

—Senator Jones should be supporting me. This is yet another discriminatory impost by a Labor Government against a large number of Australians who live outside the capital cities. This plus other factors, including the direction taken for the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on regional television, will absolutely guarantee that at the next election there will not be a Labor member outside the Brisbane metropolitan area.

SPEECH.PARA: Another major affected group will be charities, religious institutions and schools. The fringe benefits tax will, to name a few, apply to the housekeeper at parish churches; to church-run nursing homes; Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul Society hostels and of course caretakers and live-in teachers at schools and school sporting facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau, which is calling on us to strengthen the tax?

—I am glad Senator Maguire interjects. Senator Cooney drew attention to the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau earlier. Senator Cooney did not do a bad job. He is a good advocate, but he would have had the worst brief of his life. I am sure that, had he been in private practice, he would have knocked it back. The point about the Bureau is that so far that gentleman has not read his mauve book, because he is going to get caught. This will simply mean that church and charity groups will have less money available for the welfare, education, health and other social welfare programs they provide. These people do not fit the image of tall poppy tax evaders. I am sure that everyone would agree that these people are not tall poppy tax evaders, yet they are the ones who will be hit by this fringe benefits tax.
—Who?
—The honourable senator should go to the St Vincent de Paul Society.
—It is excluded.
—No, it is not excluded. This hastily conceived tax will give the Australian Labor Party a lot of time to repent at its leisure after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I would like to address the effect of fringe benefits on the mining industry. This is an industry which has contributed much to the economy of Australia but which has suffered at the hands of governments both State and Federal. The industry has suffered in recent times at the hands of a depressed world market, some irresponsible union actions and destructive government controls. It is unable to claim legitimate business entertaining expenses for overseas customers to whom it would like to sell our products. Conditions of service in remote mining areas such as housing and transportation are an absolute requirement to get people to work in those areas. The provision of these facilities has never been aimed at avoiding taxation. It might be hard for people from the smaller States to understand that. I know Senator Jones will, because he has been up there. In the last 20 years, as explained by Senator Boswell, the mining companies have built many towns, railways, ports and so on at no expense whatsoever to the taxpayers of Australia. They have also made contributions to the economy by way of exports, payroll taxes, royalties, direct taxation, the iniquitous export duty and extortionary rail freight charges, which have been enormous and out of proportion to the demands on any other industry. Yet without the mining industry our standard of living would be close to the bottom of the list of Third World countries.

For some of the mining companies the fringe benefits tax is the last straw. I know that sometimes people talk wildly and become prophets of doom, but this is not wild language, it is fact. It will remove whatever profit they were making. Some of the socialist ideologues on the other side will have a little gloat about that. What they do not realise is that their little gloat will contribute to the economic demise of our country. A company or an industry without profits cannot survive and when it goes a few hundred or a few thousand more breadwinners go, unwillingly, forced by this Government on to the unemployment benefit. Our mining resources have been described as non-renewable resources. The level of our exports depends on productivity and the costs of production. Every artificial cost, whether it be the plethora of extortionist government charges or extravagant labour conditions, reduces our competitiveness and more importantly reduces the level of our economically recoverable reserves, thus shortening the life of mines and employment life. Australia cannot afford this blatant attack on its natural resources and the next generation will have to pay very dearly for the cost of this big government with its attendant legalised plunder of our country. An enemy of Australia could not do more damage than is being done by this Labor Government. The fringe benefits tax is the final straw. Does the Government care? Does the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the author of the fringe benefits tax and the unelected government of this country, care? Of course not, otherwise it would not be hellbent on destroying the economy and putting at risk the jobs of every worker in the productive sector. Without these people there cannot be a public sector.

I am on the board of a small underground coal mine at Blackwater in Queensland. I have no financial interest in the mine. I am on the board for two reasons: Firstly, it enables me to have a continuing understanding of the difficulties of mining. Secondly, and more importantly, because in co-operation with the miners' union, the mine, which was being closed, was put back on its feet. The miners readily agreed to more productive work practices and, as a result, there are now about 250 families in Blackwater which would not be there today but for that co-operative effort. This tax places this underground mine and other mines throughout Australia in a totally unprofitable position. To a mine in such a condition this tax is a new export duty which varies between $1 and $3 a tonne, depending on whether the mine is an open cut mine or an underground mine. If this is not discrimination against a major export industry, if it is not discrimination against a labour intensive underground mine, I do not know what is.

Senator Walsh, surprisingly to me because he is usually very balanced on these matters, said a few days ago that companies should cash out their fringe benefits. For tax evasion type fringe benefits, nobody would disagree with that. I would not disagree with that. For the mining areas, this is simply not possible. As mentioned earlier, the provision of cheap housing is essential to obtain and retain employees. It is interesting to note that when there were layoffs in New South Wales coal areas, men were recruited into the Bowen basin. Even with the so-called fringe benefits, they returned to the Hunter Valley when jobs picked up. So much for the massive fringe benefits that are paid to mining people!

I received a telex which was also sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Button, Senator Walsh and others. It was sent by the South Blackwater mine, a mine with which I have no involvement whatsoever, and part of that telex reads:

Should the tax be applied, we shall have to consider either passing it on to the employees or closing the underground operations, fully recognising the potentially disastrous industrial ramifications of either course. Only two years ago your Government through Minister Walsh sensibly initiated exemption legislation to the coal export duty that helped the continuance of underground operations at South Blackwater and offered the mine prospects of ongoing but still very marginal viability. Now we are faced with the dichotomy of the proposed housing tax wiping out most of that benefit.
I repeat: As far as the mining industry is concerned, this is no more or less than a new export duty which is not even tax deductible. The old export duty was tax deductible.

In conclusion, this is the most divisive, unpopular, unwanted, inequitable tax package ever foisted on the Australian public. Administratively it is going to be an unworkable nightmare, as attested to by employees of the Australian Taxation Office who contacted my office after attending an in-house seminar and said: `We hope this thing does not go through because we are not going to be able to administer it'. This came from Tax Office employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The accountants are up in arms. They say they cannot administer it.

—The accountants, of course, will gain if the industry can afford to pay them the extra money. We have middle Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Small Business Association, Mr Bob Ansett and others saying that they will not pay it. Since the issuing by the Tax Office of the massive mauve booklet, my office has been inundated with calls from people saying they have thrown their books in the rubbish tin. We have heard honourable senators opposite expressing shock and horror that Mr Ansett should publicly express his feelings, yet we have not heard a peep about the day of protest yesterday when 500,000 people were forced to down tools by militant trade unions. We have not heard a peep about the 30,000 members of the coal miners union who are going out on strike tonight for 24 hours to force a productivity case. Bob Ansett's protest is nothing compared to the effect of that industrial action on this staggering economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has on its hands a tax revolt of a magnitude never before seen in this country. It is self-inflicted, all because of a failed tax summit and a deal made in the middle of the night by the ACTU and the emeritus President of the ACTU who is now the Prime Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After seven months it has finally arrived-a package of four fringe benefits tax Bills freshly guillotined through the House of Representatives with the traditional respect for other people's feelings and views that the Australian Labor Party is known for. What did the Government promise? It promised a fairer and simpler tax system which would encourage investment. What did we get? We got four Bills, 151 pages of legislation, and 170 pages of explanatory memorandum. This legislation is extraordinarily complex. It is legislation which actually perverts the basis on which tax is levied at present. It introduces new taxes. It is a set of Bills which positively incite and encourage people to break the law, which should be the direct converse of any legislation we introduce. It is absolutely devastating on the business and commercial world in Australia. Would a Labor Government lie to us? Damned right it has on this when it talks about it being simpler and fairer and encouraging investment.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no sympathy and no one on this side of the House has absolutely any sympathy at all for people who cheat on their proper, legal tax liabilities. It is common knowledge that taxes have been evaded by people having their income understated, by taking a lower salary or a lower set of wages than the market in fairness would pay them for a position, and taking the balance, the reduction in the income, in the form of other benefits, whether in the form of a car, a house, paid holidays, paid trips, school fees, loans at cut rates or things like that. None of us support the artificial reduction of income and thereby the artificial reduction of the liability to pay tax that is implied there. It is morally wrong for that to be done. But the point that the Labor Party cannot understand is that it is also legally wrong under the legislation that is on the books at present. All it needs is the courage and the backbone to apply the law as it stands at present. This damned Government has had three years to do that. It cannot evade that responsibility. It has had three years to see that the laws were applied, but it has not done so. It has now come in with this blunderbuss legislation which is going to have a devastating effect across the whole of the commercial world.

I concede that there are some grey areas that cannot be covered by such a simple approach as I have put forward, but those areas can be covered by relatively simple amendments to the legislation we have at present covering income tax. My first criticism of this legislation is that it is just cowardice and incompetence that the Labor Party does not apply the law as it is on the statute book at present. In turn, it has taken counsel of its fears, prejudices and phobias and had a lash at the whole of the business community of Australia. Incidentally, it has unleashed the dogs in the Australian Taxation Office-people who want to be locked up the whole time because their whole function in life is to tax and tax until there is nothing left in the community. It takes a strong, intelligent and informed government to keep the Australian Taxation Office in check, but the Australian Labor Party has never had the ability to sit on the Taxation Office and to get some fairness and justice into its rapacious claims.

The second point I have against this legislation is that the fundamental basis upon which income tax is levied in Australia is and always has been that the person who receives the benefit pays the tax. This legislation turns that principle entirely on its head. Under the proposed legislation, the person who receives the benefit will not have a tax liability; the person who provides the benefit is the one who will specifically pay. There is no reason at all for that, because the present law-I am sorry that, as a non-lawyer, I have to lecture members of the Labor Party all the time on points of law, but they are incredibly thick in this area-specifically forbids barter deals. One cannot avoid one's business obligations with respect to income tax or company tax liabilities by entering into barter deals. That is another buttress against people who are evading their true tax liability. I do not agree with this shifting of the onus on to the provider instead of the person who gets the benefit. It is fundamentally wrong and fundamentally unworkable in the longer term in the commercial world.

The third criticism of this legislation is that the cost of imposing it is out of all reason for the benefit it might bring to the Taxation Office. I do not have any doubt that at the end of the day the tax collection figures will be less than they are at present, because the people who are cheating will have more avenues by which to cheat under this complex legislation than they have under existing legislation. While I am talking about cheats, I would like to talk about the Labor Party. I believe that members of the Labor Party have been blatantly dishonest in the way they have marketed this legislation. They have brought forward 151 pages of legislation and 170 pages of explanatory memorandum and their Treasurer (Mr Keating)-the world's best Treasurer, the undertaker-has reduced the whole thing to one simplistic sentence. To justify 151 pages of legislation he has said to people: `If I pay income tax, you should not get a tax-free car'. He has reduced 151 pages of legislation to a trite half truth like that. Possibly that is all the Treasurer can understand about the legislation. I would not be surprised about that.

A very large number of people in the Liberal Party and the National Party want to speak about this iniquitous legislation. I pay full tribute to my colleagues who preceded me in this debate and who have dealt with the many anomalies in the legislation, particularly those who have dealt with the anomalous situation of charities and beneficial welfare organisations. I include in that group bodies such as the National Trust, which work for the corporate good of the community without in any sense at all getting any personal reward or benefit from it, and which will be penalised under this new legislation. Under this legislation, when people are moved to support the charities in society, instead of the benefit of their generosity going to the people they intend to receive it, it will go into the rapacious hands of this Labor Government and the Taxation Office-which is not the reason why people make gifts in the first place-but I do not think the general public realises that at present.

I wish to take a couple of minutes talking about two areas in which this legislation will impact. The first is rural Australia, and the second is transport costs for the whole of the Australian community. Senator Boswell spoke at length on rural Australia, and I would like to add something to his remarks. I make a declaration here that I have a personal financial interest in this area, being involved in primary production. People who live in rural Australia, remote from the towns, enjoy a lifestyle which is quite distinct and quite different from that of the overwhelming number of Australians who live in suburbia. By and large, the houses that they live in are built to a very much lower standard of comfort and convenience than the average house in suburban Australia. There are good reasons for that. It costs a lot to haul materials two or three hundred miles or more from a railhead. It is very hard to get skilled tradesmen. Bush carpenters literally are that. They are people who seldom have had any trade training. Bush painters and plumbers are very rare; generally work in this area comes under the umbrella of odd jobs.

The amenities in those houses are far fewer than those in suburbia. There is no television in most of rural Queensland; there is no telephone. The electricity supplies are very indifferent and variable. Electricity is usually generated on the property. It is certainly not part of the main grid. Mail services do not exist and people might have to drive to the nearest town to pick up their mail. The availability of milk and food supplies at short notice are facilities that residents on properties and farms in distant areas just do not have. All this adds up to a major inconvenience and to very real factors in those residents' costs of living.

The employees, by and large, share the same conditions as the owners or managers of the properties. Just as standards vary for owners, they vary greatly for the conditions under which employees are employed. They vary from the one extreme, where the employees live in parity with and almost as members of the family, to the other, where the employees are quite separate from and have a demonstrably lower standard of living than the owner of the property. But certainly an employee on a farm or cattle station is living in a house, a hut or a set of quarters of a standard that is very much below what the average Australian urban dweller lives in. I venture the opinion that a large number of people in towns and cities in Australia would not consider, let alone live in, the conditions in which many employees and owners of properties live.

These people live in sub-standard accommodation in comparison with that in urban areas. They may get some food from the property. If a beast is killed on the property, everyone shares in that because that is the custom of the area. They may get the use of a vehicle to go into town at the weekends, when someone is sick, to pick up supplies or to do some personal business; they may get some fuel. But the characteristic of their lifestyle is that it is not regulated, it does not conform to a set award such as those which unions impose on employees in industry. Employees live under conditions which are mutually acceptable to the manager and to them, which vary from property to property.

This legislation sets out to tax every possible `benefit' that these people might receive. It will tax that benefit in the hands of the provider, not the recipient. Let us spend a moment looking at the practicalities of this. Firstly, let us deal with the place of residence. How are we to set a fair market value for a hut on a cattle property in the middle of Queensland or the middle of Western Australia? Where is the market that we are to judge it against? There is no way it can be done. That value is a notional figure. To give people a concession because they live in a remote area really is tokenism at an insulting level. Let us take electricity. I think most properties generate their own electricity. How are we to separate out the fraction that goes to supply a 60-watt bulb in a single room in a men's quarters or something like that? Even if it is on the grid and is part of the supply from the generating authority, there is only one meter on a property, only one input, and the whole property is served off that point. How are we to set a fair figure for the benefit an employee receives? One has only to state this to see how stupid and impractical the whole proposition is. How are we to assign a value to food when a beast is killed? If it is not given to the employee, is it to go bad because there is not enough storage space? This is so impractical that there is really not much point talking about it. The net effect of this legislation will be a great increase in hassle for the property administration. There will be real costs involved here, at a time when rural Australia is on its knees fighting for its markets.

The sad part is that we are not dealing with cheats in this environment. Neither the property owners nor the employees are tax cheats. They are not the people who are ripping off hundreds of millions out of smart share trading operations on the Australian market that the Labor Party supports and encourages, because those people are the big donors to the Labor Party campaign funds; no, these are average little Australians struggling to make a living doing an essential service for this country.

Let us look at another point-the provisions in this legislation for the use of vehicles. This is one of the most farcical things that could ever have been foisted on the property operators. I refer to the requirements that a log book should be kept for a four-wheel-drive vehicle that a person is to run on the property. One has to keep a log book and every day one uses that vehicle one must enter the date of the journey. One must enter the odometer reading at the beginning and the end of the journey. One has to enter the number of kilometres travelled and the purpose of the journey. If one has to take some bales of hay to feed some weaners in a distant paddock one will have to enter the name of the driver and the date on which the entry was made. One has also to enter the name of the person making the entry. It all has to be in English and signed by the person making the entry. People like Senator McKiernan would have difficulty in doing that, but I can imagine some sleek bureaucrat in Canberra thinking that would be a simple exercise.

I guess that no one in the Labor Party today has ever worked on a property. I certainly have. I have been up before dawn and out mustering cattle all day long. It is absolutely impossible to put those impositions on someone who is working in the country. One does not carry log books and ball point pens in the glove boxes of four- wheel-drive working vehicles on properties. One does not have odometers that work in most cases. Farm vehicles are rough vehicles. The concept that one can neatly say how many kilometres one has travelled each day is frankly for the birds. One does not have time to keep those sorts of records. One works from sun-up to sunset doing tasks that often arise spontaneously. I go back to the late 1960s when I remember a friend of mine on a neighbouring property, one of the family ones, who, in a great drought, was driving about 18 hours a day. That was all he did for months and months, and he put up a huge mileage. He just filled up his water tank on the truck and kept the petrol tank full and drove from before dawn until about 11 o'clock every night for months.

To ask a person like that, who is coping with a drought, to keep a log book with all this stuff in it on a daily basis is so impracticable. One cannot believe that any sane adult would propose it. It is all a nonsense; it is meaningless. The vehicle is there on the property because it is a working vehicle. It is not there to take guests from town out duck shooting. It is not there to take employees or the owners 500 or 600 miles into town. It is a simple working vehicle. Why should we load people up with over-legislation and over-regulation? But that is the obsession of the Labor Party. It wishes to reduce us all to grey uniformity by regulating and grinding everything down.

The second thing I want to talk about is the effect that this legislation will have on the Australian transport industry. This legislation will result in great increases in transport costs. It was said some years ago that at least 25 per cent of the gross domestic product of Australia goes in transport costs. If that is true, and I believe it is, we have a major interest in getting our transport costs down as low as possible to be competitive. But what does the Labor Party do? It has a crack at the time-honoured practice of travel by airline employees and former airline employees by taxing that benefit.

I happen to believe that if someone works in an industry and has contributed a lifetime to that industry and it has been the practice to give free travel when a person retires or while working for that industry, that is it. I think the airlines take it a little far because I do not see that that benefit should apply to girlfriends, fiancees, parents, brothers and sisters. I believe that the benefit should be restricted to the person concerned and spouse. I do not think that it should be open ended, but it is not my business to say that. Fundamentally, it is the business of the management of the airline to decide what practices it wishes to follow for the benefit of its employees. If the airline says, `If you work for us for 20 years you will be entitled to five trips a year within Australia or one trip overseas', that is the airline's business. It is not the business of Government to sit on that airline. The airline can make the decisions as to how it wishes to carve up its cake.

Now the Government is saying to the airlines that all the travel undertaken by its employees will be taxable because the Government believes that it is a benefit. The airlines have said; `Very well, we will pay the benefit'. The figures I have seen in the Press-and they have not been rejected-are to the extent that this will cost the Australian airlines, Trans-Australia Airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Qantas Airways Ltd, between $11m and $13m annually. That is their estimate at present. That does not come out of thin air. The person who will pay that sum will be the poor Australian traveller who wants to fly between Sydney and Perth, and the rest of it. I hope the people in Perth, who have the highest air fares in Australia, get stuck into this socialist Labor Government and say: `What the hell are you doing to our fares by billing them up like this?' This is an absolutely unreasonable thing to do.

The House has before it a set of four Bills. I believe that it is some of the most tragically misguided legislation we have ever seen before this Parliament. It shows no understanding of the practicalities of the Australian commercial world. I do not believe one can reduce the commercial world to simple logical precepts in which everyone does exactly the same thing. I believe a government must strive for fairness and equality between all sections of the community. But where we have practices that have been enshrined for generations-the way people live in the country areas in Australia, the way people work for airlines and the rest of it-there is no point in upsetting them for no benefit to the public purse.

The Government is introducing some very new principles which turn the basis of a taxation liability from the hands of the recipients to the hands of the providers. We are creating a new tax because the taxation rate on this is at the company tax level which is higher than the personal income tax level, or it can be in some cases. Many things that formerly were not liable for tax are now to be taxed, so the Government is creating a new tax base. Knowing governments, I believe the certainty is that that tax base will be expanded in future. What we are doing at the end of the day is increasing costs to Australian industry and commerce at a time when we cannot afford that imposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill and allied Bills that we are now debating make an absolute lie of the claim of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that he was going to introduce a taxation system into this country that would be a simple and fair one that could be understood by all. As Senator MacGibbon pointed out, this package of Bills comes to us freshly guillotined from the other place. It is meant to be simple legislation but contains pages and pages of clause after clause of provisions and explanations.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal specifically with this legislation, I wish to refer to some comments made earlier in the debate by Senator Maguire, a Labor senator from South Australia, my own State. If I understood the good senator correctly, he said that the Opposition position on this package of Bills shows how ready, willing and able we are to get into bed with any particular interest group. Senator Brownhill in my view clearly outlined the manner in which Labor looks after its own vested interests, namely its base support, the unions. One can ask any average Australian how concerned he or she is with the unions and the benefits they get. I suggest that, if Senator Maguire wants to concern himself with those who care for vested interests, let him first look to his Party's relationship with the unions.

The second point which I would like to make with respect to Senator Maguire's comments is that, as I understood him, this legislation was going to get those who are cheating the system. What has not been explained, by Senator Maguire or others, is why the Government cannot get at those who are cheating the system by using the current tax legislation. As Senator MacGibbon said, we on this side of the chamber have no sympathy with tax cheats, but that does not mean that we believe that this legislation is the answer in that respect. Nor, as Senator MacGibbon pointed out, will this legislation specifically affect tax cheats. It will affect thousands of average Australians whom one could not in one's wildest dreams classify as tax cheats. It will affect thousands of rural Australians whom one could not classify as tax cheats.

The simplicity of this package of Bills has been referred to by most of the speakers on this side of the chamber. It is an absolute joke. It will mean more complications for business, for the user of the benefit, and for the poor old pay as you earn taxpayer who happens to have the use of a car as part of his salary package, and as Senator MacGibbon capably outlined it will mean an enormous administrative burden compared to that which the taxpayer may have now. I agree with Senator MacGibbon that this package of Bills just reflects the cowardice and incompetence of this Government in not sorting out the Australian Taxation Office with the laws which are already in place, and that this Government wants, through this legislation, to get at the business community and to get what it can through it.
