If this legislation is so easy to understand-this is one of the criteria set by the Treasurer -and endorsed by the majority of Australians, which is another criterion set by the Treasurer, why is it that my electorate office, and the electorate offices of many other senators and members, are being flooded with telephone calls and letters from concerned Australians who are frightened and unsure about what will happen? Let us remember that we are late in May and a new tax year begins very soon. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard just four of the letters which I have received. The Minister who was previously at the table has seen these letters and has agreed that that can be done.

PROPOSED FRINGE BENEFITS TAXATION

I am writing on behalf of The National Trust of South Australia to express our deep concern at the proposed measure affecting the provision of accommodation to the wardens of our properties. This is contained in the Fringe Benefits Taxation Assessment Bill 1986, as introduced into the House of Representatives on 2 May 1986. As you know the Bill is designed to tax benefits as specified, provided by an employer to an employee in relation to their employment activities. We are dismayed that these provisions will have an unintended and seriously detrimental effect on the heritage conservation activities of The National Trust of South Australia.

As you may be aware The National Trust of South Australia has in its care some 102 built, and 34 natural heritage properties. Whilst some of these properties could be extremely valuable from a commercial aspect, more importantly they are invaluable from a national heritage point of view. To prevent vandalism and monitor the condition of the buildings the Trust maintains a level of surveillance where possible at the sensitive properties by the installation of live-in wardens. In return for these simple but essential duties and for supervising visitors the Trust provides the wardens with free accommodation in the property. From our understanding of its provisions it appears that this rent-free accommodation will be caught within the ambit of the Bill under Clause 137 defining salaries or wages and Clause 148 defining benefits.

Trust earnings from the properties for which it cares are severely restricted by their nature and the 18 properties in which we have had to install wardens merely give an acceptable living standard for the incumbents to provide these essential services.

There is only one paid executive member of staff in the Trust. Together with two specialists, through some 80 branches and committees, they service the thousands of volunteers who are engaged in operating and administering the Trust throughout the State.

It is hard to believe that the proposed legislation is intended to place further financial burdens on a non-profit volunteer organisation which already has the greatest difficulty in finding the large funds necessary to undertake a major portion of the State's heritage conservation work. We raise these implications with you as we feel sure you will agree that this is not the intention of the legislation, and we ask you to support our position by moving an appropriate Amendment.
Yours faithfully

FRINGE BENEFITS TAX TO SLAM HOTEL/MOTEL WORKFORCE
The fringe benefits tax on employee accommodation and meals will increase the nation's hotel and motel tariffs and charges by an average of 9.6 per cent.

``This imposition will force hotels and motels around Australia to generate this additional revenue in order just to pay the so-called in-house fringe benefits'', said Graham Couch, executive director of Flag Inns Limited.

``The average accommodation business demands 24-hour, 7-day a week onsite management. Essentially, this means personnel must reside on the premises in order to effectively provide the full services offered by the business and demanded by the consumer. Yet the Government wishes to put a further tax on this service.

``As the tax is non-deductible, a measure which in itself runs counter to section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, the industry will need to derive an additional $150 million in order to meet the tax.

``Tariffs and charges will need to increase by 9.6% across the board to cover the cost. This, together with the increase of labour and all other costs of operations, will result in a massive inflationary increase in accommodation and hospitality costs of some 20% in the next twelve months. This will have horrendous consequences for the economy and for our competitiveness in the international marketplace.
``The tax is on labour costs and not on `tall poppy' fringe benefits, as was the initial proposition.

``Following a 30% reduction to restaurant turnover as a result of the non-deductibility of entertainment costs, this legislation, if passed, will further reduce the labour workforce and send many businesses, which are only just surviving with the record highest real interest rates, to the wall.

``In the interests of stability of the economy, reduced inflation, and growth in the workforce, we urge you to oppose the legislation.''

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not deal with these letters in detail because they have been incorporated so there is no need, but I will just refer quickly to them individually. The first is from St Ann's College Inc., a university college in Adelaide. That letter outlines and reflects the concerns of the university collegiate housing groups around Australia. They are very concerned about what will happen to them, with the extra costs which this tax will put on them, and with what effect it will have on the fees that may have to be charged to students using that college.

SPEECH.PARA: The second letter I wish to refer to is one I have received from the Lord Mayor of Adelaide. This letter draws a distinction between those officers working for the City of Adelaide and who have the discretionary private use of a vehicle as part of their remuneration. He points out that there are 11 such officers. He also points out that there are 45 other employees who have the use of a vehicle after hours, not as a part of their salary package but because they are expected after hours to be able to attend to council business when problems arise. It seems ludicrous that these people will be affected in this way.

The third letter I wish to refer to is one which I have received from the National Trust of South Australia. It is concerned-this letter reflects the concern of presumably National Trust and equivalent bodies around Australia-with the consequences of their need to have live-in wardens in the residences which they are protecting. The fourth letter is in fact a telex from Flag Inns Ltd. That telex reflects the very real concerns of the motel industry in Australia. One could go on and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard letters from each individual group which is concerned and has a fear of the way in which this tax will operate and how it will effect the whole industry as well as the individual people writing the letters.

If this tax is so easy to understand and is endorsed by the majority of Australians, why is it that the rural sector is so up in arms about the introduction of it, as Senator MacGibbon and Senator Brownhill so capably canvassed in their speeches earlier. I have had many calls and letters of concern from people in the rural sector. They are concerned at the effect this tax will have on so-called fringe benefits which people working for them receive, not because it is a fringe benefit in perhaps the traditional sense of the word, a discretionary part of their income but it is a fringe benefit which they receive as an absolute necessity because of the geographical location, for example, of where they live. There may not be alternative housing for people in those places so housing has to be provided. There is no choice. It is not a discretionary fringe benefit which is paid to rural people as a non-cash benefit to supplement their salaries to evade tax; it is a fringe benefit which they get as a consequence of the nature of the industry in which they work. Another industry which will greatly be affected by this particular tax is the airline industry. Again, there is no point in my outlining for honourable senators present the effect that this tax will have on that industry. It has been amply outlined before.

I would like to make a brief reference to the effect on the car industry. A variety of figures have been quoted about how many people will lose their jobs. I do not want to attempt to put my finger to the wind and give a numerical guess on how many people I think will lose their jobs in my State because of this tax. Suffice it to say that it is not a concern expressed only by members of the Opposition. This is a concern expressed by the Labor Premier in my State, Mr Bannon. While on the topic of Labor people who may have some concern with this tax, I recall a media clipping several weeks ago saying that Senator Georges, after his suspension from the Australian Labor Party, made a comment, the import of which was, as I understood it, that the Labor Party needed to do a bit of growing up, and that that growing up would take place when the Labor Party could see its way to giving some freedom to its members of parliament in votes. As I understood the Press release the point which was being made was that the time had come for people elected for the Labor Party not to simply be seat warmers and go along with the Caucus line but to have some individuality. In this respect, I would be interested to see what South Australian senators will do.

I note that Senator Maguire has spoken in this debate, and I note that Senator Foreman, Senator Elstob, Senator Bolkus and Senator Crowley have not spoken in this debate. It is disgraceful that they have chosen not to do so. Since the question of whether this tax will affect their State has been raised in such a public manner by people on both sides of the political spectrum, I would have thought that it would be the proper thing to do for a senator for South Australia, Liberal or Labor, to address this question at least, particularly because there seems to be indecision within various groups in the Labor Party about this. I mean by that that the Labor Premier in South Australia does not want this tax to proceed in the manner in which it apparently will.

The next point which I would like to address is the burden which this tax places on the business community, a community we are looking to, or should be looking to at the moment, to thrive, to assist us to get out of the mess which we are in with our balance of payments. We should be doing everything that we can to encourage a thriving business community in this country. Instead of that, as Senator MacGibbon pointed out, a tax which one normally thinks is paid for by the person receiving the benefit is now to be paid by the person who is giving the benefit. I think we should ask ourselves why the Government is asking the business community to do what the Australian Tax Commissioner should have been doing for donkeys years.

If honourable senators speak to a variety of accountants-I have spoken to them in Adelaide and I do not assume that they are a different breed to those in other States-they will tell them that the pursuit of the taxable element of the non-cash portion of salary packages has been negligible. In other words, they say that the Commissioner has been absolutely slack. They believe that a significant amount of tax that should have and could have been collected under the existing tax laws has simply been ignored. I do not know whether that was by direction. The inference is that we have a slack Taxation Office and this Government should be bringing it into line and pursuing these benefits through existing laws.

That does not seen to be too much to ask. The Commissioner seems to be a keen sort of gentleman. He sent out his much publicised inquisitorial letter before the legislation was passed and before the last horse trading had been done with the Australian Democrats. We still do not know exactly what will happen. The Commissioner wrote off with great zeal inquiring into matters relating to legislation which had not yet passed this chamber. As he seemed to have such zeal in that area, I cannot adequately explain why he-euphemistically speaking his Office-seems to have lacked in the past the zeal to use all the powers that he has under the existing legislation.

Tonight I would also like to refer briefly to the position of the taxpayer whose non-cash portion of his salary will now be subject to this tax. As has been amply outlined, if that person uses a car, he or she may well have an enormous burden of paperwork and log books. In an administrative sense this measure seems to be a most inefficient way to proceed. I understand that some employers will-in fact I understand that some already have-outline plans to give their employees a choice. Quite simply they will say: `The situation is this: The cost to us is going to go up by so much. That means that either some of you go or some of your benefits go'. Employers will give their employees the choice. What a dreadful position for those people to be put in. If the Government had been doing its job in the first place and if the Taxation Office had been doing its job in the first place, we would not be in this position and the Government would not be suggesting this ludicrous package referred to as the fringe benefits tax.

In approaching my conclusion I return to the question of simplicity. As I have said-I simply want to reinforce it-the implementation of this package will be a nightmare for business, a nightmare for accountants and a nightmare for a number of PAYE taxpayers who will be involved in the administrative mechanisms for the collection of this tax. It makes the claim of the Treasurer that he wants to reform the taxation system so that it is a simpler and fairer system an absolute joke.

The last point I wish to make relates to the Australian Democrats and their role in this matter. As we all know, their slogan is that they want to keep the bastards honest. To me and lots of other Australians that means that they will keep people to a particular standard. If that is what the Democrats are on about and if I were not a committed Liberal, I might be induced to vote for them, but the trouble is that their standard keeps changing. So day by day one does not really know what they will keep the particular government of the day to. Their standards change according to what bargain they can strike with those who are in government at the time. I will not go so far as to call them the prostitutes of politics; they are simply horse traders. In my mind there is no policy or principle that guides the Democrats. Their claim of keeping the bastards honest is a lot of rubbish; they are simply horse traders. In my view Senator Chipp should read the open letter addressed to him in the media-I believe it was in the Australian-and devote a considerable period to reflecting on those remarks. There are many Australians who are sick to death of a few people who have been elected to the senate wavering around, not on principle, but simply on the best bargain that they can strike. On that note, I will conclude. There is nothing else I want to say that has not been said before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity that the whole of the Senate has had to debate the very real problems facing the Government and the country as a whole. I say that because it is the first time the Government has admitted many things. Over the last 18 months to two years, the Opposition has been a lone voice in warning the community of the impending catastrophe facing our nation. It has now been joined, belatedly, by the Labor Government. In a flash of genuine concern-I believe that it was genuine-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told us that his plans just have not worked. He said that our economic situation was a disaster, that Australia has fallen into a hole and that our economy now equals that of a banana republic. He told us that we cannot go on living the way we are when we are not earning enough to supplement that lifestyle. At last the Treasurer has told Australians that.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past we were told by the Government: `She'll be right, mate. There's a J-curve just around the corner and as long as we all continue to abide by the wages accord we will continue to receive full wage increases in line with the inflation rate'. Even though the productivity situation was pretty dicey, we could do that. After all, the J-curve was just around the corner. We were told that because productivity had risen in some industries we could all ask for a 3 per cent productivity rise in the form of superannuation. Indeed, the Government attempted to intimidate the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in that way. Every time the Opposition warned that these policies would be a disaster, the Government ridiculed it and the media said that it was just being political. So the man in the street was lulled into a false sense of security and he spent up big on expensive imports.

The first warning came when the value of the Australian dollar dropped and interest rates went up. However, this was all ignored by the Government, which kept telling the Australian people that those high interest rates would not last long. It said: `Do not forget that the J-curve is just around the corner'. Meanwhile, the dollar continued to fall and interest rates continued to climb. Then housing money started to dry up. Who would lend money at 13 1/2 per cent when he could get 20 per cent? Not many. The J-curve was still around the corner but it had not arrived so the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) put up the interest rates on housing loans to 15 per cent. The Opposition continued to issue warnings. It was still a lone voice saying: `Things have got to change. The Government cannot continue to hide its head and live in a fool's paradise'. We could not afford the Government's generosity in its agreement with the trade unions about the 3 per cent productivity claim when there was no productivity rise across the board.

The crunch finally came when the latest balance of payments figures were released. We found that what the Opposition had been saying over the past two years was all too true. Mr Keating's screech of anguish was heard all over Australia and then there was the refusal by the world's best Treasurer to say anything for 24 hours. It did not matter who tried to interview him, he was saying nothing. The world's best Treasurer declined to be interviewed. Finally, there was the admission that the J-curve would not arrive and that Australians must do something about it. Indeed, it was stated that we were a banana republic. Of course, that did not do much for our Australian dollar. But the Prime Minister, all the way from China, tried to drag the Treasurer to his feet. The best that the Treasurer could dream up was to say that it certainly was not his fault. He said that the reasons were, firstly, that the nasty Opposition had left him with a big deficit three years ago; and, secondly, that the prices of all our normally reliable trading goods had gone down. He said that that was what was wrong; it was not his fault, but the prices of all our major trading goods had dropped and there was nothing he could do about that. He said that, after all, his policies were still all right, although the 3 per cent productivity gain might have to be delayed-at least temporarily. Then he said that, even though he was correct, the tax cuts that he had promised for 1 September might have to be delayed-but of course only temporarily. But of course, he said that the fringe benefits tax, that we are discussing tonight, just had to go ahead because the Government has already spent that money. After all, it needs that money to pay the interest on its enormous debt; that is why this tax has to go ahead.

First of all, let us just briefly examine the two claims by Mr Keating. The first was that what happened was really not his fault but the fault of the nasty Opposition that left him the debt. I will use the deficit figures for the years 1975-76 to 1985-86. All of these figures are in 1984-85 dollar terms so they account for inflation. In 1975-76, when Gough Whitlam left us the mess that he did, Australia was $7.9 billion in debt in 1984-85 figures. The next year, the figure was $6.4 billion because the Fraser Government had come into power. The figure then went down to $5.4 billion, then $5.9 billion, then $3.2 billion, then $1.6 billion in 1980-81. In 1981-82 we were only $0.7 billion in debt. In 1982-83 it blew out to $5.1 billion because we were facing the worst drought in the nation's history. What has happened since then, when we left that debt to the Treasurer? In 1983-84 the figure was $8.5 billion. Even though it had rained and the drought had broken, it went from $5.1 billion to $8.5 billion. In 1984-85 it was $6.7 billion.

So, having got rid of the fallacy that we left the Labor Government with a large debt, let us look at the second reason given by the Treasurer-that the prices of all the things that we export have fallen and that there is really nothing that he can do about it. Of course, there is a heck of a lot that we can do about that. Our main exports come from our rural areas. Our competitors are New Zealand, the United States of America and the European Economic Community. One would hardly call them Third World countries that rely on slave labour.

Our rural industries are acknowledged to be the most efficient in the world. They certainly can compete, if only the Government would keep off their backs and let them get on with the job instead of stifling them at every turn. I will just give an example of what I mean by that. I gave the figures to the Minister yesterday. Let us look at the problem of the cost of meat inspectors in the meat industry. In Victoria for the 12 months ended March 1985 it cost the Federal Department of Primary Industry $13.7m to inspect 8.6 million units slaughtered. But the State Department of Agriculture processed 16.4 million units at a cost of $8.4m. In other words, the State could do it for 50c a head while the cost for Federal meat inspectors was $1.60 a head. That is the sort of cost that that rural industry is paying.

We have a balance of payments figure that the Treasurer assures us has turned us into a banana republic with little chance of repaying our debt. What does this Government-those banana people opposite-do? In all its wisdom it decided to impose an additional fringe benefits tax. We have been told by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association that this will cost rural industry $150m. That burden of $150m will be put on that struggling industry and will ensure that, if it had been able to compete overseas through its expertise, its chances are put paid to.

At a time when figures released by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics show a dramatic drop in net income per farm from $19,500 in 1984-85 to an estimate of just over $6,500 for this year-just one-third of the previous year's income-the Government has decided to add an additional cost of $150m. Last week I asked the Treasurer's office to tell me how the tax would affect the farming community. The answer I got from his staff was that they did not intend to divulge that figure. I asked whether they knew what the figure was and they said: `No comment. We have no intention of telling you what it is'. What are they trying to hide?

I have done a few sums. If the Government believes that they are wrong, let it correct me and tell me where I am wrong. With regard to on-farm employee accommodation, my figure, which is a very conservative one, is over $33m, using the Treasurer's figure of $40 per week for rent and allowing the 40 per cent isolation rebate on each of the 54,000 units. There are 54,000 units of such accommodation in Australia. We all know that many of those rentals will be higher than $40, but I have used the Treasurer's figures. Not all farms are in what the Treasurer, designates isolated areas. Indeed, I suppose only half of those units are in areas over 40 kilometres from a country town with a population of over 14,000. On top of those basic on-farm units, of course there are the principal farmhouses for non-family partnerships and private companies that will also incur the fringe benefits tax, as will many other types of trusts, et cetera. But, if we take just those first two, the non-family partnerships and the family companies, which clearly are covered by the fringe benefits legislation, we are told that there are 6,118 non-family partnerships and 8,601 private companies. My figure for that is $9,103,166. Apart from on-farm accommodation, other fringe benefits have to be taken into account such as meat and other produce allowed to the farm hands. The figure for meat alone is $40.5m.

But perhaps the worst part of all is the ability of the Government to tax parents for the cost of board for their children who are employed on the property. So many children follow onto the family farm. Now the father who owns the farm will be forced to pay tax on his child's accommodation and the meals supplied by the mother when that child is working on the farm. According to the little purple book, accommodation and meals will be valued at $42-which is really quite unbelievable. Then we come to consider the car on the farm. I will quote from the letter that the Commissioner of Taxation supplied to the Australian Democrats. It says:

A car owned by a company (e.g., a family company) which operates a primary production business would thus be treated as being available for private use by an employee of the company if garaged or kept at or close to the farmhouse where the employee lives.

In such a case, however, fringe benefits tax will not be payable if the car is used only for business purposes and the employer elects the cost basis of valuation rather than the statutory formula. Log book records of business and any private mileage would need to be kept. If all trips during a day are business trips only 1 log book entry would be required for the day.

The Commissioner does not say that if that farmer or employee goes to town to pick up a bit of machinery and takes his wife along to do the shopping, that is classed as private use. According to the little purple book, it is classed as private use, and therefore, the farmer has to consider that part of the usage as private use. The letter from the Commissioner of Taxation is most interesting. It underlines the Opposition's concerns. It will be interesting reading for some back bench members. I ask leave, Mr Acting Deputy President, to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION
Mr Greg Smith,...28 May 1986
Treasurer's Office,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA ACT 2600
FRINGE BENEFITS TAX ISSUES

The following notes are provided as requested on various fringe benefits tax issues that you spoke to me about as having been raised in the course of discussions with the Australian Democrats and others.
Clergymen

It has been suggested that the exemption from FBT of benefits provided by a religious institution to a minister of religion will not apply if the minister calls in socially on parishioners. That is not so. The test for exemption is whether the benefit (the use of a car) is provided principally in respect of pastoral duties or other duties or activities directly related to the practice, study, teaching or propagation of religious beliefs. If that test is satisfied, as it would be in the ordinary case of a clergyman working in a parish, the occasional use of the car for other than ``pastoral'' pursuits would be irrelevant.

An associated matter raised by the Uniting Church is whether Lay Pastors would be treated in the same way as ordained clergy for FBT purposes. Lay Pastors may act in the place of an ordained Minister in the event of a ministerial vacancy and are otherwise appointed to assist a Minister.

As a preliminary view, we think that while acting in the place of a Minister a Lay Pastor could be regarded as a Minister pro tem. On that basis fringe benefits provided to the Lay Pastor principally in respect of pastoral duties would be exempt while the Lay Pastor continued to act in the capacity of a Minister.
Cars on rural properties

The FBT legislation specifies that while a car is garaged or kept at or near the place of residence of an employee it will be taken as being available for the private use of that employee. A car owned by a company (e.g., a family company) which operates a primary production business would thus be treated as being available for private use by an employee of the company if garaged or kept at or close to the farmhouse where the employee lives.

In such a case, however, fringe benefits tax will not be payable if the car is used only for business purposes and the employer elects the cost basis of valuation rather than the statutory formula. Log book records of business and any private mileage would need to be kept. If all trips during a day are business trips only 1 log book entry would be required for the day.
Residential accommodation-caretakers, national trust buildings, etc.

The FBT rules specify that tax is payable on the market value of residential accommodation provided to employees. This would include persons such as caretakers of national trust buildings, lighthouse-keepers, etc. It has been proposed that national trust accommodation be exempt, on the grounds that the tax will reduce the amount available for restoration and maintenance etc. of the buildings. It has also been suggested that accommodation provided to persons who are required to live on premises as a condition of their employment (caretakers, hotel managers, lighthouse-keepers) should not be subject to FBT.

We see no merit in either proposition. The Government has resisted the comparable argument of charitable organisations that they should be exempted from the tax because it would eat into the funds available for charitable activities. (See Mr Evans' note to the Treasurer yesterday). FBT is effectively a tax on the remuneration of employees, and there is no reason in principle why the benefits of one class of employee should not bear the same tax as those of other employees. It would be difficult to give exemption to national trust bodies while holding the line on charities.

As to hotel managers, general caretakers, etc., we do not see any reason why such benefits should be exempted from FBT when it is well recognised that accommodation that goes with the job is part of such an employee's remuneration. If they were to be exempted from FBT, a clear tax advantage would be established over accommodation benefits provided to other employees which will generally be taxed on a market value basis. That advantage could not be justified.

There have been questions as to whether the market value rule will produce an unreasonably high FBT taxable value in some cases, e.g., where a manager is provided with accommodation in a luxury hotel or tourist resort. Here the yardstick for valuing the benefit is not what a casual paying guest would pay for accommodation in the hotel or resort. Our valuers would take the view that other parallels would be more appropriate to use in assessing the market value for FBT. For example the value of live-in accommodation of a manager of a city hotel may more appropriately be equated with rents for a reasonably comparable standard residential apartment in the vicinity charged to long term occupants. Any restrictive conditions imposed on the use of the premises occupied by a caretaker in say a national trust classified building would also be weighed in arriving at the market value appropriate to the benefit.
Board and quarters under rural awards

You also referred to the operation of the FBT legislation in relation to board and accommodation benefits provided to employees under the terms of an award. You mentioned that under a particular farm workers' award, board and accommodation provided by an employer to an employee is valued at $26 per week.

We are aware that under a number of awards an employer is required to provide either free board and accommodation to an employee or to pay the employee an allowance in lieu of board and accommodation.

Examples are the Federal Pastoral Industry Award and the Queensland Shearing Industry Award which set out the rates of pay for employees engaged in shearing. The Awards set the rate of pay for individual categories of employee on a ``Not Found'' basis, reducing the rate where meals and accommodation are provided by the employer. This reduction is the ``Not Found'' allowance, which represents the value of meals and accommodation and is treated as a living-away-from-home allowance. Where meals and accommodation are provided by the employer, the employment is said to be on a ``Found'' basis.

The current rate of ``Not Found'' allowance applicable in all Australian States, except for shearers and woolpressers under the Queensland Award, is understood to be $47.35 per week. Under the Queensland Award shearers and woolpressers are from 15 April 1985 entitled to a ``Not Found'' allowance of $81.22 per week.

The values specified in an award may be the result of many historical and other factors and do not necessarily represent the current value of the benefit. Values specified in different awards for similar kinds of benefits can also vary considerably.

Under the FBT legislation, board provided to an employee will be valued at the rate of $42 per week (less any employee contribution). That valuation will generally be concessional. In the case of non-remote accommodation, the taxable value of the benefit will be equal to the market rental value of the accommodation (less any rent paid by the employee). The market value will vary according to such factors as the size and standard of the accommodation and its location. In many cases, the market value of accommodation provided to farm workers will be quite low. If the employee concerned is living away from home, the accommodation benefit will be exempt.
B. M. NOLAN
First Assistant Commissioner

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I do not know how the Treasurer can come up with such a crippling tax on an industry on which we are relying to help Australia recover from our disastrous balance of payments. Basically, what is so unjust about this tax is that the Government has charged the employers for a tax on the income of the employees. Senator Siddons also pointed this out. The injustice of this is incredible. The Government knows only too well that if it taxed those who receive the benefit, the industrial relations shemozzle would put it out of business. It knows that the employers will pay up and that the unions, as usual, will not. But all Australians will pay eventually.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hydro Electric Commission in Tasmania, with subsidised accommodation for its workers, will be charged fringe benefits tax which it has estimated to be about $1m. Where will that money end up? It will be on the electricity bill of every Tasmanian household. We have the idiotic situation where Tarraleah is considered urban but Poatina, with another hydro-electric power station, in considered to be isolated. The accommodation allowances in those two places will vary considerably. The whole thing is ridiculous. Every Australian taxpayer will pay. Charities will be covered-religious and others. We have had letters from the National Trust of Australia. That is a very fine example of an institution that will pay. Schools and colleges where teachers live in, housekeepers--

TALK.START.PARA: —But they will not be now. Don't you know what the facts are?

—If Senator Chipp does not understand that, he needs to have another look at the legislation. Teachers and housekeepers will still pay. Caretakers as a whole and a multitude of people will pay. The Labor back bench has been absolutely hoodwinked into believing that just the wealthy executives will be disadvantaged. But 65 per cent of people receive some sort of fringe benefit. It is Labor's voters who will be disadvantaged by this tax. We on this side of politics do not believe that high executives should be able to claim as much as they do. The Taxation Office is able to cover this abuse. On this matter we would agree with the Government if it were able to rectify the situation through the normal channels. We will not and cannot agree on-and we will repeal when we get into government-taxes that tax the employer rather than people who receive the benefit. The whole situation is unjust. The Labor back bench has been completely hoodwinked by its executive.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not spoken about the way the tax affects the car industry. So many people have already spoken on that matter. The Democrats have assured us that they have done a deal with the Government. Senator Chipp is talking about it right now. They have said that they will cut the car tax by one-third. We will see what comes of that. In return they sought the written-I stress `written'-agreement of the Prime Minister. They do not trust his word, according to news reports; they have demanded it all in writing. It is obvious that the Democrats pay so little regard to the Prime Minister's word that they insist on having the agreement in writing that the tax cuts will be introduced by the end of the year. We will see what happens with the economy at the end of December.

Finally, the debate underlines the half-hearted effort by the back bench opposite. There are only four Labor speakers out of 22 on this legislation. That underlines their half-hearted efforts more than anything else. They are scared stiff of this package of Bills. How many of their supporters will be affected is only now coming home to them. Those opposite are running scared but they are not allowed to back off. As I said, the Government needs the money to pay the interest on its enormous deficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the uneducated-by that I mean someone who does not know the ways of this Government-it might seem amazing that with the economy going into recession, with the balance of trade looking like being about $15 billion in deficit this year, with inflation twice that of our trading partners and rising when theirs is falling, with interest rates still around record high levels and the dollar struggling to stand up, we are tonight debating yet another new tax with the promise of more to come. I remind the Senate that at the end of last week the House of Representatives introduced a further six taxation Bills which we are yet to debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to argue tonight that this new and additional tax in the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax Bill, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Bill and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill is unwarranted and unnecessary; that the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act are sufficient to counter abuse if they are enforced by the Commissioner of Taxation and if the Commissioner had the encouragement of this Government to enforce them; and that this tax is inflationary at a time when, as I have indicated, Australia's inflation rate is not only high but continuing to rise. I shall argue that this is an enormously complex piece of legislation when anyone would agree that one of the basic principles of all taxation law should be to keep such laws as simple as possible; that it will be administratively expensive, to say the least, again at a time when we should be reducing the administrative costs of our businesses rather than increasing them; and that it is full of anomalies and technical shortcomings.

What I do not want to argue is that a non-cash personal use benefit that arises out of employment should not be taxable. The employment package obviously should be taxed as a whole. One should not simply be able to avoid a taxation liability by receiving part of it in the form of a non-cash benefit; that has never been the attitude of this side of the chamber. So I invite the Government to forget about all the nonsense it has come out with about our wishing to support tax cheats. We say that a non-tax benefit that is part of an employment package obviously should be taxed.

However, this is a new tax. It is a new tax upon employers. It is a tax on the total value of fringe benefits provided to employees or their associates-we have a broad definition-during the tax year. Employers providing fringe benefits will be required to lodge an annual return. The employer must calculate the tax payable. I stress that it will mean a further load upon the employer. He must make the calculation of tax payable. To determine that, he must first determine what fringe benefits come within the legislation. The assessment is deemed to have been made when the return is lodged and the return is deemed to be notice of the assessment.

The legislation contains specific provisions for identifying and valuing the various kinds of fringe benefits. As I have indicated, that becomes the responsibility of the employer. Apart from New Zealand, where a somewhat similar tax was introduced last year, it is an unique form of taxation. I suppose the closest analogy could be drawn with a State payroll tax. It is a tax upon employment; a tax that is liable to be paid by the employer. The difference between this tax and the State payroll tax is that in this case it is not deductible and therefore will be more expensive to the employer. It will therefore clearly increase the costs of production which will either reduce profits, which I would have thought was undesirable now, or be passed on in the form of higher prices for goods or services, which, similarly and obviously, will contribute to domestic inflation, making our exports even more uncompetitive than they are now. I would have thought that would be undesirable even to this Government.

It is a tax which is to apply to bodies exempt from income tax. It is to apply to charities, clubs and societies, schools and tertiary and research institutions, hospitals and medical benefits associations, State and local government and union and employer organisations. So we have the ridiculous situation where a charity that is raising money from the public but which may have to provide a benefit to an employee in a distant area, or for numerous other reasons, will be taxed in this way. So those who voluntarily raise moneys for such charities could well find their contributions being paid out in the form of a fringe benefits tax. Again, I would have thought that was ridiculous. Equally ridiculous is the fact that governments are going to be paying the tax. In other words it will be taken out of one pocket to be put into another, a fact that this Government does not seem to be able to see.

It is a tax which, notwithstanding the fact that its incidence is so wide, contains clear loop- holes within the legislation. For example, it is argued that non-contributory superannuation will not be included. It is argued that interest free loans used by employees to purchase shares will not be included. It does not take much imagination to look at a whole series of dividends-based packages that will avoid the fringe benefits tax. Each of these three examples, I would have thought, was a good reason for a fringe benefits tax not to apply. Nevertheless, I have not heard from the Government that this has been done deliberately. I presume that it is just an oversight. An oversight like this will always occur in such complex legislation.

Not only are there clear loopholes in the legislation but also it is clear that there still may be benefits to an employee in an employer paying the fringe benefits tax, particularly while the rate of individual income tax remains so much higher. Obviously, if that tax rate comes down the benefits will lessen. However, as we are aware, the date for these proposed income tax cuts seems to be getting further away. We are yet to see whether they will occur. Even if they do occur, in the figures that have been put down by the Government there are still circumstances in which there will be a benefit to the employee if the employer paid the tax.

I argue that the tax is unnecessary because fringe benefits are adequately covered in the existing legislation. I spoke at some length about that in a speech I made on 1 May and, therefore, will not repeat the total argument. Section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act is adequate to catch non-cash benefits of this kind in the same way that the Income Tax Assessment Act was adequate not to allow deductions for entertainment expenses that were not incurred in the course of raising taxable income. In the same way, the Act has been found to be adequate to counter various anti-avoidance measures. Yet this Government has insisted on adding piece after piece of unnecessary legislation. Those of us on this side of the chamber would have much preferred the Government to exhaust the existing provisions of the Act before bringing to us such massive and complex additional legislation. Not only do we argue that this legislation is unnecessary but also, as I said, in my opening remarks, it is legislation of enormous complexity. Speakers before me have gone through at some length the provisions that relate particularly to car benefits provided as fringe benefits for employees. The law that we are being asked to enact is enormously complex, and I am not going to go through it all.

What I would prefer to look at rather than the legal aspect of the legislation is the administrative aspect of employers who must put into effect their obligations in relation to motor vehicle fringe benefits. I thought this was very well summarised in an article by Mr Bob Garbutt of Price Waterhouse which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on Monday 19 May of this year. The article is headed: `The Fringe Benefits Tax-Either way, it's piles of paperwork'. That is an apt heading for an analysis of the administrative ordeal under which employers will be put in implementing these provisions as they relate to car benefits. As you are aware, Mr President, a choice can be made between the statutory formula basis or the so-called operating cost basis or actual base. If the employer chooses the former, he no longer has a choice in moving to the other, so he has lost all flexibility. But if he chooses the former, the Bill does not set down specific record keeping requirements; nevertheless Price Waterhouse advises that a number of records are necessary reasonably to meet the administrative requirements.

Price Waterhouse suggests that the employer should keep a vehicle register which should show for each vehicle the base value, which will not be easy to calculate. It will have to include the purchase cost, including sales tax paid, and special rules apply in relation to that. It should include the delivery costs where applicable, the cost of any private accessories subsequently fitted and, if the car is leased, its market value at the time the lease commenced. It should also include the date of purchase, the date of sale, the number of kilometres travelled in each year ending on 31 March. For the transitional year which ends in March next year, this information has to be kept on a quarterly basis for 30 September 1986, 31 December 1986 and 31 March 1987. The record should also include the number of days in each period that the vehicle was used or was available for private use. It should also include the amount, if any, paid by the employee for car expenses not reimbursed to him in each period to which I have referred.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Canberra: Future Development Along Murrumbidgee River-Opposition's Waste Watch Committee

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In July 1984 the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Capital Territory reported to the Parliament on its inquiry into the Murrumbidgee River in the Australian Capital Territory region. One of the things that the Committee was looking into was the impact of future developments in the Territory region and Canberra's future urban development on the Murrumbidgee River. Of course that specifically refers to the development of the Tuggeranong area. That was quite specifically dealt with and I refer to paragraph 10 of chapter 5 in which we said:

SPEECH.PARA: Urban run-off from Tuggeranong already has caused considerable pollution of the Murrumbidgee at stormwater discharge points. This pollution has been worst when heavy rains have washed fine earth material from construction sites, greatly increasing turbidity in the River.

It is a fragile river, Mr President, as you will appreciate and of course it does not belong only to the Australian Capital Territory. It starts in New South Wales and it continues on for a considerable distance in that State. We therefore have a great responsibility to see that what we do in our portion of the river does not cause pollution in other parts. I have received correspondence from Mr John Rowland, the President of the Conservation Council of the South-East Region and Canberra, a voluntary group which represents about 25 organisations and takes an interest in conservation. It certainly took an interest, along with many other people, in the inquiry to which I have referred. He refers to the Council's dismay-that is my word-at the damage currently being done to the Murrumbidgee by run-off, in particular from the development works in Tuggeranong and specifically Calwell and Theodore, he says, rather than the town centre site itself.

The Committee spent a lot of time looking at the impact of the town centre development. It was our view that the lake should go in first to protect the river from the development, but we accepted the National Capital Development Commission's assurance that it would be able to put in place procedures that would protect it, and it is hoped that that is happening. I will seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard as well as other correspondence which tells the story. I will not go into it in detail. There is a letter to the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) relating to the activities of the ACT Electricity Authority and its apparent failure to protect the area, and there is reference to what may perhaps be regarded as an offence under the Water Pollution Ordinance in relation to Tuggeranong Creek; there is a letter to the Chief Inspector of the Residential Leases Section of the Department of Territories concerning inspection processes; a letter to the Assistant Secretary of the Land Management Branch of the Department of Territories; and a letter to an Assistant Commissioner of the NCDC, all discussing the issues which are involved and the numbers of people concerned in the development in that area.

I think the Minister needs to institute an urgent examination of the practices of development in the Tuggeranong area. We need to ensure that damage from run-off into the Murrumbidgee River-as I said, a fragile river-is avoided. With the heavy rains that we have had recently, that is difficult and of course if we have further rains the problem will continue. I now seek leave to have those letters incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
CONSERVATION COUNCIL OF THE SOUTH-EAST REGION & CANBERRA (INC.)
PO Box 1875,
Canberra City,
Australia
Senator Margaret Reid
Parliament House
Canberra 2601
Dear Senator Reid,

I enclose copies of some recent correspondence to the NCDC, Mr Scholes, the Residential Leases section of the Department of Territories, and the Land Management Branch of the Department, regarding the damage currently being done by run-off to the Murrumbidgee from land development works in Tuggeranong. The key areas of concern, it is now apparent, are in Calwell and Theodore, rather thant the Town Centre itself. Both the NCDC and the Department of Territories Environmental Protection Section have been quite open about the magnitude of the problem. The question is now what remedies can be found-such as seeking the necessary NCDC contract variations, tightening up the Department's `handover' requirements and enforcing the provisions of the Water Pollution Ordinance on both private contractors and government authorities (notably ACTEA and Telecom). Time is short, with winter fast approaching. Official figures for soil run-off in one upstream tributary from a land development site after recent moderate rain were over 300 times higher than the accepted figure for a river of the Murrumbidgee's nature.
We seek the assistance of your good offices in effecting the necessary protection measures.
Our thanks for your attention.
Yours sincerely,
John Rowland
President
CONSERVATION COUNCIL OF THE SOUTH-EAST REGION & CANBERRA (INC.)
PO Box 1875,
Canberra City,
Australia
Hon. G. Scholes
Minister for Territories
Parliament House
Canberra 2601
Dear Mr Scholes,

We are writing to you in your capacity as Minister responsible for the A.C.T. Electricity Authority. We are concerned at ACTEA practices on new residential blocks, following inspections this week in the Calwell development.

We observed piles of earth from ACTEA cable-laying in gutters, above the Tuggeranong Creek; this is an offence under the Water Pollution Ordinance, with a specified fine of $10,000 (Tuggeranong Creek being a Class R Waterway). We also observed areas where ACTEA had finished, leaving bare tamped-down earth, rather than regrassed areas which are necessary to control erosion.

Can you assure us that the observed offence was an aberration, and offer assurances that it will not be repeated? Can you advise us as to ACTEA's formal guidelines for management of such works, and site regeneration?

We look forward to your co-operation in this matter.

Our thanks for our recent briefing on the Tuggeranong situation, as it affects Tuggeranong Creek and the Murrumbidgee. This of course threatens to nullify the Town Centre controls, which are clearly not designed to withstand the combined impact of storm run-off from the upstream suburban catchment and the Centre itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise briefly to express my concern at a speech made in the other House last night in the adjournment debate by a Mr Gear from Canning, who sought to attack the Waste Watch Committee on several grounds. Basically, in effect, he was trying to hold us I suppose in terrorem; he tried to terrorise the Waste Watch Committee out of its proper task of seeking information by way of the methods available to us, despite the Government's attempts to block the flow of information to me and my Committee. The methods we have available to us include the reading of reports, which we do with some interest and enthusiasm; the telephoning of departmental officers to gain information that should properly be available to us; and when that source is blocked by instructions from the Government itself, as it has been in the matter of the community employment program through the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, we have to use the other more expensive methods available.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that Mr Gear in making his complaints was obviously either unaware of or deliberately chose not to reveal the fact that members of the Waste Watch Committee had been blocked from getting information from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on what we understood to be the instruction of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that no information be given to us over the telephone by officers of his Department, even when the information simply involved asking for the date a release was made, for the amount of that release, or the formal name of the recipients of the money involved in that release. We have been told that simple questions like that are to be referred to the Minister's office, on the instruction of the Minister.

I have no reason to disbelieve the public servants involved. It is a clear and deliberate attempt to limit the flow of information-information that is in the public interest-to the Waste Watch Committee. As a result, we have had no option but to seek information through measures that are far more expensive and Mr Gear, in the other place, has complained about the costs of the search for such information. All I suggest to Mr Gear is that he advise his ministerial colleagues that if they are so desperate to save money in the search for information, they provide it much more readily than has been the case so far so that more expensive methods, particularly using the Freedom of Information Act, will not be necessary.

We have been forced to use that Act after having been refused information by this Government on an increasing number of occasions. We have to use the provisions of the Act to try to force information out. I can assure the Government that at the weekend it will be seeing some of the results of the use of the Freedom of Information Act, which was the only way we could get information in a couple of matters which are naturally very embarrassing to the Government and, having received the information, we now understand why the Government was so keen to block the supply of that information. But for Mr Gear to pretend that it is somehow improper for the Waste Watch Committee to use the remedies available to it-expensive though they may be-because easier and less expensive remedies are being denied to us by this Government which is supposed to be committed to the concept of open govern- ment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—Exactly. As my cousin Senator Peter Baume says, `Ha!' This Government has made a mockery of the concept of open government. Its continual refusals to provide information which should properly be made available and which ultimately is, after appeal, forced to be released, is a disgrace. I need only remind the Senate of the fact that this Government, having already and continually misused what it was pleased to describe as a forward deficit estimate, from its first year on, has refused to release similar information which it was prepared to misuse in relation to the Fraser Government. The Government has refused to release such information because it says that forward estimates of the deficit are misleading and it is not in the public interest for them to be revealed. That simply demonstrates the double standards of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am more concerned about Mr Gear's attack on the Waste Watch Committee. He said that the Committee has cost more in Public Service revenue than it has saved in the waste it has exposed. I believe that Mr Gear was being the hatchet man for the Ministry, which is now becoming, naturally and properly, unnerved about the success of the Waste Watch Committee in exposing ridiculous and disgraceful examples of Government waste. This is a crude and, I suggest, offensive method of trying to force the Waste Watch Committee, by seeking to accuse it of being wasteful in its search for information, out of the arena so that it will cease its activities of exposing the incompetence and waste in so many areas of this Government. I can assure the Government that its efforts will be unsuccessful. I can assure the media that we will continue to provide information of public interest and of public concern about governmental waste, whether we get it despite Government objection and Government obfuscation or not. I am intrigued to see, by the way, that Mr Gear has called on Senator Walsh to require all questions on notice to be costed so that an accurate cost of any abuse of this research service can be identified. I am interested to see that he is now in favour of adding an additional cost-I am not quite certain whether Senator Walsh will be overjoyed by that thought-in order to try once again to hold us in terrorem to frighten us out of making quite proper requests.

There is one other point I would like to make and that is that Mr Gear says that, because the Committee has not contacted any of the Ministers responsible for the spending it criticises to offer any advice on ways in which taxpayers' money can be saved, he believes that this shows that the Committee is not interested in playing a constructive role in saving money or lowering taxes. I remind Mr Gear and the Government that when the Grace Committee established its extraordinary effectiveness in the United States of America it was suggested to this Government that it might be very useful indeed if a similar committee were established in Australia. The private sector pressed for it and this Opposition pressed for it, but this Government refused to be a party to such an arrangement because it has so much to hide. It would not have an independent body like the Grace Committee in the United States, which was so successful in curbing government waste, examining this Government's waste and spending. The Waste Watch Committee of the Opposition was created because of the refusal of the Government to accept the proposition that an independent body like the Grace Committee should be appointed. If the Government wants someone to provide it and its Ministers with information let it accept the offer or the suggestion that was made to it by this Opposition and by the private sector and not come on with this sanctimonious rubbish about how the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee is not behaving properly if it first does not reveal to the Minister involved where there is such evidence of waste.

I repeat: This kind of nonsense will not diminish our enthusiasm, nor will attempts to belittle our endeavours by referring, for example, to a former Prime Minister's car bill. I have dealt with that matter on other occasions. I do hope that the whole question of car costs will be resolved when Mr Neil Brown takes what I hope will be some strong action in this matter, particularly in the matter of the applying to him of bills for which he had and should have had absolutely no responsibility. I remind the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) that when people raise, as Mr Gear did, clearly on ministerial instruction, the matters of Mr Fraser's car bill, there is clear evidence that the whole administration and costing arrangements of the Commonwealth car pool are ludicrous. The $250,000 car bill last year for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is a clear nonsense. I use that example not to criticise the Prime Minister's car use but simply to say that of that $250,000 that the Prime Minister had marked against him for his car use last year his personal car use was listed as being $130,000, which would have required him to have been in his personal car 22 hours out of the 24 hours of every day of the year at the normal costing rate. In other words, the costings are absolute nonsense. I would hope that using the Prime Minister's car bill as an example demonstrates that. I can also assure the Government that any attempts to frighten us out of continuing our work will fail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not here for the whole of Senator Michael Baume's speech. As for his remarks on the distribution of costs for the use of Commonwealth cars, I could not agree with him more. In fact, many of us have questioned the manner in which this calculation has been made, not only by this Government but by previous governments and previous administrations. The only thing I would say about it is that the sort of pot shotting that has been going on at Mr Neil Brown and others about the costs of cars and travel is something that has been going on for as long as I have been here. In fact, one year I was the subject of that sort of behaviour. The leader of the pack baying at me at the time, publicly and privately I might add, was none other than the Hon. Neil Brown. I must say that it was with considerable pleasure that I saw the headlines that he received over his car use. I must say that I did not join in that sort of thing. I was just pleased that somebody who had been living by the sword was copping a bit of the sword himself.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a bit much for Senator Michael Baume to think that someone like George Gear is egged on by Ministers in this Government to frighten the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. I do not think anybody frightens the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee any more than the Waste Watch Committee frightens the Government. But I will say that what Mr Gear did was to point out, as he is entitled to do and as he will do again and as other people will do, to the people of this country that the Waste Watch Committee's activities cost taxpayers money. It is no good Senator Michael Baume saying to someone like me who was a shadow Minister from 1976 to 1983 that it is outrageous for this Government or any Minister in this Government to tell his public servants to be limited in the answers they give to Opposition senators. I well remember that in that whole six years no officers from the Department of Social Security were allowed to speak to me at all. In fact, in the case of the Greek conspiracy case I got up in this place and asked question after question, but I never got any answers from the Minister or from the public servants. In fact, this whole sordid tale leaked out bit by bit.

I believe in the freedom of information legislation but I also believe that the costs of that freedom of information legislation should be exposed in this place. I point out to Senator Michael Baume that a Minister in the Government of which he was at one stage a supporter and an employee used the freedom of information legislation, at a cost of thousands of dollars, to find out personal details of the lives of members of the Government, to find out whether they were married to the people they were living with. When he got that information he distributed it around the electorate, not in his name but through members of his Party in the electorate, who then passed it on. In one case it was given to Senator Harradine, who refused to use it and refused to participate in that sort of nonsense.

I happen to be very much in favour of the Freedom of Information Act. I am very much in favour of freedom of information. I think it is a great advance and I support it very much, but it can be abused. It can be overused, and it can be abused in the way that a Minister in the previous Government abused it to find out the personal details of people's lives. I think that, if that happens, George Gear or anyone else in this Parliament has every right to expose that sort of behaviour and expose the costs of the use of that legislation.

I wish the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee well. I see that in the first few weeks it had a few problems and got a few things wrong. I dare say that it will get some things right and some things wrong. We may all benefit from it. As long as honourable senators opposite do not keep the President and me up, by bringing it up every night on the adjournment, I will be happy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.51 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was there a report in the London Sunday Times on 15 December 1985 which refers to the forced detention, interrogation and subsequent rape and torture of an employee of the United States Embassy in San Salvador, Mrs Graciela Menendez de Inglesias.

(2) Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs investigate the allegations in this report that members of the American Embassy security department illegally arrested and interrogated her then handed her over to the brutal Salvadoran Treasury Police who subjected her to at least 15 days of torture including repeated rape in order to procure a `confession' of her alleged guerrilla sympathies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the report in the London Times of 15 December 1985.

(2) It appears that Mrs Menendez was an employee of the United States Embassy in San Salvador and that she was detained and interrogated on suspicion of passing information about other staff members to insurgents. My Department has obtained certain information about her subsequent treatment but it is not sufficient to enable me to judge the validity of each of the allegations. I can say that the Salvadoran Treasury Police have a notoriously poor record of treatment of detained persons. The account given of Mrs Menendez's treatment by them is consistent with their reputation.

While there are gaps in the information available, there are elements of this case which give me cause for concern. It is, however, beyond Australian resources to conduct a detailed investigation. Mrs Menendez has, of course, been able to leave El Salvador, following a court ruling that there was insufficient evidence to justify her continued detention.
