QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Is the area confined in the coverage of Lat. 31*.46''S/32*.04''S, and Long. 115*.34''E/115*.44''E, classified as Australian Territorial Sea; if not, what sections does the Australian Territorial Sea take of this area; and
(b) are the South Passage Channel markers, shown on Chart AUS 114, position approximately 32*01''S 115*37.5''E, in Australian Territorial Seas.

(2) Is the Australian Government considered a responsible Government which would be expected to abide by the requirements of its membership with the International Association of Lighthouse Authorities (IALA).

(3) (a) Does the Minister for Transport agree that while the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973, and the United Nations Convention of Territorial Seas and Contiguous Zones, may not prevent co-operative arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth, the responsibility must still remain with the Commonwealth as laid down in the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980, and the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980; if not, what is the explanation;

(b) would the Minister in reading the last sentence on the final page (Page 9) of the IALA Maritime Buoyage System Handbook, agree that the document contains the sentence ``confirmation that the buoyage changes in specific areas have been carried out will normally be announced in Radio Navigational Warnings and in Notice to Mariners''.
(4) (a) Does the Minister state that the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980, and the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980, do not apply to certain areas of Australian Territorial Waters.

(b) has the Minister, or other Ministers of this Government or of previous Governments, handed responsibility for such International Agreements and Acts of Parliament as are cited above, to the individual States; if so, by what form and method has he, or they, passed on these responsibilities.

(5) (a) Is the Minister stating in answer to my previous Question on Notice, No. 735 (section 5) that vessels within Territorial waters but outside parts that the Commonwealth Department declare are not their responsibility, such as the Fremantle Port Authority Area, are not entitled to be warned by the Department of Transport, even when the Department knows that the vessel is entering that area where a known danger exists;
(b) are they to be warned only by the local authority, even when it is known that the authority does not have radio facilities of sufficient range to pass on such warnings with reliability; and

(c) is the Minister prepared to admit that it is not the responsibility of the Commonwealth Department to send out radio warnings to all those concerned in all Australian territorial waters, despite the fact that the Commonwealth Navigation Act 1912, and the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973, state that all concerned must be warned, and the fact that through the International Conventions relating to Safety of Life at Sea the Commonwealth Government agrees to give such warnings, and the fact that the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 clearly state that the Commonwealth retains the responsibility for these Conventions and Acts.

(6) (a) Does the Minister state through his answer to my previous Question on Notice, No. 735 (section 6), that because these Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980 do not assign specific ministerial responsibility, the Acts do not apply to the Department;

(b) does the Minister now state, after claiming that section 6 of these Acts does not prevent co-operative arrangements between State and Commonwealth, that once such co-operative arrangements are agreed to, this absolves the Commonwealth Government of all responsibility under the Commonwealth Acts of Parliament and International Agreements to warn all those concerned of dangers, and that those others with whom they have decided to arrange to co-operate may or may not abide by these acts and conventions, as they see fit or as they are physically capable of abiding by them according to their limited facilities.
(7) (a) Could the Minister elaborate on the reference to ``co-operative arrangements'' contained in the final sentence of his previous answer to my Question; and

(b) is the Minister stating that co-operative arrangements are already in place with the Fremantle Port Authority (FPA), its Minister, the State Transport Department, or other relevant controlling authority.

(8) If the Minister or his Department have entered a co-operative arrangement with the controlling body of the FPA, would not this situation then be covered by the fourth section of the Minister's answer to my previous Question, when he states that through his Departmental Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre he authorises warnings of danger to navigation that relate to those areas for which the Federal Government accepts responsibility, as part of a shared responsibility with the States and Territories for the provision of marine navigational aids.

(9) If the Minister does not agree with the proposition in Section 8 of this Question, then does he agree that the Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre would be responsible for sending out warnings because they retain such responsibility under the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980, as they have not entered into a co-operative arrangement with the FPA. (See answer to Question on Notice No. 735, Hansard, 11 February 1986, p. 140.)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) No. The Australian Territorial Sea is that area three nautical miles seaward of the baselines proclaimed in accordance with the international law.

In respect of the area in question the Territorial Sea baselines (published in Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S 29 dated 9 February 1983) are as follows, commencing from position 32* 07' 20''S, 115* 39' 23'' E; from 32* 07' 20''S, 115* 39' 23''E, to 32* 04' 03''S, 115* 38' 00''E; from 32* 04' 03''S, 115* 38' 00''E to 32* 01'47''S, 115* 31' 39''E, thence following low water mark of Rottnest Island. Clockwise, to position 31* 59' 27''S, 115* 32' 28''E; from 31* 59' 27''S, 115* 32' 28''E to 31* 56' 22''S, 115* 45' 10''E; then following low water mark of mainland, in a general NNW direction to 26* 08' 42''S, 113* 09' 26''E.
(b) no, they are internal waters.

(2) The International Association of Lighthouse Authorities (IALA) is a non-government body which brings together its members in order to exchange information and promulgate improvements based on the latest technology. Membership is open to agencies responsible for navigational aids, port authorities and commercial organisations. The Federal Department of Transport is a member of IALA and participates in the activities of the organisation.

(3) (a) The Commonwealth and the States at the Premiers' Conference in June 1979 completed an agreement for the settlement of offshore constitutional issues (known as the Offshore Constitutional Settlement), which took full account of international, national and State interests and produced a solution agreed to by all States on what matters are appropriate for Commonwealth, State or joint administration and how the various agreed arrangements should be implemented. Pursuant thereto the Commonwealth enacted, inter alia, the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980. The effect of the former Act is to give each State the same powers with respect to the adjacent territorial sea (including the seabed) as it would have if the waters were within the limits of the State. The effect of the latter Act is to vest in each State proprietary rights and title in respect of the adjacent territorial sea (subject to certain exemptions). At international law, although the Commonwealth accepts international obligations, and benefits from rights, under international treaties, the means by which any such obligations are to be given effect domestically is a matter for the Commonwealth. Consistent with international law, responsibility for implementation of such obligations domestically can rest with the Australian States for areas within the jurisdiction of the States. Although section 6 of each of the Acts mentioned above confirms the position at international law that nothing in those Acts affects the rights and duties of the Commonwealth under international law, any question regarding any adverse effect on an Australian citizen of an alleged failure by Australia to comply with international law is a matter to be determined solely in accordance with arrangements in Australian law, both Commonwealth and State. Section 6 of each of the Acts is of no assistance in this regard.

(b) the publication referred to is a booklet produced by the British Hydrographic Office intended to assist mariners in the changeover of the IALA System of Buoyage. The sentence, when read in the context of the whole section entitled ``Implementation of the IALA Buoyage System'', refers to notification of the change to the IALA System. In Australia the changeover was completed by 31 December 1982 and at that time mariners had been advised through radio navigation warnings and notices to mariners.
The IALA Maritime Buoyage System booklet issued by IALA does not include any reference to promulgating buoyage changes.

(4) (a) The Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 and the Coastal Waters (State Titles) Act 1980 apply to the `coastal waters of the State'. Sub-section 3 (1) of each of those Acts contains the following definition:
` ``coastal waters of the State'' means, in relation to each State-
(a) the part or parts of the territorial sea of Australia that is or are within the adjacent area in respect of the State, other than any part referred to in sub-section 4 (2); and

(b) any sea that is on the landward side of any part of the territorial sea of Australia and is within the adjacent area in respect of the State but is not within the limits of the State or of a Territory.'
Section 4 of the former Act further elaborates on the extent of the territorial sea and coastal waters, by way of the following provisions:

`4. (1) For the purposes of this Act, the limits of the territorial sea of Australia shall be the limits existing from time to time, ascertained consistently with the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973 and instruments under that Act and with any agreement (whether made before or after the commencement of this Act) for the time being in force between Australia and another country with respect to the outer limit of a particular part of that territorial sea.

(2) If at any time the breadth of the territorial sea of Australia is determined or declared to be greater than 3 nautical miles, references in this Act to the coastal waters of the State do not include, in relation to any State, any part of the territorial sea of Australia that would not be within the limits of that territorial sea if the breadth of that territorial sea had continued to be 3 nautical miles.'
Sub-section 3 (1) of the former Act also contains the following definition:

` ``adjacent area in respect of the State'' means, in relation to each State, the area the boundary of which is described under the heading referring to that State in Schedule 3 to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act.'

(4) (b)It is inapt to speak of Commonwealth Ministers having handed responsibility for Commonwealth Acts of Parliament to individual States. In relation to the provisions of the cited International Agreements concerning notification of dangers to shipping, co-operative arrangements between the Commonwealth and each of the States stem from an exchange of letters between the Prime Minister and the Premier of each State in 1934.

(5) (a) With regard to Question on Notice No. 735 (section 5), neither the previous answer nor the question made any reference to ``vessels within Territorial waters but outside parts that the Commonwealth Department declares are not their responsibility''. Where responsibility is shared between the Commonwealth and the States, the sharing of responsibility and the determination of the parts of the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible results from arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State, not from any declaration made by the Commonwealth Department.

As stated in my previous answer the Department of Transport is only obliged to send out warnings of dangers to navigation in relation to those parts of the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible. It will nevertheless issue warnings for other areas when requested to do so by the responsible authority.

(b) No. The Commonwealth will issue warnings of occurrences within ports when requested to do so by the responsible authority. Where a local authority considers its radio facilities to have insufficient range to pass on warnings with reliability it may request the Commonwealth to issue an appropriate warning. The Department of Transport understands that the style and location of the radio facilities operated by the Fremantle Port Authority would have a nominal range of 18.6 nautical miles.

(c) See answer to question (3) (a). The Federal Government is aware of the various responsibilities on parties having an involvement in navigational safety in the Australian territorial waters and meets its obligations in respect of those parts of the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible. The Acts referred to in the question do not state what the question suggests they do.

(6) (a) No. However, as indicated in the answer to question (3) (a), the Acts deal with the legislative powers and titles of the States in respect of coastal waters. Those Acts have an effect on the domestic exercise of jurisdiction by the Commonwealth in the context of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement.
(b) See answer to question (3) (a).

(7) (a) Co-operative arrangements are an integral part of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement. Such arrangements between the States and the Commonwealth concerning implementation of international maritime agreements take a number of forms, most commonly through administrative arrangements or complementary legislation. For instance, the terms of the agreement on certain aspects of shipping and navigation were confirmed as part of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement of 1979.

(b) Yes. Co-operative arrangements with Western Australia in respect of shared responsibility for marine navigation aids and radio warnings stem from an exchange of letters between the Prime Minister and the Premier of Western Australia in 1934. These arrangements provide that the responsibility of the Commonwealth in regard to provision and maintenance of lights and other aids to navigation ends with the erection and maintenance of those aids necessary for ocean navigation. Provision of port, river and minor aids to navigation is a matter for the State Government or local authority. In this context radio warnings are regarded as `other aids to navigation'.

(8) The Department of Transport has not entered into a co-operative arrangement with the controlling body of the Fremantle Port Authority. The co-operative arrangement with Western Australia in respect of shared responsibility for marine navigational aids stems from an exchange of correspondence between the Prime Minister and the Premier of Western Australia in 1934. Resulting from that exchange the Department of Transport is only required to send out warnings of danger to navigation in relation to those parts of the shared responsibility for which the Commonwealth is responsible.
(9) See answer to (8) above.
